fields.headline: Holland 1 - 0 Czech Republic
fields.trailText:
Holland: van der Sar, Reiziger, Stam, F. de Boer, Zenden, Seedorf, Cocu, Davids, Kluivert, Bergkamp, van Bronckhorst.
Substitutes: Bosvelt, Konterman, Makaay, Numan, Overmars, Westerveld, Winter, R. de Boer, de Goey, van Vossen, van Hooijdonk.
fields.body:
Holland: van der Sar, Reiziger, Stam, F. de Boer, Zenden, Seedorf, Cocu, Davids, Kluivert, Bergkamp, van Bronckhorst.
Substitutes: Bosvelt, Konterman, Makaay, Numan, Overmars, Westerveld, Winter, R. de Boer, de Goey, van Vossen, van Hooijdonk.

Czech Republic: Srnicek, Repka, Latal, Nedved, Nemec, Poborsky, Koller, Rosicky, Smicer, Rada, Gabriel.
Substitutes: Bejbl, Blazek, Fukal, Horvath, Jankulovski, Kuka, Lokvenc, Maier, Novotny, Vlcek.

Referee: Perluigi Collina (Italy)

No Overmars for the co-hosts - Zenden takes his place. Big noise greeted the Dutch to their first game in Euro 2000. The home side are understandably hot favourites tonight, but the Czechs are no mugs.

1 min The Czechs start the match with the 19 year-old Rosicky dropped well and truly in at the deep end, due to Patrik Berger's suspension. Will he sink or swim?
3 Early doors, but the Czechs do not appear overawed and seem content to let the Dutch do their pretty passing thing with one eye on the quick counter.
6 Davids is sandwiched between Repka and Latal in the Czech area, and tries to look as aggrieved as you can in orange shades. The hairless Collina remains unmoved.
7 Davids in his shades again. The midfielder breaks from the centre circle past two Czechs and into the area, centre-left. His low drive is deflected for a corner. The set-piece is wasted, which seems to be international football's current lietmotif.
11 The Czechs, in white, get a free kick just inside the Dutch half. Latal picks it up on the right and feeds Poborsky, who loses the ball to Van Bronkhorst. I guess we'll call that their first 'attack'.
14 A corner from the left for Holland. Bergkamp takes, the centre is cleared as far as Kluivert, who collects, turns and shoots in one movement. Repka makes a vital block from 15 yards and Bergkamp follows up with a snap shot from an acute angle on the left that Srnicek does well to hold. Crowd volume goes up a few notches.
15 Karel Poborsky is almost sent through but is adjudged offside, much to the relief of 99% of the fans in this Amsterdam Arena.
18 Repka turned inside-out by Kluivert, who races away and shoots towards the bottom-left-hand corner. Srnicek parries the effort and then recovers to do enough to distract Zenden from slotting home from an acute angle. Bergkamp is over-eager with the corner and Srnicek catches the ball at his far post.
19 He doesn't just overhit crosses you know. Bergkamp, in a little space on the left, makes Latal seasick with a combination of twists and turns, before shooting from 15 yards across Srnicek and just wide of the far post. How long can the Czechs hold out?
22 A free kick to Holland from the right. Van Bronkhorst swings it in with his left foot and Srnicek is happy to punch the cross away. This summer, punching is the new catching.
23 If you can't beat 'em, foul 'em. Nedved pulls Davids to the ground after the beshaded one had glided past him on the left. Collina is unimpressed and books him.
26 The Czechs have managed to stop the home side attacking for 30 seconds, but in the process of catching their collective breath, surrender possession. Bergkamp collects with his back to Repka, which he immediately regrets as the Czech defender mows down Dennis with an agricultural challenge. Bergkamp takes a while to get to his feet.
27 Bergkamp clattered over again, again from behind. Collina is keeping an eye on the oft-fouled Dutchman, and a card will probably accompany the next rough tackle.
30 The visitors would have doubtless taken nil-nil after half an hour had they been offered as much at 7:44pm. Latal does a good job of containing Zenden on the left of the Czech area.
32 Another corner to Holland, this time from the right. Cleared, but then Davids, de Boer, Zenden and van Bronkhorst all combine to torment the Czech defence until Srnicek can come and claim a weak lobbed pass.
36 In this veritable (what's the collective noun?) embarrassment(?) of orange-clad skill, one man stands out as the sheep on wolf's clothing. Big-score-in-scrabble-first-name Zenden has contributed to at least five moves breaking down with an overeager first touch or poorly-placed pass. They'd be better off missing him out all together.
38 Frank de Boer, the Dutch captain, is booked for a clumsy challenge on Nedved. The crowd are incredulous. The Czech free kick, in a good position wide right, is wasted.
40 The Czech's continue their stubborn resistance, and the Dutch are starting to look a little less composed than they were during the early stages of this match. Uncharacteristically Davids is hassled off the ball on the right, and Nedved feeds Smicer in the centre, who tries to play the return ball but the linesman indicates otherwise. Offside, free kick Holland.
44 Dennis Bergkamp, apart from his crossing, has been excellent this half. A long ball from de Boer is met by a cushion Bergkamp header. Seedorf, largely anonymous this period, strikes a netbuster straight into Rep's midriff and the Czechs breathe again.
46 Hearts in Dutch mouths as Nerved, in space centre left, hits a rasping, curling drive that beats van der Sar all ends up, but just sails wide of the keeper's top-left-hand corner.
47 Half time: Holland 0 - 0 Czech Republic. As the teams walk off the pitch, Kluivert had to be pulled away from referee Collina by a team-mate. What's all that about, then?

45 Th Dutch start the second half with a little less fizz than at the kick-off.
47 Nedved, surrounded on the left of the Dutch area, somehow conjures a ball into the far post. Van der Sar missed the centre and Poborsky, on his own 3 yards from goal, misses a gilt-edged opportunity to the disbelief of his team-mates.
48 The Dutch come forward again with Zenden cutting in from the left. Poborsky makes it a couple of minutes to forget by fouling the Barcelona winger 25 yards from goal. Collina books him, when he probably could have let him go and watch him put it in the crowd.
50 A surreal free kick as the ball is rolled to Stam, who strikes a piledriver that Srnicek does well to parry. you don't see that very often.
54 Jan Koller almost sends 50,000 Dutchmen into despair as he meets a low cross with his right foot from 10 yards. Van de Sar makes a great save to preserve the deadlock.
56 Nedved clean through on the left, but instead of the square ball to Poborsky in acres of space, he tries to beat Van der Sar at his near post, unsuccessfully.
57 The disappointing Seedorf is substituted for Ronald de Boer.
58 Nedved rises majestically above Davids to meet a Smicer cross. His header strikes van der Sar's left upright and bounces along the goal-line into the relieved keeper's arms. Nedved cannot believe it.
62 Davids' trickery on the left gives him enough space to float in a cross. Srnicek comes to meet the ball with his fists but clatters into the unfortunate Gabriel, who lies writhing on the ground next to the goal.
64 Poborsky floats in a free kick from the right flank 50 yards from goal. The big man Koller rises to meet the ball with his shoulder and the ball cannons off van der Sar's crossbar with the Dutch keeper well beaten.
66 A corner to the Czechs, from the left. Repka tries to flick the ball on at the near post, but the Dutch are able to clear.
67 A Serie A set-too as Repka (Fiorentina) fouls Davids (Juventus) and is booked by Italian referee Collina. The Czech continues to rant at the ref and Davids, until Collina puts his hand on his chest and pushes him away. Nice one, ref!
69 Latal is laid up with cramp and is signalling to be substituted. Overmars is jogging by the sideline and Stam is also having a problem with his left eye - he's gone off to get stitched up. Sure enough, Bejbl comes on as a substitute for Latal.
72 Nedved is involved in a clash of heads and leaves the field for treatment. It's ten-a-side at the moment.
74 All the injuries have disrupted the flow of the game at the moment. Stam has had a lot of stitches above his left eye, but the injury is too serious and Stam is substituted, with Konterman coming on in his place.
76 A great chance for the Czechs, as Poborsky and Rosicky break up the right. The cross is cut out by Frank de Boer and the Dutch are lucky to escape without being punished for leaving so much space at the back>
79 Nedved and Zenden collide in the middle. It's Zenden's last 'contribution', as Overmars comes on as his substitute. Nedved is carried off on a stretcher but rejoins the action with a heavily strapped right arm.
82 Overmars gets his first go at Poborsky on the left. He manages o get in the cross, but Repka heads it away. The play is switched to Reiziger, who forces a corner on the right. Konterman makes the late run and the ball hits his foot rather than a full-blooded strike. The effort bounces wide of the near post.
84 Smicer's work here is done. He is substituted for Kuka.
86 The Czech's keep battling and the men in Orange are starting to look a little desperate.
87 Rosicky dances his way in from the right as three nervous Dutchmen watch his quick feet. Eventually Davids stabs the ball clear, and the Dutch can break.
88 Penalty to Holland! Referee Collina's just earned himself free room and board in Holland for life. Ronald de Boer was, apparently, held back from jumping to meet a cross from Overmars on the left.
90 GOAL! Holland 1 - 0 Czech Republic Frank de Boer makes no mistake from the spot and the Czechs are heartbroken.
91 Four extra minutes to play. If there's any justice the Czechs will score two.
92 Van Bronkhorst is booked for an agricultural challenge and then it all kicks off with shenanigans on the Czech bench. Collina jogs over and brandishes the red card at Latal, who has just come off.
94 A flurry of corners for the visitors causes some anxious moments for the Dutch. The last throw of the dice comes from a free kick taken deep in his won half by Srnicek, who finds Koller in the Dutch area. His chested pass finds Bejbl, who can only blaze wide from 10 yards out.
95 Lucky, lucky Holland 1 - 0 Czech Republic

webTitle: Don't sit back and twiddle your thumbs

fields.headline: Don't sit back and twiddle your thumbs
fields.standfirst:
Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy calls on Labour to be less timid and to restore public faith in politics
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy calls on Labour to be less timid and to restore public faith in politics
fields.body:
Be ambitious, Tony - and the Women's Institute might invite you back next year. With less than a year before the general election, where is the Government going?

The PM's appearance at the WI conference last Wednesday was a surreal moment. How on earth did the most popular Prime Minister since records began find himself being given the slow handclap?

It may be that the jeering did indeed come from an unrepresentative minority, as Downing Street has subsequently spun. Or it may be that his speech was too party political for such an audience. Both probably apply in small measure.

But there is also a sense that the shine has come off the Government. Trust has been lost. People don't accept the 'Trust me, I'm Tony' approach any more. Above all, there is a sense that the Government has run out of steam. Too many people feel no great enthusiasm for it and no longer believe anything it does will make much difference to their lives.

This is extremely disappointing - because a government that fails to inspire damages not only itself, but the whole business of politics. When its only way of whipping up interest is through a simplistic debate about Oxford dons, we are all diminished. And it makes the trash politics of William Hague look less absurd than it is.

The Government should reinvigorate political debate by ditching its poverty of ambition. But it seems to have run out of steam on a whole host of commitments. Take devolution. In 1997, people voted en masse for two parties, ourselves and Labour, who they thought would change the very nature of politics.

Labour started to do that, but it has now ground to a halt. It has kicked the Jenkins report on fair votes and the Wakeham report on reform of the Lords into the long grass. Why? Fear of opposition.

The same applies to freedom of information, where the Government's timidity has done it no favours. Meanwhile, the Government has made no significant moves to meet the real desire for more power in the regions of England. What are they scared of?

Constitutional modernisation should be accompanied by leadership in Europe. Given the benign economic scenario and the Prime Minister's parliamentary majority, it defies belief that he should not have shown some real leadership on the single currency. He left it too late and will now have to wait until the next Parliament.

In the next year, the Government could have achieved much to stabilise the overvalued pound by setting out a clear strategy for joining the euro, but has shied away from doing it.

Instead of creating phoney arguments about the selection practices at Oxford, the Government could have courageously admitted that, sometimes, resources are the answer.

Why has the Prime Minister not taken a bigger lead on the environment? Why has Labour abandoned Britain's pensioners? There is so much Tony Blair could do with the remaining time left in this Parliament.

Why do I get the impression he is twiddling his fingers, waiting for polling day and trying not to offend anyone this side of an election? How much better if he showed some true grit and used the time to take some big decisions.

There is much more that the Government could do. But a start on these areas would do much to restore faith in the political process. Leadership on the constitution and Europe would take us into a new era of politics.

Valuing public servants would boost morale among those on the front line of implementing government policy. A new approach to sustainability would revolutionise the way we think about the environment. And helping the poorest pensioners would show that politicians can deliver on bread and butter issues.

Westminster is a jungle - and the hunter can always smell fear on its prey. The worst thing Blair can do is to run scared and allow a culture of timidity to overcome Whitehall. After 18 years of misery under the Tories, Blair and New Labour were not elected to take easy decisions.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst:
...discuss workplacemistakes ... nicely
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: ...discuss workplacemistakes ... nicely
fields.body:
1 Don't go into the discussion thinking that your colleague is an idiot or wilfully malevolent. Human beings are good at seeing things purely from their own perspective. If your assistant did something that seems stupid or lazy - packed the wrong slides into your presentation case, for instance - there will be other factors that you need to discuss and discover. You may well have helped the problem along - by being so irritable, perhaps, that people dislike checking things with you.

2 Avoid blaming people at all costs. Blame gets a poor response from most of us, because it usually involves an unfair judgment of our aims and the threat of punishment. You will not have the sensible talk you need to have, nor prevent the error happening again, if you start by saying: 'How the hell could you be so stupid?'

3 Make your first commandment 'Thou shalt seek to understand'. Gain as much information as you can about your colleague's intentions. Motives are far more complicated than we usually think.

4 Phrase your comments carefully. Something like 'You're always trying to make me look stupid' shows that you have already convicted your colleague. Putting it more accurately - 'I feel stupid when you shout at me' - lets them explain their motives.

5 Don't bottle up your need to confront - but do it in a calm and rational manner. 'When important feelings remain unexpressed, you may experience a loss of self-esteem,' say the authors of Difficult Conversations *. 'You [also] hurt the relationship.'

6 State exactly what you want to get from the resolved situation. Assertiveness training courses are based on the very sensible belief that the first step to success is communicating what you want.

7 Think about your own failed relationships and uncomfortable confrontations and try to work out what went wrong. Few arguments are caused by a disagreement over the facts; clumsy emotional interactions are far more common (and avoidable).

8 Consideryour own weaknesses. We are all very good at believing our own propaganda. If you believe that you are a powerful person, or a good person, you could react badly to people who do not seem to recognise this. But if you detect such beliefs in yourself, you can react more calmly and constructively.

 Difficult Conversations, by Douglas Stone, Bruce Patton and Sheila Heen of the Harvard Negotiation Project, is published by Penguin at £7.99.

Few arguments are caused by a disagreement over the facts; clumsy emotional interactions are far more common (and avoidable). 8 Consideryour own weaknesses. We are all very good at believing our own propaganda. If you believe that you are a powerful person, or a good person, you could react badly to people who do not seem to recognise this. But if you detect such beliefs in yourself, you can react more calmly and constructively.  Difficult Conversations, by Douglas Stone, Bruce Patton and Sheila Heen of the Harvard Negotiation Project, is published by Penguin at £7.99.

webTitle: Equitable in last bid to avoid payouts

fields.headline: Equitable in last bid to avoid payouts
fields.trailText: The bitter battle that could determine the future of Equitable Life enters its final stage tomorrow when the company appeals to the Lords against investors trying to stop cuts to their guaranteed annuities.
fields.body:
The bitter battle that could determine the future of Equitable Life enters its final stage tomorrow when the company appeals to the Lords against investors trying to stop cuts to their guaranteed annuities.

The dispute with 90,000 policyholders has already seriously damaged Equitable's reputation, and defeat in the Lords would make it vulnerable to takeover by a predatory insurer such as Prudential. Its credit rating has been downgraded by Standard & Poor's because of a decline in new business.

Guaranteed annuities, used as a marketing ploy by Equitable to sell 'with profits' pension policies between 1957 and 1988, promise that policyholders will receive an income worth 11 per cent of the value of their pension fund on retirement. Market annuity rates have plunged in the last few years to between 8 and 9 per cent, making the annuities very expensive to honour.

Other insurers, such as Scottish Widows, decided to absorb the extra cost. But Equitable announced that it would pay smaller final bonuses to pension holders who exercised their right to a guaranteed annuity. This would cut the size of their pension funds on retirement, reducing the pension income they could earn to the same level as other 'with profits' pension policyholders.

Enraged policyholders claim they should be awarded a larger proportion of the full final bonus rate being paid to other policyholders, plus a higher annuity rate.

Stuart Bayliss of Annuity Direct, who has spearheaded the Equitable Life Policyholders Action Group, says: 'Equitable is trying to say that the guarantee is valueless - that it does not entitle holders to any more benefits than those who have other types of annuity. We dispute that.'

Equitable won round one of the court battle but lost in the Court of Appeal. Lord Woolf, master of the rolls, said it was 'not a permissible exercise of discretion' for the insurer to apply different rates for final bonuses depending on how a policy holder chose to take his or her benefits.

Equitable has been forced to set aside £1.5bn to cover the cost of honouring the guaranteed annuities, although even Bayliss admits that not all policyholders will want them. Guaranteed annuities cannot be inflation linked or made payable to a spouse after the death of the annuity holder, making them unsuitable for many pensioners.

The appeal is likely to take four to five days, with the verdict not expected before July.

webTitle: References: it's worth doing them by the book

fields.headline: References: it's worth doing them by the book
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: When I applied for a new job recently, the manager I currently work for gave me a very unsatisfactory reference. Things have gone very badly between us. After our personnel department intervened, she called a staff meeting, publicly apologised to me and said we would have to rebuild our relationship. What can I do about the reference?
fields.body:
When I applied for a new job recently, the manager I currently work for gave me a very unsatisfactory reference. Things have gone very badly between us. After our personnel department intervened, she called a staff meeting, publicly apologised to me and said we would have to rebuild our relationship. What can I do about the reference?

 Employers have a legal duty - a 'duty of care' - to employees and to the next employer to provide fair and accurate references. If you get a bad and unfair reference which stops you getting another job, you could sue for damages in the High Court. Judges regularly award damages to employees who have lost out in this way. One employee recently got £200,000.

A sensible employer would at least consider settling before they took on the legal costs of defending this sort of case. If they decided to fight it, however, you would have to produce your evidence. If you had had rows with your boss, that could be held against you. On the other hand, a fair reference would usually be produced methodically - with input from the personnel department, not just your boss.

The development of the law over the past five years has worried employers so much that some try not to give references any more. Legal advice from Pinsent Curtis. Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: The greed mortgaging our future
fields.standfirst:
The pursuit of short-term gains in supposed shareholder value is at everyone's expense, reports Simon Caulkin
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The pursuit of short-term gains in supposed shareholder value is at everyone's expense, reports Simon Caulkin.
fields.body:
It takes a brave, some would say foolhardy, man to denounce the scriptures in church before an audience of bishops. This is in effect what Allan Kennedy does in The End of Shareholder Value (Orion, £18.99), a new book in which the author, a management consultant who has spent his life working for some of the world's best-known companies, takes an axe to the principles his clients hold most dear. Briefly, Kennedy argues that for the last 20 years, US companies have mortgaged the future in pursuit of short-term financial gain for shareholders. Somewhere, he charges, shareholder value changed from a means of business to its end. The destructive consequences for other stakeholders - employees, customers, suppliers and governments - have been incalculable.

Crucial to the process has been the discovery of stock options as a means of 'aligning' management interests with those of shareholders. Stock options are essentially an accounting anomaly, without which they would never have been so widely adopted. But for executives their beauty is that they legitimise management greed: who can complain if top executives share in the riches created for shareholders? Although ordinary investors have benefited from the booming stock markets of the 1990s, it is Kennedy's case that the 'value' created is illusory, the product of downsizing, outsourcing, and restructuring, and financial-engineering ploys like share-buybacks and mergers. None of this has anything to do with customers and products - as will be discovered by investors to their cost when the bubble bursts. By this time the real beneficiaries, boards and top managers (in the US largely the same), will be safely retired. As one top CEO, taxed with the inadequacy of his long-term strategy, told Kennedy: 'Why the fuck should I care? I'll be long gone before anyone finds out.'

Short-termism is not in itself a new argument. But Kennedy laces it with a fresh historical perspective. He sees the purpose of business evolving over time. In the first and second waves of business formation, from the family capitalism of the 19th century to the technocratic 1970s, making money was a by-product of benefiting humanity. P&G and Unilever were representative of the first wave, HP and Polaroid of the second. At the end of the second wave, however, a new mentality emerged. This was fuelled by technical developments in company valuation leading to the idea that the only purpose of companies was to increase shareholder value, and by the technological revolution. For Kennedy, these currents converged in the foundation of Intel, inventor of the microprocessor - a company set up, as one employee put it, 'to steal' the process invented by its predecessor, Fairchild.

Thus was the age of pure greed born, which finds its apogee in the excesses and abuses of the internet start-ups, many of which have no purpose beyond the flotation that will make their founders rich and leave others to turn the shells into a viable business. It is hardly news that the character of new firms is conditioned by the circumstances of their setting up. But existing business too is caught up in the corrup tion of purpose. Take Jack Welch, for instance, the lauded CEO of the revered General Electric. Quintupled sales with a workforce reduced by one-third would seem to brook no argument.

While conceding that Welch is 'extraordinarily talented', Kennedy shows that under Welch GE's biggest investment - $30 billion - has been in share buy-backs. To pay for this, he charges, GE has put its future at risk by slashing payroll, marketing and research and development. GE now makes most of its money from financial services. 'Roll back 20 years to walkie-talkies, the predecessor of mobile phones, and GE was the market No 1. Now Nokia is No 1 and GE is nowhere. That's a direct consequence of shareholder value thinking,' Kennedy alleges. When Welch retires at the end of 2000 he is expected to make up to $1bn on his stock options.

Looking at developments in perspective also allows Kennedy to see the dynamic in the shareholder value process. Every action produces a reaction. In this case, the other stakeholders trampled in the rush for shareholder value are fighting back. Kennedy produces the astonishing finding that up to 20 per cent of Americans earning over $100,000 now use specialist lawyers and agents to negotiate the best deal with a new employer. 'They aren't doing com panies any favours,' he notes.

Meanwhile, suppliers are consolidating apace to give themselves the muscle to resist never-ending demands for lower prices. There are now just two or three car-seat manufacturers in the world, and other industries such as aerospace and textiles are going in the same direction. Finally customer loyalty has been declining with increasing consumer disillusion - and the internet, with its potential for instant comparison, is set to give it the coup de grace. 'Internet shopping will kill branded goods stone dead,' says Kennedy.

Kennedy believes Europe can still avert the worst excesses of what another writer, Edward Luttwak, has termed 'turbo-capitalism'. But he has little comfort for the US. 'No one wants to imagine a world in which the stock market doesn't go up 100 per cent a year. The attitude is: don't threaten my portfolio,' he says. What's more, the excesses can't reach the political agenda because both political parties are in hock to corporate funding. 'In an ideal world, we'd correct the abuses through regulation,' says Kennedy. 'Unfortunately, I don't think anything less than a major crash will make people step back and look clearly at where it's all gone wrong.'

 simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Tesco v Safeway is winner for shoppers

fields.headline: Tesco v Safeway is winner for shoppers
fields.trailText: Tesco and Safeway are locked in battle over the latter's 'Best Deals Ever' discounts - but customers are getting the last laugh.
fields.body:
Tesco and Safeway are locked in battle over the latter's 'Best Deals Ever' discounts - but customers are getting the last laugh.

Tesco is offering to match Safeway's deals for any customer who produces the promotional leaflet at stores in Wells, Somerset and Brownhills, Walsall. So Safeway sent staff round to flood the Tesco car park with its leaflets - and to tell customers that, if Tesco sold out, the offers would still be available at their local Safeway.

Safeway has carefully constructed its campaign so that it is difficult for rivals to match. Promotions vary across the country and change every week. For example, Walsall shoppers could buy Aquafresh toothpaste for 69p, down from £1.52 while, in the west country, four cans of Heinz spaghetti went from £1.35 to 49p. Safeway plans sufficient stock levels in advance, whereas Tesco quickly runs out - irritating its own customers as well as those it hopes to steal.

A Safeway spokesman dismissed Tesco's activity. Tesco would only say that take-up on its spoiler had been 'quite small'.

Safeway dropped its ABC loyalty card last month to focus on Best Deals. Tesco and Sainsbury are both offering to swap ABC cards for points in their schemes. Tesco said 200,000 had taken up the offer. Best Deals has boosted Safeway's sales increases well above rivals'.

webTitle: Give Standard a new mutual life

fields.headline: Give Standard a new mutual life
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Many Standard Life policyholders will find the temptation to vote for demutualisation almost irresistible. The admission by the insurer's own management that 'steps would be taken' to ensure that no existing policyholders lost out through conversion makes it seem an open and shut case.
fields.body:
Many Standard Life policyholders will find the temptation to vote for demutualisation almost irresistible. The admission by the insurer's own management that 'steps would be taken' to ensure that no existing policyholders lost out through conversion makes it seem an open and shut case.

But it is not. Returns to people topping up pensions with the company will worsen, and given that pensions accounted for 70 per cent of its new business last year, newer policyholders will do worse than they expected. It is impossible to know whether their windfalls would make up for this, but they may not, especially if, as Standard Life suggests, payouts to newer clients will be relatively modest. It is also unlikely that the flotation windfalls would be as attractive for many as pro-conversion campaigner Fred Woollard's figures suggest.

Future returns would be lower than past ones. Voting to protect people you don't know, or who are not yet born, is an act of goodwill. But if you take a highly principled view of investment issues, this will matter.

Standard Life deserves a second chance as a mutual, so policyholders should vote no... this time. If the man agement wins, and it will be close, it must do much more to promote the value of its mutual status.

Yes, Standard Life has a strong performance record but it could be doing better on pensions (see above). It was among the first insurers to improve surrender and transfer values on endowments and pensions and we should see more of this.It should offer a guarantee on endowments to clients at risk of shortfalls. The management has refused to consider special bonuses before the vote to avoid accusations of bribery, but abstract talk about mutuality will not be enough in future.

The insurer could also take a lead in promoting ethical selling in an industry where few organisations are trusted.

webTitle: Will the vote be to float?

fields.headline: Will the vote be to float?
fields.standfirst: Fate of the biggest mutual will be decided by its members this month
fields.trailText: Policyholders with Standard Life have less than two weeks to decide whether to let the insurance company remain as a mutual organisation or convert it into a public company.
fields.body:
Policyholders with Standard Life have less than two weeks to decide whether to let the insurance company remain as a mutual organisation or convert it into a public company. The deadline for postal votes in the ballot is 23 June, and the final vote will be taken on 27 June.

As members prepare to vote, we summarise the arguments of the firm's management which believes passionately that the organisation should retain its current status, alongside the case of Fred Woollard, the wealthy policyholder who wants the insurer to convert. To assist readers in making their decision we also set out the views of insurance analysts and experts.

Fred Woollard

 Standard Life policyholders will receive average windfalls of between £5,000 and £6,300 if the company floats on the stock exchange.

 Mortgage shortfalls would be made up by demutualisation gains.

 Every existing policy will receive free shares worth more than any possible loss caused by a change of status.

 Policyholders would benefit from any growth in the value of shares as well as dividends.

 The Standard Life Members' Action Group proposes that in a conversion charities would receive 1 per cent of the shares, worth more than £120 million, while 1.5 per cent would go to Standard Life staff.

 The management is not as accountable to its policyholders as it would be if the company was a public one.

Standard Life

 Demutualisation would require the management to divert profits to shareholders. Conversion would mean lower returns on future policies and top-ups to existing policies.

 Chief executive Scott Bell says that while some policyholders will 'clearly be better off by taking a windfall' those who top up pensions will lose outas will future policyholders.

 Standard Life's performance record for pensions and life insurance policies over the past 15 years is 9 per cent better than the average for 'proprietary' companies.

 The insurer is owned and run solely for the benefit of policyholders.

 Half the 2.3 million existing policyholders would get less than £2,500 in windfalls, assuming a stock market valuation of £12 billion.

 The windfalls would not be instant. It could take two years to prepare the company for flotation.

 Standard Life does not need Plc status to expand its business; it has launched a bank that now has £5bn of loans and last week launched the UK's first 25-year capped rate loan.

 Reports about endowment 'shortfalls' have exaggerated the possible problem with loans backed by Standard Life policies.

The experts

 John Russell, of HSBC bank, predicts that the management will win the vote. He says it is 'grossly misleading' to suggest that windfalls would average £6,100 because many policies have only been running for short periods of time.

 Janet Walford, editor of Money Management Magazine, says that for 25-year endowments Standard Life has appeared in top 10 tables for 29 of the last 30 years. But looking at policies running over 10, 15, 20 and 25 years, measured over the last decade, it has achieved 24 top ten places out of a possible 40.

 David Nisbet at Deutsche Bank says members will benefit from conversion but the decision is a fine one because the insurer has performed well for them.

 Paul Greenwell of William M. Mercer says people whose policies have a long way to run should vote no, while those near maturity should vote yes.

Comment: Give Standard a new mutual life

Many Standard Life policyholders will find the temptation to vote for demutualisation almost irresistible. The admission by the insurer's own management that 'steps would be taken' to ensure that no existing policyholders lost out through conversion makes it seem an open and shut case.

But it is not. Returns to people topping up pensions with the company will worsen, and given that pensions accounted for 70 per cent of its new business last year, newer policyholders will do worse than they expected. It is impossible to know whether their windfalls would make up for this, but they may not, especially if, as Standard Life suggests, payouts to newer clients will be relatively modest. It is also unlikely that the flotation windfalls would be as attractive for many as pro-conversion campaigner Fred Woollard's figures suggest.

Future returns would be lower than past ones. Voting to protect people you don't know, or who are not yet born, is an act of goodwill. But if you take a highly principled view of investment issues, this will matter.

Standard Life deserves a second chance as a mutual, so policyholders should vote no - this time. If the management wins, and it will be close, it must do much more to promote the value of its mutual status.

Yes, Standard Life has a strong performance record but it could be doing better on pensions (see above). It was among the first insurers to improve surrender and transfer values on endowments and pensions and we should see more of this.It should offer a guarantee on endowments to clients at risk of shortfalls. The management has refused to consider special bonuses before the vote to avoid accusations of bribery, but abstract talk about mutuality will not be enough in future.

The insurer could also take a lead in promoting ethical selling in an industry where few organisations are trusted.

Maria Scott

The experts  John Russell, of HSBC bank, predicts that the management will win the vote. He says it is 'grossly misleading' to suggest that windfalls would average £6,100 because many policies have only been running for short periods of time.  Janet Walford, editor of Money Management Magazine, says that for 25-year endowments Standard Life has appeared in top 10 tables for 29 of the last 30 years. But looking at policies running over 10, 15, 20 and 25 years, measured over the last decade, it has achieved 24 top ten places out of a possible 40.  David Nisbet at Deutsche Bank says members will benefit from conversion but the decision is a fine one because the insurer has performed well for them.  Paul Greenwell of William M. Mercer says people whose policies have a long way to run should vote no, while those near maturity should vote yes. Comment: Give Standard a new mutual life Many Standard Life policyholders will find the temptation to vote for demutualisation almost irresistible. The admission by the insurer's own management that 'steps would be taken' to ensure that no existing policyholders lost out through conversion makes it seem an open and shut case. But it is not. Returns to people topping up pensions with the company will worsen, and given that pensions accounted for 70 per cent of its new business last year, newer policyholders will do worse than they expected. It is impossible to know whether their windfalls would make up for this, but they may not, especially if, as Standard Life suggests, payouts to newer clients will be relatively modest. It is also unlikely that the flotation windfalls would be as attractive for many as pro-conversion campaigner Fred Woollard's figures suggest. Future returns would be lower than past ones. Voting to protect people you don't know, or who are not yet born, is an act of goodwill. But if you take a highly principled view of investment issues, this will matter. Standard Life deserves a second chance as a mutual, so policyholders should vote no - this time. If the management wins, and it will be close, it must do much more to promote the value of its mutual status. Yes, Standard Life has a strong performance record but it could be doing better on pensions (see above). It was among the first insurers to improve surrender and transfer values on endowments and pensions and we should see more of this.It should offer a guarantee on endowments to clients at risk of shortfalls. The management has refused to consider special bonuses before the vote to avoid accusations of bribery, but abstract talk about mutuality will not be enough in future. The insurer could also take a lead in promoting ethical selling in an industry where few organisations are trusted. Maria Scott

webTitle: A job, old boy? The school ties that still bind

fields.headline: A job, old boy? The school ties that still bind
fields.standfirst:
Behind the cloak of meritocracy, networks carry on, writes Caroline Palmer
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Behind the cloak of meritocracy, networks carry on.
fields.body:
As the row rages over whether the old boy network, with its roots in the public school system, is still influencing who gets into the Oxbridge colleges, and by implication the top jobs, the workplace is as good an environment as any to look for evidence of its continuing existence.

Once, the Code of the Bertie Woosters may have seemed more relevant to the boardrooms of larger companies than those drafted by the Equal Opportunities Commission. But now you could be forgiven for believing that we live in a meritocracy: more and more firms declare that they are equal opportunities employers, and breaking the race, sex or disability laws becomes more and more expensive.

Look more closely, however, and you'll find vestiges of the old order, if sometimes in a modern guise.

Business consultant Judi James, who has visited dozens of companies over many years, says: 'The genuine old boys' network does still exist, and its members are the dinosaurs of business. It usually operates in very large companies, where there are still some people at the top who think the way you button your jacket says more about you than how you do your job. Some are just there until they pop their clogs.

'I've spoken to people who say they would like to look a bit different at work, but the chief executive or chairman thinks a pin-striped suit and school tie still matters.'

You need look no further than the law to find confirmation of this. The solicitors' governing body, the Law Society, is still waiting for a response from the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, to its decision, late last year to boycott the 'secret soundings' that lead to the appointment of judges and QCs. The society's president, Robert Sayer, says this system is 'more appropriate to the nineteenth century than the twenty-first'.

It keeps alive an 'outdated, discriminatory old boys' network' and unfairly favours 'the traditional elite of the bar in preference to solicitors, women and ethnic minorities', the society says.

According to Sayer, this system, which Lord Irvine shows no sign of changing, leads to people appointing their friends. Fifty-two per cent of judicial appointments are made from only seven barristers' chambers.

In the medical profession, Health Minister John Denham this month announced that doctors will in future have annual appraisals. This came in response to the results of a year-long inquiry into gynaecologist Rodney Ledward. The inquiry held that an 'old boys' network' had been crucial in keeping him in his post for 17 years, despite a flood of complaints from patients and staff. About 400 women have now spoken out about healthy wombs being removed and other disastrous operations.

Meanwhile, in the wider, and in theory more aggressive, world of business, friends are equally important. In KPMG Consulting's 1999 Business Leadership survey most of the 200 senior directors of large companies in the UK and the Irish Republic believed that leadership positions are gained through hard work - on average this was awarded seven out of 10 in terms of importance.

Yet the report goes on: 'Interestingly, however, given the alleged meritocratic outlook of modern business, it would appear that the age of the old school tie is far from over. Most surprisingly, the younger group [the under-45s] are more inclined to rate "knowing the right people" as an important factor in career progression than their older equivalents.'

On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 as the most important, 51 per cent of the younger age group gave an answer of 7 or above, compared with just 28 per cent of the older group.

A higher proportion of these same younger respondents were Oxbridge-educated, the KPMG study found.

And in a twist to the notion of the importance of powerful friends, the survey noted a rise of the 'power couple': 'There is strong evidence to suggest that, in their personal lives, younger business leaders are showing a greater tendency to form "power partnerships" with those of a similar business status.' Who said the age of romance was dead?

Knowing the right people does not just help you to climb the slippery pole - it can also help to ensure that you are paid sufficiently well for your efforts. Working on the premise that 'highly paid' directors have their boards' remuneration committees to thank for their annual salary increases, the left-wing magazine Labour Research , which is not linked to the Labour Party, examined the composition of the remuneration committees of 98 of the largest FTSE 100 companies to find out who was responsible for some of the whopping pay rises enjoyed by many UK company directors.

It found that only 392 directors made up the remuneration committees of all 98 companies. Just 33 - or 8.4 per cent - of them are women. Thirty of the overall total sit on more than one remuneration committee; and between them they hold 67 remuneration committee positions on top of other directorships. Two of the directors each have four seats on remuneration committees and a further three each hold three such positions.

This tendency is also very evident on the other side of the Atlantic. A study by the AFL-CIO, the US equivalent of the Trades Union Congress, found that American boardrooms are 'rigged to overpay' chief executives. 'Cronyism, personal friend ships and inter-relationships between top executives and corporate compensation committees and boards contribute to runaway executive salaries', it adds.

But while the old adage still rings true in the workplace: that it is not what you know but who you know that matters when it comes to getting a job, a promotion or a pay rise, the basis of that relationship is changing. The school or college you went to may not always be the most important factor in your favour.

As Tony Blair exhorted the Labour faithful at last year's party conference to 'sweep away the old elites', there is evidence that this is already happening in the workplace - but only because they are being replaced by a new elite.

James says: 'The traditional mob are still there and wielding influence, but there is also the young old boys' network, which is just as elitist [see box], and trying to join it can be very time-consuming. It is who you know that counts.

'One manager said to me recently, "We can't get on with our work, We're all too busy networking".'

fields.headline: Long search for net rewards
fields.standfirst: Why isn't online banking easier, asks Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Why isn't online banking easier?
fields.body:
Internet fever has turned into a plague. You can't open a newspaper or turn on the TV without being bombarded with adverts for the latest dotcom. Banks, supermarkets, clothing retailers, airlines, estate agents and investment houses are all urging customers to buy their goods and services on the net.

Consumers testing out the internet experience have not always been pleased with the results. Cash has received numerous complaints from readers who have had difficulty with net banks, and in this issue you can read the results (and frustrations) of three fairly computer-literate journalists trying to use supermarket online ordering sites.

Richard Thackray, director of online bank First-e, says these problems are partly caused by the age and (un)sophistication of PCs owned by consumers. While banks and other financial organisations have state-of-the-art systems, their customers are often using elderly hardware and software.

But he also thinks customers' aggravations are exacerbated by their expectations. 'We thought customers would compare our service levels to those of the high street banks. But they don't - we're being compared with the best e-commerce sites, like Amazon.com.'

These teething problems obscure the fact that the internet can bring genuine benefits. Internet banking services have already shown that the cost savings of a computer-based business can be passed on. Mac Millington, managing director of business-to-consumer products at Abbey National, says that banking processes at Abbey's new online bank, Cahoot, (launching tomorrow) cost 60 per cent of the amount paid by traditional branch-based banks. 'This percentage will fall as we build up customer numbers. We will share the savings with our customers.'

Egg, the first deposit and investment bank to offer its services purely via the internet, initially led the field on rates, and is still offering a competitive 'no notice' account at 6.3 per cent gross for sums of £1 or more. Likewise Smile, the Co-op's online bank, pays 4.75 per cent gross on sums of £1 upwards in its current account, while First-e pays 4.88 per cent gross (although its current account does not yet offer direct debits or standing orders).

So, how does the newest net bank shape up? Cahoot is offering credit cards free from interest charges in the first year for the first 25,000 customers. However, those who miss the special offer will have to pay between 7 per cent and 11 per cent, considerably more expensive than other credit cards already on the market.

The bank will not be sending out monthly paper statements - customers must remember to visit their account at Cahoot to make payments, a move designed to keep customers coming back to the site. The bank's current account rate is also disappointing - between 3 and 4.4 per cent - compared with competitors.

Millington defends the pricing on the grounds that Cahoot wants to launch with rates that it can sustain indefinitely. He also believes that customers will be swayed by service standards. Cahoot has outsourced much of its admin to Fiserve, a third-party administration specialist. Outsourcing is often criticised on the grounds that the product provider can lose control over service standards, but Millington defends this decision: 'All the shift managers will be our staff, all the training is by us and we have agreements on service standards.'

 Cash is interested in hearing what readers think of those standards. Email jill.insley@observer.co.uk

Borrowing

www.uk.eloan.com A one-stop shop for mortgages, with more than 45 lenders on its books.
www.charcolonline.co.uk The site for John Charcol, one of the UK's leading independent mortgage brokers. This guides you to the right loan by asking questions.
www.moneygator.com Independent broker listing mortgages, credit cards and personal loans.

Homebuying and selling

www.easier.co.uk Independent site that lets you advertise your home free in return for selling your name on to financial services providers.
www.houseweb.com Charges £40 to list your home for an indefinite period.
www.propertyfinder.co.uk Hosts the web pages of upmarket agents Knight Frank, Hamptons and FPD Savills, as well as nationwide chains like Bradford & Bingley. Features about 23,000 properties.
www.rightmove.co.uk Set up by Countrywide Assured, Connells, Halifax and the Royal & SunAlliance, it has about 120,000 properties.
www.propwise.com A property gateway that reviews many of the online property and mortgage websites.

News and information

Work Unlimited Up-to-the-minute news and advice from the online team at the Guardian.
www.citywire.co.uk Investigative news site specialising in the stock market and equity based funds.
www.mrscohen.com A chatty mixture of news and advice from author and TV presenter Bernice Cohen and her team.
www.ft.com Financial news as it happens and the previous day's stories as they appear in the pink one.
www.hemscott.net News and advice, plus one of the livelier chat rooms for UK investors.
www.teletext.co.uk/finance A free service from Teletext that features real-time share prices for up to 3,000 companies.

Advice

www.sort.co.uk Independent financial advisory service. Prices range from £12.99 for Isa advice to £99.99 for a financial health check.
www.law4today.com Offers 'free nonsense but sound advice, plus DIY legal kits and forms to buy and download'.
www.find.co.uk A directory of financial sites. www.financialplanning.org.uk (The Institute of Financial Planning), www.sofa.org (The Society of Financial Advisers), and www.ifap.org.uk (IFA Promotion) can all help you find a financial adviser in your area.

Investment

www.chasedevere.co.uk Execution-only Isa investment with six investment houses, plus news and views.
www.tqonline.co.uk Execution-only Isa investment with 10 investment houses, with much of the initial charge rebated back to you in the form of cash or extra units.
www.egg.com/investments Prudential subsidiary Egg is the first to launch an online 'fund supermarket', offering 150 funds from 12 investment houses at knock-down prices. Investors will get 1 per cent cashback on Isa investments until June 30. You need an Egg Savings Account to deal

Stockbroking

www.idealing.com Execution-only share dealing at a flat rate of £10 per trade. Customers must pay a quarterly charge of £5. A minimum of £500 is required to open an account.
www.dljdirect.co.uk Execution-only broker which charges 0.75 per cent of the value of each order, minimum £14.95, maximum £37.50.
www.tdwaterhouse.co.uk Currently the UK's biggest online broker. Charges 1 per cent on deals up to £1,999 (minimum £12.95) and 0.2 per cent on deals of £2,000 or more (maximum £45).

webTitle: Banks lead us to mobile temptation

fields.headline: Banks lead us to mobile temptation
fields.standfirst: The finance world is queuing up to exploit Wap phones, reports Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: The finance world is queuing up to exploit Wap phones, reports Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
Suddenly everyone seems to be talking about Wap. Once an idea familiar only to a handful of techno-anoraks, now everyone is busy comparing websites on their Wap mobile phones.

Wap (pronounced to rhyme with snap) stands for Wireless Application Protocol, a set of standards agreed by the major players in the telecoms industry which determines the configuration of web pages so that they can be accessed quickly and easily by mobile phones.

Businesses are investing hundreds of millions of pounds in making sure they will benefit. Already we have Europe's first Wap auction, shopping and directory site, www.CallRed.com, that is designed to help 'time-poor' consumers purchase goods or bid for memorabilia online while on the move. Last month the UK's second largest mobile phone operator, BT Cellnet, said it was to sell its Wap phones in 1,500 Asda, Safeway, Sainsbury and Tesco stores.

The likes of BT Cellnet and Vodafone know that in the future they won't be making their money from conventional telephony, but from people who want to browse, buy, order, view, sell whatever, wherever and whenever they want.

One of the key services that will benefit from Wap technology is banking, some of whose biggest names are rushing to arm customers with Wap phones. The Halifax's internet bank, Intelligent Finance is handing out the devices for free to its first 150,000 customers through an alliance with BT Cellnet. Leading online rival Egg is in the middle of a two-month Wap trial. The range of services being tested is limited at the moment. Users can check their balance and obtain mini-statements from their current and credit card accounts. There is also a stripped-down share viewing service.

The Woolwich, however, is fanatical about Wap. It started offering the service nearly two months ago, enabling its account holders to buy a Nokia 7110 handset, which sells for £130 when signing up to Vodafone, for £50. Users are given free connection and 20 per cent off Vodafone's usual monthly line rental.

The Woolwich service, in a taste of things to come perhaps, allows users to transfer money between accounts, pay bills, check balances and recent transactions, and access a range of information services, such as the news and weather.

With other banks catching the Wap bug, it can't be long before we're all being offered free or heavily subsidised handsets. But such offers will carry terms and conditions - and when banks start issuing customers with mobile phones, alarm bells should sound.

To buy a Wap phone without signing up to a particular operator can cost anything between £350 and £700. The reason they are a cheaper on the high street is because the operator, Vodafone for example, subsidises their cost in return for the user signing up to a contract.

Likewise, your bank will issue you with a Wap phone only if you agree to accept a range of conditions. Woolwich customers, for example, have to take its credit card and open a current account.

It is important to read the small print and check what you are signing up to. Do you have to go on to a particular tariff? Do you have to use the phone for a certain number of minutes a month? Will you end up paying more in credit card charges than you've saved on your Wap phone?

You may even decide it is wise to wait a bit. Wap is not a passing fad and more deals and offers will be coming on the market over the next few months. First Direct, for example, will launch its own Wap service next month.

You might want to hold back to see which banks have the best technology and phones as well as the best financial offers.

Whichever deal you choose, the days of bank queues are practically over.

The likes of BT Cellnet and Vodafone know that in the future they won't be making their money from conventional telephony, but from people who want to browse, buy, order, view, sell whatever, wherever and whenever they want. One of the key services that will benefit from Wap technology is banking, some of whose biggest names are rushing to arm customers with Wap phones. The Halifax's internet bank, Intelligent Finance is handing out the devices for free to its first 150,000 customers through an alliance with BT Cellnet. Leading online rival Egg is in the middle of a two-month Wap trial. The range of services being tested is limited at the moment. Users can check their balance and obtain mini-statements from their current and credit card accounts. There is also a stripped-down share viewing service. The Woolwich, however, is fanatical about Wap. It started offering the service nearly two months ago, enabling its account holders to buy a Nokia 7110 handset, which sells for £130 when signing up to Vodafone, for £50. Users are given free connection and 20 per cent off Vodafone's usual monthly line rental. The Woolwich service, in a taste of things to come perhaps, allows users to transfer money between accounts, pay bills, check balances and recent transactions, and access a range of information services, such as the news and weather. With other banks catching the Wap bug, it can't be long before we're all being offered free or heavily subsidised handsets. But such offers will carry terms and conditions - and when banks start issuing customers with mobile phones, alarm bells should sound. To buy a Wap phone without signing up to a particular operator can cost anything between £350 and £700. The reason they are a cheaper on the high street is because the operator, Vodafone for example, subsidises their cost in return for the user signing up to a contract. Likewise, your bank will issue you with a Wap phone only if you agree to accept a range of conditions. Woolwich customers, for example, have to take its credit card and open a current account. It is important to read the small print and check what you are signing up to. Do you have to go on to a particular tariff? Do you have to use the phone for a certain number of minutes a month? Will you end up paying more in credit card charges than you've saved on your Wap phone? You may even decide it is wise to wait a bit. Wap is not a passing fad and more deals and offers will be coming on the market over the next few months. First Direct, for example, will launch its own Wap service next month. You might want to hold back to see which banks have the best technology and phones as well as the best financial offers. Whichever deal you choose, the days of bank queues are practically over.

fields.headline: What's in a chromosome?
fields.standfirst: Scientists have almost mapped the human genome, writes Sarah Cunningham, and such work could affect our chances of getting life insurance and, ultimately, jobs.
fields.trailText: For those individuals who need to take the highly stressful step of undergoing a genetic test, the consequent effect that it will have on their ability to obtain income protection, insurance or a mortgage is a key additional concern.
fields.body:
The relentless march of science always seems to stir up messy human problems which are far removed from the lab or the lecture theatre. In the case of genetics, it is unlikely that those who launched the human genome project in the Eighties gave much thought to the issue of insurance.

But for those individuals who consider taking the highly stressful step of undergoing a genetic test, the effect on their ability to buy income protection, life, travel and medical cover, or to obtain mortgages, is a key concern.

Around the world, hundreds of scientists are striving to map out and interpret all the genes that go to make a human being. The completion of the project is expected to lead to massive leaps forward in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases, and in predicting, through the identification of faulty genes, an individual's pre-disposition to certain conditions.

Already available are genetic tests that can indicate whether you are likely to have inherited one of a handful of relatively rare diseases that afflicted other members of your family. But within the next five to 10 years doctors believe they will have tests relating to the most common conditions that cause years of symptoms and premature death.

According to a report in the medical magazine, the Lancet, earlier this year, all UK centres offering genetic testing for breast cancer had seen patients who refused testing because they were worried the results could affect their insurability. In the case of breast cancer this is particularly worrying. Preventative measures - albeit drastic ones such as taking Tamoxifen, a powerful drug, or even prophylactic mastectomy - can be taken if the tests show you are likely to develop the disease.

There are currently seven so-called monogenic conditions for which there is a genetic test used by the British insurance industry. Apart from hereditary breast cancer, the tests are for Huntington's disease, early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease, Myotonic dystrophy, familial adenomatosis polyposis, multiple endocrine neoplasia, and hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy.

The Association of British Insurers (ABI) has drawn up a code of practice that allows its members to ask applicants whether they have undergone genetic testing for any of these conditions, and their outcome. No insurer should ever ask an applicant to take a test.

The Government has set up the Genetic and Insurance Committee, or GAIC, which is to consider the accuracy and reliability of these tests, and of others the industry may present in the future. It is due to make its first pronouncements this summer. If it decides that any of the existing tests should not be used by insurers, the ABI has said it will refund any extra premiums so far paid by life policy applicants - about 4 per cent of the total - who are considered so risky that they have to pay between 50 per cent and five times more than normal. About 1 per cent are refused cover altogether because their risks are considered too high.

Delyth Morgan, the chief executive of the Breakthrough Breast Cancer campaign, is worried. 'Our position is that we've missed out a stage in the debate in considering the accuracy of the tests. We should be considering whether we should be using these tests at all.'

The Government decided in 1998 to ignore a recommendation from the Human Genetics Advisory Committee that it place a moratorium on the use of such tests. But in several other countries, including France and the Netherlands, there are moratoria in place. In Austria, Denmark and 18 states in the US, a complete ban has been put on using genetic testing to assess risk.

Harry Cayton of the Alzheimer's Society is equally concerned about the position in this country. He says that few people are currently affected by the insurance industry's access to genetic test information because there are so few types of test available, and they are for relatively rare strains of the diseases involved. For example, the hereditary breast cancer for which tests have been developed accounts for only about 5 per cent of all cases of that disease in the UK.

In the case of Alzheimer's, the test is for the 1 per cent of sufferers who develop an inherited early-onset strain. But work on identifying genes behind late-onset Alzheimer's, which afflicts a large proportion of the population, is going on. This is expected to result in tests becoming available in the next few years.

Furthermore, tests for a predisposition to heart disease are thought to be not far off. Many people whose close relatives have died from heart conditions will wish to take tests because they will want to know if they should change their diet and lifestyle, or undergo regular checkups and perhaps take some medication as preventative measures. But will they then find themselves paying inflated insurance premiums, or unable to get cover at all?

'If I were the insurance industry I would be pushing now when it is easy, because I would know it would be of great benefit to me in five or 10 years time. Once the principle is established that the industry can use this data, the pattern will be set,' Cayton said.

Some in the medical profession fear that probing questions from insurers could dissuade some people from undergoing tests as part of clinical trials. Another fear is that insurance companies could bring in compulsory testing for some applicants through the back door by making cover prohibitively expensive for those with a family history of chronic illnesses who have not taken the relevant test.

Standard Life is one of the few insurance companies to state that it does not need to know whether you have taken a genetic test. But if you wish to put on your application form that you have had a negative result for a test for, for example, Huntington's disease, then this is taken into account. In fact the test for Huntington's is one where a test result could actually help someone applying for insurance. If one of your parents suffered from the disease, then there is a 50-50 chance that you will develop it.

'If we had an application from someone with a fam ily history of Huntington's disease there could be an extra charge,' John Gibb, chief underwriter at Standard Life explained. 'If the result [which they tell us about] is negative then they would go onto ordinary rates.' And even if you choose to tell Standard Life you have had a positive result, it will charge you as if you are still a 50-50 risk.

However, this laudable stance is unlikely to last. According to Gibb, further developments in genetic testing mean that 'it is not a sustainable approach in the long-term'. He supports the ABI's position on wanting access to genetic test data. And he does not believe that fears of an uninsurable underclass will be realised. 'I think it is alarmist. If you look at the history of dealing with medical conditions, the more you know the better insurance you can offer. The more knowledge that is available, the easier it is to assess a risk.'

Malcolm Tarling, a spokesman for the ABI, said: 'We want to do all we can to reassure people.' But he pointed out: 'There is already a group of people who cannot get life assurance; people with terminal cancer or full-blown Aids.'

In Britain the chief concern is that applications for life assurance and mortgages might be affected. Mortgage lenders do not tend to insist on life cover nowadays, but homebuyers with partners, spouses and children generally want to protect their families. The ABI code of practice specifies that people should not be asked about genetic testing when applying for life cover on homeloans up to £100,000.

In the US, as befits a country where private medicine is the norm, there is a great deal of concern about health insurance. 'It worries me that because we have a publicly-funded health service we do not think too much about this. In the US, where health has to be insured, it is a huge issue,' said Breakthrough's Morgan. This campaign suggests we should not allow the existence of the National Health Service to make us complacent. The future of the NHS is the subject of constant debate and some bodies, such as the Institute of Directors, are arguing for a move towards an insurance-based health service.

Cayton of the Alzheimer's Society is concerned insurers access to test results 'will put paid to any idea of any insurance-based long-term care system'. Insurers are unlikely to offer affordable premiums to anyone who eventually tests positive for late-onset Alzheimer's, he suggests. Therefore those who will have most need of long-term care may not be able to get insured. So it could be argued that insurers' insistence on access to genetic test results is unfair to individuals, and likely to undermine potential reforms of the welfare state.

For their part, insurers argue that not having access to test results would also be unfair. If, for example, someone took a genetic test and discovered they were 80 per cent likely to develop a fatal disease within a few years, then they could buy multiple insurance policies at standard rates - if they did not need to tell the insurers about taking the test.

The insurers also argue that looking at genetic tests is only an attempt to refine the current practice of studying family history. For example, if someone's parent had a disease that can be inherited, insurers are likely to charge them extra or even refuse cover. But if the applicant has a test that comes back negative, or if they have a positive test but then some treatment that means they will not get the disease, then it could put them back into the low-risk group that would mean lower premiums.

This will offer little comfort to a group of people whose genes make them likely to develop incurable diseases. It is this group that risks becoming the uninsurable underclass of the twenty-first century. Just hope you never find out you are part of it.

Diseases they can test for

Tests for potential policyholders are approved by the Association of British Insurers for many conditions.

1. Huntington's disease, formerly known as Huntington's Chorea, is a rare inherited brain disorder. It causes involuntary dance-like movements (chorea, from the Greek for dance) and dementia. There is no cure, but the symptoms can be treated. It begins most often in mid-adulthood and progresses slowly. A blood test can show whether you inherited the disease from your parents. Without the test, you are presumed to be a 50-50 risk.

2. Myotonic dystrophy (MD). An inherited neuromuscular disease in which there is progressive muscle weakening and wasting. Can become more severe as it is passed from one generation to another. The classic physical signs include atrophy of facial muscles, cataracts and delayed muscle relaxation.

3. Familial adenomatosis polyposis. People affected develop multiple large-bowel polyps, usually after the age of 20, which later, almost inevitably, develop into bowel cancer. People who are at 50 per cent risk, as the offspring or siblings of an affected person, are offered screening for a particular genetic mutation. Those that test positive are offered regular colonoscopic screening and, when appropriate, a total colectomy, or the removal of the colon. According to the ABI, positive or negative genetic tests in a healthy person have high relevance to insurance contracts. Insurers would take into account the markedly improved prognosis of a gene-positive individual who has appropriate surgery.

4. Multiple endocrine neoplasia. Rare conditions in which benign or malignant tumours develop in two or more endocrine glands. Genetic testing has been available two years.

5. Familial Alzheimer's disease. Kills nerve cells in areas of the brain, leading to the loss of memory and language. In more than 95 per cent of cases the cause is either multifactorial, or non-genetic. The ABI believes genetic test reults would only be relevant to insurers if, in a particular family, there was a known mutation in one of the rare causative genes.

6. Hereditary breast cancer. As with Alzheimer's, the great majority of people affected do not have specific gene defects likely to to cause a strong predisposition in their relatives. In the small number of families in which there is a known mutation in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, any genetic test results available from a relative at risk would have a serious bearing on several types of insurance. A women aged 30 with a known BRCA1 mutation and a family history of breast cancer, for example, would lose about seven years' life expectancy.

7. Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy. Varies greatly in severity, but most sufferers will have a specific gene change. Life expectancy is not reduced for most of them. Late onset might affect long-term care insurance.

webTitle: Umpire gives Lara taste for sweet revenge

fields.headline: Umpire gives Lara taste for sweet revenge
fields.trailText: Brian Lara's discomfort continues, this time against Glamorgan. The tabloids were particularly keen to gloat at his form, perhaps anxious to enjoy their moment before any backlash over the next few weeks.
fields.body:
Brian Lara's discomfort continues, this time against Glamorgan. The tabloids were particularly keen to gloat at his form, perhaps anxious to enjoy their moment before any backlash over the next few weeks. Lara will have been even more stoked up for revenge by the nature of his dismissal in the second innings in Cardiff. On a pitch seemingly constructed of suet, he was victim of a scandalous lbw decision, his pad so far north of the off-stump it was almost in Wrexham.

Without wishing to give too much away about the strenuous working life of the sportswriter, I know this because I was watching the coverage of the day's play on television. The purple overlay that Sky now run down the middle of the pitch has revolutionised the viewer's ability to read lbws. Before the innovation I was an lbw illiterate: even after repeated replays I couldn't work out if the ball would have hit the stumps.

Now with the benefit of advances such as Sky's strip and Channel 4's x-ray camera, the doubt has been removed from what always used to be solely a matter of judgment. It is the equivalent of the arrival of DNA testing in criminal cases.

And yet Lara was still obliged to walk. Worse, such decisions will continue to be made until umpires embrace technology. In matters of lbw doubt, a quick call to a third official with access to television monitors would immediately resolve the issue.

The precedent has already been set with run-outs, so why not lbw? Particularly in the current atmosphere, when poor decisions can easily be misinterpreted as financially motivated. Far from undermining the authority of the umpire, technological redress would shore it up. Not even the stroppiest of dissenters could argue with decisions based on the purple strip.

In the meantime, the Cardiff umpire seems to have guaranteed one thing. Judging by the way the West Indies bowlers were motivated to perform on Thursday, we may have seen the last smug headlines for a while about the decline of the supermen.
