webTitle: The truth, the half-truth and nothing but the start yet

fields.headline: The truth, the half-truth and nothing but the start yet
fields.trailText: The more that emerges as Judge Edwin King thunders in off his long run in the corruption commission hearing in Cape Town, the more one wonders. The proceedings, which are expected to last several months, are only three days old with the shine still on.
fields.body:
The more that emerges as Judge Edwin King thunders in off his long run in the corruption commission hearing in Cape Town, the more one wonders. Already the evidence of other players, Pat Symcox, Derek Crookes, Daryll Cullinan and Herschelle Gibbs, followed yesterday by Henry Williams and Pieter Strydom, has damned Hansie Cronje beyond his own admissions, yet the proceedings, which are expected to last several months, are only three days old with the shine still on.

It is riveting stuff but even now the feeling is that we ain't seen nothing yet. The rumour is that Satan, under a life ban himself, is to be subpoenaed to give evidence on how he ensnared the former captain. And the tapes in the possession of the Delhi police are, according to one insider who has heard them, mind-boggling, though we must wait for proceedings in India before their content becomes public; they will not form part of King's inquiry.

Modern international cricket, with its barmy scheduling, makes intense demands. Between the start of the World Cup in May last year and this week Pakistan have played 46 one-day internationals. Anyone who has experienced such rigours might have felt a twinge of empathy with the South African team when, at the end of a gruelling trip to India, they were told to play an extra match in Nagpur.

It was, apparently, originally a benefit bash which then turned into a full limited-overs international. The South Africans were knackered if not plain ill, and not unreasonably were peeved.

So when, on behalf of bookmakers, Cronje offered his side money, oodles of it, for a poor performance, it is just about understandable, if not excusable, that some decided they might as well take it. Good sense prevailed for the most part but of the two - Cronje and Gibbs - who say they succumbed, it is Gibbs who intrigues me.

Think back to the World Cup, that first fantastic encounter between South Africa and Australia and the moment when Steve Waugh clipped a gentle catch to Gibbs at midwicket and watched amazed as one of the world's top fielders grassed it.

At first sight it looked as if the fielder had got ahead of himself and was throwing the ball aloft before he had caught it. Later Cronje waffled on about a bruised thumb. The young Gibbs was forced to endure the Australian captain thereafter telling him: "You dropped the World Cup, pal." He had, as it turned out, and now we all wonder once more.

The match in Nagpur is equally intriguing for its anomalies, not least the individual performance of Gibbs who, according to his testimony, had been offered $15,000 (£10,000) by Cronje to score fewer than 20 runs and had accepted.

I n the event he hit his first two deliveries for four and scored 74 from 53 balls. He says he had wanted the money to help support his divorced mother, so this represents some change of heart. Was it a pang of conscience or did he get scared? Surely he did not just get carried away on the euphoria of his innings and, once past 20, thought to hell with it?

Could it be that Gibbs has, in fact, been dealing in half-truths - he agreed to the bribe, he says, but because of what happened he did not collect - to dilute the impact of his misdemeanour?

Already the evidence of other players, Pat Symcox, Derek Crookes, Daryll Cullinan and Herschelle Gibbs, followed yesterday by Henry Williams and Pieter Strydom, has damned Hansie Cronje beyond his own admissions, yet the proceedings, which are expected to last several months, are only three days old with the shine still on. It is riveting stuff but even now the feeling is that we ain't seen nothing yet. The rumour is that Satan, under a life ban himself, is to be subpoenaed to give evidence on how he ensnared the former captain. And the tapes in the possession of the Delhi police are, according to one insider who has heard them, mind-boggling, though we must wait for proceedings in India before their content becomes public; they will not form part of King's inquiry. Modern international cricket, with its barmy scheduling, makes intense demands. Between the start of the World Cup in May last year and this week Pakistan have played 46 one-day internationals. Anyone who has experienced such rigours might have felt a twinge of empathy with the South African team when, at the end of a gruelling trip to India, they were told to play an extra match in Nagpur. It was, apparently, originally a benefit bash which then turned into a full limited-overs international. The South Africans were knackered if not plain ill, and not unreasonably were peeved. So when, on behalf of bookmakers, Cronje offered his side money, oodles of it, for a poor performance, it is just about understandable, if not excusable, that some decided they might as well take it. webTitle: Strydom tells of Cronje's test bet

fields.headline: Strydom tells of Cronje's test bet
fields.trailText: The network of corruption at the heart of South African cricket was further exposed yesterday when two more test players told the King Commission that they received offers totalling $35,000 (£23,000) from Hansie Cronje to perform badly.
fields.body:
The network of corruption at the heart of South African cricket was further exposed yesterday when two more test players told the King Commission that they received offers totalling $35,000 (£23,000) from Hansie Cronje to perform badly.

The batsman Pieter Strydom and the fast bowler Henry Williams admitted that South Africa's former captain actively sought them out with inducements during the two-match series against India this year.

Strydom , who made his debut against England during this year's controversial fifth test at Centurion, also claimed that Cronje asked him to place a bet on the outcome of that match after the captain's last-day declaration made victory for South Africa possible.

Appearing tense and short of breath, Strydom told the inquiry: "Hansie called me to his room before the first test in Bombay and said, in a joking kind of way, that we could get 70,000 rand (£6,600) if we scored less than 250 in our first innings. I was shocked. I said no, it was only my second test, maybe if I'd played 80 or 90 I might consider it. I left his room and thought 'shit, maybe I've just passed some kind of test . . .' "

Strydom said that later that same day Cronje "nudged me in the ribs and said 'what about 140,000?' " It was then, Strydom conceded, that he believed it was no joke.

Under cross-examination Strydom was asked how Cronje could possibly hope to fix a test innings with the assistance of just one other player. At that point the United Cricket Board of South Africa's advocate interrupted and asked Strydom if he knew of anyone else who had been approached. He replied: "I believe Mark Boucher and Jacques Kallis were also approached."

These players are believed to have been approached before the second test but both are known to have angrily rejected the offers. The pair will provide testimonies next week.

Strydom also gave details of a proposal he said Cronje made to him at the final test against England, when rain had restricted play to 46 overs in four days. "Hansie asked me what I thought the odds would be against a result. I said I didn't know but I knew a guy who probably did," stammered Strydom, under obvious strain.

"He said, 'Well, call him and find out what they are and put 50 rand (£5) on a South African win. I called my friend and he said he would try to find some odds; I said put 50 rand on for me and 50 for Hansie, but he couldn't get any odds. I would have been very stupid and I'm very lucky there were no odds available." Later he admitted that his intention to gamble carried almost the same ramifications as gambling itself.

The morning session heard Henry Williams corroborate Herschelle Gibbs's previous-day account of an offer Cronje made to the pair to underperform during the fifth one-day international against India in Nagpur on March 19.

Williams said he accepted an offer of $15,000 made by Cronje in their hotel room for conceding at least 50 runs in his 10 overs. "When I walked out of the bathroom I saw Hansie Cronje in our room. He had a big smile on his face and was talking to Gibbs.

"He [Cronje] said someone he did not name had phoned him and said he would pay money for us to throw the game. I had to concede more than 50 runs in my overs.

"Gibbs had to score less than 20 and the team had to score less than 270. I was nervous but, because Herschelle agreed, so did I. I had a lot of respect for my captain and, if he could do it, so why couldn't I? I was stupid and I should have known better."

The only respite for Cronje came with the blank testimony of the spin bowler Nicky Boje, who has been charged along with Gibbs, Cronje and Strydom by Delhi police with fraud and criminal conspiracy. Boje was asked whether he would take a lie-detector test. "Any time," he replied. He has, apparently, always volunteered to take one.

In a separate development Gibbs, who had admitted accepting a bribe offer from Cronje on Thursday, was dropped for the tour of Sri Lanka and will now face a disciplinary commission.

After learning his fate Gibbs apologised to Ali Bacher, the UCBSA managing director, an official told the inquiry. "Gibbs telephoned Bacher . . . and said: 'Ali, I'm desperately sorry for what I've done,' " she said.

webTitle: Powell out to rub a 23-year itch

fields.headline: Powell out to rub a 23-year itch
fields.standfirst: Glamorgan's rising star seeks recognition beyond a day out at Lord's
fields.trailText: Mike Powell is 23 and it was 23 years ago that Glamorgan made their first and, until today, their only appearance in a one-day final.
fields.body:
Mike Powell is 23 and it was 23 years ago that Glamorgan made their first and, until today, their only appearance in a one-day final. With an ingenuity for finding tickets honed on years of experience at rugby grounds such as Twickenham and Lansdowne Road, the Welsh took over Lord's for the 1977 Gillette Cup final against Middlesex.

But that was as good as it got for Glamorgan, who slipped to a five-wicket defeat in a match chiefly remembered for the six Mike Llewellyn hit off John Emburey which landed on the pavilion roof and is acknowledged to be the biggest hit ever seen at headquarters.

Llewellyn was one of a crop of promising youngsters on Glamorgan's books. Summers of decline after their 1969 championship success were expected to be arrested by players such as Llewellyn, John Hopkins, Gwyn Richards, Alan Wilkins and Alan Lewis Jones but that potential was not fulfilled.

Glamorgan have slumped again since winning the championship three years ago; in the Second Division of both the County Championship and the National League, their appearance in today's Benson & Hedges Cup final against Gloucestershire comes as a welcome diversion and a dream made reality after failing in four semi-finals since 1988.

They have missed Hugh Morris, Tony Cottey and Waqar Younis from the 1997 vintage. fields.headline: Franco Rossi
fields.standfirst:
Italian director of gay cult movie who abandoned neo-realist promise for television success
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Franco Rossi, the Italian director who worked with Pasolini, and whose films in the 1950s won him attention as a promising addition to the neo-realist second generation, has died aged 81. Despite his early cinematic success, he earned more lasting fame with Italian audiences as the maker of high-class television mini-series adapted from Homer and Virgil.
fields.body:
Franco Rossi, the Italian director who worked with Pasolini, and whose films in the 1950s won him attention as a promising addition to the neo-realist second generation, has died aged 81. Despite his early cinematic success, he earned more lasting fame with Italian audiences as the maker of high-class television mini-series adapted from Homer and Virgil.

Rossi was born in Florence, where he took part in anti-fascist resistance. After obtaining a master's degree in philosophy, he worked for the city's radio station. In 1948, he moved to Rome, where he was one of the founders of a radio programme dedicated to poetry, The Nightingale Theatre. His early cinema work was in the dubbing studios, and as an assistant to Mario Camerini and Renato Castellani.

In 1952, Rossi got his first chance to direct. I falsari was a crime thriller about a band of forgers, and he made several other potboilers before, in 1954, directing Il seduttore. Starring Alberto Sordi, and based on a play by the Catholic dramatist Diego Fabbri -which Luchino Visconti had directed on the stage - the film was Rossi's first huge success.

The play was freely adapted to suit the comic talents of Sordi, who was already being identified as the transgressive, average Italian man, in this case a husband who believes he can hold on to the affections of both his wife and two mistresses. During production, Rossi had difficulty restraining Sordi's excesses.

Yet it was his next two films for which he will be best remembered: Amici per la pelle (Friends For Life, 1955) and Morte di un amico (Death Of A Friend, 1960). Both dealt with loyalty between young male friends. The former, aimed at child audiences, was a touching story of misunderstanding between two boys of different social backgrounds on the playing fields. With its De Sica-like feel, it won the Catholic Film Office award at the Venice festival in the year of its release.

Death Of A Friend was based on a story by Pier Paolo Pasolini, who worked on the script with Rossi. A story set among petty thieves and prostitutes in the Roman suburbs, in many ways it anticipated what Pasolini was to achieve in his own first film, Accattone. Thanks to its subject matter, and to the Mediterranean good looks of Gianni Garko and Spyros Focas, the two young men making their acting debuts, the film inevitably became a gay cult movie - and Focas went on to star in Visconti's Rocco And His Brothers.

Rossi was to choose a quite different subject for his next project, Odissea Nuda (Naked Odyssey, 1960). Shot in Polynesia, it was about a modern Ulysses travelling the south seas in search of identity. Dino De Laurentiis, who had already produced a filmic Ulysses with Kirk Douglas, went on to hire Rossi to direct The Odyssey, a mammoth (for those times) series for RAI-TV, which became a major cultural event, with Yugoslav actor Bekim Fehmiu as Ulysses and Irene Papas as Penelope. Each of the seven episodes was introduced by the ageing poet Giuseppe Ungaretti reading excerpts from Homer, which so irritated one critic that he accused Rossi of turning Homer's princesses into washerwomen.

Though in years to come Rossi was to make the occasional film, including Smog, shot in Los Angeles in 1962, in which he tried none too successfuly to emulate Antonioni, he more or less abandoned cinema for a career as one of Italian television's most accomplished directors. After Homer, he scored a hit with The Aeneid, and his later subjects ranged from Garibaldi, as a young man, to a Quo Vadis? with a curious script inventing Jesus's childhood.

Among Rossi's most interesting works for television were two stories on his favourite themes: the traumas of friendship and loyalty. Both set in Italy's fascist period, one was the adaptation of an anti-fascist novel by politician Luigi Preti, Giovinezza, Giovinezza (the title referring to the young fascists' anthem), while the other, Storia d'amore e d'amicizia (Story Of Love And Friendship, 1982) was about Roman boxers.

Before his recent stroke, Rossi had returned to work as a dubbing director. He is survived by his wife and two sons.

Franco Rossi, film and television director, born April 28 1919; died June 5 2000

webTitle: Cinema gives up the fight to attract soccer widows

fields.headline: Cinema gives up the fight to attract soccer widows
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Even the might of the movies has to bow to the power of football. During the last World Cup the studios made the mistake of releasing a string of "chick flicks" confident that thousands of football widows would flood the cinemas.
fields.body:
Even the might of the movies has to bow to the power of football. During the last World Cup the studios made the mistake of releasing a string of "chick flicks" confident that thousands of football widows would flood the cinemas.

They could not have been more wrong. As research later revealed, 40% of women preferred to stay at home and watch the football.

This time Hollywood is conceding defeat by offloading a whole flock of turkeys and saccharine dross during June.

Blockbusters such as Mel Gibson's latest Brit-basher, The Patriot; George Clooney in The Perfect Storm, and Mission Impossible 2, for which Tom Cruise did his own stunts, have ducked out of a clash with Euro 2000. All three will be released later in the summer.

Instead, those who try to escape Euro 2000 fever in the cinema will have to make do with the sugary romance Return To Me, starring X-Files actor David Duchovny; The Next Best Thing, the latest proof of Madonna's limitations as an actor, or the grisly prospect of Sandra Bullock playing a drug-guzzling newspaper columnist in 28 Days.

For connoisseurs of the truly awful, there is The Barber Of Siberia, starring Richard Harris and Julia Ormond, which was cut in half before its premiere at Cannes last year but still bombed.

In among these films that have already flopped in the US, there are gems such as Woody Allen's Sweet And Lowdown, starring Sean Penn and Londoner Samantha Morton - which is considered soccer-proof - and Gladiator is expected to roar on unchallenged at the top of the box office charts.

There is also Chicken Run to look forward to, the first feature film from the creators of Wallace and Gromit, Aardman. But it will not open until June 30, by which time the distributors reckon England will be safely home with their tails between their legs.

The new British distributor, Momentum Film, hopes to tempt out older women who still seem to be immune to football, to see a version of Noel Coward's Relative Values following the unexpected hit last summer of Tea With Mussolini.

But Mary Scott, of Screen International, said distributors who had their fingers burned during the World Cup of 1998 are reluctant to take any chances. "June is always a slow month, and despite all their efforts during the World Cup it was still very slow."

If there is little comfort in the cinema for those who loath football, there is always the television. Next Monday night, when England play Portugal, This Life is finally being given a late night re-run on BBC2. Or to placate the non-sporting viewers Woody Allen's Bullets Over Broadway is being shown during the first match today.

Channel 4 has put together a formidable "girlie" combination with Little Women, Four Weddings And A Funeral and a documentary about eternal Bridget Joneses, Always The Bridesmaid, which will go head-to-head with England's clash with Germany on June 17.

With thousands queuing every day for Tate Modern, the most sublime alternative to the football has to be the Kirov Ballet's month long sojourn at the Royal Opera House, where it is performing its spectacular original 1890 version of Sleeping Beauty. English National Ballet is staging an equally lavish modern version at the Royal Albert Hall, and in the West End, Cava, an epic musical set in Moorish Spain opens at the Victoria Palace Theatre.

For classical music-lovers the Aldeburgh festival runs for the next three weeks. And for every other sort of music Glastonbury festival will be making its annual splash on the weekend of June 23-25.

webTitle: US yellow bus plan to cut school traffic

fields.headline: US yellow bus plan to cut school traffic
fields.standfirst:
UK operator gets set to bring in American-style dedicated transport for pupils from Scotland to London, to reduce jams on roads.
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: American style yellow school buses will become a familiar sight throughout Britain under plans announced yesterday by the UK's largest bus operator.
fields.body:
American style yellow school buses will become a familiar sight throughout Britain under plans announced yesterday by the UK's largest bus operator.

Several local authorities from Scotland to the London area were said by FirstGroup to be ready to sign up to the project. The initiative is designed to boost child safety and to reduce rush hour road congestion through the increased use of school buses.

Muir Lockhead, FirstGroup's chief executive, said that the scheme had the backing of the government because it would help to reduce congestion in large conurbations. In London alone, the Department of Transport says that cars on the school run add 20 minutes to rush hour travelling time.

At the moment, the government estimates that up to 20% of the UK's morning rush hour traffic is caused by the school run, adding to the number of road accidents.

Mr Lockhead said: "America's yellow school buses are known and respected throughout the world as one of the safest forms of transport. We believe that introducing these vehicles into Britain will change travel patterns for both parents and children."

Mr Lockhead, who is in Baltimore to finalise details of the building and transfer of yellow buses to Britain, believes there are real synergies between its UK bus operations in more than 40 towns and cities, and its flourishing US school bus operations. It is the second-largest operator of school buses in America.

Throughout the US FirstGroup carries more than 650,000 students daily on 11,000 yellow school buses. These operate on behalf of local school boards in 26 different states.

In the US, some 54% of children under 12 use a school bus, while in the UK the figure for children of all ages travelling to school by bus is 20%.

School bus services in the UK, subcontracted by local authorities to mainly small operators, use traditional buses, many of them old, which are not built specially for school children. All yellow buses in the US are custom built, with yellow and red flashing warning lights, escape routes through the roof and the sides of the bus, and special safety devices at the front to stop children falling in front of the vehicle.

Mr Lockhead said that FirstGroup had the buying power to create a purpose-built fleet of yellow buses, each costing no more than £30,000. By next year he thought that at least 100 could be operating in the UK, with a swift rise over the next five years after testing.

The cost of a typical new single deck bus is £110,000, which no local authority can afford. Mr Lockhead said that there was no reason why some of the money raised from the government's congestion charging plans could not be used to help fund imaginative schemes in crowded cities.

The implementation of John Prescott's congestion charging plans by local authorities is still several years away. But London's new mayor, Ken Livingstone, could find the yellow bus concept politically attrac tive to support the introduction of congestion charging in central London.

Mr Lockhead said that "by reducing the need for the school run, these services will also cut double parking outside schools as parents drop off and pick up children."

A survey for FirstGroup by Robert Gordon University in Aberdeen has studied travel to school patterns across a range of schools in the city. Some 60% arrived by car, while 33% walked. Less than 1% cycled or went by bus.

The same survey found that up to 19% of parents with children at primary schools would want their children to use dedicated bus transport. The figure would rise to 38% for secondary school children.

webTitle: Derby's day spoiled by points penalty

fields.headline: Derby's day spoiled by points penalty
fields.trailText: Derbyshire were docked eight championship points for a poor pitch yesterday as the ECB underlined its determination to take a tougher line on the substandard county surfaces which it repeatedly blames for failures at test level.
fields.body:
Derbyshire were docked eight championship points for a poor pitch yesterday as the England and Wales Cricket Board underlined its determination to take a tougher line on the substandard county surfaces which it repeatedly blames for failures at test level.

Even the wettest May for many years proved no defence for Derbyshire as a two-man ECB pitch panel found enough mischief in a seaming and uneven wicket to impose the first points deduction since "pitch liaison" teams were set up at the start of the season.

Mike Denness, a former England captain, was on a routine visit to the County Ground when 19 wickets fell against Surrey on the opening day. He convened an emergency panel, calling up the former Lancashire captain David Hughes, in time to witness a further 14 wickets fall on Thursday.

"Due to the undue amount of seam movement and irregular bounce, we agreed that the pitch should be classified as poor," said Denness. "In accordance with the guidelines for rating pitches, there was no doubt that the pitch should be deducted the eight points."

Derbyshire, aggrieved at the judgment, which they blame in part on a bitter rivalry with their opponents Surrey, did at least stay in net profit yesterday as they completed a seven-wicket win over the champ- ions. Michael DiVenuto and Rob Bailey made the 47 runs still required as the home team reached 167 without further loss before lunch.

The ECB's new guidelines are meant to minimise the chance of a legal challenge, after a humiliating experience last season when Nottinghamshire staved off a threatened deduction with legal threats.

The pitch watchdogs interviewed the umpires, Barry Dudleston and Vanburn Holder, the captains, Dominic Cork and Adam Hollioake, and Derbyshire's head groundsman Barry Marsh before reaching their decision.

Derbyshire will believe that they have been made scapegoats, although their traditional reliance on lavishly seaming pitches has offended ECB sensibilities for the past decade or more.

The county's history is one of constant opposition to ECB policy on virtually every subject that can be named, from central contracts to the switch from three- to four-day championship cricket and the fashionable contention that the county game's main purpose is to further the development of a successful England side.

Even the wettest May for many years proved no defence for Derbyshire as a two-man ECB pitch panel found enough mischief in a seaming and uneven wicket to impose the first points deduction since "pitch liaison" teams were set up at the start of the season. Mike Denness, a former England captain, was on a routine visit to the County Ground when 19 wickets fell against Surrey on the opening day. "Due to the undue amount of seam movement and irregular bounce, we agreed that the pitch should be classified as poor," said Denness. "In accordance with the guidelines for rating pitches, there was no doubt that the pitch should be deducted the eight points." fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: If Darren Gough ruled the world, as opposed to merely the Pennines, there would be 30 board contractees rather than a dozen. A shameless plug for Yorkshire chums such as Matthew Hoggard and Paul Hutchison? Perhaps, but the new order has had little discernible impact on the England spearhead, whose sometimes blinkered devotion to the white rose can still give Roy Hattersley a run for his money.
fields.body:
If Darren Gough ruled the world, as opposed to merely the Pennines, there would be 30 board contractees rather than a dozen. A shameless plug for Yorkshire chums such as Matthew Hoggard and Paul Hutchison? Perhaps, but the new order has had little discernible impact on the England spearhead, whose sometimes blinkered devotion to the white rose can still give Roy Hattersley a run for his money.

Marc Symington and Martin Speight held Gough up at the Riverside yesterday, putting Durham, five down overnight, in the black via a seventh-wicket stand of 72, but "Dazzler" did for Symington and finished with six for 63, his best county return for two summers.

Requiring 97 in a shade over four sessions to nudge Lancashire off the top of the First Division, the visitors quickly lost three wickets, Michael Vaughan following a first-innings 94 in his comeback with seven, before Richard Blakey de-furrowed brows. Given the way the Chester-le-Street square is tormenting batsmen, small wonder Derbyshire feel miffed at being the first English victims of the PLO (pitch liaison officers).

Ten wickets already bagged, Andy Caddick, who will share the new ball with Gough against West Indies next week, capped an inspiring match for Somerset against Kent at Bath with that ever-broadening bat. Entering at 152 for eight, with 38 wanted, he and Ian Blackwell completed the job without alarm, lifting their side to fourth in the table.

Nor did the late-order derring-do subside at Trent Bridge, where Andy Harris's championship debut for Nottinghamshire continued its eventful way. Taking his career-best score to 39, he and Usman Afzaal had equalled the county's record last-wicket alliance of 152 when Glenn McGrath, kept waiting half a day for his eighth victim, decided enough was enough. "He bowled one around chest-high, Andy went back and trod on his wicket," said Clive Rice, Nottinghamshire's manager. "[McGrath] was pretty hacked off by that stage."

Suitably emboldened, Harris counted Graeme Hick among his four scalps as Worcestershire, the Second Division leaders, extended their lead to 381 before declaring, Vikram Solanki prodding the selectors with 80 off 100 balls.

webTitle: I'll deliver on the big stage

fields.headline: I'll deliver on the big stage
fields.standfirst: ...and prove my English critics wrong
fields.trailText: 'I feel confident going into Euro 2000. I'm genuinely puzzled that I'm considered in England to be a player who fails to deliver on the highest stage. Ask anyone in Holland and they'll tell you my reputation is quite the opposite.'
fields.body:
Euro 2000 is here and Holland has changed colour. There are orange flags everywhere, windows are painted orange and, as we drove through the countryside recently, it seemed entire villages had turned orange. Most people here seem to be treating the event as an extended national holiday.

Every time you turn on the TV someone is having their say on the tournament and even from within our very private, fenced-off camp, we have sensed the anticipation growing. We seem to have been building up to this tournament for so long, it's a relief finally to be getting underway.

There have been a lot of raised eyebrows that Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink was not included in the Dutch squad. I can understand the surprise because Jimmy had a great season with Atletico Madrid despite the fact that they were relegated. It was the coach Frank Rijkaard's decision and he couldn't take everyone, but once Ruud van Nistelrooy was injured I think most people expected Jimmy to go.

Instead Pierre van Hooijdonk was selected because he's seen as a useful target man who can make a big difference with his strength. He has that ability to break open a defence by getting on the end of long balls if that's necessary late on in a tight match.

Most people are picking ourselves and France as the favourites and I'd go along with that. I've a very strong feeling that my Arsenal team-mate Thierry Henry will do well this summer. I predict he will be the player of the tournament and would not be surprised if he finished top scorer.

But I really wish people would talk less about his pace and start focusing on what is an even bigger threat - his finishing. There have been many fast players down the years who could not finish and that is not really much use. Thierry has such coolness and precision in front of goal it's frightening. I look forward to our duel later in the tournament.

I'm expecting the early group games to be fairly cagey. All international tournaments I've taken part in have started slowly. I think expectations can grow so out of proportion during the build-up to a tournament that players feel very edgy at the start.

Not surprisingly a lot of my Dutch team-mates have asked me how I feel about England's chances this summer. I think they have decent potential and there is no doubting the quality of their players. But the critical factor will be whether Kevin Keegan can get the balance of the team right, as there still seems to be a lot of debate about formations and personnel.

What's interesting for me about the England team is that the entire squad - Steve McManaman excepted - play in the English league while, if you look at the Dutch squad, we are drawn from leagues in five different countries. I think the key player for England will be Tony Adams - and I'm not just saying that because he's my team-mate. He and Sol Campbell are vital for England, they provide the rock that makes the team very hard to break down.

As for our opening game against the Czech Republic tomorrow, we played them in a friendly last November and it was a tough game for us. We found them hard to break down because they play with five strong defenders. It was a good test for us because a lot of sides will play five across the back during Euro 2000. The game ended 1-1, which leaves it well poised for this encounter.

Their defender Thomas Repka is a frighteningly strong player and Pavel Nedved in midfield is a formidable opponent who can create plenty of chances for his team. We'll need to keep an eye on him.

A lot of commentators have questioned Holland's defensive ability. I think our style of play means we always risk conceding goals but we try to mitigate that with good attacks. Obviously we try to concede as few goals as possible but we also want our defenders to play football and not just mark the strikers. And you can't ask them to take part in attacks and always keep a clean sheet. However, we have been working hard on our defensive strategies and recognise that this is something we are going to have to continue working on.

As for my own game, I feel confident going into Euro 2000. I'm genuinely puzzled that I'm considered in England to be a player who fails to deliver on the highest stage. Ask anyone in Holland and they'll tell you my reputation is quite the opposite. I'm not being arrogant but I think I've proved during other international tournaments to be the player that made the difference. My goal against Argentina in the quarter-finals of the World Cup proves I'm able to cope on the highest stage.

I like big events and know how to prepare for and focus on big games and tournaments. Anyone who says otherwise doesn't know much about my career or football. It goes without saying that I look forward to making them eat their words this summer.

webTitle: World champions beware Danes bearing humble pie

fields.headline: World champions beware Danes bearing humble pie
fields.standfirst: France v Denmark
fields.trailText: Although it required a faux pas from a Russian goalkeeper to help ensure they are here at all, France's jitters in the qualifiers are long forgotten.
fields.body:
Every tournament must have a Group of Death and Euro 2000 will be no different from the norm. This year's is, logically enough, Group D but one suspects it will take something altogether more dastardly to squeeze the life out of the French.

Although it required a faux pas from a Russian goalkeeper to help ensure they are here at all, France's jitters in the qualifiers are long forgotten and their status as world champions demands their inclusion among the favourites to climb the winners' podium in Rotterdam on July 2.

With the Czechs and Dutch to come in a group comprising four previous winners, the natural assumption is that tomorrow's Danish fare inside the Jan Breydel stadium will probably be their least demanding exercise. It would be hard to argue otherwise.

Much, of course, could depend on Nicolas Anelka being in the right form (not to mention frame of mind) but Les Bleus have other attacking options even if their young and frequently misguided striker decides to throw one of his wobblies.

Thierry Henry's surge of form after overcoming his teething problems at Arsenal should justify a first-team place, especially with Christophe Dugarry suspended, while behind him remain many of the usual suspects from France 98.

Indeed, if continuity breeds success, then France must already be halfway there. Their coach Roger Lemerre was Aimé Jacquet's right-hand man in the World Cup and no fewer than 18 members of his squad were involved two years ago.

Zinedine Zidane has been strangely overlooked among the nominations for the tournament's most likely stars but the former world and European footballer of the year is still a force to be reckoned with and, if Didier Deschamps continues to wilt, this could finally be the chance for Patrick Vieira to prove his international worth.

"This set of players won the World Cup, so there is no reason why we cannot win the European Championship," Lemerre said yesterday. "We will travel to Bruges with a lot of confidence but a lot of humility as well, for we are facing a side that is making its fifth successive appearance in these championships. That record speaks for itself."

As Lemerre says, and as more than the odd pundit can testify, underestimating the Danes is not a good idea. With an audacity that had to be seen to be believed, they confounded everyone by winning the competition in 1992 after starting as 100-1 outsiders and, indeed, being invited to make up the numbers in sweden only because Yugoslavia had been barred from competing at the last minute. Furthermore, their record against France is good, winning four of their last seven games.

If lavish servings of humble pie are to be dished up again, however, they will need to find a star from somewhere. Otherwise, booking the flight home is almost certain to be Bo Johansson's final act after four years as national coach. The Swede's contract runs out after the finals and Morten Olsen and Michael Laudrup are said to be waiting in the wings.

His cause is not helped by an injury crisis which could leave him with only 15 players to choose from. Only Rene Henriksen of the first-choice defence is likely to play.

"It will take something special for us to go through," admitted Johansson. "This is definitely the hardest of all the groups and we are classed as one of the weaker teams in the competition."

Even if the Laudrup brothers have long since departed, Peter Schmeichel remains very much a part of the furniture. And with Fabien Barthez in the French goal, the contest between Manchester United's custodians past and present will provide an intriguing sub-plot to the main event.

Venue Jan Breydel stadium, Bruges

Kick-off 5pm BST

Referee Günter Benkö

(Austria)

Record France 3 wins; Denmark 5 wins; 1 draw

Television

Live on ITV from 4.30pm. Highlights at 11.50pm

fields.headline: Views from the commentary box
fields.trailText: How much do football writers know? Find out exactly how little by reading their predictions for Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Richard Williams

Portugal's time might not come until 2004, when the country plays host to the next European Championship, but it would be good to see the current generation receiving some reward for their luxuriant artistry. Luis Figo, Rui Costa, Paulo Sergio, Sa Pinto and the rest have yet to match the impact they made at Under-21 level but if they play up to their potential then only a handful of sides - Holland, France, Spain - will stand a chance of stopping them.

Martin Thorpe

How about Spain to complete a unique double after the all-Spanish Champions League final won by Real Madrid. That success plus La Liga's growing reputation as the best league in the world should help with the lack of self-belief which has seen previous Spain teams drift out of tournaments. This present team were the most impressive qualifiers, scoring 42 goals in eight games - testament to Jose Antonio Camacho's liberating effect as coach since replacing the defence-minded Javier Clemente.

Harry Pearson

Germany . It always pays to bet on your fears. Ît would be nice to think Real Madrid's sparkling performances in winning the Champions League might herald a new age of attacking football, but national teams are rarely as enterprising as club sides. The Germans are currently inadequate in practically every area except one: in Oliver Kahn they have the best goalkeeper. And they have not lost a shoot-out since 1976. Both may be decisive if the knockout stages bog down as they did last time.

Darren Tackle

There's only going to be one winner. And with all due respect to everyone else - your Turks, your Germans, your Dutch - it's pretty obvious who are the continent's top boys right now. Martial spirit, bulldog blood, Dunkirk whatsit. All that. Yeah, the England lads will walk it, no question. The football? Oh, I thought you meant the real stuff. Dunno about the football. Brazil? Sorry you're asking the wrong geezer: I lost the will to live after Keegan picked Phil Neville.

Jon Brodkin

Only West Germany in 1972 and 1974 have won the European Championship and World Cup back to back. But France look ready to match them. They may have stuttered into the finals but their squad looks stronger than the one that triumphed two years ago. As if to make sure they will not lose their way, they come equipped with the complete A-Z, from Anelka to Zidane .Take them to squeeze out Holland in the final.

Daniel Taylor

It would be bad news for those weary of Frank Leboeuf crowing about his medal collection, but I'm going for France . The world champions have not won a major tournament on foreign soil but they have the firepower to emerge unscathed from the so-called Group of Death and to have the tricolours flying over Rotterdam on July 2.

Ian Ross

Gary Lineker's assertion that any one of 10 countries could emerge from a pack of arguably dubious quality is probably correct. I suspect England may fall foul of Italy at the quarter-final stage. With Germany lacking youthful legs, Spain likely to fluff their lines and Holland not quite as good as they insist they are, I go for France . This is on the basis that they won the World Cup without a true goalscorer and mindful that Thierry Henry has blossomed.

Roy Collins

The Czechs may be a good each-way bet but Spain have such an easy-looking group and potentially a relatively easy path to the semi- finals that one must fancy them to do themselves justice at last. Italy have had a terrible run of results but the draw also favours them and they have a habit of improving during tournaments.

Vivek Chaudhary

Little is ever expected of Belgium and the team's dour approach in the past has won them few friends at home or abroad. But Belgium is bouncing and Euro 2000 is ripe for an upset. We might be able to name a famous Belgian by the time Euro 2000 is over.

fields.headline: The Odds Fellow
fields.trailText: It's time to double up on the Dutch.
fields.body:
There will be a vast array of prices on Euro 2000 and the best advice to punters is not to bet on everything. Holland , our long-range tip at 9-2 last year, can still be backed at 7-2 with Coral. The Dutch coach Frank Rijkaard has a squad of top-class players at his disposal and they could play all their games on home soil.

France, 13-2 with Eurobet and 5-1 elsewhere, have been the choice of many professional punters. When you add the goalscoring abilities of Thierry Henry, Nicolas Anelka and David Trezeguet to the experience of the 1998 World Cup winners it is not hard to see why. But this could be the time when Spain , so impressive in their qualifying games, finally shake off their tag of underachievers, and Jose Antonio Camacho's team are worth a saver at 6-1 with Coral.

England, 10-1 with Chandler and Paddy Power, may not have the all-round strength to win the title but can reach the semi-finals at 4-1 with Hill's. Italy, 15-2 with Bet Direct, have failed to capture the imagination, and Germany, 12-1 with Ladbrokes, have been virtually written off.

Belgium , 20-1 with Coral, will play all their group games in Brussels. They look capable of reaching the quarter-finals at 15-8 with Coral and are a sporting bet to go through to the last four at 6-1 with Coral.

Punters should note that Paddy Power is offering to refund all losing outright bets if the surviving home nation wins the title and also to refund all single bets on England games if any of Keegan's players are sent off.

fields.headline: So who's going to win?
fields.standfirst: We asked lots of people their opinions - then ditched anyone who had no kind of claim on celebrity
fields.trailText: We asked lots of people their opinions - then ditched anyone who had no kind of claim on celebrity.
fields.body:
Lord Hattersley

Former Labour deputy leader

My tip for Euro 2000 is England, a prediction I can easily justify. I used to be a politician and I recognise the penalties of not sounding patriotic. So I have blocked out of my mind England's appalling record in the qualifying matches, the weakness on the left side of the pitch , and the fear that Shearer is losing his pace and that Beckham will lose his temper. Were it not for my obligation to support the mother country I would put my imaginary bet on France. If Nicolas Anelka - as talented as he is intolerable - begins to perform I would have no doubt I would win.

George Best

Legend

I'm backing Spain and Holland . I know the Spanish have continually bottled it when it comes to the major tournaments but the talent in their squad is frightening and if they don't do it this time you feel they never will. As for the Dutch, they spend more time fighting one another than the opposition but if home advantage counts for anything they must go close.

Marjan Setinc

Slovenian ambassador to Britain

I only say Slovenia will win Euro 2000 because I am the ambassador. In reality Spain are probably favourites but only just. Having had three teams in the Champions League semi-finals, and with a number of home-grown players in each, they just have the edge over other teams. But there is less difference between the teams than there used to be.

Rachel Anderson

Football agent

I'd like to think it would be England but to be honest I think it's got a good chance of being Holland , if only because of the great influence of playing on home territory. These things tend to go in cycles, don't they, and I know Holland have been working really hard after going through a bad spell.

Franz Beckenbauer

Germany's former captain and coach, president of Bayern Munich

Germany are capable of defending our title successfully, not because we will make spectacular progress but because the other teams are not better than we are. France, Italy and England all experienced difficulties in qualifying as well. Somehow we're in the same situation as after the 1994 World Cup: we were knocked out [in the quarter-finals] and after that Berti Vogts managed to win the 1996 European title.

Phil Cornwell

Comedian and star of BBC2's Stella Street

Turkey. You'd be laughing the other side of your face if it was them come July. Logically you'd have to fancy Holland: home advantage, good players, technically excellent. But I can't look much further than Germany . I know everyone's writing them off but they're big, athletic, determined. Plus they always win in the end. Pity England-Germany is in the group stage. Course that could be the final. But you can't see England there, can you?

Antonio Pinto

Three times winner of the London marathon

Naturally I want Portugal to win but there are a lot of other very good candidates. If I had to put money on one team it would be Holland , who will have the support of the home crowds firmly behind them.

Jim Smith

Derby County manager

I saw France beat Croatia the other night and they were playing with a lot of confidence and arrogance. They can be tremendous in attack and they would be my favourites. The Spaniards have had a great season at club level so they would be my second tip but there is always that nagging doubt about them being bad travellers.

Ian Rush

Former Liverpool, Juventus and Wales striker

I've seen Holland quoted at 3-1 but for me the best odds are Italy at 8-1. They are always there or thereabouts and losing to Norway last weekend might just work in their favour. After them I would say Holland. They have the home advantage but a lot depends on how Dennis Bergkamp and Patrick Kluivert play. Bergkamp has not had the best season but I'm sure he will do well.

Kevin Day

Comedian and TV host

Spain . If only because I've been predicting they'll win a major tournament ever since I could talk and the law of averages suggest I must get it right eventually. They've always flattered to deceive but this time I think their fantastic club form will be something for them to fall back on. But I think Tore Andre Flo will be the top scorer.

Tim Foster

Member of the British Olympic coxless four

I fancy Spain . They were hard done by in 1996 when they outplayed England, had a bona fide goal ruled out and lost on penalties. They have quality throughout the side and Raul up front is unpredictable and creative and my idea of the star of the championship. I'm worried for England. They are a team without stars, but that is not necessarily a bad thing. If Sol Campbell finds some form that could be the key, but as a Spurs fan I would say that, wouldn't I?

Matt Elliott

Leicester and Scotland defender

There are probably 12 teams with a realistic chance, including England, but I just fancy this could be Spain 's year. It's strange that they never seem to do it in major competitions but they dominated the Champions League. Other than them it is difficult to see past France and Holland.

Keith Allen

Comedian, actor and founder member of Fat Les, whose single Jerusalem is the official England Euro 2000 song

England can go all the way and will probably get at least to the semi-finals. From then on it's up to the countenance divine.

webTitle: Neville plans to send Figo backwards

fields.headline: Neville plans to send Figo backwards
fields.standfirst: Keegan's versatile man of the left sees attack as best form of defence
fields.trailText: It used to be only Wales and Northern Ireland who were forced to pick Premiership reserves. Suddenly England find themselves in the same boat.
fields.body:
It used to be only Wales and Northern Ireland who were forced to pick Premiership reserves. Suddenly England find themselves in the same boat.

If one were to ask which player, apart from Alan Shearer, has appeared in all Kevin Keegan's 13 games in charge of England, a few guesses would be needed before the name Phil Neville cropped up.

Yet the defender who cannot even hold down a regular starting place for Manchester United has become a vital cog in the England machine.

At first his appeal to Keegan centred on his versatility; he was someone the manager kept in the squad as cover at full-back and wing-back. Of late, however, Neville's indispensable attraction has been his ability to slot in on the troubled left side.

It is often the way of things that one man's misfortune is another's gain. Had Graeme le Saux or Jason Wilcox been fit, Neville would probably not have made the final 22, which is exactly what happened to him before the last World Cup. And it upset him greatly.

But Neville's adaptability has seen him make a decent if unspectacular job of playing full-back and wing-back on the left. "I've always been fit when others haven't and I've never let Kevin Keegan down," he says. "So hopefully that stands me in good stead.

"There is a bit of a problem down the left-hand side and nothing can change the situation. We're not going to pluck a Ryan Giggs out from somewhere. So hopefully there's going to be a long England career there for me. There is no doubt in my mind I can play that position."

What makes Neville's rise to prominence even more remarkable is that he is actually right footed. On Monday England's unlikely hero is set to face one of the biggest tests of an odd-job-man career: marking one of the best right wingers in the world, Luis Figo.

The Portuguese player's propensity to drift inside or even pop up on the left guarantees Neville at least some respite from the fray. But even so the confrontation promises to be a demanding test of his credentials.

"I played against him for about 20 minutes when United played Barcelona at Old Trafford," he says. "And I've watched a lot of him on the telly. He's one of the great players in world football."

England's success in muzzling Figo will, of course, not just be Neville's responsibility alone. Keegan's ploy of playing Dennis Wise on the left wing against Brazil to stop the forward runs of Cafu at source was largely seen as a tactical dry run for Portugal.

Keegan's determination not to lose his opening game suggests that the more defensive Wise will be preferred to Steve McManaman for that role on Monday.

But either way Neville is ready to answer whatever questions are asked of him on what seems to have become his specialist subject.

"Figo loves to take defenders on," he says. "Some wingers get the ball and pass it off but Figo constantly tries to beat you. He runs at you 10 times, always looking to beat you once.

"Many times this season I've seen him embarrass defenders. But you've got to trust your own ability and make sure you don't build up these players to be bigger than they actually are. I've got to treat him no differently than any other left-winger."

Suddenly, from questions being asked of Neville, the roles are reversed. "The way I approach marking a winger is by getting forward and making sure he is defending most of the time.

"So whoever is on the England left wing would occupy the right-back who would then not be able to feed the right-winger. I've always been taught at United that the best form of defence is attack. So let's get him running backwards.

"Sometimes you can sit back and invite people on to you. You can't do that against Luis Figo. You've got to pose him the questions."

The examination begins in Eindhoven at 7.45 pm on Monday.

webTitle: Keegan shines as England's human face

fields.headline: Keegan shines as England's human face
fields.standfirst: The manager maintains his humour, poise and generosity even as the days of reckoning draw near
fields.trailText: When a Portuguese journalist asked him whether the match was likely to be a contest between technique and strength, Keegan didn't miss a beat. 'I'd never say that Portugal were just strong.' He replied.
fields.body:
His nature may be forever poised between laughter and tears, but Kevin Keegan is still smiling as England approach their opening match in Euro 2000. Yesterday we saw the Keegan who was hired to banish the bad smell left by the previous regime, a man full of relaxed humour and rational optimism.

Once the business of Alan Shearer's left knee was out of the way, most of the questions for the coach concerned England's left flank, and the identity of the player who will be stationed there when they meet Portugal in Eindhoven on Monday night. Keegan wasn't saying, but he refused to seem paranoid about it. "I know who I'm going to pick," he said at yesterday's press conference, "and we'll meet for alibis afterwards."

Barely 72 hours ahead of England's opening match in Euro 2000, his sense of humour is not just intact but thriving. When a Portuguese journalist asked him whether the match was likely to be a contest between technique and strength, Keegan didn't miss a beat. "Oh," he replied, "I'd never say that Portugal were just strong."

The sunny side of his nature is among Keegan's greatest assets, probably more important than his experience, his competitive instinct and his oft-disparaged tactical expertise. A few minutes before he appeared, Phil Neville had been talking about how Keegan had abolished separate seating for players and coaching staff at meal times. So would he go and sit next to Keegan? Certainly, he said. And would he do the same with Sir Alex Ferguson, whom he has known since he was 11 years old? Er, no.

The cultivation of approachability is the luxury of a national coach, who has no long-term disciplinary or contractual difficulties to deal with when he confronts his squad. Whatever Keegan may lack in terms of tactical sophistication, his players respond to his warmth and humanity. But there are other factors that come into play. And since hardly anyone imagines that England's footballers are intrinsically good enough to win Euro 2000, the question must be: is their coach lucky? Or, perhaps more pertinently, is he ready and able to embrace the unexpected?

Keegan claims to have decided his line-up for Monday night's match some time ago, and no doubt he is hoping that things go according to plan over the next three weeks. But it may take something entirely unpredictable to turn his squad into a formation capable of making progress at the expense of teams who seem, on the face of it, better equipped in terms of strategy and self-assurance.

To outsiders, the single most disquieting feature of Keegan's build-up to the tournament has been the lack of certainty surrounding the team's shape and organisation. Is it designed to exploit well-established national characteristics or to make the most of individual talents? Will it be reshaped to take account of the strengths and weaknesses of opponents, or is Keegan confident enough to let the opposition do the worrying? He is right to draw a measure of reassurance from the results of England's last three significant fixtures, the drawn games against Argentina and Brazil and the defeat of Ukraine, but the reality of competition will provide a different level of test.

And still, almost 40 years after Alf Ramsey became the first to assume the right of selecting the team, no one really knows what makes a good England manager. Whenever a new one is needed, the criteria for selection are determined chiefly by negative reference to the man on his way out. Whatever he was, in other words, the new man must not be.

Glenn Hoddle came into the job after Euro 96, chosen largely because, by comparison with his predecessor Terry Venables, he was young and untainted by scandal. Once installed, he also showed himself to be lacking in man-management skills, a moderniser ill-equipped to transmit enthusiasm along with his undoubted tactical acumen. The draw in Rome that took England to the 1998 World Cup finals represented a remarkable achievement, yet Hoddle's subsequent handling of David Beckham and Michael Owen laid him open to the suspicion that, as a former player whose own game was touched by genius, he found it difficult to acknowledge similar gifts in younger men.

Blithe spirit

There are no such problems with Keegan. As a self-made footballer who transcended his own limitations, he adores those blessed with the kind of talent he never had. He is an enabler, a cheerleader, a provider of unstinting and unqualified support for his squad. These qualities, like his inherent sense of chivalry, are not affected or assumed. They are bred into his bone.

When he takes part in training games, he amplifies his players' enthusiasm by sharing it, by validating the childhood dreams that still linger in the minds of those who must now face a sometimes hostile reality. He shows that, even in this billion-pound industry, a sense of joy remains an essential part of the equation. And his uncomplicated vivacity can be as much a tonic to a veteran such as Tony Adams as it is to a novice such as Steven Gerrard.

Keegan has recently been criticised for hanging on to his older players - there are plenty who would like to see Emile Heskey and Nigel Martyn replacing Alan Shearer and David Seaman in time for Monday night's kick-off - but loyalty is another of his characteristics, as is the belief that class is permanent. And in his defence he can point to the fact that, thanks to his faith in Heskey, Gerrard, Gareth Barry and Richard Wright, England have the second youngest squad in Euro 2000, after Spain. The hint of caution that has entered his planning in recent months - exemplified by the instruction to Paul Scholes to stay back against Brazil - could be banished by his response to a sudden and unexpected turn of events.

For whatever impression may be conveyed by his cheerful nature and his desire to please, Kevin Keegan is not bland. His famous tantrums - one of which led, a quarter of a century ago, to his angry exit from Don Revie's England squad - are the flipside of his impulsive generosity, triggered by a powerful sense of pride.

One evening some years ago, during his tenure as Newcastle United's manager, Keegan was sitting in the departure lounge at Heathrow, waiting to board the shuttle back home. He looked tired, like a businessman at the end of a hard day, and he had his head buried in a magazine when two fans approached him. But he put it down and turned to them and spent the next 10 minutes talking football with unforced ease and interest. Had they been Pele and Franz Beckenbauer they could not have been treated with more courtesy. Over the next three weeks, he may even get the luck he deserves.

Whenever a new one is needed, the criteria for selection are determined chiefly by negative reference to the man on his way out. Whatever he was, in other words, the new man must not be. Glenn Hoddle came into the job after Euro 96, chosen largely because, by comparison with his predecessor Terry Venables, he was young and untainted by scandal. Once installed, he also showed himself to be lacking in man-management skills, a moderniser ill-equipped to transmit enthusiasm along with his undoubted tactical acumen. The draw in Rome that took England to the 1998 World Cup finals represented a remarkable achievement, yet Hoddle's subsequent handling of David Beckham and Michael Owen laid him open to the suspicion that, as a former player whose own game was touched by genius, he found it difficult to acknowledge similar gifts in younger men. Blithe spirit There are no such problems with Keegan. As a self-made footballer who transcended his own limitations, he adores those blessed with the kind of talent he never had. He is an enabler, a cheerleader, a provider of unstinting and unqualified support for his squad. These qualities, like his inherent sense of chivalry, are not affected or assumed. They are bred into his bone. When he takes part in training games, he amplifies his players' enthusiasm by sharing it, by validating the childhood dreams that still linger in the minds of those who must now face a sometimes hostile reality. He shows that, even in this billion-pound industry, a sense of joy remains an essential part of the equation. And his uncomplicated vivacity can be as much a tonic to a veteran such as Tony Adams as it is to a novice such as Steven Gerrard. Keegan has recently been criticised for hanging on to his older players - there are plenty who would like to see Emile Heskey and Nigel Martyn replacing Alan Shearer and David Seaman in time for Monday night's kick-off - but loyalty is another of his characteristics, as is the belief that class is permanent. And in his defence he can point to the fact that, thanks to his faith in Heskey, Gerrard, Gareth Barry and Richard Wright, England have the second youngest squad in Euro 2000, after Spain. The hint of caution that has entered his planning in recent months - exemplified by the instruction to Paul Scholes to stay back against Brazil - could be banished by his response to a sudden and unexpected turn of events. For whatever impression may be conveyed by his cheerful nature and his desire to please, Kevin Keegan is not bland. His famous tantrums - one of which led, a quarter of a century ago, to his angry exit from Don Revie's England squad - are the flipside of his impulsive generosity, triggered by a powerful sense of pride. One evening some years ago, during his tenure as Newcastle United's manager, Keegan was sitting in the departure lounge at Heathrow, waiting to board the shuttle back home. He looked tired, like a businessman at the end of a hard day, and he had his head buried in a magazine when two fans approached him. But he put it down and turned to them and spent the next 10 minutes talking football with unforced ease and interest. Had they been Pele and Franz Beckenbauer they could not have been treated with more courtesy. Over the next three weeks, he may even get the luck he deserves.

fields.headline: Belgium 2 - 1 Sweden
fields.trailText:
Belgium: De Wilde, Deflandre, Valgaeren, Staelens, Vanderhaege, Wilmots, Goor, E. Mpenza, Strupar, Verheyen, Leonard.
Substitutes: De Vlieger, Herpoel, Clement, Walem, Peeters, Nilis, Van Kerckhoven, Van Meir, De Bilde, Hendrikx, M. Mpenza.
fields.body:
Belgium: De Wilde, Deflandre, Valgaeren, Staelens, Vanderhaege, Wilmots, Goor, E. Mpenza, Strupar, Verheyen, Leonard.
Substitutes: De Vlieger, Herpoel, Clement, Walem, Peeters, Nilis, Van Kerckhoven, Van Meir, De Bilde, Hendrikx, M. Mpenza.

Sweden: Hedman, Nilsson, P. Andersson, Bjorklund, Ljungberg, Petterson, Alexandersson, Mellberg, D. Andersson, Mjallby, K. Andersson.
Substitutes: Asper, Lucic, Sundgren, Mild, Gustafsson, Svensson, A. Andersson, Osmanovski, Larsson, Allback.

Referee: Markhus Merk (Germany)

The host nation has reached the semi-final stage in the last five European Championships, so not much pressure on Belgium then. After an encouraging warm-up campaign, the home side will look to Staelens and Strupar to surprise the Swedes, who went into a pre-kick-off huddle.

1 min So here we go for the next month. Sweden kick off. Will this be a draw like so many opening games?
2 Kennet Andersson tries to break the deadlock early with a rasping shot from the right well saved by De Wilde.
4 Belgium break sharply from defence, looking confident and fluid in coming forward. Wilmots and Goor combine well and the cross from the left doesn't do justice to the smooth build-up play. Encouraging signs for the home side though.
6 First set-piece for Sweden, 25 yards out centre-right. Patrik Andersson drives the ball low to De Wilde's right-hand upright, and a Belgian defender gets the slightest of touches to force a corner. The centre is cleared by Valgaeren, and the home supporters can breathe again.
8 Staelens saves Belgian blushes by intercepting Alexandersson's header through for Petterson, with only De Wilde to beat.
9 Kennet Andersson and most of Sweden start to celebrate as his header arrows goalwards from the corner, but the effort is a hair's breadth wide and De Wilde's heart can start beating again.
10 Something for the home supporters to cheer about after a breathless ten minutes. Mpenza (E) wriggles his way between to defenders to latch onto a through-ball, only to be ruled offside. He looks like a handful though, and will continue to cause Sweden problems at the back.
12 A corner to Belgium, from the right, hit to the far post and headed away by Bjorklund. The Swedes look more comfortable against the Belgian aerial threat than the other way around. The clearance is fed to Petterson, who looked to be tugged back in the Belgian area, but the referee listens to the crowd and is unmoved.
14 Wilmots, in a little space on the right, almost finds Branco Strupar with a lobbed through-ball. The Belgian striker just fails to control the ball over his shoulder and a relieved Hedman collects.
17 Strupar again the target as Belgium enjoy a good spell of attacking play. The Derby County man collects a chest-high pass with his back to the area 25 yards out, and swivels and hits a rising volley in one movement. A little too rising, but good skill nonetheless. Goal kick.
19 Real end-to-end stuff as Petterson is almost played through to the Belgian goal. De Wilde clears upfield and the ball is nodded on to Strupar, who is crowded out by Nilsson. Goal kick.
22 A free kick to Belgium, won by Wilmots' determination. All of 35 yards out on the right, Strupar meets the set-piece centre with a header but his effort does not threaten Hedman thanks to Mellberg's challenge.
24 Wilmots almost opens the scoring for Belgium, with a late run to meet a cross from the right. His diving header was slightly mis-timed, and Hedman is lucky o collect the ball which trickles into his arms. The Belgian midfielder knows that it was a good chance.
25 A corner to Sweden from the left. De Wilde shows confidence to coming for a deep cross and plucking it off Petterson's head. Belgium then break upfield and Verheyen, in a lot of space, can only blaze his shot well over the bar from 25 yards.
28 Another corner for Sweden, again from the left, again from Petterson and again claimed by De Wilde at the far post. Something tells me the Swedes should vary their delivery somewhat.
30 Sweden are making a lot of use of Hedman's prodigious length from clearances. His kicks are travelling three-quarters of the length of the pitch and causing havoc in the Belgian defence. Again Petterson just fails to latch onto another Hedman Howitzer.
31 A mis-kick from Andersson (P) lets in Mpenza (E) down the right. His cutback is aimed at Wilmots, who scuffs his shot into a Swedish defender and the momentum is lost.
34 A tackle from behind by Staelens leaves Petterson poleaxed 25 yards out on the right. The centre disappoints, hit straight at De Wilde.
37 A defensive lapse by Sweden sees the ball fall to Strupar halfway into the Swedish half. With passing options left and right, the Belgian opts to drive the ball gently into Hedman's arms.
38 Ljundberg breathes a sigh of relief as his positioning on the right flank almost leads to a Belgian goal. Vanderhaege, in the space the Arsenal man has afforded him, crosses to the far post and finds Mpenza rising to meet the ball. His header is firm but high. Hedman glares at Ljundberg.
41 Good skill by Ljundberg to turn his man on a sixpence and drive towards goal. His pace takes him to within 20 yards on the centre-right, but the low drive is straight at De Wilde.
43 GOAL! Belgium 1 - 0 Sweden Nilsson, after doing very little wrong for 42 minutes, has a momentary lapse that lets in Bart Goor on the left. The winger's pace takes him past Bjorklund in the area, and the low shot beats Hedman at his near post. Everyone, bar eleven Swedes, go nuts.
46 Half time: Belgium 1 - 0 Sweden.

45 Belgium restart the match. Sweden have substituted the unfortunate Nilsson for Lucic.
46 GOAL! Belgium 2 - 0 Sweden Mpenza, fed by a chested ball from Strupar past the stranded Lucic, drives an unstoppable shot past Hedman and into the top corner from 20 yards on the left. A great, great shot worthy of a daft celebration, which Mpenza duly provides.
48 It is all Belgium at the moment - wave after wave of the Red Devils are raining down on the Swedish defence, which is looking really shaken up.
50 Sweden call in the cavalry, substituting Petterson for Larsson.
52 Larsson wins a corner on the left. The set-piece is played short and flicked on by Larsson, into the arms of De Wilde.
53 GOAL! Belgium 2 - 1 Sweden All of Mjallby's Christmases and birthdays come at once as De Wilde, collecting a routine back-pass from Deflandre, steps on the ball and then promptly falls over it to gift the Sweden and Celtic striker a tap in to an open goal. A glimmer of hope for Sweden, then.
57 Ljundberg almost makes it a dream five minutes for Sweden. An Andersson through-ball is too much for the Belgian offside trap, and Freddy races clear towards De Wilde. The Belgian keeper is slow to come off his line and lucky to save with his legs when Ljundberg should have scored. So close.
59 Mjallby, Sweden's newest hero, is the latest Swede to beat the home side's shaky offside trap. Clean through on De Wilde's goal centre-right, he cuts back and then waits long enough for Valgaeren to tackle him. Even he looks baffled with what he was trying to do.
64 Staelens, shadowing Larsson on the right, bundles his charge over 25 yards out. The free kick is curled by Kennet Andersson, right footed and curling into De Wilde's near post. The wall ensures that the shot lacks the necessary bend. Goal kick.
66 A clumsy challenge by Verheyen on the left earns him a booking. The free kick, 10 yards in from the touchline and 35 yards out, is floated harmlessly into the Belgian area and cleared with aplomb.
68 Great play from Verheyen on the right earns Belgium a corner. A the centre is overhit and played back in. Hedman comes to claim and makes a hash of it, but the referee feels some sympathy and is blowing his whistle as Mpenza rolls the ball into the net. Free kick.
69 The Belgians make their first change of the night - Nilis comes on as a substitute for Strupar. Sweden follow suit with their last change; Daniel Andersson off for Osmanovski.
72 A corner to Sweden from the left. De Wilde comes and flaps. Kennet Andersson gets a head to it but Belgium manage to get he ball clear.
74 Belgium's build-up play has been looking more and more impressive the longer the game has continued. Luc Nilis, released on the right, fires in an outswinging cross picked up by Goor, who draws a foul from Ljundberg. The set-piece, where both sides have disappointed, is another weak affair, driven straight into the wall from 25 yards centre-left.
74 Luc Nilis clips Ljundberg's heels an sends him down in font of the referee. Unsurprisingly, he is booked.
80 Sent off Patrik Andersson, booked in the first half, clips Goor late and in full flight on the left. The referee has no choice but to show the red card and no one really complains, not even Andersson himself. Big winnings for those who chose under on the re card spread-bet then. Nilis curls the free kick precisely onto the roof of the net.
83 Nilis, enjoying the space available late in the game and against ten men, break down the right ad with two team-mates screaming for the ball around the penalty spot, he calmly lobs the ball over Hedman's bar. His manager must be frothing at the mouth.
87 Alexandersson, with a free kick in a central position 50 yards out, finds the head of Mjallby on the left of the Belgian area. His header is powerful and well directed, and De Wilde is forced to tip the effort over the bar.
88 After much messing around due to cramp and the like, a corner to Sweden from the left. A curling, far post centre aimed at Larsson coming round the back is caught by the feline De Wilde, who seems to have all his confidence back.
90 Four extra minutes to play, All that writhing around with 'cramp' does you no good, you see.
92 So much space now for Belgium to run at Sweden. Mpenza traps and turns on the left, feeding Wilmots with a lay-off. The midfielder strikes it first-time, 25 yards out centre-right. Wide and poor pretty much describes the result.
94 Full time: Belgium 2 - 1 Sweden.
