fields.headline: Fame beckons for Belgians
fields.standfirst: The co-hosts go into tonight's opener with Sweden sensing their best chance of reaching the final since 1980, writes  Daniel Taylor :   Belgium v Sweden
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan may have nominated Belgium as his dark horses but finding anyone here willing to back their chances has been almost as tricky as making it across the Grand Place without being accosted by one of its ubiquitous waiters.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan may have nominated Belgium as his dark horses but finding anyone here willing to back their chances has been almost as tricky as making it across the Grand Place without being accosted by one of its ubiquitous waiters.

One punter with perhaps more money than sense - "a twerp from Antwerp", according to one Belgian journalist - has placed almost BF500,000 (£8,000) on the joint hosts beating Sweden tonight and winning the tournament. If the unmistakable air of resignation engulfing most of his compatriots is an accurate gauge, he should not fret if his betting slip goes through the wash.

"We know that no one is giving us a chance," the national coach Robert Waseige sighed yesterday. "Sometimes when I listen to the people it is as though we are not even involved."

All this pessimism, yet Belgium's pre-tournament results are not to be sniffed at. Of their eight matches under Waseige they have lost only to England and have beaten Norway 2-0 and Italy 3-1 on their travels.

Even so there has been a conspicuous lack of tub-thumping at their training base this week. Only a few weeks since predicting a place in the final, Belgium's player of the year Lorenzo Staelens is backtracking at a steady rate, saying: "We just aren't strong enough." Even Waseige admits that their record in major tournaments is very ordinary. "I cannot tell you the reason but we cannot escape the facts."

At the age of 60, having been out of work for the best part of 18 months after parting company with Charleroi and with a curriculum vitae containing a handful of promotions but only the 1990 Belgian Cup with FC Liege, Waseige's appointment last August was curious to say the least. A bit like giving Lawrie McMenemy the England job.

Initially there was a tidal wave of scepticism but Waseige first set about winning over his players, then the Flemish media, and has accomplished both. There was even a smattering of applause when he appeared before the press yesterday.

Such has been the national side's recent transformation that Luc Nilis has been tempted out of international retirement, having previously stated he was unavailable because of the "unworkable" regime of Waseige's predecessor Georges Leekens.

An Aston Villa player come July 1, Nilis needs a good tournament to justify his inclusion in the squad ahead of Westerlo's Toni Brogno, last season's joint leading scorer in the Jupiler league with 30 goals.

"I would not have played for Belgium again if it were not for the coach," says Nilis, who scored 18 alongside Ruud van Nistelrooy at PSV Eindhoven last season.

"Not so long ago I would have laughed if people said I would be playing in these championships. But since the change of manager there is a new sense of togetherness and I want to be part of it.

"People are saying we have no chance, but the hosts always tend to do well in major competitions. Just look at France in the last World Cup: they were not fancied but they emerged as the best team."

Since Belgium lost to West Germany 2-1 in the 1980 European Championship final, two decades of less-than-heroic failure have cultivated the suspicion that they would probably not be in this tournament but for their automatic qualification by virtue of being co-hosts.

And, with Enzo Scifo past his sell-by date, the checklist of Belgian players is unlikely to have spectators rushing to the King Baudouin stadium here this evening.

The Diables Rouges will be confronted by a Sweden team who finished top of England's qualifying group, conceding only one goal.

"They have shown that they are a tough side but we have the crowd on our side and we must use that to our advantage," says Belgium's captain Marc Wilmots. "It is a good game for us to start our championships."

Waseige, the first Walloon to manage his national team, has as his main problem something Keegan can only dream about: an excess of left-sided players. One such, the winger-cum-attacker Bart Goor, is worth watching but Belgium are unlikely to score many goals; the Croatia-born Branko Strupar of Derby County and Schalke 04's livewire Emile Mpenza, or Mr 1000 Volts as he is known to his team-mates, will start in the strikers' roles, with the former PSV team-mates Gilles de Bilde and Nilis in reserve.

If the lack of star quality troubles Waseige he conceals it well. "We do not have glory-hunters and nor do we want them," he says.

"We have a group of players who are willing to work as a team rather than individuals. Despite everything that has been said, they know there will never be a better chance for Belgium to win this competition.

"It does not matter that my players are not as well known as those from Italy, Holland and England. Perhaps people will be able to name them better in a few weeks. And, besides, don't people always say it is impossible to name famous Belgians?"

Indeed they do. "It has become something of an international joke," scowls Marc Tielemans, editor of the Famous Belgians website. "People are always asking the same question so I started the definitive list. I find that five examples normally shut them up."

Only time will tell whether Belgium's Euro 2000 justifies Waseige's inclusion, but a nation is not holding its breath.

Venue King Baudouin stadium, Brussels

Kick-off 7.45pm BST

Referee Markus Merk (Germany)

Record Belgium 5 wins; Sweden 5 wins; 2 draws

Television

Live on ITV from 7pm and Eurosport from 7.30pm. Highlights: BBC1 at 11.10pm

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 7.30pm

"I would not have played for Belgium again if it were not for the coach," says Nilis, who scored 18 alongside Ruud van Nistelrooy at PSV Eindhoven last season. "Not so long ago I would have laughed if people said I would be playing in these championships. But since the change of manager there is a new sense of togetherness and I want to be part of it. "People are saying we have no chance, but the hosts always tend to do well in major competitions. Just look at France in the last World Cup: they were not fancied but they emerged as the best team." Since Belgium lost to West Germany 2-1 in the 1980 European Championship final, two decades of less-than-heroic failure have cultivated the suspicion that they would probably not be in this tournament but for their automatic qualification by virtue of being co-hosts. And, with Enzo Scifo past his sell-by date, the checklist of Belgian players is unlikely to have spectators rushing to the King Baudouin stadium here this evening. The Diables Rouges will be confronted by a Sweden team who finished top of England's qualifying group, conceding only one goal. "They have shown that they are a tough side but we have the crowd on our side and we must use that to our advantage," says Belgium's captain Marc Wilmots. "It is a good game for us to start our championships." Waseige, the first Walloon to manage his national team, has as his main problem something Keegan can only dream about: an excess of left-sided players. One such, the winger-cum-attacker Bart Goor, is worth watching but Belgium are unlikely to score many goals; the Croatia-born Branko Strupar of Derby County and Schalke 04's livewire Emile Mpenza, or Mr 1000 Volts as he is known to his team-mates, will start in the strikers' roles, with the former PSV team-mates Gilles de Bilde and Nilis in reserve. If the lack of star quality troubles Waseige he conceals it well. "We do not have glory-hunters and nor do we want them," he says. "We have a group of players who are willing to work as a team rather than individuals. Despite everything that has been said, they know there will never be a better chance for Belgium to win this competition. "It does not matter that my players are not as well known as those from Italy, Holland and England. Perhaps people will be able to name them better in a few weeks. And, besides, don't people always say it is impossible to name famous Belgians?" Indeed they do. "It has become something of an international joke," scowls Marc Tielemans, editor of the Famous Belgians website. "People are always asking the same question so I started the definitive list. I find that five examples normally shut them up." Only time will tell whether Belgium's Euro 2000 justifies Waseige's inclusion, but a nation is not holding its breath. fields.headline: Euro 2000 Shorts
fields.trailText: Economists at ABN-Amro, the Dutch bank, have pleaded with Frank Rijkaard's side not to win the tournament, saying that the ensuing feel-good factor would boost consumer spending and inflation.
fields.body:
Two players from each side will be randomly selected for drug tests during each game in Euro 2000. A draw will take place at half-time and the teams will be told which players have been chosen 15 minutes before the end. Players will then have 30 minutes after the final whistle to shower and fulfil media commitments before the test, which will be conducted in front of nine witnesses. Samples will be analysed in Belgium or Germany, neither laboratory working on samples from its own team.

 Norway's Ole Gunnar Solskjaer flew back into England yesterday to see the birth of his son. The Manchester United striker arrived at the hospital minutes before his fiancee Silje Lyngvaer gave birth at 8.05am. He should return to Holland in time to play Spain on Tuesday. There were similar celebrations in the Belgium camp where the wife of the defender Philippe Leonard gave birth to a daughter, Julia, on Thursday night. "We're going to have one glass of champagne to celebrate," said Belgium's coach Robert Waseige. "We don't want to celebrate too much." Sheffield Wednesday's Gilles de Bilde toasted his 29th birthday yesterday with a large strawberry gateaux.

 Romania's Gheorghe Hagi has recovered from a groin injury and will be fit to face Germany on Monday. "It is a massive boost for us," said the Chelsea defender Dan Petrescu. "There is not one German player capable of stopping Hagi," boasted the midfielder Dorinel Munteanu.

 A poll of the Belgium squad yesterday revealed that they believe Holland (10 votes) are the favourites, ahead of Spain (eight). Patrick Kluivert is rated the most likely top goalscorer, and Germany (14 votes) the probable big-name flop, followed by England, Italy and France with three votes each.

 The Holland assistant manager Johan Neeskens is furious after detailed plans for Holland's last-minute training disappeared from the team coach. His bag, also containing tracksuits, towels and information on his new club, NEC Nijmegen, went missing somewhere between Geneva and Amsterdam. "At the moment anything connected to the Dutch team is hot property," he said. "Perhaps someone has stolen the bag. It is extremely annoying."

 Economists at ABN-Amro, the Dutch bank, have pleaded with Frank Rijkaard's side not to win the tournament, saying that the ensuing feel-good factor would boost consumer spending and inflation. "A further boost could be harmful," they said. "We call on the sense of national duty of the Dutch players and managers." They would like to see an Italy v Germany final, as both countries could do with a boost to their flagging finances. France's economy has not stopped growing since the 1998 World Cup, and Germany's Euro 96 victory launched a three-year boom.

 Jamie Redknapp, the Liverpool midfielder who was ruled out of Euro 2000 with a knee injury, will join the BBC's squad of expert analysts on Monday, though he may have to leave to receive treatment.

 The largest single bet on any team to win the tournament was placed on England yesterday - by a German. William Hill said the £5,000 bet had helped to push England's odds down to 9-1.

 Good news for hooligans arrested in Amsterdam over the next few weeks: the giant temporary detention centre that will house them has been equipped with huge video screens to show all the action. It is, however, the only good news: conditions in the 2,500-capacity converted warehouse otherwise sound less enticing.

webTitle: Denizli dismissive of Azzurri as Zoff ponders Totti factor

fields.headline: Denizli dismissive of Azzurri as Zoff ponders Totti factor
fields.standfirst:
Turkey aim to catch slow-starting Italians cold:
Turkey v Italy
fields.trailText: The Turkey coach, Mustafa Denizli, talks a damn fine game; quite often a far better game than his team are actually capable of playing.
fields.body:
Turkey's Mustafa Denizli is likely to spend the early hours of tomorrow morning suffering from stress-related insomnia as he strolls through his team's training centre in Enschede.

An amiable man, Denizli has a deserved reputation as one who could convince even the most learned scholars that black is in fact white and the earth is flat. That is to say the Turkey coach talks a damn fine game; quite often a far better game than his team are actually capable of playing.

Unfortunately for such coaches, be they besuited or tracksuited, there inevitably comes a time when the talking either stops or, more likely, turns from idle boasting to the delivery of heart-felt apologies and half-baked excuses.

For Denizli that time will come tomorrow afternoon here when Turkey's campaign opens against the Group B favourites Italy.

Despite his obvious charm, Denizli would appear to have little respect for the Azzurri because, having watched Italy slip to a 1-0 defeat in Norway last weekend, he saw little in the way Dino Zoff's side performed to concern him.

"Italy played as Italy usually do and if they should play like that against us there really is no need for us to worry," he said. "I know that Turkey can beat them in this game.

"Italy do tend to come good in these sort of tournaments but they always seem to need time in which to warm up. So I am content to come up against them in our first fixture. I hope we can take full advantage of their slowness to start."

As Denizli stoked up Turkish fires, which hardly needed it after Galatasaray's Uefa Cup triumph, Zoff was presumably countering by pointing out to his squad that tomorrow's opponents departed the last European Championship in England with the poorest record of any of the contestants: three games, three defeats, no goals.

Italy headed for Belgium and the Netherlands with the reassuring words of their prime minister (well, he was when they left home) Giuliano Amato ringing in their ears.

Subscribing to the theory that slowcoaches do occasionally come first, Amato said: "When you start in pole position you are cursed." A little deep, perhaps, but the point is salient.

Legend has it that Zoff smiles only when convinced no one is watching, but this time he has good reason for believing the fates are conspiring against him.

Having lost the striker Christian Vieri and the goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to injury, Zoff must decide whether to gamble on the extravagant talents of Roma's Francesco Totti, a player of incalculable worth yet one who has lost both his touch and his way in recent weeks.

Neither Totti nor his strike partner Filippo Inzaghi seri ously threatened the Norwegian goal and Zoff acknowledged the deficiency in attack.

"We really were not dangerous against Norway; we were definitely missing something in that department," he said. But he added: "If you believe what the papers have been saying it seems we have not scored a goal in the last 100 games. It is not yet time to make things tragic."

True, but after Italy's failure at the group stage of Euro 96, Zoff would be the first to acknowledge that if they fail to negotiate what is a relat- ively straightforward section this time derision will be ready to embrace him in much the same manner as gnawing uncertainty has smothered his Turkish counterpart.

Venue Gelredome, Arnhem

Kick-off 1.30pm BST

Referee Hugh Dallas

(Scotland)

Record Turkey 0 wins; Italy 6 wins; 1 draw

Television

Live on BBC1 from 1.15pm

Highlights on ITV at 11.50pm

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 12.30pm

webTitle: D-day for Shearer in the battle of wounded knee

fields.headline: D-day for Shearer in the battle of wounded knee
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer will lead out England against Portugal in Eindhoven on Monday night provided he comes through a practice session this morning without aggravating the knee injury which has forced him to miss five days' training.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer will lead out England against Portugal in Eindhoven on Monday night provided he comes through a practice session this morning without aggravating the knee injury which has forced him to miss five days' training.

Kevin Keegan took the England captain off early in the second half of last Saturday's final warm-up game in Malta. Shearer came down awkwardly on the knee which had been bothering him for several weeks and he had a precautionary scan on Thursday.

The England coach remains confident that Shearer will make the opening match and the word from the medics here bears out his optimism. The only worry is that Shearer may feel he wants more rest before committing the knee to a full training session.

"Alan's injury isn't serious," Keegan said yesterday. "His only problem is the clock and whether or not he will make it in time. My feeling is that he will be OK. And even if he doesn't play against Portugal he will have five days to make the game against Germany. So while I would prefer Alan to train I would be prepared to give him another 24 hours because of what he means to us.

"It won't be easy for him if he does train in the morning. Alan's fitness will be a matter for consulation between the player, the medical staff and myself. But it's got to be my decision at the end of the day."

Keegan would not risk a partly fit Shearer against Portugal simply because it is the opening match and one England know they must not lose. He remains confident that if necessary players such as Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler have the maturity to fill in for the England captain.

"They may be kids but they're not fazed by anything," he stressed. "From what we've seen, and in spite of their relative lack of international experience, they're capable of taking leading roles."

Assuming Shearer is fit, Keegan has already decided the who and the how of his team for Eindhoven. "I know the system I will play and the people I will play," he said yesterday. The feeling is growing that the side will show only one change from the 1-1 draw with Brazil, with Tony Adams rejoining Sol Campbell in a back four and Martin Keown standing down.

England (4-4-2, probable): Seaman; G Neville, Adams, Campbell, P Neville; Beckham, Ince, Scholes, Wise; Shearer, Owen.

webTitle: Czechs on a roll to rock locals

fields.headline: Czechs on a roll to rock locals
fields.standfirst:
The Euro 96 runners-up are confident of taking Holland in their stride:
Holland v Czech Republic
fields.trailText: The Euro 96 runners-up certainly face a tough task to progress, let alone go one better. France and Denmark await but first come the co-hosts tomorrow, and the Dutch mood is clear. The balloons and Hup Holland flags are showing.
fields.body:
If first impressions count, the Czechs must expect an uncomfortable time. Their 6ft 7in striker Jan Koller arrived at their headquarters here to discover he needed a new bed which would fit him; team-mates found the hotel rooms too small. Dutch and French fans would doubtless tell them not to worry - that they will not be staying long after all.

The Euro 96 runners-up certainly face a tough task to progress, let alone go one better. France and Denmark await but first come the co-hosts tomorrow, and the Dutch mood is clear. The balloons and Hup Holland flags are showing. The water in one fountain has even been dyed. The locals believe the future's bright, the future's Oranje.

The Czechs, though, deserve respect. They are flattered by the statistics (third in Fifa's rankings, 10 wins out of 10 in qualifying and those silver medals). But their resilient, skilful players are no pushovers, even after a bad night's sleep. In England they came through a group containing Italy, Germany and Russia. They fancy a repeat.

"People don't expect us to get through but inside we believe we can do it," said Pavel Srnicek, the No1 keeper despite not being an automatic choice for Sheffield Wednesday. "After Euro 96 a lot of the players moved to big European clubs and we have the quality and experience of that."

Srnicek admits he would settle for a point tomorrow, and a 1-1 draw in Eindhoven in a friendly last November gives cause for hope. The balding, towering Koller scored that day and gave Jaap Stam a tough time. Perhaps Holland should use the Amsterdam Arena's retractable roof to make the 27-year-old play with a stoop.

Since his debut 16 months ago Koller has established himself as an international giant in more ways than one. His 14 appearances have yielded 13 goals. Not bad for someone sold by Sparta Prague to Lokeren for around £70,000. Anderlecht paid nearer £3m last year.

"Jan is strong but also fast and good with his feet," Srnicek said. "Some people treat him as a joke because of how he looks but he's a quality player. He's a key man in attacking and defending free- kicks and when we're under pressure he can hold up the ball and lay it off. That's what you need against teams like Holland. They are at home so they have to attack. Maybe this will work to our advantage and we can sneak one or two."

The Dutch have a tendency to lose concentration but their greater quality and attacking pace should see them through. Marc Overmars is expected to recover from injury and could prosper if the Czechs field the inexperienced defenders Petr Gabriel and Milan Fukal. Jozef Chovanec's side are definitely without Patrik Berger, who begins a two-match ban. "It will not be easy to fill that gap," the coach said.

Presumably it was not Chovanec in the helicopter spotted above one of Holland's private training sessions yesterday. But if Frank Rijkaard is keeping much to himself he had good news for a public who want sexy football, albeit a more successful version than Ruud Gullit gave Newcastle.

"We know the Dutch want to win in a certain manner," he said. "Beautiful football is one of the objectives. If we play attractive football we give our selves more chances but effectiveness is vital too. There are certain teams that play in a defensive way but there will be a time when they have to come out and play. That's when we can benefit."

Chovanec, a former PSV Eindhoven player, does not have a reputation for negativity. He will look to his playmaker Pavel Nedved of Lazio, whose battle with Edgar Davids promises to be critical. The Dutch hope Davids can run a midfield as well as he apparently runs through buildings. A skyscraper in Rotterdam, pictured on page one, shows him charging through one side and emerging the other.

For Nedved the biggest worry seemed to be the referee Pierluigi Collina. He and Tomas Repka, the Fiorentina defender, have been sent off three times between them in Italy, on each occasion by Collina for dissent. "He is smiling and laughing with players," Repka said, "and suddenly he plunges the knife in your back."

Of course the knives will be out for Rijkaard if he fails. He said he would stress to his defence the need for communication but will not announce the team to his players until tomorrow. "I think it should be made at the last minute," he said. "It gives a little extra tension. I also don't see any advantage in saying it now."

Too often the Dutch have struggled to turn superiority into victory under Rijkaard, winning only four of his 17 games. As the coach told his critics: "You wouldn't judge Pavarotti by the way he sings in the shower." But he knows the Czechs are ready if anyone slips on the soap.

Venue Amsterdam Arena

Kick-off 7.45pm BST

Referee Pierluigi Collina

(Italy)

Record Holland 0 wins; Czech Republic 1 win; 2 draws

Television

Live on BBC1 from 7.30pm and Eurosport from 7pm. Highlights on ITV at 11.50pm

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 7.30pm

webTitle: Ball's record stuck in unlikely groove

fields.headline: Ball's record stuck in unlikely groove
fields.trailText: The brilliant BBC series Three Lions ended last night, detailing 34 years of the sort of incompetence which hardly makes the chest swell with anticipation at England's latest expedition.
fields.body:
The brilliant BBC series Three Lions ended last night, detailing 34 years of the sort of incompetence which hardly makes the chest swell with anticipation at England's latest expedition. What made the series so watchable was the way it dredged up enough previously unseen material to revivify scenes that had long since jaded through familiarity.

Bobby Moore's home videos, for instance, were a cack-handed joy: the golden boy appeared incapable of holding a camera steady. Even more revealing was how much has changed in the technical coverage of football. In 1986 it took until the next day, when the still photographs showing the incident from a different view had been processed, to prove conclusively that Diego Maradona had used his hand for his first against England.

Nowadays every angle would have been covered and his dexterity immediately shown and reshown in mega slo-mo. It wouldn't have made any difference to the outcome but it would have added to the sense of righteous indignation.

But whatever Three Lions' freshness, one thing doesn't change: Alan Ball talking about '66. "Never a day goes by without someone reminding me about that day," he chirruped. Surely what he meant was: "Never a day goes by without me reminding someone about that day."

fields.headline: White's week
fields.standfirst: Why keepers love shoot-outs:  Condemned Southgate still can't take the P
fields.trailText: Why keepers love shoot-outs: Condemned Southgate still can't take the P.
fields.body:
As a punishment, Gareth Southgate's surely does not fit the crime. There he was, this most articulate and thoughtful of players, at the England camp on Thursday, obliged to run through a procedure so familiar he must have committed the script to heart long ago. Facing a press conference, Southgate knew the pattern: cursory attention would be paid to the current state of the England party, brief mention would be made of the team's chances, someone would raise the subject of his transfer request and probable move to Stamford Bridge. And then out it would come: the P word.

"So, Gareth, will you take a penalty this time round?"

Judging by the look on his face when the representative of the Press Association asked it, given the choice of retribution for his error four years ago of having all his limbs removed or being required to answer the same question every time he is interviewed for the rest of his life, Southgate would have cheerfully sacrificed an arm or two.

But such is the hold the shoot-out has. Since it was introduced to international competitions in 1976 (the only occasion, incidentally, Germany has lost one) it has weighed heavy on our collective memories. And not only in England, where the team's departure from the last three major tournaments in which they have participated has been on penalties. The Dutch have a similar record to ours - two semis and a quarter-final have been lost that way - and the Italians have contrived to lose four, including the biggest of the lot, the World Cup final of 1994, a game now remembered solely for Roberto Baggio's extravagant scoop at the last. No doubt Euro 2000 will produce another 12-yard lottery.

The only wonder is that some sharp marketeer hasn't introduced a trophy, in the manner of the Golden Boot, to commemorate the poor sap who loses it this time. If anyone had, smart punters would already be queuing at their bookies to stake the mortgage on Gary Neville taking home the golden pizza.

For a television audience, the shoot-out's condensed dramas have become central to its enjoyment of tournaments. When ITV gleaned the biggest viewing figures in its history for the England-Argentina match at the last World Cup, the 28m were assembled in their front rooms only for the 15 minutes of penalties. During much of the rest of the game almost half that number were otherwise engaged. Whole books have been written - Andrew Anthony's On Penalties but the latest - assessing the peculiar psychology of the shoot-out. Though in truth, none of the verbiage has yet to match the analysis of Gareth Southgate's mum: "He should have kicked it harder."

And whereas most of the players honing their techniques over the next few days will be hoping there is no chance of them being consigned to a lifetime answering the same question at press conferences, there is one group of individuals who would not mind at all if a crucial game were still inconclusive after 120 minutes: the goalkeepers.

"Whoever wrote that book the Goalkeeper's Fear Of The Penalty clearly never played in goal," says Peter Chapman, author of the Goalkeeper's History of Britain, written entirely from the perspective of the No1. "The fact is most goalies love penalties because no one is expecting you to save any of them. The ignominy of missing a penalty is far greater than if you fail to save any. And if you do save one, you're a hero."

All that, though, may be about to change. New Scientist magazine this week published research by John Moores University, Liverpool, which suggests that goalkeepers ought to be able to predict precisely where a penalty kick is about to be placed, by watching the alignment of the taker's hips.

"I suppose you could say this is typical of the victim/martyr complex of the goalkeeper," says Chapman, "but it seems to me someone somewhere is trying to screw up the fun for us keepers by placing the burden of expectation on our shoulders.

"People won't think 'Hey, well done' if you stop one, they'll be wondering how come you don't stop them all. At the level I played at, I always watched their eyes. I'd see which way they were looking and dive in the opposite direction. Nine times out of 10 I was right. Mind you, I expect the Euro 2000 players are a bit subtler than that."

Don't be too sure. Any goalkeeper facing England in a shoot-out may find the Liverpool study less than useful. Hard to work out which way a player's hips are aligned when his knees are wobbling like half-set jelly.

fields.headline: All of a blur
fields.trailText: When West Germany met Holland in Hamburg in the semi-finals of the 1988 European Championship, and Holland won, the Italian football headlines declared it a victory for Milan over Internazionale, who had provided the key players in each team.
fields.body:
It could be argued that the European Championship that matters most this year has already been completed. Two and a half weeks ago Real Madrid beat Valencia in Paris to win the Champions League, a competition which now dwarfs every other tournament except the World Cup.

The qualifying rounds for the next Champions League are only a few weeks away. In the meantime the leading players will don national costumes, stand to attention for their national anthems, make patriotic noises and try to convince themselves that winning Euro 2000 is their hearts' desire.

Maybe, in the shorter term, it is. Remember the wild German celebrations at Wembley four years ago when Oliver Bierhoff's goal in sudden-death extra-time ended Czech resistance?

Of course, the cynical view was that the eruption on to the pitch from the German bench helped convince the referee that it was not worth halting the hugging to consult the linesman, whose flag had been raised as the ball entered the net. Yet the German glee was genuine enough. In the end all teams like winning things.

Nevertheless it is impossible to avoid noticing that among the 16 finalists competing in the European Championship, which starts today, few can be said to reflect either the strength of the football being played in their countries or the make-up of their best club sides.

Take today's opening match. Only half the Belgium team play in Belgium and their most successful clubs draw heavily on foreign talent. Almost the entire Sweden side are based abroad.

Spain and Italy will field strong line-ups drawn from their own leagues but their leading clubs are still full of imports. The strength of France, the World Cup holders, is based in England, Italy and Germany.

England only partly represent the best of the football being played in the Premiership. True, players from Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool make up the bulk of Kevin Keegan's side but, if England were to meet a Premiership foreign XI over five games, who would win the more times?

International football was not always cross-pollinated in this way. When West Germany and Holland met in the final of the 1974 World Cup it really was a contest between the best of what was being seen within those countries. Bayern Munich, in their own Olympic stadium, were taking on a Dutch team drawn from Ajax and Feyenoord. Yet, when the same countries met in Hamburg in the semi-finals of the 1988 European Championship, and Holland won, the Italian football headlines declared it a victory for Milan over Internazionale, who had provided the key players in each team.

A consoling thought for certain England supporters is that, even if Keegan's team do not reach the final in Rotterdam, there is a fair chance that someone on the pitch will give somebody something to cheer about, even if it is only Leicester City's Muzzy Izzet sitting on the Turkey bench.

The football played by England teams has never represented the best of the football being played in England. When Alf Ramsey's side were winning the World Cup in 1966, Denis Law, one of the finest English league players of his generation, was brooding over his putts and reflecting that at least Scotland should have been there to give Ramsey a better run for his money.

It would be unwise to speculate on precisely what George Best was doing that afternoon. Suffice to say the finest player produced by British football never appeared in a major international tournament, a fate which will be shared by Ryan Giggs unless there is a Wales revival worthy of Lazarus.

The strength of English football has always lain in the diversity it has enjoyed from beyond its boundaries. "You know what the trouble with our football is," Ron Greenwood used to say. "Too many foreigners." And he was referring to what was then a steady influx into the Football League from Scotland, Wales and Ireland.

Given the trickle of genuine foreign talent after the ban on imports was partially lifted in 1978 and the present influx post-Bosman, it is a wonder any serious-minded person gives a fig for England ever being able to reproduce the lone success of 1966 in either a World Cup or a European Championship.

E ven then few expected Ramsey to fulfil his much-mocked prediction that England would win the Jules Rimet trophy. Now Bobby Moore, Bobby Charlton, Geoff Hurst, Gordon Banks and the rest are held up as icons of a golden age of English achievement that is long gone.

Yet this period of English supremacy was relatively brief and undoubtedly helped by the fact that for neither the 1966 and 1970 World Cups did Ramsey have to cope with the tiresome business of qualifying. In terms of achievement, Bobby Robson's feat in both qualifying for the 1990 World Cup and reaching the semi-finals ran Ramsey close.

Now Keegan has the chance to bring home a little glory. Few believe his team will win Euro 2000 and some doubt whether England will get past the opening round. But this England team may yet surprise us, if only for their ability to maintain a distinction in importance between country and club which is becoming increasingly blurred.

fields.headline: Beware men in grey
fields.standfirst: As Euro 2000 kicks off in Brussels today, some think that England's style could be tailor-made to cause an upset.
fields.trailText: As Euro 2000 kicks off in Brussels today, David Lacey thinks that England's style could be tailor-made to cause an upset.
fields.body:
Whoever has kitted out the England squad in grey suits for the European Championship may have shown an unexpected degree of prescience. Functionalism is more likely to win Euro 2000 than flair, and in football it is always unwise to underestimate the power and influence of men in grey.

The days leading up to a major tournament belong to the romantics. There is no harm in imagining the title being won by an exquisite touch from Dennis Bergkamp, a nod and a wink from Zinedine Zidane, a flash of genius from Raul or one of David Beckham's outrageous free-kicks.

With luck the coming three weeks in the Low Countries will witness moments such as this and more besides. Yet reality suggests the championship will be won by the side that has the best-organised base, in defence and midfield, from which to launch the swift counter-attacks which are fundamental to the modern game.

No team can now get away with possessing a handful of skilled individuals if their defence is flabby and inefficient. The great Brazilian side of 1970 had Pele, Tostao, Jairzinho and Gerson to make up for their shortcomings at the back but in the last World Cup final, once Ronaldo went broody, they were punished by France, and in particular Zidane, for elementary errors at set pieces.

When Brazil won the 1994 World Cup, courtesy of Roberto Baggio's miss in a penalty shoot-out, they owed their success as much to Dunga's consistency as a defensive midfielder as Romario's excellence up front. The European Championships of 1992 and 1996 were won by worthy rather than outstanding sides from Denmark and Germany.

Not since Marco van Basten met a long cross from Arnold Muhren with an astonishing volley into the Soviet Union net from the narrowest of angles to complete Holland's triumph in the 1988 tournament has either of the biggest international prizes been won with similar panache.

Take away the untypically English atmosphere of carnival that greeted every match England played at Wembley and the rest of Euro 96 was for the most part a prosaic, plodding affair which promised something better in the opening phase but then became bogged down in stalemates and shoot-outs.

Such a fate will await Euro 2000 unless the fancied teams impose themselves early on the competition or an underrated side or two gain confidence as they go along, rather as the Czech Republic did last time. The fact that this appears to be a more open contest than usual, with only France and Spain looking like teams in any sort of tournament-winning form since the qualifiers, makes for interesting odds but does not guarantee a high standard of performance. It is in nobody's interest to allow opponents time and space in which to play. The Dutch alone make it a policy to hang loose at the back, and much good this did Barcelona in Valencia in the Champions League semi-finals.

Most coaches will concentrate on stifling opponents in midfield while relying on their best passers to probe for openings. Germany, Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Portugal and the Czech Republic will all adopt this approach in the hope that the likes of Mehmet Scholl, Kjetil Rekdal, Daniel Andersson, Marc Wilmots, Rui Costa and Pavel Nedved can find a way through the maze.

France, Italy, Spain, Holland and England should have a wider range of options because each possess a greater variety of players. As world champions France are going into Euro 2000 as favourites in the minds of many but again the form, fitness and above all the mood of Zidane is central to their chances. Thierry Henry and, perhaps, Nicolas Anelka will give them more goalscoring potential than their largely token strike-force two years ago.

The Italians were the best-looking team in the 1996 tournament but blew it in the group phase after their then coach, Arrigo Sacchi, fielded a weakened team against the Czechs and lost. The injury which is keeping Christian Vieri out of Dino Zoff's attack this time means more will be asked of the erratic Alessandro del Piero, along with the hope that Francesco Totti proves himself the prodigy he has promised to be.

Is this to be Spain's year at international as well as club level? Real Madrid won the Champions League in stunning fashion and even if an English player, Steve McManaman, an Argentine, Redondo, and a Brazilian, Roberto Carlos, shared much of the credit, Raul and Michel Salgado will provide strong elements of that triumph. Add in Abelardo and Josep Guardiola from Barcelona plus Gaizka Mendieta, a talismanic influence for Valencia, the Champions League runners-up, and Spain clearly have more going for them than most.

But then they nearly always do, only to drift out of a tournament before the later stages. Spain were unlucky against England at Wembley in 1996, when they lost a quarter-final on penalties after crucial refereeing decisions had gone against them in the actual match. Certainly they have the quality to reach the final this time.

Dutch mood swings

For the Dutch this almost goes without saying. If Frank Rijkaard's team do not at least make the final after playing on home soil or the grass next door, Holland will consider themselves failures. And with Bergkamp and Patrick Kluivert backed by Edgar Davids, Clarence Seedorf, Philip Cocu and, if he is fit, Marc Overmars, how can they possibly fail?

The simple answer is because they are Dutch footballers with all the inconsistencies of form and mood which this implies. Since France 98 their results have been indifferent, their performances patchy, and though the squad have taken more happily to Rijkaard than some of his predecessors, there persists the fear that the team will not achieve an inner toughness to match their outstanding technique.

All of which leaves the men in the grey suits. Oh, titter ye not, but England could become European champions in Rotterdam on July 2.

It is not likely because Keegan's defence is too reliant on the uncertain fitness of Tony Adams and the team as a whole is too prone to giving the ball away. But in Beckham, Alan Shearer, Michael Owen and Paul Scholes, England have a nice assortment of potential match-winners, and should they negotiate the opening round then anything is possible. If Holland are the logical choice as winners, with France second favourites, then England are surely the dark horses or at least a darker shade of grey.

And Kev does know a bit about the gee-gees.

webTitle: Deadline set for TV rights battle

fields.headline: Deadline set for TV rights battle
fields.trailText: Broadcast rights for the Premier League from the 2001 season will be awarded next week, settling the most lucrative and fiercely fought battle in British television history.
fields.body:
Broadcast rights for the Premier League from the 2001 season will be awarded next week, settling the most lucrative and fiercely fought battle in British television history.

The Premier League club chairmen yesterday voted to move forward with sealed bids to be handed in by Wednesday, with the winners being named the following morning.

The bids will be for 66 live matches, 40 pay-per-view games and a single free-to-air highlights package instead of the two originally proposed. In effect the BBC and ITV are in a winner-takes-all situation.

Clubs have also decided that the live rights must be held by a different broadcaster to the holder of the pay-per-view package. Estimates have suggested that the bidding for the three-year contracts will lead to a £2bn windfall for the clubs.

fields.headline: First-aid kit
fields.trailText: Antiseptic wipes and cream, plasters, crepe bandage,safety pins, scissors, paracetamol.
fields.body:
I just grab a few things from the bathroom cabinet.
Sure you wouldn't like a pouch?

Depends what's in it
Antiseptic wipes and cream, plasters, crepe bandage,safety pins, scissors, paracetamol. That's the basic one.

Not much good in the Matto Grosso.
No, but fine for visiting most developed countries: proper medical help within 24 hours.

But I'm going upcountry.
More than two days from a clinic? You need a bigger kit, even in Europe and the US. Various dressings, a sling, adhesive tape, plastic gloves, stronger analgesics, a general antibiotic, water-purifying tablets. Talk to your doctor before you go.

Who makes the kits?
Lifesystems, Nomad, Go Travel Products are three good brands. About £8 for a basic pocket pack, £20 for a sterile set, £40 for a mountain leader kit.

And where do I get them?
Boots, some chemists, specialist outdoor shops,clinics like the Royal Free Hospital Travel Health Centre in London (020-7830 2885).The Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine has a travel clinic and advice line (0906 7088807). So has The Scottish Centre for Infections and Environmental Health (0141- 300 1100) and Bristol Royal Infirmary (0117 9284848). And most GPs do travel clinics and immunisations.

fields.headline: WAP shop
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor looks ahead to see how WAP phones will aid travellers worldwide
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor looks ahead to see how WAP phones will aid travellers worldwide
fields.body:
What do you do if you want to send an email, look at a website or even read the Guardian on holiday? Business travellers may have a laptop, and the better-off may own a PDA (Personal Digital Assistant) but many mobile phones now have access to WAP (wireless application protocol) technology, which travellers can use to catch up with the information they don't want to leave behind - football and cricket scores, news and comment, weather reports and emails.

Net Café Guide
The ICG lists the addresses and details of more than 3,000 internet cafés around the world. All the listings are searchable, so there's no need to heed the frequent exhortations to buy the book - unless you have no itinerary whatsoever.

CitySync
Palm owners can download city guides on to their hand-held computer for just under $20 each. The cities currently available are Paris, London, Sydney, San Francisco, New York, Las Vegas, Hong Kong, Chicago, Los Angeles, Miami and Bangkok.

eKno
eKno is a free service, run in association with Lonely Planet, which enables travellers to store passport and other details in a virtual "vault". If the documents are stolen, copies can be retrieved in an emergency. E-mail, voicemail and "text-to-speech" mail (meaning you can check e-mails without the need for a screen and net connection) are also part of the package.

So you need a PDA?
A critical guide to the PDAs on the market, with links to their respective websites. This is a regularly-updated but brief summary which you might want to supplement with one of those glossy, heavy old-media magazines that exist to review and advertise new gadgetry.

Wapalize
Anyone wondering whether to bother with a WAP phone - though apparently it might be worth waiting for the old-fashioned-sounding but much faster GPRS (General Packet Radio Service) versions - can see how the Guardian Unlimited WAP service looks on screen by visiting this site.

AvantGo
AvantGo provides a means of receiving internet services on a PDA, anywhere in the world. In other words, it enables you to download various channels via a computer with a net connection. The 52 dedicated travel channels include information from reviews from Fodors guidebooks, flight tracking, interactive maps, American Express and lastminute.com.

Steve Kropla's help for World Travellers
Chiefly of help to laptop users, this is a guide to the various types of phone line used around the world, voltages, plug conventions and direct dialling codes.

fields.headline: Branch lines
fields.standfirst: There is more to the Aegean than bare rock, concrete hotels and luke-warm moussaka.  Ben  Mallalieu finds a greener Greece
fields.trailText: There is more to the Aegean than bare rock, concrete hotels and luke-warm moussaka. Ben Mallalieu finds a greener Greece
fields.body:
The narrow Pelion peninsula rises in only half a dozen miles to 5,000ft, high enough for skiing in winter with a clear view of the sea. The villages on the western side are recognisably Greek, with tavernas along the sea edge between tall, white-painted eucalyptus trees. To the south, it begins to look like Tuscany, with lines of Mediterranean cypresses and poplars and hillsides of camomile. But the north-east corner is unique.

The village houses have sloping stone roofs, like Cotswold cottages. They are also slightly Tyrolean, slightly Yemeni, a little like Charles Rennie Mackintosh, but unlike anything you would expect to find in Greece. Or anywhere.

The mountains are covered in a dense forest of plane, sweet chestnut, walnut, oak and holly. There are more than 2,000 species of indigenous plants, including ferns, moss and clematis. You cannot walk far without hearing the sound of running water. The air is fresh even in August.

By the coast, bougainvillaea grows from "English" lawns of grass, daisies and buttercups. Rhododendrons and camellias look happier than anywhere in mainland Europe. Roses thrive untroubled by blackfly or mildew. At Damouchari in mid-May, a magnolia grandiflora was in flower, three months out of season.

But the best plant of all was the plane tree in the main square in Tsagarada, one of the most extraordinary plants anywhere in the world. It is said to be 1,500 years old and has a trunk more than 25ft in diameter, far wider than the largest English oak. One of its branches is propped up on a stone plinth, as though it is leaning against a bar. Contrary to the usual laws of botany, two other branches join together 20ft above the trunk to form a single, seamless arm.

It doesn't seem like a plant at all, more like a giant cuttlefish. You can imagine it staring at you like a chess player who has just made the winning move and is waiting to see how long it takes you to realise.

The original inhabitants of the area claimed descent from Ixion, an oak god with mistletoe genitals (although how anyone could sire children with mistletoe genitals is not clear). They worshipped the centaur in fly agaric-fuelled rituals, and their promiscuity shocked the more straitlaced Hellenes.

The cave of the centaurs can still be found in the mountains above Milies, but few echoes remain of the early inhabitants and their bizarre cults. They were driven out in the dawn of the classical age, and the modern settlements were founded by Slavs from the north in the 6th century AD.

Late one night, I met a large, very healthy-looking fox. But there are no longer any bears, wild boar or wolves in the forest. And definitely no centaurs.

Unlike anywhere else in the western Mediterranean, Pelion has enjoyed 1,500 years of virtually unbroken prosperity and stability. Even the 1955 earthquake, which flattened Volos and much else besides, passed Pelion by. It is still a very affluent place. The roads are free of pot-holes. The water is safe to drink. The lavatories work.

This is not a peasant culture. The old lady in the hills selling herbs and preserved fruit is probably the wife of the retired director-general of Greece Telecom.

The Ottoman empire, which did so much damage to the rest of Greece, left Pelion largely alone. It became an intellectual and artistic centre, and many villages have art galleries and bohemian communities.

On the front of the hotel in Damouchari is large banner for peace in the Balkans. The hotel's owner looks like someone from the Paris left bank in the 50s or 60s. At night, round the smouldering wood fire in the bar, he and his friends play a fusion of modern jazz and traditional Greek folk music. The garden and the bar are full of odd objects.

The pebbles on the small beach at Damouchari are like giant mint imperials. Half an hour's walk to the south, Milopotamos is as pretty a beach as you are likely to find anywhere. On an early-summer morning, it was completely deserted.

This is serious walking country, criss-crossed with 800km of stone-paved tracks, most of them more than 500 years old. You can hire a pro fessional guide for the day or you can take it easy and go by taxi to the next higher village, making your own way back.

A little train, which once took olive oil and fruit to Volos, now carries tourists from Ano Lehonia to Milies (£4 return). (The clocktower at Ano Lehonia showed four different times, all of them wrong.) Sadly, the engine has been converted to diesel, but the passengers no longer have to get out and push, as often used to be the case. It chugs along at 10 miles an hour, over narrow-arched viaducts and a spectacular iron bridge. When it goes through a tunnel, it feels like a fairground ghost train.

The railway was designed by the father of Giorgio de Chirico, the great metaphysical painter and father of surrealism. As a child, he lived in a house overlooking the railway, and the train and the viaducts were recurring symbols in much of his work.

Between 1912 and 1919, he painted a series of empty, dreamlike townscapes with arched buildings, long shadows, odd perspectives, steam trains frozen in time, clocks at unlikely times, statues and everyday objects taken out of their usual context. The art books tell you that his pictures were a product of his bizarre imagination, but most of the ingredients can be found in Pelion.

There are no paintings by de Chirico in Milies, but up from the station in the church by the square, there is a Hieronymous Bosch-like fresco of the Last Judgment, which is every bit as weird.

The island at the end

Trikeri is so little known that it doesn't even get a mention in most guidebooks.

It is not much more than a mile across, with a population of fewer than 100. There are three tavernas, one simple hotel, no roads, no cars - transport by foot, donkey or boat - dozens of sandy coves and plenty of olive trees, juniper, oleander and wild flowers.

Best of all is the disused monastery, an arcaded courtyard of cells with a small 18th-century church and an overgrown garden of orange trees and madonna lilies. An unworldly old lady called Hermione now runs the place as a rest house for travellers.

Asked how much it cost to stay, she said: "This is holy ground. There is no charge. If they wish, visitors may make a donation to church funds."

In mid-May, there were no visitors. I didn't suppose there would be many more in the height of summer.

Pelion menu

You would be unlucky to have a bad or overpriced meal on Pelion. Greek cookery does not require a great deal of skill, and there is no shortage of high-quality ingredients.

Prices, menus and standards are pretty uniform, and you can safely choose a restaurant for its setting - on the seafront or in one of the many flagstoned village squares under the plane trees - and not pay more than £6 a head.

Local specialities include tyropsomi - a cheese pie - and spetzofai , a stew of spicy sausage and pale green peppers. They are also very fond of rabbit. There is not much call for luke-warm moussaka and chips.

The local wines, both red and white, are thought by some people to be a slight improvement on retsina.

The local spirit, tsipouru, is rather like ouzo only far stronger. You may think that, as bright ideas go, "let's make something like ouzo but twice as deadly" doesn't rate very high, but the locals are remarkably proud of it and will be delighted if you order some. It could be the last thing you remember.

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Rambling rose | Star stream | Best B&B
fields.body:
Rambling rose
Wild Rose holidays for women, a walking and special-interest company, has issued its latest brochure. Holidays are based in south-west England and the Mediterranean. All women are welcome. Details from 01752 822609.

Star stream
Eurostar has expanded the number of trains on the Paris route for the summer. On the busiest day, Friday, there are now 23 trains from London, starting at 7.23am and running until 10.53pm.

Best B&B
Pearl Taylor of Upper Newton Farmhouse, Kinnersley, Herefordshire, has been named B&B landlady of the year in a competition run by the AA. She was selected from more than 3,500 establishments in the AA Bed and Breakfast Guide 2000, price £9.99.

Heart break
The British Heart Foundation is organising a 10-day sponsored bike ride in Thailand from November 18-28 to raise money. Half the cycling will be off-road. For details, freecall 0500 200575.

Fly by ferry
Travellers who take a car to Ireland on Stena this summer between July 1 and August 31 will get two return flights with buzz from Stansted to one of nine European destinations. Some restrictions apply. Tel: 08705 787 787.

Camera action
Almost a quarter of foreign visitors to Futuroscope, France's theme park of the moving image near Poitiers, are British. From this week, the journey will be easier with the opening of a new TGV station at the park. The door-to-door journey from London will now take six hours. Rail Europe 08705 848848.

Volunteers wanted
International Voluntary Service still has opportunities available for the summer, with more than 800 two- to four-week projects from working with children and refugees to tackling issues such as racism, drug abuse, homelessness and ecology. Tel: 01206 298215, www.ivsgbn.demon.co.uk

Free kick
Book a flight with no-frills airline buzz and you could win two free tickets to the England v Germany Euro 2000 match on June 17. E-mail your booking reference to theythinkitsallover@buzzaway.com and your name will be entered in a prize draw. The competition closes at 6pm Wednesday. The winners will be flown to Charleroi on a special charter flight. Details on www.buzzaway.com

fields.headline: High five
fields.standfirst: Whether you're a novice or Spiderman, expert  Ed Douglas  finds five climbs for you to try
fields.trailText: Whether you're a novice or Spiderman, expert Ed Douglas finds five climbs for you to try.
fields.body:
The Castle
Stoke Newington

If you climbed trees as a kid you will love climbing walls. Forget any preconceptions about bearded men in offensively-coloured anoraks eating Kendal mint cake. Wall climbing doesn't require you to be rugged. It takes place indoors, is safe, and will exercise all your muscles in a more natural way than pumping iron. It will also make you supple since flexibility is an integral part of climbing.

The Castle is a Grade 2 listed pumping station in Stoke Newington leased from Thames Water. Inside, the converted structure houses a cliff, made of wooden panels coated with resin. The wall is around 40ft high and covered with holds which you use to haul - or dance, depending on your experience - your way up, as you would on a ladder. There are ropes to tie into which will hold you should you fall. Using these requires some basic training and the Castle runs courses for those who have never tried climbing before; a third of its clients are newcomers. It's the perfect way to learn the ropes in a safe environment.

Climbing centres like the Castle have attracted more women to the sport which is rapidly losing its macho image. The Castle runs a women's group on Monday evenings. Although non-climbers think that you have to be exceptionally strong to clamber up a wall, good power-to-weight ratio and a lot of grace are more useful.

· The Castle (0208-211 7000) Green Lanes, Stoke Newington, London N4 2HA, runs an introductory course of one evening per week for four weeks for £99 including equipment hire. This will give you enough expertise to use the wall in safety, but there are further courses available. Open Monday to Friday 2pm to 10pm, Saturday and Sunday 10am to 7pm. The centre has a café, but the local pubs aren't up to much, so try the Vietnamese restaurant Aulac in Highbury Park Road (020-7704 9187). Most cities and towns now have at least one wall. Call the British Mountaineering Council on 0161-445 4747 for more details.

Stanage
The Peak District

The gritstone edges of Derbyshire and Yorkshire are wild, soulful places and Stanage, a few miles west of Sheffield, is the most famous of them all. With climbs no more than 60ft high, the crag is a natural place for beginners to take their first tentative steps in the vertical without having to worry too much about never getting down again. And at over three miles long with around a thousand different routes spread along the cliff, there is plenty of room for everyone.

Britain may not have the biggest cliffs in the world, but we certainly stuff the opposition when it comes to types of rock, and, for many climbers, gritstone is the best rock of all - rough to the touch and sculpted into bluff round shapes by the wind and rain.

There is every kind of climbing here, from easy-angled slabs that you can pad up on your feet to jutting overhangs that require beefy arms and a very positive approach. The crag is also a magnet for "boulderers", the surfers of the climbing world, who eschew ropes and confine themselves to small boulders where they practise short climbs - known as "problems" - with Zen-like dedication.

· Many indoor walls either run their own courses on crags like Stanage or can put you in touch with those who do. The Foundry climbing centre in Sheffield runs a First Steps Rock Weekend for £105. Call 0114 2763995 or visit www.greatadventures.co.uk. Alternatively, you can approach a local climbing club. The British Mountaineering Council holds a list of those in you area (0161-445 4747). Many climbers at Stanage use Longland's café in Hathersage to eat, but it's also worth taking a trip into central Sheffield for a curry at Nirmals (0114 2724054).

Chair Ladder
Cornwall

The other area of climbing where Britain leads the world comes courtesy of the Northern Atlantic. The west coast, from Cape Cornwall to Cape Wrath, bristles with sea-cliffs and those in Cornwall are among the most popular. Chair Ladder on the southern coast of West Penwith is about as far west as you can get and, with the base of the cliff washed by high tide, it has a wild atmosphere, the ocean at your back adding an extra dimension to the experience.

Although its position above the sea can seem intimidating, especially to novices, Chair Ladder has a host of easier climbs, and the rough granite is full of holds for your hands and feet. It's the best place in Britain to start sea-cliff climbing.

· Chair Ladder is near the village of Porthgwarra where there is a café. For an outstanding pub, try the Star Inn in St Just on the northern coast. Compass West at nearby Sennen Cove runs climbing courses for novices (01736 871447) and the National Mountain Centre based at Plas y Brenin in North Wales also runs a residential course in West Penwith (01690 720214).

The Cuillins
Isle of Skye

If you're looking to do your rock climbing in one of the most sublime landscapes on earth, then the Cuillins of Skye offer the best opportunity, provided it isn't raining. Rising straight out of the ocean, the main ridge is some eight miles long, never drops below 2,500ft and has more than 20 tops over 3,000ft. A traverse, usually requiring a very long day, is a major undertaking for an experienced party, but you can hire a guide or content yourself with climbing parts of it, like the huge crags at Sron na Ciche and the bizarre pinnacle of the Cioch. There are much harder climbs but the Cuillins are real mountains and full of danger.

· The Isle of Skye is a nine-hour drive from London or two hours from Inverness Airport. There are many qualified mountain guides in north-west Scotland - those carrying the IFMGA carnet - available at the British Mountain Guides website. The Sligachan Inn is a popular base for climbers, but save time for a visit to the Talisker Distillery in Carbost.

Clogwyn Du'r
Snowdon

"Cloggy" holds a special place in the history of climbing and is one of the most compelling views in Britain. Cloggy occupies a northern flank of Snowdon above Llyn Du'r Arddu, a sweeping amphitheatre of rock around the indigo waters of the lake. Climbs reach more than 600ft in height, so this is no place for beginners, but one of the easier routes is a realistic ambition for those with some experience.

North Wales has a lot of rock climbing, and the National Mountain Centre at Plas y Brenin in the small village of Capel Curig is a popular place to learn with a huge variety of courses. There is limestone on the coast, and even the old slate quarries in nearby Llanberis are popular, but Cloggy really is something else. As Lord's is to cricket, so this cliff is to climbing.

· The National Mountain Centre at Plas y Brenin has an excellent website at www.pyb.co.uk with details of its residential courses, or call 01690 720214 for a brochure. If you want to experience climbing culture at first hand, then pay a visit to Pete's Eats on Llanberis' High Street for pints of tea and a good fry-up.

webTitle: Bank pulls plug on 'cruel' animal lab

fields.headline: Bank pulls plug on 'cruel' animal lab
fields.trailText: The Royal Bank of Scotland is to pull the plug on a £20m overdraft with the controversial animal testing laboratory Huntingdon Life Sciences after bank staff were threatened by animal rights protesters.
fields.body:
The Royal Bank of Scotland is to pull the plug on a £20m overdraft with the controversial animal testing laboratory Huntingdon Life Sciences after bank staff were threatened by animal rights protesters.

The Edinburgh-based bank's involvement with the laboratory is the result of its takeover of NatWest which had allowed the firm to borrow £22.5m to run its business. Industry sources confirmed last night the overdraft facility will not be renewed when the deal with RBS expires in August.

The decision leaves the laboratory searching for new sources of crucial funding before the debt becomes repayable on August 31 and follows months of intimidation of the bank's staff by animals rights groups such as Stop Huntingdon Animals Cruelty.

The overdraft facility was set up two years ago by NatWest around the time new management was installed at Huntingdon's laboratories after it was exposed for cruel treatment of puppies and told to clean up its act by the government.

Huntingdon's corporate broker, German banking group WestLB Panmure, has also severed ties with the laboratory. Protests against the laboratory have increased. The most recent took place on Thursday against City firms linked to Huntingdon Life Sciences.

The Labour Party's staff pension fund has ordered its fund managers, Phillips & Drew, to ditch its holding in the laboratory. Phillips & Drew no longer owns any shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences. It held an 11% stake until February.

In April, pensioner David Braybrook, one of 1,700 of the then investors in company, opened his front door to find protesters on his doorstep.

The bank last night refused to confirm or deny the decision to stop providing banking facilities, citing reasons of "client confidentiality".

Huntingdon's annual report contains a note which makes clear the critical nature of the loans. The report said that while the directors were confident about the outcome of the negotiations it was "too early to predict the outcome".

Brian Cass, managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, denied he knew that the bank would not renew the facility but said the laboratory had always known it would come to an end in August.

The Cheltenham-based Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty campaigners insisted last night there would be no let up in the campaign "until Huntingdon closes".

"Demonstrations in the City will be stepped up," a spokeswoman said.

Huntingdon Life Sciences, which employs 1,100 on two sites in the UK and another 220 in the US, says it carries out non-clinical safety trials for pharmaceutical companies.

fields.headline: Coast to coast
fields.standfirst: Crossing the Channel throws up more variations than the British weather. Here we show you every which way to go and regular Channel hopper  Anne McHardy offers some money-saving tips
fields.trailText: Crossing the Channel throws up more variations than the British weather. Here we show you every which way to go and regular Channel hopper Anne McHardy offers some money-saving tips
fields.body:
William the Conqueror, hell bent in 1066 on East Sussex, meant to set sail from Normandy, but bad weather drove him north. Huddled in the mouth of the Somme, the ambitious descendant of the Vikings regrouped to sail across La Manche.

Crossings of the English Channel, as we prefer to call it, pepper our literature and history. Armies used it through the Hundred Years' War. Smugglers use it still. Dickens' heroine in A Tale of Two Cities has a nightmare crossing. Agatha Christie's characters drive long-nosed Thirties' tourers on to ferries. Hitler established a submarine fleet at Boulogne. My mother, as a schoolgirl, was one of the civilians evacuated in the 1939 phoney war, taken in a tiny fishing boat from St Malo.

If the gods are against us, we may still experience the thrills of early travellers. A force nine gale can make a rough 90 minutes out of even the shortest route, Dover to Calais. A couple of times a summer, ferocious weather turns that into 17 or so hours, with the ferry unable to dock.

For the most part, though, the Channel is more a challenge to the ticket-bargain instinct than to sea legs, with the Great British holidaymaker facing a minefield of deals. The last decade has been dominated by the end of duty-free sales. Price rises did not immediately follow rationalisation of Customs' duties since the operators pegged them to retain passengers. This year, the effect is showing, with rises of up to 27% across all companies. However, competition for travellers remains fierce so there are deals.

The mechanics are worth a thought. Choice one is which drive you prefer in England. Dover or Folkestone is fine from London, but from Birmingham or Liverpool or Glasgow then Newhaven, Southampton and Portsmouth may be attractive. Choice two is the Chunnel or a ferry. If you get sea sick, choose the Chunnel. If you are claustrophobic, the ferry. For the rest, planning starts with deciding what best suits your party and your pocket, remembering that road miles stack up pounds in petrol plus nervous strain. If you want an overnight port-side stop, choose France. Hotels are cheaper.

Personally, looking for a speedy arrival near or north of Calais, I go for the tunnel. I prefer 30 minutes' reading the paper in my car in a Chunnel train to 90 minutes on a ferry. The odd tenner is worth it to avoid the nag from the kids about on-board special offers.

Said kids, however, like the ferry, games machines and all, especially if there is a McDonald's. For the disabled and those with young children, the tunnel comes with the benefit of no staircases, although ferries provide help and, if forewarned, load people needing access first. For pet owners, with quaran tine relaxation, the Chunnel is probably better than leaving Fido inside the car in the hold. Some ferries will take animals, some not, but hold travel is normal and can be hot, noisy and frightening.

P&O has Conran restaurants, where the food is passable and adults can eat in peace while the kids stuff hamburgers elsewhere. But cramming three courses in 90 minutes is a recipe for indigestion. Breakfast is the short-crossing meal. Newhaven-Dieppe at two hours offers more digestion time, but lousy food. Take sandwiches. Le Havre, Caen or Cherbourg, or St Malo with P&O Portsmouth or Brittany Ferries and five to 10 hours at sea are the dining crossings.

If your journey is to the south of France, or Spain, then travelling through Calais adds at least two to three hours' driving. The toll road costs Ffr40 to reach Rouen. The upside is that it zooms through places straight from history for you to take coffee breaks in, from Crecy to the Somme.

Boulogne only takes 20 miles off any drive but the Hovercraft sails almost into the main street and the town has fish restaurants worthy of France's biggest fishing port. It is a good place to idle before the slog to the Mediterranean.

Dieppe, also picturesque, and 130 miles south, is the closest port to Paris. It has suffered from the cross- channel operators' wars. P&O pulled out its four-hour ferries, preferring the mass market of Calais, and Hoverspeed, the Boulogne operator, now fills the slot with a limited fast-craft summer service. Portsmouth-Le Havre, with P&O Portsmouth and Portsmouth-Caen, Cherbourg or St Malo with Brittany Ferries, which markets itself on sailing halfway down France, give real sea crossings, with cinemas and overnight cabinets and, once landed, easy access to places like Bayeux and the Normandy Landing beaches and Brittany's craggy beaches.

Phoning operators direct or using the internet gives flexibility. Most carriers have early-booking schemes. Most charge about £10 per ticket bought at the port. All have loyalty schemes - some involve a fee, some a minimum number of crossings. All are worth checking even for a once-a-year travellers. Check short-stay offers and the super-low fares that companies don't rush to promote. They exist to show how extensive a company's range is. Even if they are meant as window dressing, you can buy them.

I cross most months, using different routes, and this month almost paid £147, with a loyalty discount, for a five-day ferry ticket when I was going for three days and a £99 offer existed. I gave my loyalty number to the sales person - and the three-day price wasn't being quoted to loyalty travellers. Which company doesn't matter. All are the same. It is a jungle out there. The sport is outsmarting them.

Huddled in the mouth of the Somme, the ambitious descendant of the Vikings regrouped to sail across La Manche. Crossings of the English Channel, as we prefer to call it, pepper our literature and history. Armies used it through the Hundred Years' War. Smugglers use it still. Dickens' heroine in A Tale of Two Cities has a nightmare crossing. Agatha Christie's characters drive long-nosed Thirties' tourers on to ferries. Hitler established a submarine fleet at Boulogne. My mother, as a schoolgirl, was one of the civilians evacuated in the 1939 phoney war, taken in a tiny fishing boat from St Malo. If the gods are against us, we may still experience the thrills of early travellers. A force nine gale can make a rough 90 minutes out of even the shortest route, Dover to Calais. A couple of times a summer, ferocious weather turns that into 17 or so hours, with the ferry unable to dock. For the most part, though, the Channel is more a challenge to the ticket-bargain instinct than to sea legs, with the Great British holidaymaker facing a minefield of deals. The last decade has been dominated by the end of duty-free sales. Price rises did not immediately follow rationalisation of Customs' duties since the operators pegged them to retain passengers. This year, the effect is showing, with rises of up to 27% across all companies. However, competition for travellers remains fierce so there are deals. The mechanics are worth a thought. Choice one is which drive you prefer in England. Dover or Folkestone is fine from London, but from Birmingham or Liverpool or Glasgow then Newhaven, Southampton and Portsmouth may be attractive. Choice two is the Chunnel or a ferry. If you get sea sick, choose the Chunnel. If you are claustrophobic, the ferry. For the rest, planning starts with deciding what best suits your party and your pocket, remembering that road miles stack up pounds in petrol plus nervous strain. If you want an overnight port-side stop, choose France. Hotels are cheaper. Personally, looking for a speedy arrival near or north of Calais, I go for the tunnel. I prefer 30 minutes' reading the paper in my car in a Chunnel train to 90 minutes on a ferry. The odd tenner is worth it to avoid the nag from the kids about on-board special offers. Said kids, however, like the ferry, games machines and all, especially if there is a McDonald's. For the disabled and those with young children, the tunnel comes with the benefit of no staircases, although ferries provide help and, if forewarned, load people needing access first. For pet owners, with quaran tine relaxation, the Chunnel is probably better than leaving Fido inside the car in the hold. Some ferries will take animals, some not, but hold travel is normal and can be hot, noisy and frightening. P&O has Conran restaurants, where the food is passable and adults can eat in peace while the kids stuff hamburgers elsewhere. But cramming three courses in 90 minutes is a recipe for indigestion. Breakfast is the short-crossing meal. Newhaven-Dieppe at two hours offers more digestion time, but lousy food. Take sandwiches. Le Havre, Caen or Cherbourg, or St Malo with P&O Portsmouth or Brittany Ferries and five to 10 hours at sea are the dining crossings. If your journey is to the south of France, or Spain, then travelling through Calais adds at least two to three hours' driving. The toll road costs Ffr40 to reach Rouen. The upside is that it zooms through places straight from history for you to take coffee breaks in, from Crecy to the Somme. Boulogne only takes 20 miles off any drive but the Hovercraft sails almost into the main street and the town has fish restaurants worthy of France's biggest fishing port. It is a good place to idle before the slog to the Mediterranean. Dieppe, also picturesque, and 130 miles south, is the closest port to Paris. It has suffered from the cross- channel operators' wars. P&O pulled out its four-hour ferries, preferring the mass market of Calais, and Hoverspeed, the Boulogne operator, now fills the slot with a limited fast-craft summer service. Portsmouth-Le Havre, with P&O Portsmouth and Portsmouth-Caen, Cherbourg or St Malo with Brittany Ferries, which markets itself on sailing halfway down France, give real sea crossings, with cinemas and overnight cabinets and, once landed, easy access to places like Bayeux and the Normandy Landing beaches and Brittany's craggy beaches. Phoning operators direct or using the internet gives flexibility. Most carriers have early-booking schemes. Most charge about £10 per ticket bought at the port. All have loyalty schemes - some involve a fee, some a minimum number of crossings. All are worth checking even for a once-a-year travellers. Check short-stay offers and the super-low fares that companies don't rush to promote. They exist to show how extensive a company's range is. Even if they are meant as window dressing, you can buy them. I cross most months, using different routes, and this month almost paid £147, with a loyalty discount, for a five-day ferry ticket when I was going for three days and a £99 offer existed. I gave my loyalty number to the sales person - and the three-day price wasn't being quoted to loyalty travellers. Which company doesn't matter. All are the same. It is a jungle out there. The sport is outsmarting them.
