fields.headline: The Point Hotel, Edinburgh
fields.trailText: Address: 34 Bread Street, Edinburgh, EH3 9AF
fields.body:
Address: 34 Bread Street, Edinburgh, EH3 9AF

Tel: 0131-221 5555

Web address: www.point-hotel.co.uk

First Impressions: Fantastically modern lobby: all white walls and steel pillars. But the helpful reception staff manage to dissolve the impression that you've walked in to an intimidatingly trendy joint.

What are the rooms like? The white rooms with their walnut furniture make a stark contrast to the fluorescent lighting of the corridors outside. Many have views of the castle.

The bed test: You could fit quite a few extra friends between the crisp sheets, if you were that way inclined.

The bathroom test: A double Jacuzzi with leatherette headrests set amid acres of blond wood and chrome fittings. Need we say more.

The restaurant: Three courses of reasonable cooking for £12.95 would be bloody good value anywhere in Edinburgh. In these settings, it's downright remarkable.

What is there to see within walking distance? There's the castle, the Royal Mile, the Old Town, the New Town.

What is there within a 10-minute drive? Don't take a car to Edinburgh. Parking is a nightmare.

How much a night? Weekend deals from £60 for a double, but splash out and get a suite from £130.

Would you go back? It would be churlish not to.

fields.headline: So near, yet so far
fields.standfirst: www.expedia.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.expedia.co.uk
fields.body:
Isn't Expedia something to do with Microsoft?
Like Hotmail and the Internet Explorer browser, Expedia is a scion of the Gates empire. But it is a quoted company and thrives in its own right. I used to be reluctant to mention it, but six months ago...

You were converted?
I was searching for a flight and realised that Expedia's database was remarkably easy to use - and it also had the cheapest flight. One of the best features is the Fare Tracker, which identifies the cheapest flights to any destination and will either email them to you each week, or store them on the site for future reference.

What else is there?
Package holidays, car hire and hotel bookings. Expedia is a mainstream service which, because it deals with hotel chains and larger companies, is particularly useful for business travellers. The Rough Guides have also been roped in, along with lastminute.com and a specialist in golfing holidays.

Business and golf... Does it get any more exciting?
Expedia is a calmly functional service. Book a flight here and six months later the site will have remembered all the details. One day, all sites will treat us this way. And perhaps by then the shock of being greeted by a computer interface will no longer seem so sinister.

A word of warning
I recently found a cheap Middle East Airlines flight on the site, and asked Expedia to reserve seats for me. Next day, I was told that the tickets had each gone up by £75.

Bad luck. But they didn't guarantee the price would stay the same, did they?
No. But a new search revealed that the same MEA flights were still available at the lower price.

Did Expedia put the price up because it knew you were interested?
According to the company's UK MD, nothing underhand was going on. The price had gone up when MEA's system looked at the reservation and increased the fare because more seats had been sold on those flights - which is common practice among airlines.But Expedia uses a database called Worldspan to obtain its own information, and Worldspan still listed the lower price.

A breakdown in communications?
Apparently. According to Expedia, this only happens with smaller airlines like MEA; BA and the other major airlines have better systems.

It doesn't seem fair to sell identical flights at the same time at different prices, though, does it?
Indeed not. That's why I'm warning you.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Wrigley Field

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Wrigley Field
fields.standfirst: Simon Inglis
fields.trailText: Simon Inglis, author of Sightlines, A Stadium Odyssey
fields.body:
Why: I have been enthralled by stadiums since I was six and first went to Villa Park. The last vestiges of that old ground are being bulldozed this summer. Wrigley Field, the home of the Chicago Cubs, stands for continuity, tradition and the coming together of a community and a stadium, so much so that the area around it is called Wrigleyville. The charm and innocence of this ball park seem an age away from the machine-like stadiums we will see at Euro 2000, particularly Amsterdam and Arnhem. I have visited several hundred stadiums around the world and Wrigley Field is a haven of consensus and good humour - a reminder of the essence of spectator sport. What we are talking about here is a 39,000-seater park opened in 1912 and the last of the great old ball parks to survive modernity. They only installed floodlights in 1998.

What's the best thing: Architecturally it is not outstanding, but it retains all the features one expects of pre-war America - a brick perimeter wall decked in ivy, a hand-operated scoreboard, the clank of the El train passing within yards of the bleachers - and it is surrounded by houses with fabulous views over the diamond. From the upper tiers, you can look out over one of the great cityscapes - and get there in 20 minutes. The ballpark is surrounded by bars and restaurants. My favourite is Murphy's on the corner of Waveland and Sheridan.

My advice: Get there early and get a seat in the bleachers and buy a hot-dog, cold beer and talk to your neighbours. Tickets from $6 to $25. See www.chicagocubs.com

How do I get there? British Airways Holidays runs four-night trips to Chicago, departing Thursdays from £699pp. Call 0870 2424243 for details.

 Simon Inglis is the author of Sightlines, A Stadium Odyssey, published by Yellow Jersey Press at £18.

Europe

webTitle: 2,600 a day dying in Congolese war

fields.headline: 2,600 a day dying in Congolese war
fields.trailText: Inside the crumbling university hospital women and babies cried out for food and medicine; hundreds of wounded, sick and dying Congolese civilians lay on bloodstained mattresses, while Rwandan and Ugandan troops traded gunfire in the fifth day of fighting.
fields.byline: Hrvoje Hranjski  in Kisangani and  Victoria Brittain
fields.body:
Inside the crumbling university hospital women and babies cried out for food and medicine; hundreds of wounded, sick and dying Congolese civilians lay on bloodstained mattresses, while Rwandan and Ugandan troops traded gunfire in the fifth day of fighting.

Kisangani is the new centre of a dramatically deteriorating situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Much of the country is out of contact with any outsiders and a new survey by the International Rescue Committee (IRC) sheds light on what is happening across this vast country.

The New York-based IRC estimates that 1.7m people have died from the war in the northern and eastern provinces alone in the past two years. Of those, 200,000 were direct war deaths; the vast majority were due to the war-related collapse of the health and food infrastructure.

"It's as if the entire population of Houston was wiped off the face of the Earth in a matter of months," the IRC's president, Reynold Levy, said.

"On average, some 2,600 people are dying every day in this war and our research found that the first months of the year 2000 were even worse than 1999," said the study's author, epidemiologist Les Roberts.

In Kisangani, the Red Cross said yesterday that more than 100 civilians have been killed in the shooting and shelling and another 700 injured in the past five days. Most of the city's estimated 200,000 residents remained trapped under fire in the cellars of their homes or in hastily dug holes in the ground. There was no water or electricity and food supplies were running out.

Alexander Liebeskind, a Red Cross delegate, said his car was hit by gunfire yesterday when he went out to inspect the dire conditions in the city's four hospitals, one of which was hit by a mortar round on Thursday.

"We cannot collect the dead from the street and houses. Part of the city is destroyed. Doctors cannot move from their homes. There is no cease-fire," said Lieutenant-Colonel Danilo Paiva, head of the 22-man UN military observer team based in the city.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, spoke to the Rwandan and Ugandan presidents by phone on Thursday and secured the promise of a ceasefire to take effect later in the day, but it failed within hours.

The latest flare up in this sideline to Congo's own civil war, which also involves seven foreign armies, started last Sunday after two previous bouts of fighting between the former allies were defused by regional summit meetings.

Uganda and Rwanda back three rival Congolese rebel groups in the north - none of them effective fighting forces. Control of Kisangani - the country's third city - is key to whatever political settlement eventually emerges for Congo. Its capital, Kinshasa, is now held by the weak government of President Laurent Kabila.

This third round of fighting between Uganda and Rwanda followed a surprise meeting between President Kabila and the Rwandan president, Paul Kagame. It was the first time these two central figures in this war had ever met.

They recommitted themselves to the Lusaka peace agreement of last year which would remove the seven foreign armies from the country and disarm the thousands of men responsible for Rwanda's genocide now in Kabila's army.

In Kisangani this week a detailed plan to demilitarise the city failed when Ugandan units, withdrawing simultaneously with Rwandan troops, first changed the agreed route and then fired on a withdrawing Rwandan unit. The fighting escalated from there.

As small arms rattled through the city yesterday one UN observer, Lieutenant-Colonel Khan Khalid, said: "They are trying to scare the population. They want to restrict the movement of UN monitors and humanitarian agencies. The fighting has no clear objectives. Neither side has advanced."

 Hrvoje Hranjski is a writer for the Associated Press

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Island race | Cliveden clues | Baby boom
fields.body:
Island race
Some 1,580 yachts set sail from the Royal Yacht Squadron in Cowes at 6.30am today to race around the Isle Of Wight. Best vantage points include Yarmouth, The Needles, St Catherine's Point, Ventnor and Bonchurch, Ryde Pier and Gilkicker Point.

 Details: 01983-296621

Cliveden clues
Follow the clues around the gardens of Cliveden to find the hidden treasure, part of the National Trust's Neptune Coastline Campaign.

 Today, 11am-4pm. Adults free/child £1.50. Cliveden, Taplow, Maidenhead, Bucks (01494-7555620)

Baby boom
The world's longest motion simulator ride and the first 3D show of a baby's life in the womb are among the crowd-pullers at Newcastle's new Life Interactive World.

 Open daily 10am-6pm. £6.95/£4.50, family £19.95. Times Square, Scotswood Road, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-243 8210)

Garden steps
Watch the Rambert Dance Company rehearsing around Blickling Hall this week, culminating in a garden performance on Friday.

 Rambert June 11-16, performance 2.30pm-5.30pm. Garden (and performance) entrance only £3.20/£1.85. Hall and gardens open daily 10am-4pm (£6.50/£3.25). Blickling, nr Aylsham, Norfolk (01263-738049)

Shopping adventure
Glasgow's huge new Outdoor Experience is partly landscaped to resemble a Scottish hillside, with 10 outdoor interactive areas where shoppers can test and trial clothes and equipment, including a 20ft ice wall.

 Open daily 8.30am-7pm (Thurs/Fri 8pm, Sun 10am-6pm). Couper St, Townshead, Glasgow (0141-559 5450)

Holocaust exhibit
The new Holocaust exhibition at the Imperial War Museum may leave you feeling that civilisation is only skin deep.

 Open daily 10am-6pm, exhibition permanent. £5.50/under-16s free. Lambeth Road, London SE1 (020-7416 5000)

Around Britten
Two young pianists, one of the BBC's New Generation Artists and the Borodin String Quartet join students from the Britten-Pears School at Aldeburgh's 53rd Music Festival.

 Runs until June 25. Snape Maltings Concert Hall, Snape, Saxmundham, Suffolk (01728-687110)

Leith festival
A week of arts, music and children's events kicks off on Leith Links, on the outskirts of Edinburgh, with bands, pipe drums, country dancing, ceilidhs and fireworks.

 Various venues until June 16, mostly free. Brochures from local shops, libraries etc

fields.headline: Bridge partners - Copenhagen
fields.standfirst: The 10-mile crossing opens next month linking Copenhagen and Malmö.  Andrew Spooner finds out what's happening on either side
fields.trailText: Copenhagen: The 10-mile crossing opens next month linking Copenhagen and Malmö. Andrew Spooner finds out what's happening on either side
fields.body:
The Øresund Bridge is Scandinavia's most ambitious building project ever, linking Copenhagen in Denmark and Malmö in Sweden.

The bridge has three sections: a 2.5-mile tunnel, a 2.5-mile man-made island and a five-mile cable-stayed bridge. It took six years to build and will be officially opened on July 1 by Queen Margrethe of Denmark and King Carl Gustaf of Sweden. The first road traffic will cross at 11pm the same day, rail traffic a day later. Car toll is 230kr (£20) and a single crossing by train 60kr (£5.25).

Despite the recent football riot, Copenhagen is one of the most laid-back cities in northern Europe. With almost constant sea breezes and many green spaces, it often doesn't feel like you're in a major European city. There's also a lack of traffic - everybody cycles or takes the excellent public transport.

Copenhagen is a liberal place - dope smoking, while illegal, is mostly tolerated, although the police will bust you if you are too open. There is a booming sex industry in the backstreets of Vesterbro, and the Gay scene claims to be second only to San Francisco.

Copenhagen is Scandinavia's party town. Weekday evenings can be spookily quiet, but at weekends the city really gets moving. Many places stay open until 5am, and most people start their evenings at midnight.

The two major drawbacks are the weather and prices: even in mid-summer it can be cool and wet, while a half -decent three-course meal can set you back about £35.

 11.45kr = £1. Transport from Copenhagen Airport: train 18kr, 15mins; taxi 125kr 25mins. Tourist office: Bernstorffsgade 1, tel: 33 11 13 25, www.visitcopenhagen.dk

Best places to visit

Glyptotek
Dantes Plads 7
Impressive collection of Etruscan, Roman, Danish and French art.
Open: Tues-Sun 10am-4pm; 30kr/free Wed & Sun.
www.glyptoteket.dk

Tivoli
Vesterbrogade 3
The world-famous pleasure garden has colourfully-lit, well-tended lawns, boating ponds, fairground rides and a concert hall.
Open: mid-April to Sept, daily 11am-midnight.
Admission: mid-June to mid-Aug, 49kr; other times 39kr. Rides from 10kr.
www.tivoli.dk

Christiania
Badsmandstræde
A huge squat dating from the early 70s, it epitomises Danish liberalism. Pusher Street can be intimidating, so head for the greener areas situated on the old city bastions.

Where to stay

For budget accommodation, contact the tourist office which has a huge list of rooms in private homes for as little as £15 per person per night.

DGI Byens Hotel
Tietgensgade 65
Pure Scandinavian hi-tech minimalism. Good location near the central station.
Cost per night: 1,395kr.
Tel: 33 29 80 50.
www.dgi-byen.dk

71 Nyhavn
A luxurious renovated wood-beamed warehouse in the middle of the old docks.
Cost per night: 1,500kr.
Tel: 33 43 62 00. www.71nyhavnhotelcopenhagen.dk

Skt Jørgen
Julius Thomsens Gade 22
Quiet family hotel close to the lakes that ring the city centre.
Cost per night: 600kr.
Tel: 35 37 15 11.
www.hotellist.dk/st.jorgen

Bars and clubs

Rabes Have
Langebrogade 8
The oldest bar in Copenhagen - since 1632 - this bohemian bar offers everything a local pub should.
Open until midnight, daily.

Musen og Elefanten
Vestergade 21
A combination of heavy rock and powerful Elephant beer poured from a carved elephant trunk.
Open: Sat-Thurs 5pm-2am, Fri 3pm-5am.

Pussy Galore's Flying Circus
Skt Hans Torv 30
Exotic cocktails and outdoor seating on one of Copenhagen's hippest squares.
Open: Mon-Fri 8am-2am Sat-Sun 9am-2am. www. pussy-galore.dk

Rust
Guldbergsgade 8
Multi-faceted venue with a very hip nightclub.
Open: Wed-Sat 11pm- 5am. Admission: 30-50kr.
www.rust.dk.

Copenhagen Jazzhouse
Niels Hemmingsensgade 10
Copenhagen's premier jazz venue. On club nights, live Blue Note gives way to a mix of R'n'B and Soul.
Club nights Thurs-Sat 6pm-5am.
www.jazzhouse.dk

Food

Konrad
Pilestrædet 12
A sharp, ultra-chic restaurant serving excellent modern Scandinavian cuisine - with prices to match.
Tel: 3393 2929.
Open: Mon-Wed noon-midnight, Thurs until 1am, Fri & Sat until 4am, Sun closed.

David's
Sølvgade 91
A gem of a take-away. The Mediterranean-inspired food is fantastic - orders take 30 minutes, so phone ahead. It's near the lakes, a great setting for alfresco summer dining.
Tel: 3313 8056. Open: Tues-Fri 6pm-9pm.

Glyptotek
(see above)
Combine a visit to one of the city's best art museums with a wonderful lunch in the steamy and fragrant winter gardens. Pricy, but their pickled herring and sour cream is the best.

La Glace Conditori
Skoubogade 3
A quaint tea house. Find a seat, point out what you want, pay at the counter and a charmingly prim waitress will bring exquisite Danish pastries.
Open: Mon-Fri 8am-5pm, Sat opens at 9am, closed Sun.

What's going on in Malmö

webTitle: Gaynor Aaltonen: A bottle of water | A duvet | Pebbles

fields.headline: Gaynor Aaltonen never travels without
fields.trailText: A bottle of water | A duvet | Pebbles
fields.body:
A necessity: Water because the National Trust is not just about country houses, it's about countryside, mountains and walking, which I do a lot of. I take a bottle of water whenever I'm going outdoors.

A luxury: A duvet. Before we got married, my husband and I travelled around Spain in a Volkswagen Beetle and we had a duvet in the back. When we couldn't find anywhere to stay, we would go to sleep wrapped in the duvet.

A memento: I love picking up pebbles from beaches. Although I can't remember where each one is from, the last one I picked up was from the beach in Formby, where I was looking at prehistoric footprints preserved in the sand.

If only: I wish there was an integrated system so that visitors could get to Trust properties easily.

 Gaynor Aaltonen is editor of The National Trust Magazine

fields.headline: Bridge partners - Malmö
fields.standfirst: The 10-mile crossing opens next month linking Copenhagen and Malmö.  Andrew Spooner finds out what's happening on either side
fields.trailText: Malmö: The 10-mile crossing opens next month linking Copenhagen and Malmö. Andrew Spooner finds out what's happening on either side
fields.body:
For its first 400 years, Malmö was the second most important city in Denmark after Copenhagen. But in 1658, it was handed over to the Swedes along with a massive part of what is now southern Sweden.

The old city around Stortorget is a mix of Gothic and Dutch Renaissance architecture, with delightful parks and waterways providing a relaxing counterpoint to the bustle. For shopping, head down Södergatan where a collection of lively cafés spread themselves over the pedestrianised street during the summer.

Cutting through the Øresund Park brings you to a stretch of decent beach called the Golden Coast. The city's busy nightlife is focused on Lilla Torg. All the bars here are worth a look - Moosehead caters to a younger set while a maturer crowd frequents Mellow Yellow.

 13.25kr = £1. Transport from Copenhagen Airport: train (from July 2) 20mins, 60kr. Tourist office: inside Central Station, tel: 040/30 01 50, www.tourism.malmoe.com

Best places to visit

Malmöhus
Malmöhusvagen
This 15th-century castle is now a museum with a series of furnished interiors from Renaissance to art nouveau. The grounds provide lovely spots for picnics and walks.
Open daily, June-Aug 10am-4pm, Sept-May noon-4pm. Admission: 40kr.

St Petri Church
Göran Olsgatan
This14th-century church is splendidly Gothic outside and pleasantly airy inside. Most of the murals were destroyed in the Reformation, but a side chapel has a preserved vaulted ceiling depicting New Testament figures.
Open: Mon-Fri 8am-6pm, Sat 9am-6pm, Sun 10am-6pm; free.

Where to stay

Savoy
Norra Vallgatan
With special summer deals, this wonderfully stylish hotel is excellently positioned opposite the main station. Also has an elegant restaurant.
Cost per night: 800-1,700kr.
Tel: 94, 040/70 230.

Food

Radhus Källaven
Stortorget
Situated in the basement of the 16th-century city hall serving great traditional and modern Scandinavian food.

Spot Restaurant
Stor Nygatan 33
Italian food with all ingredients specially imported.
Closed Sundays.

 Andrew Spooner is the co-author of The Mini-Rough Guide to Copenhagen to be published next February

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Fellow readers offer you the benefit of their experience
fields.body:
Pauline McCormack asked if flying to Australia via the US was better for avoiding jet-lag, and were there any other advantages in taking this route.

I have travelled to Australia twice in the last five years, both times via the "standard" Asian route. I have always found jetlag to be worse returning (ie flying west) than going - possibly because when you are going, the excitement of the trip helps to overcome the discomforts and boredom.
Sue Byron-Swire

Flying west and gaining time does seem to have a less severe effect on the body. However, it makes little difference when flying to Australia. Whichever route you decide, you can't alter the time difference between the UK and Australia.
Ann Collins

One huge advantage of going west to Oz is that your luggage allowance will be calculated on the American "piece" system ie two pieces as opposed to the normal European economy allowance of 22kg. If you travel Virgin/Air New Zealand as we did, you can stop over at as many Pacific Islands as you want. Maybe give Fiji a miss though.
Nick Berry

This week's question

I want to travel to New York by ship towards the end of September, returning in October. I am not looking for an expensive cruise and ideally would like to go on a cargo boat which takes a few passengers at a price not exceeding twice a reasonable airfare. Any suggestions?
Linnea Glynne-RuleIf

fields.headline: Blunkett backs Tools for Schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited special report: Tools for schools
fields.trailText: The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, has lent his support to an initiative backed by the Guardian to get more computers into schools, urging business lenders to donate equipment which can be upgraded for use in the classroom.
fields.body:
The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, has lent his support to an initiative backed by the Guardian to get more computers into schools, urging business lenders to donate equipment which can be upgraded for use in the classroom.

In a letter to 30 of the country's top chief executives, Mr Blunkett says: "It is in all our interests that future generations are IT literate and have good access to modern technology from a young age." Companies with a high turnover of PCs donating them to Tools for Schools "would be playing a vital role in young people's education and future life chances", he adds.

TFS, a registered charity that places high specification refurbished computers in schools across the UK, asked Mr Blunkett for his help to get more companies donating their redundant machines. The scheme is backed by the Guardian, and last year received the endorsement of the prime minister.

The chief executive Dorian Jabri said yesterday: "We needed the clout of the education secretary to get the message out loud and clear that there is an enormous pool of computers that can easily be recycled from industry into schools."

Every year, hundreds of thousands of PCs are replaced by companies; many are dumped, some are sold off cheaply, and very few end up in schools.

"Many schools on our books are struggling with computers that are older than the children using them. We want to transform children's access to new technology.

"By refurbishing donated computers to the highest standard, we can introduce a critical mass of excellent computers into the education system, replacing worthless PCs and giving pupils greater and better access to what must now be considered basic learning tools," Mr Jabri added.

Tools for Schools is also calling on companies to prepare for the requirements of European legislation on the disposal of technical hardware. The latest draft of the waste, electrical and electronic equipment directive stipulates that 90% of IT equipment and 70% of monitors must be reused or recycled.

The charity claims that many companies have poorly managed computer disposal policies, and argues it can provide them with a tailor made solution using the highest standards of refurbishment.

"We provide an easy and cost effective means by which large companies can dispose of hardware they no longer need. All data is wiped clean to ensure that confidential information is irretrievable, and every computer undergoes a rigorous health and safety check as part of the refurbishment process," said Mr Jabri.

Institutions which have already donated computers to Tools for Schools include airports operator BAA, the Derbyshire Building Society, broadcasters including BSkyB, Channel 5, and ITV companies, and the Institute of Directors.

fields.headline: Model islands
fields.standfirst: Where do the well-heeled - and well-dressed - go to get away from it all? Fashion writer  Jess Cartner-Morley swaps the catwalk for the casually-smart beaches of St Martin and Anguilla
fields.trailText: Where do the well-heeled - and well-dressed - go to get away from it all? Fashion writer Jess Cartner-Morley swaps the catwalk for the casually-smart beaches of St Martin and Anguilla
fields.body:
The first thing to know about going to the Caribbean is that everybody you tell - even those who quite like you - will hate you for it. You might as well announce you're planning to share a penthouse in Chelsea Harbour with Tamara Beckwith. Not that it matters: when you're drinking rum punch watching a mango-coloured sunset, it's difficult to recall that the rest of the world even exists, much less worry about what it might think.

While much of the Caribbean has become more accessible and affordable in recent years, islands such as Anguilla and St Martin are still closer to life as it is in Bond films than to life as you or I might know it. This is a world of icing-sugar sand and champagne-laden speedboats; a world where chocolate-dipped strawberries appear as if by magic in your bedroom and everyone starts each holiday looking as tanned and sleek as if they've just returned from their last one. Hotels such as La Samanna on St Martin, or Malliouhana on Anguilla, would never be so gauche as to describe themselves as "glamorous" or "exclusive" - the preferred term is "upscale" - but to fit in, you do need to think rich.

On arrival at La Samanna, we were shown to our beachfront villas, which included fully kitted-out kitchens. "Oh, so you can do self-catering," said one of our group. Liliana, the impeccably courteous guest-relations person, could not disguise her horror at such a notion. "The kitchens are for guests who prefer to have a chef come and cook for them in their suite." Of course, silly us.

A few days later in Malliouhana, as meal arrangements were being explained to us, another enquired whether breakfast was served as a buffet. Jasmin, the inevitably glamorous guest-relations person, clapped her manicured hands in amusement at such an idea. "A buffet! No... we don't do buffets at Malliouhana."

Only 15 minutes apart by boat, St Martin and Anguilla are nonetheless entirely different. St Martin is a dressed-up, see-and-be-seen island, while Anguilla is altogether more laid back. Physically, too, they are in contrast: St Martin is mountainous, with bright blue sea and golden sand; Anguilla flat and sandy, with the palest turquoise sea and silver-white sand.

St Martin

Despite its diminutive size - just 37 square miles - St Martin hosts more than one million visitors a year. The island is divided into two distinct sides, one administered by the French and the other by the Dutch. This poses few practical problems for the visitor, however - there is no passport control between the two, and the dual currency issue can be sidestepped by bringing US dollars, which are accepted everywhere. The Dutch side is renowned for its casinos, the French side for its attention to fine dining.

Driving from St Martin airport to La Samanna, at the far west point of the French area on Baie Longue, the impact of hurricanes on this region can be seen in the ongoing rebuilding programmes - after 35 years of calm, this area of the Eastern Caribbean has been ravaged in the last decade. St Martin had still not fully recovered from Hurricane Luis, which took direct aim at the island in 1995, when Hurricane Lenny struck last November. Travellers should note that hurricane season is September, but the otherwise year-round perfect weather can be affected by stray hurricanes and weather systems between August and November.

Accommodation

La Samanna, made up of a main building with spectacular ocean views and villas which stretch along the bay, is pure white, with terracotta floors, bright Mexican tiles and gaudy exotic flowers - Mediterranean chic in paradise. The rooms are spacious, but not too grand - even though the bathroom was bigger than my entire flat. Stand-out features of a very chi-chi hotel are the swimming pool, which is large enough for decent lengths and has a poolside bar perfect for post-swim refreshments (I recommend the strawberry daiquiris) and the restaurant, where first-class French cuisine and wine are served on a terrace overlooking the ocean.

Apparently it is not uncommon for guests, swept away by the romance of sunsets and suntans, to decide to get married while they are here. This is entirely feasible - frankly, anyone who takes you on holiday to a place like this has got to be worth marrying - and can be arranged, with officials roped in from the more lenient Dutch side of the island.

Where to eat

But if the Air of Romance for which the Caribbean is famed isn't enough to keep you occupied on St Martin, head down for lunch at Orient Beach, a long stretch of white sand dotted with relaxed, shady restaurants. Kontiki restaurant and beach bar (tel: 590 87 43 27, $30 a head) specialises in fish and seafood, and overlooks the nudist stretch of the beach, so there's no shortage of interesting views.

What to do and see

If you're still restless, there are watersports to be sampled - waterskiing, windsurfing, jetskiing are all easily arranged, while the less adventurous among us found the snorkelling more than enough. A trip on a boat is one of the best ways to pass the time (and to perfect that millionaire tan). We took The Great Escape, La Samanna's boat, captained by Vinny Agosta - who is an ex-NYPD detective inspector (homicide). An unwelcome intrusion of the nastier side of life into an island paradise, you might think, but when you see the size of the barracudas snaking through the snorkelling coves, Vinny is exactly the kind of guy you want watching your back.

If you're on a boat, it's worth making a detour for at Karibuki, a tiny restaurant on the sandy island of Ilet Pinel offering plates of piquant conch and the freshest lobster in the shade of a palm tree.

Anguilla

Fifteen minutes on a ferry, and we were in Anguilla. The island has an air of peacefulness that comes from having been - in the nicest possible way - something of a backwater. Until recently, after all, a perfect climate and 33 dazzling white sand beaches was of less interest to the rest of the world than the greener, richer surrounding islands. And tourism has still not reached a level to disturb the calm: fishing is still the island's primary industry.

Accommodation

Meads Bay, on the north of the island, was recently voted the seventh best beach in the world, and is the setting for the phenomenally stylish Malliouhana Hotel. The staff are without exception charming, the food and wine out of this world, the rooms huge and each with terraces, the better to admire the stunning views. There are no TVs in the rooms (far too classy for that), although children are kept happy with cartoons and videos in the TV room. In fact, with three swimming pools and a supervised playground complete with giant waterslide, children seemed to be as content as us adults were, lounging on the private, sheltered Turtle Cove or in the cool shuttered bar (CD of choice: Macy Gray).

What to see and do

We visited the rum factory on Road Bay (264 497 5003), where you can take a tour, have a tasting and buy a bottle. At a nearby gift shop, a self-help book entitled The Courage To Be Rich was a fair pointer toward the type of tourism this island attracts. The monthly guide for visitors, What We Do in Anguilla, was also available - this is worth looking out for, even if you plan to do very little, for its restaurant listings.

Where to eat

Although Malliouhana's 20,000-strong wine cellar and exquisite menu (tuna and shrimp skewered with island fruits and sauteed squash spaghetti) would take months to explore thoroughly, a little adventurousness is well rewarded (however, bargain dining is seldom on the menu - expect to pay at least $20 for a main course almost everywhere).

Unmissable is the lunchtime island restaurant of Scilly Cay (264 497 5123), run by a man called Gorgeous and his beautiful wife. From Island Harbour, wave and they'll send the boat across to fetch you, and deposit you under a thatched hut or on the tiny beach where you can tuck into huge portions of crayfish and potent rum punch. Perfect for evenings is Mangoes Seaside Grill (264 497 6479), run by New Yorker David Schnittlich, with a beach-deck location, delicious sesame snapper and lobster cakes, and great desserts.

The airy Cedar Grove Café at the Rendezvous Bay Hotel (tel: 264 497 6549) is more West Indian than many other establishments, the shrimp curry utterly delicious, and we were enchanted by the oral history of Anguilla as related by the hotel's octagenarian owner, Lydia Gumbs.

Sitting on the veranda under the soporific whirl of wooden fans, the world seemed to buzz away like an irritating mosquito, and that all-important, other-side-of-the-world, pure-relaxation feeling descended. This is a feeling I normally associate with rucksacks, beach huts, and bottles of beer; yet here I was, having my champagne glass attentively refilled, and feeling just as peaceful. A worrying thought: I could get used to this.

Caribbean glamour: a guide for packing

Never one to stint on the packing (my rule with suitcases is that if I can lift it myself, I don't have nearly enough shoes), I arrived weighed down with armfuls of swimwear, several frocks, a few sarongs, a bag of sunglasses and enough pairs of mules for a centipede on a round-the-world walk. I'd like to tell you that I'd overpacked hideously, but it just wasn't true. Everyone was smarter than me, and there's nothing more aggravating than having wardrobe-envy when you're thousands of miles from Bond Street. I spent the whole of the first evening in La Samanna in silent mortification because my bra strap was showing and I was convinced I'd ruined everyone's evening with this heinous sartorial oversight.

 A bikini wardrobe is a must. You'll need at least three: a designer label for posing, a stay-put number for swimming, and a strapless one for sunbathing.

 Leave your status handbag at home - a basket is much chicer, especially if it's Gucci.

 Make sure your sunglasses have the right label (preferably Chanel).

 Don't reckon on living in shorts and T-shirts - men will need shirts with collars and long trousers for evening . Top marks for linen shirts. Minus points for mobile phone at dinner.

 Sarongs are good (for men and women) - especially Versace ones. Take shorts as well - sarongs are no good for climbing into speedboats - but go for tailored Bermuda style.

 Go for neutral colours rather than beach-ball brights, unless you're 10. White is always a winner: think Ralph Lauren advert, even if it's from Gap.

 Most female guests look like they grew up in a beauty salon so, if you don't want to get depressed every time you go down to dinner, take some nice frocks.

 Resurrect that pashmina - they don't seem to know it's over.

 Take kitten heels - more glam than flats, but easier to walk in after a few rum punches.

 Don't forget to pop into Gucci for your monogrammed snorkel and flippers.

This is entirely feasible - frankly, anyone who takes you on holiday to a place like this has got to be worth marrying - and can be arranged, with officials roped in from the more lenient Dutch side of the island. Where to eat But if the Air of Romance for which the Caribbean is famed isn't enough to keep you occupied on St Martin, head down for lunch at Orient Beach, a long stretch of white sand dotted with relaxed, shady restaurants. Kontiki restaurant and beach bar (tel: 590 87 43 27, $30 a head) specialises in fish and seafood, and overlooks the nudist stretch of the beach, so there's no shortage of interesting views. What to do and see If you're still restless, there are watersports to be sampled - waterskiing, windsurfing, jetskiing are all easily arranged, while the less adventurous among us found the snorkelling more than enough. A trip on a boat is one of the best ways to pass the time (and to perfect that millionaire tan). We took The Great Escape, La Samanna's boat, captained by Vinny Agosta - who is an ex-NYPD detective inspector (homicide). An unwelcome intrusion of the nastier side of life into an island paradise, you might think, but when you see the size of the barracudas snaking through the snorkelling coves, Vinny is exactly the kind of guy you want watching your back. If you're on a boat, it's worth making a detour for at Karibuki, a tiny restaurant on the sandy island of Ilet Pinel offering plates of piquant conch and the freshest lobster in the shade of a palm tree. Anguilla Fifteen minutes on a ferry, and we were in Anguilla. The island has an air of peacefulness that comes from having been - in the nicest possible way - something of a backwater. Until recently, after all, a perfect climate and 33 dazzling white sand beaches was of less interest to the rest of the world than the greener, richer surrounding islands. And tourism has still not reached a level to disturb the calm: fishing is still the island's primary industry. Accommodation Meads Bay, on the north of the island, was recently voted the seventh best beach in the world, and is the setting for the phenomenally stylish Malliouhana Hotel. The staff are without exception charming, the food and wine out of this world, the rooms huge and each with terraces, the better to admire the stunning views. There are no TVs in the rooms (far too classy for that), although children are kept happy with cartoons and videos in the TV room. In fact, with three swimming pools and a supervised playground complete with giant waterslide, children seemed to be as content as us adults were, lounging on the private, sheltered Turtle Cove or in the cool shuttered bar (CD of choice: Macy Gray). What to see and do We visited the rum factory on Road Bay (264 497 5003), where you can take a tour, have a tasting and buy a bottle. At a nearby gift shop, a self-help book entitled The Courage To Be Rich was a fair pointer toward the type of tourism this island attracts. The monthly guide for visitors, What We Do in Anguilla, was also available - this is worth looking out for, even if you plan to do very little, for its restaurant listings. Where to eat Although Malliouhana's 20,000-strong wine cellar and exquisite menu (tuna and shrimp skewered with island fruits and sauteed squash spaghetti) would take months to explore thoroughly, a little adventurousness is well rewarded (however, bargain dining is seldom on the menu - expect to pay at least $20 for a main course almost everywhere). Unmissable is the lunchtime island restaurant of Scilly Cay (264 497 5123), run by a man called Gorgeous and his beautiful wife. From Island Harbour, wave and they'll send the boat across to fetch you, and deposit you under a thatched hut or on the tiny beach where you can tuck into huge portions of crayfish and potent rum punch. Perfect for evenings is Mangoes Seaside Grill (264 497 6479), run by New Yorker David Schnittlich, with a beach-deck location, delicious sesame snapper and lobster cakes, and great desserts. The airy Cedar Grove Café at the Rendezvous Bay Hotel (tel: 264 497 6549) is more West Indian than many other establishments, the shrimp curry utterly delicious, and we were enchanted by the oral history of Anguilla as related by the hotel's octagenarian owner, Lydia Gumbs. Sitting on the veranda under the soporific whirl of wooden fans, the world seemed to buzz away like an irritating mosquito, and that all-important, other-side-of-the-world, pure-relaxation feeling descended. This is a feeling I normally associate with rucksacks, beach huts, and bottles of beer; yet here I was, having my champagne glass attentively refilled, and feeling just as peaceful. A worrying thought: I could get used to this. Caribbean glamour: a guide for packing Never one to stint on the packing (my rule with suitcases is that if I can lift it myself, I don't have nearly enough shoes), I arrived weighed down with armfuls of swimwear, several frocks, a few sarongs, a bag of sunglasses and enough pairs of mules for a centipede on a round-the-world walk. I'd like to tell you that I'd overpacked hideously, but it just wasn't true. Everyone was smarter than me, and there's nothing more aggravating than having wardrobe-envy when you're thousands of miles from Bond Street. I spent the whole of the first evening in La Samanna in silent mortification because my bra strap was showing and I was convinced I'd ruined everyone's evening with this heinous sartorial oversight.  A bikini wardrobe is a must. You'll need at least three: a designer label for posing, a stay-put number for swimming, and a strapless one for sunbathing.  Leave your status handbag at home - a basket is much chicer, especially if it's Gucci.  Make sure your sunglasses have the right label (preferably Chanel).  Don't reckon on living in shorts and T-shirts - men will need shirts with collars and long trousers for evening . Top marks for linen shirts. Minus points for mobile phone at dinner.  Sarongs are good (for men and women) - especially Versace ones. Take shorts as well - sarongs are no good for climbing into speedboats - but go for tailored Bermuda style.  Go for neutral colours rather than beach-ball brights, unless you're 10. White is always a winner: think Ralph Lauren advert, even if it's from Gap.  Most female guests look like they grew up in a beauty salon so, if you don't want to get depressed every time you go down to dinner, take some nice frocks.  Resurrect that pashmina - they don't seem to know it's over.  Take kitten heels - more glam than flats, but easier to walk in after a few rum punches.  Don't forget to pop into Gucci for your monogrammed snorkel and flippers.

fields.trailText: Belgian police recorded their first arrests of Euro 2000 yesterday - but the three Englishmen detained for possessing offensive weapons were journalists, not hooligans.
fields.body:
Belgian police recorded their first arrests of Euro 2000 yesterday - but the three Englishmen detained for possessing offensive weapons were journalists, not hooligans.

As the country prepares for one of the biggest security operations in its history with today's start of Euro 2000, Belgian police officers in Brussels detained two News of the World reporters who were posing for photographs in a Brussels park with hunting knives and a crossbow.

Initally officers thought they had stumbled across a hooligan gang preparing for violence but the reporters and photographer convinced police that it was all in the line of duty. They had bought the weapons as part of a story highlighting their availability in Belgium and the trio were released with a caution after being held for 24 hours.

A News of the World spokeswoman said: "Our journalists were investigating the widespread availability of lethal weapons when they were detained by police. Once the police were satisfied that our team were engaged in a legitimate journalistic exercise, they were set free unconditionally and they have been assured they can remain in Belgium with their official accreditation for Euro 2000."

Brussels police said: "They were seen with knives so our officers acted in accordance with the law. We are being very vigilant at the moment. The journalists were questioned by a prosecutor but it has been decided that no action will be taken against them. You cannot carry such weapons without a hunting permit and you can only walk around with these weapons in a hunting area."

While the journalists may have been left red-faced by the encounter, police said the arrests underlined claims that they would mount a tight security operation for Euro 2000.

An official from the British embassy in Belgium said: "The message to visitors to Belgium during Euro 2000 is that they should realise that swift action will be taken if they fail to obey the law. The local police have extra public order powers and it is inadvisable for anyone to carry weapons."

Thousands of England fans are expected to arrive in the Netherlands over the weekend with most of them heading for Amsterdam. Around 2,000 police officers will be on duty in the Dutch capital over the weekend although England's first match against Portugal does not take place until Monday in Eindhoven.

fields.headline: Olympian heights
fields.standfirst: Crowds of tourists, athletes on hormones, bribes, arts festivals, winners who are media stars with jobs for life -  AC Grayling compares the original Olympics in Greece with the events now less than 100 days away in Sydney
fields.trailText: Crowds of tourists, athletes on hormones, bribes, arts festivals, winners who are media stars with jobs for life - AC Grayling compares the original Olympics in Greece with the events in Sydney
fields.body:
Crowds have travelled from all over the known world to swarm through the hot landscape, trampling the city into a campsite, driving up food and hotel prices. They're diverted and divested of their money between sporting events by pickpockets, beggars, jugglers, and other street artists, orators, prostitutes, vendors of greasy kebabs and cheap wine - and sellers of drugs and charms to deal with stomach upsets after thunderstorms flood overworked sanitary facilities. The athletes are pros on hormones, the winners will get sponsorship deals, there's an arts festival for added cultural appeal and the city will grow rich from the tourist trade.

Sydney, 2000? Elis in ancient Greece, 776BC - home of Olympia, site of the chief shrine to Zeus, ruler of the gods; host to the original Olympic games?It could be either.

Some of Sydney's residents are apprehensive about the prospect of a modern equivalent of Elis's tumult. Some have taken up figurative arms, forming a pressure group - People Ingeniously Subverting the Sydney Olympic Farce (Pissof, for short). They not only object to the forthcoming chaos but also to the at least 2bn Australian dollars spent on building stadiums and facilities while Sydney's housing and anti-social deprivation projects are underfunded. They object to the stringent policing planned to cope with visitors and the security scares that are now part of every Olympic experience. And they are opposed by those who anticipate making a fortune from the games; local business is the only participant in Olympics 2000 assured of a gold medal in advance.

The similarities between ancient and modern Olympics are not just in crowds and congestion. As in antiquity, the athletes who compete at Sydney will be professionally trained to ultimate fitness and will almost certainly have used body-building and performance-enhancing drugs on their way to the games. At Olympia, athletes ate animal testicles for a testosterone boost, and they knew about muscle-building drugs, stimulant herbs and energy-giving diets.

Sydney's athletes can expect rich rewards if they win; but then, Pindar, Greece's greatest lyric poet, who wrote victory odes for Olympian laureates, said that a win at the games was a meal-ticket for life, earning a four-horse chariot parade through the cheering streets of home, followed by free housing, a pension, and permanent front seats at the theatre, because the athlete had proved to his home city that the gods smiled upon it. Modern advertising deals and guaranteed jobs at the local sports centre do not seem so grand, but they count as much.

One apparent difference between Olympics past and present is that whatever gods are now honoured in the games - national pride, profit, the breaking of records - in antiquity the games were meant as a religious festival, in honour of Zeus, whose immense ivory and gold statue, sculpted by Pheidias , stood in the temple at Olympia and was one of the seven wonders of the world.

But although there were religious ceremonies and processions throughout the games, including an opening invocation to Zeus Apomyios (Zeus, averter of flies) to keep summer insects away, most visitors, who came from all over the Greek world, from Spain to the Indus, were not pilgrims but one of the three orders into which, according to Pythagoras, all mankind divides: those who come to participate, those who come to buy and sell, and those who come to watch. (Philosophers, said Pythagoras, come to watch.) The temple, though, accumulated not just prayers but thousands of rich offerings during the games, highly lucrative to the local economy.

Greek tradition said that Hercules, the human hero who became an immortal, founded the games at Olympia. They had probably been in existence for at least 500 years before the first recorded event in 776 BC, a single contest , 200-metre sprint, won by a local man, Coroebus of Elis, a cook by trade. In ensuing games other contests were added; a 400 metre dash, a long-distance race, and equestrian events for which a hippodrome was built . By 708 BC, the pentathlon was a major feature, the five events being the military skills of javelin and discus throwing, wrestling, jumping and running. Boxing and chariot racing followed, and a vicious form of no-holds-barred fighting called pankration , in which only biting and eye-gouging were forbidden.

For several centuries all the events took place on a single day, but in 472 BC they were spread for the first time over several days, with a grand ceremony at the end during which victors were given their prize, a wreath of olive leaves from the sacred grove of Zeus.

The Olympics were not the only games in the ancient world. Almost all Greek cities had such contests, and some became important events, especially the Pythian games in honour of Apollo at Delphi, which included musical as well as athletic competitions; the Isthmian games in honour of Poseidon, god of the sea, held at his shrine on the wave-lapped Isthmus of Corinth; and the Nemean games, also dedicated to Zeus, at Nemea in Argolis.

Poets wrote triumphal odes for victors at all these games, conferring immortality on them.

Music at that time meant all that the Muses inspire, so there were competitions in drama and the writing and performing of philosophical dialogues.There is a theory that this was how Plato began his philosophical career, almost by accident, impelled by literary ambition to enter dialogue competitions at the games. Then he became interested in what he was writing about, and philosophy took him over. His early dialogues fit the theory; they are highly readable, open-ended, unresolved debates, about virtue and justice, beauty and love, between Socrates and visiting Sophists or beautiful boys exercising naked in the gymnasium.

Nakedness ended the games of antiquity. Gymnast comes from gumnos in ancient Greek, which means naked, for that is how the boys and men, and in Sparta, the girls, exercised. (Coroebus of Elis was thus the original naked chef.) When Christianity became the official religion of the Roman Empire, public nudity became officially unacceptable, and in 393 AD the Emperor Theodosius banned the games. Athletics was an early victim of the humourless and prudish gloom of Christian moralism.

The biggest difference between Olympics old and new lies in the values they supposedly promote. The modern games began in 1896 at the instigation of Pierre de Courbertin, who saw himself as reviving an Olympic spirit in the interests of world peace. Ever since 1829, when the Greeks freed themselves from Turkish rule, efforts had been made to restart the games as an expression of Greek national identity and solidarity, but the endeavour failed. When Courbertin took hold of the project he gave it an expressly international character, and claimed for it the values which admirers of classical civilisation fondly imagined were exemplified in those simpler and manlier times.

But if he had truly followed the spirit of the original games, he would have admitted no women or foreigners, for in antiquity only Greek-speaking men could compete, and the only women allowed to watch were priestesses of Demeter. There was no place for the hundreds of thousands of slaves on whom Greek life depended, except in their usual roles of servitude. In its racial exclusivity and celebration of a master culture, the ancient games has its closest parallel in the 1936 Munich Olympics, run by the Nazis. Whereas the modern spirit extols the virtue of participation - sportsmanship is what counts; taking part is as important as winning, and losing can be done with grace and courage - in ancient times losers were mocked, reviled, jeered and disgraced, sometimes not daring to return home afterwards. There was room for only one winner; to come second was to be nowhere.

So important were the Olympic games in the ancient world that the calendar was set by them. They took place every four years, between mid-August and mid-September, and the four-year gap between them was an Olympiad. Although Pindar wrote many kinds of poems, only his four books of epinicians survive, the triumphal odes dedicated to victors at the games. They were hugely popular and widely read. In a play by Aristophanes, set in the 420s BC, a man asks his son to read him a Pindaric ode, and the boy chooses one that celebrates a victory 40 years earlier.

The games were like the World Cup, only much bigger, and its heroes, who filled the popular imagination for decades and even centuries, gave Pindar and fellow poets the opportunity to retell myths, and to proclaim high moral and aesthetic aspirations for their culture. "Let us not admit any contest greater than Olympia," sang Pindar; "where Zeus presides over the race, so that the glory of victors might shine in the city of their birth, founded by some marvel of the gods."

We cannot know what the level of ancient athleticism was like. When the games "resumed" in 1896, the 100 yards sprint was won in 12 seconds, but it is easy to guess that a fit Greek of the epoch of Pindar would beat that without trouble. In an age which so enjoyed physical beauty, to which health is central, and which therefore valued an austere life and the enjoyment of exercise, it is easy to believe that Greek art accurately represents people capable of giving the best of today's athletes a run for their money.

In Sydney it will be the money that is run for, that is sure; and in this too the old and new are alike. The amateur ideal, introduced by Courbertin, did not exist in ancient times, for although the Olympian prize was supposed to be glory, signified by the olive-leaf chaplet, it was, as Pindar put it, a ticket to a very easy life. The ancient stakes were immensely high. Athletes had professional trainers - gumnastes - and spent years in preparation, just as they do now. They left nothing to chance, not even bribery.

The amateur ideal did not last long in modern times either, and for the same reason: the level of determination and commitment required to compete at Olympic level is not open to part-timers.

Perhaps the biggest difference between Sydney now and Olympia then is that the latter was bluntly honest in its exclusion of all but Greek men, and in its acceptance that the games were no game, but a tough fight for rewards. Modern Olympics are not one whit purer in motive than their antique forerunners, but they pretend to be, employing a grand rhetoric of international peace, the spirit of friendly competition, the joy and pleasure of exercise, the good-natured and good-hearted aspiration to fun and endeavour. But although this is just rhetoric, and without the poetry of Pindar, I like it: it might one day become true.

webTitle: Prince Baltasar Carlos in Silver, Velazquez (1632-3)

fields.headline: Prince Baltasar Carlos in Silver, Velazquez (1632-3)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Diego Velazquez (1599-1660), who painted low-life scenes before becoming a salaried painter to Philip IV of Spain and one of the monarch's favourite courtiers, and providing him with portraits of princes, nobles, buffoons and dwarves.

Subject Prince Baltasar Carlos (1629-1646), son of Philip IV, whom Velazquez painted several times: on horseback, at the royal stables, as a hunter, always emphasising his destiny as a future king - before the prince'4s death at the age of 17.

Distinguishing features: This is a painting of a small boy - if painted in 1632 he was three - whose face is an exquisite image of childhood: cherubic cheeks, innocent gaze, golden curls. This perfect little prince is already preparing himself, with his sword and sceptre-like staff, for the kingly part he never lived to play.

When people commissioned portraits in the past they wanted something we now want from a photograph: a true likeness. More than that, in the 17th century the portrait became the grandest, most sophisticated, philosophical kind of art. By taking its premise seriously, Velazquez in Spain 4and Rembrandt in the Netherlands turned it into a metaphysical meditation.

Velazquez's paintings of the Spanish royal family and their retainers are so disconcerting that today we can't help seeing them as subversive. Why did he paint dwarves and jesters with the same dignity he gave noblemen? Velazquez was not just a court painter, he was a hugely successful courtier who was promoted from year to year and was trusted to mould the image of the Spanish royal family. He once even had the job of censoring portraits of the king.

In this painting Prince Baltasar Carlos is wearing silver, but although Velazquez records the opulence of his dress you know this is not what the picture is about. Whereas his contemporary Rubens, or Van Dyck, might picture royal power through the richness of appearance, Velazquez frames things differently. The prince is set in a space that is theatrical, with the open curtain to his right around him is darkness. It can be read as resplendent flattery: the boy is the light. His silver and pink satin garments and most of all his glowing face and golden curls illuminate the world. His stance - firmly clutching a staff and with hi4s left hand on his sword - announce that he is born to be king. The very adult hat on the cushion is there ready for him to put on when the time comes.

Yet behind him is that void. If this space is a theatre, it is to modern eyes a rather Beckett-like one. Velazquez isolates his subjects to heighten the mystery of identity. What makes one person different from another what is power, royalty? What is the illuminating magic inside this little boy?

In 1631 Velazquez painted the boy in the same pose, with one of the royal dwarves beside him. The dwarf holds a rattle which looks like a sceptre and an apple that looks like an orb while the Prince looks regally ahead the dwarf's attention is off to the left somewhere - it is mobile, unfixed, more how we look at the world. To be royal in both paintings is to lack the fluidity of others. It is to be a prisoner of one's own glory.

Did they like it? Yes. Velazquez continued to receive promotion and paint royal portraits until the end of his life and the royal collection of his paintings is still in the Prado, Madrid.

Where is it? Wallace Collection, London W1 (020-7935 0687).

fields.headline: Age shall not wither them
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: Because of Mrs Wormington's advanced age (95), it is like having a living history book permanently open on the kitchen table
fields.body:
Saturday, June 3, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Because of Mrs Wormington's advanced age (95), it is like having a living history book permanently open on the kitchen table. A mention of Dunkirk brings an anecdote about the little boat, the Betty Grable, that her younger brother Cedric sailed across the English Channel during the evacuation. "He weren't the same when he came back," she said. "He took up knitting and joined the Communist party." Apparently, both of these activities were enough to banish him from the bosom of the Wormington family. "I used to write to him in secret," she said. "And on his birthday I'd send him a knitting pattern." William and Glen have been glued to the Dunkirk coverage across television, hoping to see Cedric on the Betty Grable.

Sunday, June 4

My mother came round to stay with Mrs Wormington and the boys while I went to see my father in hospital. His original injuries are healing, but he is still ill with the infection he caught in hospital. Apparently, his body has shrugged off most of the powerful antibiotics given to him. My father has taken to boasting about this - as in "there's not an antibiotic alive that can touch George Mole".

Tania, his newish wife, has worked hard to turn him into a middle-class new man. But, I fear, to no avail. Since his garden pagoda accident, he has reverted to type: the Sun is delivered to his bed every morning by the Women's Voluntary Service, and he inevitably picks all the stodgy items on the computerised menu form. Tania has given up reading improving literature to him, since he laughed out loud at the end of Jonathan Livingston Seagull.

When I arrive home, I find a heartening scene of inter-generational harmony. Mrs Wormington, my mother, Glen and William are sitting in a circle passing the nit comb from one to the other. William has introduced head lice into our house yet again.

Ivan Braithwaite came to pick up my mother. He has recently been diagnosed as suffering from over-choice syndrome. He broke down in the washing-powder aisle at Safeway. He was observed on a CCTV camera to be acting bizarrely - walking up and down the aisle for a full 20 minutes while scribbling calculations on a notepad. He then knelt by the boxes of Persil biological tablets and wept. When my mother finally turned up to collect him, he was sitting in the manager's office, hungry and thirsty. He'd been offered tea or coffee and ginger nuts or digestives, but had, of course, been unable to choose between them.

I don't like the man, but I sympathise with his affliction. My own temples start to throb when it comes to choosing between the hundreds of shampoos on offer.

Monday June 5

Worked on Sty, my pig novel. Since finishing with Pamela Pigg, I have been writing better than ever I have done before. Was P Pig blocking me in some way?

Tuesday, June 6

While the boys were at school and Mrs Wormington was having her feet done by a peripatetic chiropodist, I wrote 250 words of Sty. Should I give my pig-hero a name, or should the pig stand for struggling humanity? I need literary advice from an editor.

10pm. Just looked up "Editors" on the net and found the editor of the year...

To: Walrus Books, Kensington

Dear Louise Moore,
Congratulations on your prestigious win. My name is Adrian Mole. I am a full-time carer and part-time novelist and dramatist (as yet unpublished and unperformed). My current work-in-progress is a stream-of-consciousness novel about a pig. I have set myself some problems - obviously, I am not a pig myself and I have no idea what pigs think about all day. May I come to see you? I remain, madam your most humble and obedient servant,

Adrian Mole.

fields.headline: Syria's President Assad dies
fields.trailText: President Hafez Assad of Syria died this morning in Damascus. He was 69 and had for some time suffered from heart problems and diabetes.
fields.body:
President Hafez Assad of Syria died this morning in Damascus. He was 69 and had for some time suffered from heart problems and diabetes.

In breaking the news to the Syrian public, state-run television announced: "Death has taken away from Syria a leader." The announcer's voice choked as he began to cry.

Syrian television showed MPs standing, heads bowed in the chamber for a moment of silence, wiping away tears.

The country President Assad led for 30 years was isolated and economically troubled, but Syria's autocratic president never hinted he saw himself as a man defeated.

The Israeli government expressed sorrow at the death and said it would continue to work for peace with its longtime foe.

"The Israeli government understands the sorrow of the Syrian people over the passing of President Hafez Assad," said a statement released by prime minister Ehud Barak's office.

"Israel worked in the past to achieve peace and will continue to do so in the future."

The statement also expressed hope that quiet would be maintained along the border with Syria and Lebanon. Israel withdrew its troops from southern Lebanon May 24 after an 18-year occupation. Syria is considered the main power broker in Lebanon.

Stop-start peace talks between Israel and Syria broke down in January because Syria insisted on assurances that Israel would withdraw from the Golan Heights and hand over land extending down to the Sea of Galilee. Israel refused to make such a pledge and insisted that security arrangements must be agreed first. Israel captured the strategic Golan plateau from Syria in the 1967 war when Assad was defence minister

A skilful and ruthless politician, Assad often succeeded by keeping both foes and friends guessing, reversing course suddenly when he saw an advantage.

Syria put aside enmity with the United States to join the US-led coalition against his longtime rival Iraq during the 1990-91 Gulf crisis. Assad sent troops to help drive Iraq out of Kuwait, and later reaped diplomatic and financial benefits that included $2bn from Saudi Arabia.

Assad could never be discounted in the Middle East equation. "The Lion of Damascus" - his family name means lion in Arabic - was one of the Middle East's longest-serving leaders. He was credited with bringing political stability to a country of 9m that saw repeated coups after independence from France in 1946. Assad's bloodless takeover was the last coup since 1970.

Assad built a Soviet-style personality cult at home, his portrait plastered everywhere in Syria. Born on October 6, 1930 into a peasant family from the minority Alawite Muslim sect, he plotted his way to power through the ranks of the military and the socialist Ba'ath Party.

He worked long hours and prided himself on managing the minutest details of his administration. His discipline extended to his private life - he was a vegetarian who abstained from alcohol, but rumours of ill health have dogged him since a heart attack in 1983.

He survived several reported several coup attempts, including a failed 1984 effort by his ambitious brother Rifaat.

Like his hero Saladin, the Kurdish warrior who defeated the Crusaders in the 12th Century, Assad dreamed of becoming the unchallenged leader of the Arab world. Israel, though, was an alternative centre of power in the region and, in Assad's view intent on weakening its Arab neighbours. His attempts to rally other Arab leaders to present a unified front against Israel gained little ground. He derided Egypt for signing a peace treaty with Israel in 1979. Jordan signed its own peace in 1994 and the Palestinians were pursuing yet another settlement with the Jewish state - Assad has clashed with Yasser Arafat for control of the Palestinian cause. Syria and its client state Lebanon faced the prospect of being the last of Israel's neighbours to work out a peace deal.

Assad's confrontation with Western-backed Israel led to close ties with Moscow. The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 was a blow, but also presented an opening for much-needed reform. Legislation meant to encourage private investment was enacted in 1991, but progress has been slow.

Assad maintained a vast army of secret police and informers. His government jailed thousands of political prisoners without trial during his rule, according to human rights groups.

In March this year the first cabinet reshuffle in eight years was seen as part of the leadership's campaign to respond to domestic concerns by modernising the administration and eradicating corruption.

Assad's son and chosen heir, Bashar, has championed economic reform and led the anti-corruption drive. Bashar's elder brother Basil had been groomed as heir, until his death in a car crash in 1994. Assad also had three other sons and a daughter.

fields.headline: For love of the dame
fields.standfirst: Kevin Costner is pitching for our attention once again with the third instalment in his  baseball trilogy. The only trouble, says Joe Queenan, is that the star has taken his eye off the  ball
fields.trailText: Kevin Costner is pitching for our attention once again with the third instalment in his baseball trilogy. The only trouble, says Joe Queenan, is that the star has taken his eye off the ball
fields.body:
For Love Of The Game is a movie fraught with bittersweet ironies, but that doesn't mean you should rush out to see it. The third and least successful instalment in the Kevin Costner Baseball Trilogy that began with the superb Bull Durham and the elegiac Field Of Dreams, For Love Of The Game is a movie about a once-dominant pitcher (the American equivalent of a cricket bowler) who is now far past his prime. That the role of Billy Chapel is played by a once-dominant actor (The Bodyguard, Robin Hood: Prince Of Thieves, The Untouchables, Dances With Wolves) who is now far past his prime is the most striking of the bittersweet ironies that permeate this movie. But like I said, that's not necessarily a good reason to run out and see it.

One reason that For Love Of The Game is not nearly as successful as Field Of Dreams and Bull Durham is because of the role Costner inhabits. In Bull Durham, Costner played a minor-league catcher, a hard-working, likeable guy who simply did not have enough talent to play in the major leagues. In short, he was an Everyman. In Field Of Dreams, he played the archetypal middle-American male, imbued with a reverence for family, tradition and baseball. Again, he was Everyman. But in For Love Of The Game, he plays an ageing jock who is a bit of a lush and who must now learn the hard way that baseball isn't everything. He is rich, he is famous, he sports a championship ring and he has a girl in every port. In a word, he is Everydude. How the audience is supposed to identify or feel sorry for this guy is anybody's guess.

The oddest thing about For Love Of The Game is that it is a sports movie that seems to have been made for people who don't know much about or even like sports. In my own oblique little way, I am trying to suggest that it is a sports movie made for women. Unlike Bull Durham and Field Of Dreams, which are basically movies about the American male's belief in the healing power of baseball - a belief I happen to share - For Love Of The Game is a movie about the healing power of Kristy Swanson.

It is a movie in which an ageing athlete, having walked away from the game he loves after pitching one of the most magnificent games in the history of the sport, cries himself to sleep at night because his girlfriend is moving to London. This, I submit, would never happen in real life; she wouldn't move to London, and he wouldn't cry if she did. Not after pitching a perfect game, in which not a single batter managed to reach base against him. This is a movie that first entices the audience with the possibility that the hero is going to achieve the impossible dream, and then tells us that the dream, while impossible, wasn't all that important. For Love Of The Game? More like For Love Of The Dame.

The unflattering parallels with Bull Durham and Field Of Dreams do not end here. Where the former had wit and style and clever plot twists, and the latter exuded a goofy innocence, For Love Of The Game is calculating and generic, with a screenplay drafted by a committee of script doctors. Of course Costner is going to meet his beautiful girlfriend when her car breaks down on the side of the road; when was the last time a homely woman's car broke down on the Interstate? Of course Swanson will be a writer for Elle who knows absolutely nothing about baseball. And of course she will wear schoolmarmish eyeglasses. How else would we know that she is intelligent?

That's not all. It goes without saying that we will have the fish-out-of-water scene where Swanson comes to Yankee Stadium and feels like an idiot. Of course we will have the fish-out-of-water scene where Costner visits a trendy downtown art gallery and feels like an idiot. Of course she will be a single mother with a rebellious daughter who doesn't trust men. Of course they will learn to love him because he is warm, sensitive and has a fantastic ski lodge in Montana. Of course he will stick his hand inside an electric saw and nearly wreck his career until the love of a good woman pulls him through. Of course all the fans at Yankee Stadium will tawk like dis because New Yawkers in da movies always tawk like dis, even though most New Yawkers woin't actually born dere and tawk like normal people. And of course his best friend will be a spit-and-sawdust yokel with a heart as wide as the Caucasus and a brain the size of a peanut. In the end, this isn't a movie about love or friendship or self-recognition, and it certainly isn't a movie about baseball. It's a movie about every other Strong Silent Type meets Miss Smartypants movie you've ever seen: The Horse Whisperer Bangs The Drum Slowly.

When Kevin Costner took Hollywood by storm in the late 80s, audiences were beguiled by his plodding sincerity, by a winning dumbness that had not been seen since the days of Gary Cooper. Back then, Costner's movies fell into two groups: those in which he merely seemed naive (No Way Out, Field Of Dreams, Bull Durham, Robin Hood) and those in which he seemed like an outright numskull (Dances With Wolves, The Bodyguard, The Untouchables.) But as time went on, this act got tired, and very expensive, and though Costner continued to make big oafish movies (Waterworld, Wyatt Earp, The Postman), the public was no longer interested in seeing them.

For a brief moment (Tin Cup) a couple of years ago it seemed that Costner might be getting his career back on track, but then came the unfortunate Message In A Bottle and now the wan For Love Of The Game. Unlike Billy Chapel, whose career is clearly over at the end of this film, Kevin Costner does not seem to be a pathetic has-been a la Sylvester Stallone or Arnold Schwarzenegger. Far more gifted than those two lummoxes, he seems like the kind of actor who still has a few good things left in store for him if he can only find the right script. For Love Of The Game isn't it.

 For Love Of The Game is out on Friday
