Back then, Costner's movies fell into two groups: those in which he merely seemed naive (No Way Out, Field Of Dreams, Bull Durham, Robin Hood) and those in which he seemed like an outright numskull (Dances With Wolves, The Bodyguard, The Untouchables.) But as time went on, this act got tired, and very expensive, and though Costner continued to make big oafish movies (Waterworld, Wyatt Earp, The Postman), the public was no longer interested in seeing them. For a brief moment (Tin Cup) a couple of years ago it seemed that Costner might be getting his career back on track, but then came the unfortunate Message In A Bottle and now the wan For Love Of The Game. Unlike Billy Chapel, whose career is clearly over at the end of this film, Kevin Costner does not seem to be a pathetic has-been a la Sylvester Stallone or Arnold Schwarzenegger. Far more gifted than those two lummoxes, he seems like the kind of actor who still has a few good things left in store for him if he can only find the right script. For Love Of The Game isn't it.  For Love Of The Game is out on Friday

fields.headline: Dennis and destiny
fields.standfirst: Once he played sharp-shooting cowboys and rock'n'roll rebels, but these  days Dennis Quaid is a caring family man, on and off the screen
fields.trailText: Once he played sharp-shooting cowboys and rock'n'roll rebels, but these days Dennis Quaid is a caring family man, on and off the screen
fields.body:
Back in the 80s, Dennis Quaid was a hot young actor with a wild streak as big as his home state of Texas. But a happy marriage to superstar Meg Ryan and one of the more interesting journeyman careers in modern Hollywood appear to have led him to a state of confident contentment. Now in his mid-40s, he's making a solid career out of playing solid, middle-aged guys, recently in films such as Oliver Stone's Any Given Sunday, Steven Soderbergh's new drug war epic Traffic, his own directing debut Everything That Rises, and sentimental sci-fi thriller Frequency, due for release this Friday. In the latter, Quaid is a New York fireman, killed in the line of duty in 1969, who comes into contact with his adult son from the year 1999 over a cosmically supercharged ham radio, and they work together across the decades to change their destinies.

Was talking to Jim Caviezel across 30 years, which basically must have been like you were acting alone with a box, a special challenge?

That's not what it was, really. [Director] Greg Hoblit was very ingenious. He built two sets on the same soundstage and we had two crews shooting simultaneously, so we did those scenes in real time. Jim was talking on his radio, I was talking on mine, but I could hear his real voice, so it was like doing a scene rather than being hooked up with some sort of earwig situation with some actor over in a soundproof booth. It was fantastic.

As well as time travel, the deal here is reconnecting with your dead father, the ultimate ace for a male weepy film.

Our dads get us emotional. It hits a nerve in all of us that we're working out, no matter whether you had a great relationship with him or a bad one.

Did making Frequency dredge up anything you felt about your father?

He passed away about 14 years ago. We had a great relationship, nothing was left unsaid, but this definitely brought a lot up. For years after he died, something would happen and I'd go, "Hey, I'll callÉ Oh, I can't call him, he's not here." And I still regret some things, like he's not around to see his grandson. That would've been really cool.

Let's look at it from the other side of that fence. What, if anything, did this movie make you feel as a father?

I was pretty invested in this. My son was six years old, the same age as my son in the movie when I die, while I was making this film. One thing, y'know, I have to take care of myself to be around for him. But it didn't take a movie for me to realise an important thing like that.

You do have a knack for hanging around. You work more regularly than most actors your age, and usually on good stuff.

I'm still here, man. In fact, I feel like I'm doing the best work of my career right now. So I feel, at this point, like I'm in a very good place.

That said, don't you and Meg try to get out of Hollywood whenever you can and hang out on your Montana ranch?

It's really essential. I grew up loving the country, and I just have to have it, I really need it. It goes way beyond even a refuge from public life. I need to be in the country; I just feel more comfortable there.

Is it a working ranch?

It's more like a getaway place, really. I'm not really one for having a lot of cowshit around. The working ranch thing - it sounds really romantic until you actually get out there and freeze your hands off over an ice-cold water pump.

fields.headline: Designer strides
fields.standfirst: Style guru  Stephen Bayley deplores ramblers but makes time to stroll down to his private bar and dining club in Chelsea
fields.trailText: Style guru Stephen Bayley deplores ramblers but makes time to stroll down to his private bar and dining club in Chelsea
fields.body:
Stephen Bayley is almost as scathing about recreational walking as he is about the contents of the Dome and the Government's attempts to rebrand the country as "cool Britannia".

"Don't you think it's wonderfully ironic that the offices of the Ramblers Association are at Vauxhall Cross, one of the most despoiled and blighted corners of London?" he says. "I don't want to sound vindictive, but I deplore ramblers.

"I'm against all forms of collectivism, and the group mentality of the right-to-roam movement is not for me. It's a kind of suburbanisation of the countryside, and I want the country to be markedly different from the suburbs - I want it to be wild and difficult and dangerous."

But he's not against "functional" walking, with a purpose beyond the activity itself, and he usually goes on foot between various haunts in central London - from his office near Kennington Park, say, to the Bluebird Club in King's Road, a private bar and dining room designed by his erstwhile mentor Sir Terence Conran.

His route starts with zig-zags through some of the hidden enclaves - some delightful, some not - between south London's major roads: peaceful Victorian terraces at first, then an "ugly but haunting" gasworks and a huge, thriving squat near the Oval cricket ground.

"Then I'd go down Harleyford Road, which is a traffic-infested sewer, and turn off through Vauxhall Grove," he says. "It's is an unknown area full of quite charming houses, with some very strange trees and plants. It must be the least-known residential area in central London."

This brings him to "the horrors" of Vauxhall Cross, where six major routes collide. As a libertarian and design guru, he shuns the underpass and leaps over the railings to play chicken with the traffic. He casts a partly-admiring eye on the nearby MI6 building and the exotic glass towers going up alongside.

Then it's along the river, past the "lost opportunities" of Nine Elms with a fine view of Chelsea Bridge, until a waterside recycling plant and the crumbling bulk of Battersea Power Station forces him on to main roads again to reach Battersea Park.

"From it, you also get the best view of the most beautiful part of London - that stretch of Chelsea Embankment between Chelsea Bridge and Oakley Street. It's an absolutely perfect piece of urban environment.

"You get Wren's Royal Hospital, which is one of the loveliest buildings in London, then that fabulous stretch of art-and-crafts houses, surely the happiest moment in British architectural history, and a sight of Chelsea Physic Garden."

The finale is the crossing of the delicate, pastel-painted Albert Bridge, looking down at the boats on Cadogan Pier and sidestepping into old Chelsea, between King's Road and Cheyne Walk. Bayley regards this area as the highlight of the 40-minute walk.

"Being close to water is also marvellous, and sitting near to the Buddhist temple of peace in the park and looking across the river, well, there are few better things to do than that."

Power politics

The past 20 years have done much to disprove the accusation that London has wasted its riverside sites: we've had Canary Wharf and the redevelopment of Docklands, the refurbishment of the Oxo Tower and Bankside Power Station, Chelsea Harbour, the London Eye and the Dome.

The glaring exception to this progress is Battersea Power Station, which went out of service 17 years ago and now stands derelict. A series of owners have promised much but so far done nothing.

The present owners, Parkview International, controlled by George and Victor Hwang of Hong Kong, want to turn it into "an integrated entertain ment, leisure, sport, retail and restaurant destination", with offices, hotels and flats on the rest of the site.

The plans, which need approval from Wandsworth Borough Council, envisage one glass wall and a glass roof for the power station, while preserving the rest of the huge brick structure and the twin, cream-coloured chimneys. The surrounding buildings would be lower.

The Battersea Power Station Community Group is sceptical. Spokesman Brian Barnes is concerned that the scheme has no affordable housing and that the proposed contents sound as vague as the Dome. The group will shortly be discussing the issue with the new mayor of London, Ken Livingstone.

fields.headline: The word from the wilderness
fields.standfirst: Face to Faith
fields.trailText: The Jewish festival of Shavuot was celebrated yesterday and, outside Israel, continues today
fields.body:
The Jewish festival of Shavuot was celebrated yesterday and, outside Israel, continues today

Uniquely for the Hebrew calendar, the festival of Shavuot (literally the "Feast of Weeks", or Pentecost in Greek) comes with no specific date. While other biblical festivals are defined by the day and month on which they fall - as in "the 10th day of the seventh month shall be Yom Kippur" - Shavuot comes merely "50 days after the beginning of Passover".

A hint of the intended date can be found in the creation narrative, where "the sixth day" appears with the definite object (Genesis 1: 31), as opposed to all the other days, which are defined only indirectly (a second day, a third day, etc). Rabbis infer that this refers to the sixth day of the third month (biblical months generally had no names, just numbers) after the children of Israel had left Egyptian bondage and reached the foot of Mt Sinai, where they were to receive the Torah (Exodus, Ch 19).

For the rabbis, this verified the ultimate goal of the world, and the date is therefore woven into the fabric of the creation. Indeed, the continuation of the world was contingent on Israel's acceptance of the Torah at Sinai. Otherwise, God was prepared to "return the works of creation back to chaos" (Talmud Shabbat 88a).

There is a strange and disturbing undercurrent here. Freed from slavery, the people of Israel stand beneath Sinai ready to accept the burden and glory of becoming a precious people. The Torah, in all its splendour, would be offered them, as a husband offers his beloved the choicest diamond beneath the bridal canopy. Simultaneously, they are presented with a zero-sum equation: either accept My offer of marriage, or you will be crushed beneath this mountain and bring the world to dust. Needless to say, it's an offer they cannot refuse.

The identification of Shavuot with the giving of the Torah on Mt Sinai allows the rabbis to turn the festival into a day of study. This is what traditional Jews do to this day, studying the whole first night in preparation for "receiving" the Torah symbolically the following morning.

Paradoxically, too, no specific geographical location is given for Mt Sinai (Exodus 19: 2), leading the rabbis to conclude that it is precisely in such an anonymous venue that God's word is to be heard, in a place owned by no one and thus accessible to all. The Sinai experience liberated the Israelites from both time and space, for only in such a mode could the eternal word of God be received.

The exact nature of the expe rience is tantalisingly caught in the Biblical account of the Torah-giving, when the people, according to the Hebrew text, "saw the voices" (Exodus 20: 15). The foremost commentator on the Torah, Rashi (11th-century Wurms) adds: "They saw what was heard and heard what they saw."

What, then, was the actual content of this hallucinatory, son-et-lumière encounter? On the one hand, the people cry to Moses: "You talk to us and we shall hear, and let not God speak with us, lest we die." (Exodus 20: 30). Yet a few verses earlier, the people are warned to stay where they are "lest they break through to gaze at God, and many will perish" (Exodus 19: 21) - to which Rashi adds, "that, out of their passion for God, they destroy themselves, by drawing too close to the mountain."

The Sinai event thus includes the possibility of both self-destruction and transcendent ecstasy. Sinai is located in the anonymous desert, but remains tantalisingly extra-terrestrial. Its craggy face both entices and repulses, stimulating both desire and fear. It demands a strict code of morality - regarding murder, theft, idolatry, adultery, etc. But it is also other-worldly, rooted in a cosmic awareness of God. It has to be approached with care, a sense of risk, but mostly with love.

When the sages wished to convey the sense of awe appropriate to these events, they depicted it as a day of marriage. Ecstasy, balanced by a fear of offending the object of our love, is the key mode. "Do not awake my love until she desires it," to quote the Song Of Songs. The encounter on Sinai is that between lovers in their most intimate, orgasmic moment. What greater proof of love is there than the confusion of the senses - "seeing the voices" - which reveals a total dependency on an outside force?

To be worthy of receiving Torah means being prepared to go beyond ourselves, beyond our "civilised" norms, as did Moses's father-in-law Jethro, leaving the luxury of his native Midian for the dry wastes of the desert, in order to study God's words.

Similarly, in the scroll of Ruth, which is also read on Shavuot, the heroine comes from beyond the narrow world of one people. She is the daughter of a despised race, the Moabites. Her acceptance into Israel shows that Torah is not confined. It can reach anyone and anywhere, even inside the gates of the enemy.

The festival of Shavuot is thus anonymous precisely because it is directed not just at one people but at the entire human race. It is a reminder that God's Torah belongs to everyone. It demonstrates that, ultimately, there are no boundaries. The world is one and cannot be reduced to numbers; God is one and cannot be reduced to any of our frail and limiting definitions.

Mordechai Beck is a writer and journalist based in Jerusalem

fields.headline: Soul stealers
fields.standfirst: Victoria Davenport  on svengalis of the psyche in Mad Men and Medusas and Svengali's Web
fields.trailText: Victoria Davenport on svengalis of the psyche in Mad Men and Medusas and Svengali's Web
fields.body:
Mad Men and Medusas: Reclaiming Hysteria and the Effects of Sibling Relations on the Human Condition
Juliet Mitchell
Allen Lane, £20, 380pp
Buy it at BOL

Svengali's Web: The Alien Encounter in Modern Culture
Daniel Pick
Yale, £19.95, 284pp
Buy it at BOL

Here come two books to remind us that nothing much has changed in the old unconscious: we just call things by different names. Instead of worshipping gods and fetishes we have genetics and the internet - but strip away all the fancy wrappings, and we're back to life and death and the unknown.

Juliet Mitchell is a prolific writer, psychoanalyst and feminist whose new book sets out to "reclaim" hysteria, a subject she feels has been relegated to the 19th-century consulting room. Before Freud, hysteria went through various mutations. In 5th-century Athens it was named usterie and diagnosed as being due to a wandering womb, although both men and women were thought to be susceptible to it. Christianity turned it into the work of the devil and the Renaissance recognised it as a medical concept. But it was Freud, in analysing Dora, who finally rid hysteria of its mysticism and - Mitchell argues - feminised it.

In the 20th century, psychiatrists have redefined hysteria in various ways. Histrionic personality disorder replaces hysteria as an entry in the Diagnostic Statistical Manual.

Mitchell believes that Freud brought about the feminisation of hysteria to avoid his own unconscious conflicts about the death of his brother. One of the new concepts she introduces is that, contrary to traditional psychoanalytical theory, it is sibling rivalry as much as Oedipal conflict that underlies hysteria.

Mitchell relates this to a concept called "laterality", meaning relationships not only with brothers and sisters, but with peers and partners - with anyone who might stand between ourselves and our mothers, rendering us helpless. She writes: "It is this catastrophic awareness that one is not unique which triggers the onset of hysteria." Freud, she argues, was himself a hysteric, but unable to face it, hence his suggestion that hysteria was a female disorder. The idea has since been perpetuated by a largely male medical and psychiatric profession.

Because we've done away with carnivals and symbolic rituals as a way of expressing our hysteria, we have had to find other means. In some cases, hysteria is turned in on the body; what was known as conversion hysteria in Freud's time - paralysed limbs and the like - has become psychosomatic illness. And because a major feature of hysteria is mimicry (the hysteric is even capable of imitating his or her own illness), it is very difficult to pin down.

Mitchell quite convincingly argues that hysteria is closely linked with trauma, although it is hard to know which comes first: does trauma result in hysteria, or does hysteria lead, for instance, to the recalling of an incident, as in false memory syndrome? In either case, for a man, hysteria as a result of trauma will probably be called "post-war neurosis" or even schizophrenia, while for a woman the hysteric label remains, with an implication of play-acting, deliberate or otherwise.

The fairly dense jargon in Mitchell's book - its repetition and wordiness - don't make it an easy read. Nevertheless, she has some interesting things to say about our hysterical culture and the fascinating strangeness of human behaviour.

Less of a slog, but with just as many important things to say, is Daniel Pick's Svengali. He uses George du Maurier's story Trilby as his springboard into an exploration of the Victorian psyche. Du Maurier's tale is a deceptively simple one: Svengali, an intinerant conductor of "Jewish aspect, well featured but sinister", hypnotises a young artist's model, Trilby, without her consent. She eventually marries him and becomes an international concert star, but sings only when under his spell.

The book, published in 1894, gripped readers on both sides of the Atlantic. Was Svengali purely a creation of Du Maurier's imagination, or was he a product of the age? Pick sets out to show how our unconscious needs dictate who we make into our Svengalis. Fast-paced and gripping, using as examples a broad range of people including Disraeli, Wagner and even Jenny Lind, the book shows how the figure of Svengali reflects a need to project onto the alien Other - often the foreigner - unwanted and dangerous unconscious desires. The Other then possesses the power that we have handed over, and in turn becomes both fascinating and terrifying (Pick pays tribute to Melanie Klein for her conceptualisation of projective identification).

The Victorian love of fluff and nonsense, of smoke and mirrors, covered myriad anxieties. There was an obsession with, and terror of, the unleashing of emotion, particularly sexual. The story of the innocent Trilby and her Svengali is rife with sexual implications that were picked up by an excited and anxious public.

Du Maurier received letters demanding reassurance that the relationship was merely paternal. After all, "If a prostitute could be made to renounce her trade through hypnotic interference, why might not a virtuous woman be perverted by the same method?" The Victorians were full of contradictions: fascinated by science, they were equally drawn to mesmerism and the occult. And while hypnosis was being performed on stage as entertainment, it was also being used in the consulting room by Dr Freud - upon susceptible young women not unlike Trilby.

Instead of worshipping gods and fetishes we have genetics and the internet - but strip away all the fancy wrappings, and we're back to life and death and the unknown. Juliet Mitchell is a prolific writer, psychoanalyst and feminist whose new book sets out to "reclaim" hysteria, a subject she feels has been relegated to the 19th-century consulting room. Before Freud, hysteria went through various mutations. In 5th-century Athens it was named usterie and diagnosed as being due to a wandering womb, although both men and women were thought to be susceptible to it. Christianity turned it into the work of the devil and the Renaissance recognised it as a medical concept. But it was Freud, in analysing Dora, who finally rid hysteria of its mysticism and - Mitchell argues - feminised it. In the 20th century, psychiatrists have redefined hysteria in various ways. Mitchell relates this to a concept called "laterality", meaning relationships not only with brothers and sisters, but with peers and partners - with anyone who might stand between ourselves and our mothers, rendering us helpless. She writes: "It is this catastrophic awareness that one is not unique which triggers the onset of hysteria." Freud, she argues, was himself a hysteric, but unable to face it, hence his suggestion that hysteria was a female disorder. The idea has since been perpetuated by a largely male medical and psychiatric profession. Because we've done away with carnivals and symbolic rituals as a way of expressing our hysteria, we have had to find other means. In some cases, hysteria is turned in on the body; what was known as conversion hysteria in Freud's time - paralysed limbs and the like - has become psychosomatic illness. In either case, for a man, hysteria as a result of trauma will probably be called "post-war neurosis" or even schizophrenia, while for a woman the hysteric label remains, with an implication of play-acting, deliberate or otherwise. The Victorian love of fluff and nonsense, of smoke and mirrors, covered myriad anxieties. There was an obsession with, and terror of, the unleashing of emotion, particularly sexual. The story of the innocent Trilby and her Svengali is rife with sexual implications that were picked up by an excited and anxious public. fields.headline: The freedom to love
fields.standfirst: 'In Italy, there is more prejudice against homosexuals than there is here. It is very unusual for even a known gay politician to come out'
fields.trailText: 'In Italy, there is more prejudice against homosexuals than there is here. It is very unusual for even a known gay politician to come out'
fields.body:
This is a first, I think. It certainly hasn't happened yet in British politics. The 41-year-old Italian Minister of Agriculture, Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, has just "come out" as a bisexual. This is quite different from coming out as a homosexual, which is admitting that you only fancy people of your own sex. An admission of bisexuality, on the other hand, implies that you are game for anything. In fact, that's just what the minister said: "I claim for everyone the freedom to love any person, whether it is a man or a woman," he told an Italian newspaper. "And naturally I claim this freedom for myself, since I already practise it - in theory."

What did he mean "in theory", asked the newspaper. "In reality, I don't have the time," the minister replied. "I am too busy with milk quotas and genetically-modified foods. I have theories about sex, but I don't have sex. And seeing as I am fighting a battle to free Italy of genetically-modified organisms, perhaps it's time to make it a sex-free country as well, one in which everything doesn't go back to sex. There are more important things to think about."

Given that Mr Pecoraro claims to engage in no sexual activity at all at the moment, it seems rather strange of him, as a cabinet minister, to talk publicly about what he might do if he did. He insisted he hadn't made a "confession", since he had nothing to confess. "I have no sins on my conscience, I have nothing to be ashamed of," he said. He had only discussed his belief in total sexual freedom because a journalist had asked him about it. "I am a southerner, a Mediterranean man," he said. "I believe that life should be enjoyed as much as possible." He refuses to regard himself as gay, and showed no interest in this month's Gay Pride march in Rome. He is certainly no hero of the gay community.

If he wanted a family, he would marry a woman, he insisted. And being baptised a Roman Catholic, he would probably do so in church. But knowing that he "tends not to be faithful", and not being (as he puts it) "monodirectional" in his sexual tastes, he has so far decided against getting married. Until he reached his late 20s, he had been "a fairly rigid heterosexual", he said. He had believed that even thinking about certain things was wrong. But then he had made "a cultural acquisition, that of not wanting to be categorised. And perhaps there was also a bit of boredom with monodirectional choice. As a boyfriend, I have always been unfaithful. That is why I am now single and don't live with anybody."

The only other politician I can think of who effectively admitted he had "always been unfaithful" was the late Alan Clark MP, and he was unfaithful only with women. Mr Pecoraro's press interview is remarkable not only because he reveals not the smallest moral qualm about his self-confessed promiscuity with both men and women, but because Italy is less tolerant than Britain of this kind of thing.

There is more prejudice against homosexuals there than here, especially among traditionalist Catholics and in the right-wing political parties; and there is an even greater reluctance among politicians to reveal their sexual preferences. It is very unusual for even a known Italian gay politician to come out. In a comment on Mr Pecoraro's case, the Italian newspaper La Repubblica noted that Tony Blair's easy acceptance of Peter Mandelson's relationship with his Brazilian boyfriend would be impossible to imagine in Italy.

Mr Pecoraro is a member of the Green Party, and this may help explain his frankness. Asked if he thought his indiscretions could damage his political career, he replied that he didn't think truth and transparency could do anybody any harm in a "clean" political climate. One of the many issues Mr Pecoraro has said he considers more important than sex is political corruption in Italy. He is opposed to pollution of any kind.

While it remains a mystery to me why Mr Pecoraro revealed what he did, especially since there was no scandal needing to be defused, I am impressed by the nonchalance that he brought to the discussion of his sexuality. I particularly respect his insistence that sex is not the central problem in life for people who are busy with other things. While this is obviously true, it is a brave thing to say on the eve of a major Gay Pride march. It is also rather a modest thing to say. It suggests that a person's private sexual proclivities are not nearly as important as lots of other things, as indeed they are not. But this is something that many people nowadays are curiously reluctant to admit.

fields.headline: Leave the Oxbridge amateurs alone
fields.trailText: As the sun displaces the last few inches of snow, the dribble-drip of cricket writers thawing can be heard across the country. The lesser-spotted warblers, radius commentatus, have returned from their winter migration and will soon be singing their old tunes. Lancashire and Somerset don their wellies to administer a judicious trampling to the frail buds of Oxbridge, and it's open season. Nothing else would seem quite right.
fields.body:
As the sun displaces the last few inches of snow, the dribble-drip of cricket writers thawing can be heard across the country. The lesser-spotted warblers, radius commentatus, have returned from their winter migration and will soon be singing their old tunes. Lancashire and Somerset don their wellies to administer a judicious trampling to the frail buds of Oxbridge, and it's open season. Nothing else would seem quite right.

The journalists, too, enjoy this gentle warm-up. While John Crawley eases his way into the averages with a century knock against his old Uni, the correspondents can stretch their literary muscles with a spot of Oxbridge-baiting. In the early absence of excuses for our national malaise (B&H cup, poor management, Craig White) the Varsity matches are a perfect stop-gap.

The traditions of cricket often come under fire from the gatling gun of progress. So it is with the Oxbridge match, which has become for many critics the emblem of all that is amateurish, and therefore bad, about the English game. Yet although the seasoned sage may bemoan its first-class status, no-one has yet mustered the cynicism to pull the plug on this eccentric, but loved, cousin of the county game. We're simply too fond of it. We never tire of seeing the country's leading minds get a ritual trouncing. At the hands of anybody. We revel in the fact that their combined IQ regularly exceeds their first-innings score. They are the perennial underdog and this not only makes them irresistible to the British sensibility, but a part of it.

Blues games aren't about competition. As a Cambridge girl of the '90s, if I wanted to see my side win all I had to do was go to Putney. It needs no Mystic Meg to predict the result of the Gloucestershire Gladiators v the Godmagogs XI. But what does that matter? If we really believe that an even contest truly outweighs tradition, then why do we still play for the Ashes?

At Fenner's and The Parks, the entire ground consists of people who really should be elsewhere, students and professors alike. Library escapees, blinking at the light, clasp their scorecards like the key to freedom. Arts students bask with unabashed idleness, taking warm slugs of Adnams while they try to list the last ten Cambridge men to play for England, or the last Oxford man to play for anyone at all. The pace of the cricket matches the pace of life. And if there is room for three one-day trophies in the domestic game, you need a haven for the more speculative spectator.

How could we condone the dissolution of a contest which houses so many singular opportunities? Nowhere else could you see the flashing cover-drive that stylishly completes a Tufnell half-century, or discuss Tudor economic policy with Mike Atherton over the boundary rope. Or (my personal favourite) watch Gus Fraser arrive at Fenner's sheepishly trying to conceal a double whopper with cheese beneath his jumper.

Oxbridge matches are amateur. As such they bring freshness and good humour back to a game beset by anger and administrative failure. If the Blues match is an emblem of what cricket used to mean, let it remain so, because it symbolises a love of the game in its purest form.

Emma John lives in Bath, but studied English at Downing College, Cambridge, where she played some cricket when she could. She was writing before Oxford Universities beat Northamptonshire by three wickets in the Parks on Thursday

fields.headline: Britain's economy aglow
fields.standfirst:
It is time for a real debate about the euro
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: This week has been captured for history by the Women's Institute. But it ought also to be remembered as the week when the Paris-based OECD produced a glowing report on the state of the UK economy.It concluded that the outlook for growth and inflation was not only "rather enviable", but that it was so good that Britain was within a whisker of meeting its own "convergence" criteria for joining the euro.
fields.body:
This week has been captured for history by the Women's Institute. But it ought also to be remembered as the week when the Paris-based OECD produced a glowing report on the state of the UK economy. Leaving aside some qualifications about health spending and other matters, the report was almost too glowing for Mr Blair's liking. It concluded that the outlook for growth and inflation was not only "rather enviable" - that's OECD-speak for alpha minus - but that it was so good that Britain was within a whisker of meeting its own "convergence" criteria for joining the euro. This raises the danger of opening a debate about adopting the single currency that the government desperately wants to kick into touch until after the next election, lest the Conservatives hijack it and make "save the pound" the main issue.

In October 1997, Gordon Brown laid down five tests that the UK economy had to pass before voters would be asked whether they wanted to join the third stage of economic and monetary union. Of these, the first - far and away the most important - asked: "Has the economy achieved sustainable convergence with the euro area?" The OECD found that on several of the key scores the UK was actually doing better than some of the countries that had already adopted the euro. The main exception is the exchange rate, which may fall more closely into line if the recent recovery of the euro (bolstered this week by a 0.5% rise in eurozone interest rates) continues.

Even if the UK economy did converge with that of the eurozone, it doesn't mean that entry is justified. Convergence could be the result of a temporary cyclical coincidence (just as a stopped clock is right twice a day). And, even if economic convergence was achieved, there would still remain other formidable ob stacles to membership. The most important is that the single interest rate fixed by the European Central Bank for the whole of the euro area would not necessarily be the right rate of interest for Britain's often idiosyncratic economy. The government keeps saying that the decision whether or not to recommend membership of the euro will be made on economic not political grounds, but this should be taken with a pinch of salt. Mr Blair would be unlikely to endorse entry if the economic criteria were met yet public opinion overwhelmingly hostile.

But times are changing. Just as economic opposition to joining could weaken as Europe's economy recovers strongly from recession, so political opposition may be affected by the effects of isolation. If Greece, Denmark and Sweden join, Britain could soon be the only one of the 15 members of the European Union not to have adopted the single currency. In such circumstances Britain's ability to influence the other 14 would be severely constrained. That does not suddenly make the economic objections irrelevant. But because, in the end, the decision may be based on an assessment of the political advantages of entry against the economic disadvantages, the balance between the two could be altered. Either way Mr Blair is unlikely to be able to sweep the debate under the table until after the election. Nor should he be allowed to. This is the most important and long-lasting decision he will ever have to make. It cannot, and should not, be made without a full national debate. We remain sceptical about the economic advantages of membership, but accept there are very strong arguments on both sides that cut right across party lines. Mr Blair will do his party and his country a service if he gets a national debate going. And as soon as possible.

webTitle: Cook backs Byers in euro battle

fields.headline: Cook backs Byers in euro battle
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Robin Cook last night backed Stephen Byers in the cabinet's internal battle over Britain's policy towards the European single currency by offering coded support for the trade secretary's call for the case for UK membership to be made more forcefully by its supporters.
fields.body:
Robin Cook last night backed Stephen Byers in the cabinet's internal battle over Britain's policy towards the European single currency by offering coded support for the trade secretary's call for the case for UK membership to be made more forcefully by its supporters.

"The case for Britain being inside the euro is a strong one because it's based on the fact that Europe is a strong market for Britain," said the foreign secretary. It could also help manufacturing and those who work in export industries - "if we get the economic conditions right."

Mr Byers spoke earlier yesterday in similar terms at a business convention in Bradford. Like Mr Byers, Mr Cook twas careful to insist in a series of radio and TV interviews that he was doing no more than expound the government's "wait and see" position.

Mr Byers said: "We will judge if the [Treasury's] five tests have been met early in the next parliament. If the economic tests are satisified then we should join the single currency, if that is what the government, parliament and people decide" in the promised referendum. Ministers should "continue our active preparations," said Mr Byers who underlined his upbeat tone in an interview with the pro-euro Mirror. "We need to be prepared and ready for change."

The euro has gained ground on sterling since this week's interest rate decision, helpful to advocates of convergence' between Britain and euroland. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's latest report also suggests that converging trends are running strongly.

Downing Street professed Tony Blair to be "completely relaxed" about Mr Byers's remarks. But the Treasury was not.

Gordon Brown insists that colleagues wait for his "five economic tests" of Britain's national interest to be fullfilled.

"It's ridiculous - he appears to be trying to carve out territory," a Brown adviser said of Mr Byers's intervention. The Tory ex-minister, John Redwood, accused Mr Byers of "declaring war on the chancellor."

Mr Brown may agree. "Mandelson-Byers is a strange alliance, a bizarre coalition after past rows. Tony and Gordon have decided the policy will not change and Byers, Peter Mandelson and everyone else should stick to every word," the Brown camp warned.

If the economic tests are satisified then we should join the single currency, if that is what the government, parliament and people decide" in the promised referendum. Ministers should "continue our active preparations," said Mr Byers who underlined his upbeat tone in an interview with the pro-euro Mirror. "We need to be prepared and ready for change." The euro has gained ground on sterling since this week's interest rate decision, helpful to advocates of convergence' between Britain and euroland. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's latest report also suggests that converging trends are running strongly. Downing Street professed Tony Blair to be "completely relaxed" about Mr Byers's remarks. But the Treasury was not. Gordon Brown insists that colleagues wait for his "five economic tests" of Britain's national interest to be fullfilled. "It's ridiculous - he appears to be trying to carve out territory," a Brown adviser said of Mr Byers's intervention. The Tory ex-minister, John Redwood, accused Mr Byers of "declaring war on the chancellor." Mr Brown may agree. "Mandelson-Byers is a strange alliance, a bizarre coalition after past rows. webTitle: Vital summit jump starts Franco-German motor

fields.headline: Vital summit jump starts Franco-German motor
fields.trailText: France and Germany yesterday fleshed out their commitment to closer cooperation by agreeing plans to boost European defence capabilities and pledging to work together when France takes over the EU presidency in July.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Tony Paterson  in Berlin
fields.body:
France and Germany yesterday fleshed out their commitment to closer cooperation by agreeing plans to boost European defence capabilities and pledging to work together when France takes over the EU presidency in July.

Meeting in the German city of Mainz for their twice-yearly summit, President Jacques Chirac and the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, issued a clear promise of continued reform - vital if the 15-member union is to avoid paralysis when it expands to take in new candidates from eastern and central Europe.

But despite agreeing to build a new military transport plane and a satellite system designed to decrease dependence on the US - they did not entirely meet expectations for a revival of the recently faltering axis that once drove European integration. "France and Germany are very strongly together on pushing ahead reforms of the institutions," Mr Schröder declared at the end of the one-day meeting.

"This summit was an occasion to note that, when it has to, the alliance of France and Germany works immaculately," Mr Chirac responded. "The Franco-German motor is running well."

British officials are worried that France will use its presidency for a concerted drive to reduce national vetoes in the EU and to push through a far-reaching charter of fundamental rights at next December's Nice summit.

Tony Blair, still firmly on the fence over a referendum, also fears that Berlin and Paris will try to give a more formal status to the grouping of 11 European countries which have already adopted the single currency - though the French and German finance ministers were not in Mainz yesterday.

French officials announced, meanwhile, that President Chirac is to have a private dinner with Mr Blair next Thursday, just days before the Feira summit that marks the end of Portugal's stint in the EU's rotating presidency.

No details were announced on a joint approach to the veto question, or on easing so-called "flexibility" rules by which some member states can develop closer groupings, or on giving big states more voting power in return for cutting the numbers of their commissioners in Brussels.

Germany insists its 82m-strong population deserves more voting rights than France, Britain and Italy, all with similar populations of around 58m. France is keen to see the "big four" remain equal. But Mr Chirac said he did not think this would be a problem.

By contrast, considerable progress was made on the military front, with agreement on the A400M "military airbus" that should now allow the ambitious seven-nation project to go ahead.

Britain has been the only EU member state to commit itself, so the Franco-German announcement is an important boost. The project needs orders of between 180 and 200 aircraft before production is deemed financially viable.

Europe's inability to deploy large numbers of troops and equipment quickly was demonstrated during last year's Kosovo conflict, and brought calls for rapid improvement in EU defence capabilities.

Another important step came with agreement on the Sar-Lupe radar satellite system, which will operate together with the French "Helios" optical military reconnaissance satellite and help reduce dependence on the US in a vital and sensitive area. German officials said that other EU and Nato partners would be invited to join.

Berlin has been anxious to stress a new warmth in Franco-German ties after several years of cooler relations following the death of the French president, François Mitterrand and the defeat of the former German chancellor, Helmut Kohl.

But personal and political differences between the Blairite Mr Schröder and the more traditionally socialist French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, have meant that there are limits to the depth of any new romance.

The two sides also agreed to continue to back sanctions against Austria because of the participation in government of the far-right Freedom party, previously led by the controversial Jörg Haider. Several smaller EU members have been pushing for an end to Vienna's isolation.

France and Germany also announced agreement to hold a "Balkan summit" in the Croatian capital, Zagreb, part of a wider EU strategy of encouraging reform in the countries of the former Yugoslavia - and isolating Slobodan Milosevic's Serbia.

webTitle: How Six Day war almost led to Armageddon

fields.headline: How Six Day war almost led to Armageddon
fields.standfirst:
New evidence of 1967 Soviet plan to invade Israel shows how close the world came to nuclear conflict
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The morning of June 10 1967 was "a time of great concern and utmost gravity" in the White House Situation Room, according to Llewellyn Thompson, a former ambassador to the USSR turned presidential adviser. A message had just been received over the Moscow-Washington hotline threatening Soviet military action that would lead to a nuclear confrontation. New evidence now reveals what action the Soviets were preparing: a naval landing on Israel's shores to prevent its total victory in the Six Day War.
fields.body:
The morning of June 10 1967 was "a time of great concern and utmost gravity" in the White House Situation Room, according to Llewellyn Thompson, a former ambassador to the USSR turned presidential adviser. A message had just been received over the Moscow-Washington hotline threatening Soviet military action that would lead to a nuclear confrontation. New evidence now reveals what action the Soviets were preparing: a naval landing on Israel's shores to prevent its total victory in the Six Day War.

The Soviet Union had played a central role in escalating tension in the Middle East and had falsely accused Israel of massing forces on the Syrian border. For the first time, Moscow sent much of its Black Sea fleet into the Mediterranean and backed up the Egyptian president, Gamal Abdel Nasser, when he blocked Israeli shipping in the Red Sea and demanded the removal of the United Nations force from Sinai.

In memoirs published recently, Nikita Khrushchev said the USSR's military command persuaded its political leadership to support these steps, knowing they were aimed at starting a war to destroy Israel.

On June 5, after Israel launched a pre-emptive strike against its Arab neighbours, the Soviet prime minister, Alexei Kosygin, had activated the hotline to Washington for the first time since it was installed following the Cuban missile crisis of 1962.

"I went into my office every morning at seven o'clock," said the then secretary of defence, Robert S. McNamara. "At 7.15 the telephone rang. 'Mr Secretary, this is General Smith in the War Room. Kosygin is on the hotline and wants to talk to [President Lyndon] Johnson...what should I tell him?' I said: 'Why the hell do you ask me?' He said: 'The hot line ends at the Pentagon.' It wasn't even a telephone line then but a teletype, and I didn't even know it ended there."

Mr McNamara called the sergeant standing guard outside Lyndon Johnson's door and ordered him to wake the president. Within fifteen minutes they and the secretary of state, Dean Rusk, had begun what became a nearly continuous conference in the Situation Room.

On June 10, according to Kosygin, Israeli forces were heading for the Syrian capital, Damascus. The US no longer had a manned embassy in Damascus and - incredibly - had no independent assessment of the Israeli offensive on the Golan Heights. The director of the CIA, Richard Helms, was called in, but the best he could do was to try and reach "friendly powers" which still had missions in Syria.

'A grave catastrophe'

Kosygin's message went on: "A very crucial moment has now arrived which forces us, if military actions are not stopped in the next few hours, to adopt an independent decision. We are ready to do this. However, these actions may bring us into a clash which will lead to a grave catastrophe ... we purpose [sic] that you demand from Israel that it unconditionally cease military action... we purpose to warn Israel that if this is not fulfilled, necessary actions will be taken, including military."

Mr McNamara recalled: "In effect it said: Mr President, if you want war, you'll get war."

The presidential adviser McGeorge Bundy later remembered that there had been "considerable discussion about what in fact the Soviets would be able to do to the Israelis if they did try to carry out their threat. The Russians' possibilities were really not that impressive."

But now a first hand account from one of the Soviet officers involved reveals that the Soviets were nonetheless poised to invade Israel.

In June 1967, Yuri Khripunkov was a young gunnery lieutenant on board a BPK (large anti-submarine ship) of the Soviet navy, part of a large reinforcement for the Mediterranean flotilla which had arrived from the Black Sea base of Sevastopol in early May.

In an interview, Mr Khripunkov, now 59 and a respected writer and educator, said that when Arab-Israeli hostilities broke out, his captain ordered him to raise and command a 30-man detachment of "volunteers" for a landing on the Israeli coast.

Similar parties were being assembled on all the 30-odd Soviet vessels in the Mediterranean: a total of some 1,000 men. "There was also one BDK with about 40 tanks and maybe a battalion of infantry," Mr Khripunkov said. His platoon was ordered to penetrate Haifa - Israel's main commercial harbour and naval base.

Only one of the ship's sailors refused to "volunteer". He was later transferred off the ship but not otherwise punished. Mr Khripunkov himself had no hesitations - "I was young and foolish," he said - even though the seamen were neither trained nor equipped for a commando raid on land.

"What were we supposed to accomplish, with my pistol and the sailors' AK47s? 'Get in there and see,' they told us. 'Wipe out the enemy forces'."

"It was a different world then. I had a holy faith in it all - the red flag, my officer's oath. We were going on a sacred mission, the [Israeli] aggressors had assaulted these poor Arabs and we were going to let them have it. Today I'm wiser and I probably wouldn't do it."

Mr Khripunkov's account confirms how near the Soviets came to implementation of a "contingency plan". An officer of the GRU (Soviet military intelligence) later told a senior American analyst that the defence minister, Andrei Grechko, and his team wanted to "provide the progressive Arabs with a unique and historic achievement - the destruction of Israel" for which "they would remain eternally beholden to Moscow". Though the Soviets were confident of the Arabs' capability to defeat Israel, the contingency plan was prepared.

While the landing force would probably have been overcome by Israel, it might have caused substantial casualties - and might have halted the Israeli advance. But as Mr Khripunkov points out, the gamble was much larger: globalising the conflict.

"There would have been no Israel left if we had landed. I've studied 'special weapons', and even without a hydrogen bomb, 10-15 warheads would have been enough," he said.

Mr Khripunkov and his men were well aware they were little but pawns in a global power play. "A thousand men was nothing for the USSR," he said.

"They started counting at 5m. Each side wanted to demonstrate its dominant role _ The US sends in the [Sixth] Fleet. We bring in our Black Sea squadron. They send in spy planes. We start preparing a landing in Israel. The Israeli tanks move through Sinai and are ready to skip over the Suez Canal. What then? We land our force and world war three begins? We knew it was going to happen, that the whole world would be destroyed."

This was the "grave catastrophe" threatened by Kosygin.

A member of the Israeli general staff at the time recalls hearing that a Soviet landing "had been discussed as a theoretic possibility at cabinet sessions", but there is no evidence that Israel or the US knew the particulars of the impending operation.

Mr McNamara dismissed the suggestion that, ironically, Israel itself may have prevented an early warning of this threat when its warplanes attacked and disabled the American intelligence ship Liberty in the Mediterranean on June 8, thus probably crippling US capability to eavesdrop on Soviet ships in the region.

But the ships never landed and Moscow's failure to intervene caused the Soviets considerable trouble with their other proteges, particularly Cuba.

Immediately after the Six Day War, Kosygin hastened to Havana to placate Fidel Castro's anxieties and, according to the CIA cable, "informed Castro that the USSR had been prepared to aid the UAR [United Arab Republic, Egypt's official name] in the struggle against Israel but Field Marshal Amir [Abdel-Hakim Amer], chief of the UAR armed forces, told the USSR that the UAR intended to stop fighting within several days."

Fear of domination

However, the CIA later reported that Amer and a powerful faction in the Cairo leadership had wanted to prevent total Soviet domination of Egypt.

The Soviets made their threat over the hotline only when Syria too appeared to be on the verge of defeat. Thompson was "impressed how much greater Soviet sensibility there was to the plight of the Syrians than to that of the Egyptians. At the time, the Syrians were the apple of the Russians' eye".

After Kosygin's menacing message was received, the US under-secretary of state, Nicholas Katzenbach, was dispatched from the Situation Room to "call in the Israeli ambassador and put pressure on the Israelis to accept a ceasefire". The Israelis, presumably informed of the Soviet threat, did - after completing their conquest of the Golan.

The main taskforce of the Sixth Fleet had been circling in the central Mediterranean. On June 6, Johnson had remonstrated to Kosygin because the Soviet media was repeating Nasser's "invented charge that US carrier aircraft had participated in attacks on Egypt ... you know where our carriers are".

When the "auxiliary ship" Liberty was attacked, Johnson told Kosygin that the USS Saratoga was ordered "to dispatch aircraft to investigate". So on June 10, said Mr McNamara, the fleet "was steaming west, toward Gibraltar, on a training exercise". Now, following Kosygin's threat, it was sent into the fray.

"President Johnson and I," said Mr McNamara, "decided to turn the fleet around and send it back toward Israel, not to join with Israel in an attack on Syria - not at all - but to be close enough to Israel so, if the Soviets supported a Syrian attack on Israel, we could come to Israel's defence with the fleet, prevent Israel from being annihilated."

The story, as filtered down to Mr Khripunkov's crew, was that "Brezhnev [Leonid, then first secretary of the Communist party] and the president got on the phones and realised that half an hour after we landed the world would be in ruins. And that was that."

His ship, which had at last been ordered to head for the Israeli coast, turned back and the landing was aborted. That day, Moscow severed diplomatic ties with Israel.

The landing plan remained a potentiality and appears gradually to have become known to the US and Israel. In February 1968, a CIA cable spoke of "the first information received regarding Soviet plans to participate in a limited Arab offensive against Israel ... the Soviets will actively aid the Arabs in gaining back the territory lost in the June 1967 war."

However, the document, recently declassified in a heavily censored form, states: "The Soviets made it very clear that Israel is here to stay and they will not ... facilitate its destruction".

 Isabella Ginor is an Israeli journalist specialising in the former USSR who arrived in Israel from Russia a few months before the events described in this story.

fields.headline: Sunshine policy warms old rivals
fields.standfirst: The historic talks between the two Koreas that begin on Monday in Pyongyang are being viewed with guarded optimism
fields.trailText: The teacher from Seoul urges her six-year-olds to peer into North Korea from the observation tower on Mount Odu. "Look through the telescope," she cries, jingling a stack of coins for the machine. "When you are grown up you can visit there!"
fields.byline: John Gittings on Mount Odu, South Korea
fields.body:
The teacher from Seoul urges her six-year-olds to peer into North Korea from the observation tower on Mount Odu. "Look through the telescope," she cries, jingling a stack of coins for the machine. "When you are grown up you can visit there!"

The obedient children with their identical backpacks then file back down to the North Korea Room to see images of "life under communism". Pictures of a northern elementary school show children of the same age swearing loyalty to the late President Kim Il-sung. A glass case contains an abacus, penknives and pencils of the most basic kind, which no South Korean child would use.

The coach parties continued to roll up yesterday to the Unification Observatory at Mt Odu and at other viewpoints along the 38th parallel which has divided North and South since 1953.

In Seoul, last-minute arrangements were being made for South Korean president Kim Dae-jung's historic summit - to begin on Monday in Pyongyang - with Kim Il-sung's son and successor, Kim Jong-il.

The summit is seen as the fruit of more than two years of patient "sunshine diplomacy" by the southern president. But it also confirms Kim Jong-il's political ascendancy in the north and his ability to take a bold initiative.

No one expects quick results from the summit - but no one knows either where the new process may lead.

The video presentation on Mt Odu speaks in a common language of the Korean people's "ardent wish for reunification". Adult sightseers from Seoul chorus that "reunification is good".

A shrine on Mount Odu is provided for those whose ancestral graves are in the North. Older South Koreans with relatives they have not seen for 50 years hope for progress on the difficult issue of "divided families". But most observers expect that the first barriers to fall will be economic ones; South Korea's business community "is ready to reap lucrative deals", said the Korea Times yesterday.

The Federation of Korean Industry has just put the final touches to an ambitious plan for "inter-Korean economic cooperation".

"The economic incentive is most important for the North," says researcher Hong Yong-pyo at the Korea Institute for National Unification. "They desperately need investment in infrastructure and agricultural development."

Kim Jong-il may also ask for imports of sophisticated information technology, in which he showed great interest on his recent visit to Beijing.

The development gap between North and South is clearly visible from the top of Mount Odu. Seoul's satellite towns, with their multi-lane highways, high-rise apartment blocks, outdoor golf driving ranges and bowling alleys, have almost reached the mountain's foot.

Another town now taking shape will include landscaped gardens and a giant rollercoaster. Billboards urge safety at work and the road is clogged with construction trucks.

Across the bordering Imjin river on the northern side, the only slogan to be seen proclaims "the age of self-reliance".

Small collective villages farm the land with oxen: each has its own threshing ground. The only construction of any height is an 18-metre pillar, named the Immortality Tower, in front of a memorial hall for Kim Il-sung.

The highway north from Panmunjom through Kaesong and on to Pyongyang, like all other major roads in North Korea, is almost bare of traffic as a result of fuel shortages and lack of vehicles. In the South, dense traffic streams along the Freedom Road passing Mt Odu to Panmunjom while a network of suburban buses and trains links the satellite towns.

The two-and-a-half mile wide Demilitarised Zone (DMZ), which runs from coast to coast for 150 miles, has been peaceful since 1976 when North Koreans armed with axes killed two American officers in an ugly dispute over pruning a tree.

The incident almost led to war when the US military proposed using surface-to-surface missiles to punish the North Koreans. But President Gerald Ford vetoed the plan fearing that hostilities would escalate.

The DMZ is now home to rare Manchurian cranes and endangered mammals including black bears and Korean deer. But the South Korean ministry of agriculture plans to turn large tracts into massive fields for growing ginseng.

North Korean ginseng is already on sale at the gift shop on Mount Odu, with other exotic products including a potent "adder wine" - each bottle containing an adder carcass.

Department stores in Seoul have staged special promotions featuring North Korean goods.

Whatever happens at next week's summit, attitudes in the South towards the North are expected to become more sophisticated as its curiosity value diminishes - but it appears it may take some time.

"I am very angry with some of my male colleagues," said a woman journalist in Seoul this week. "They are already talking about how they hope to get a maid from the North."

1950-53 : Korean war fought to stalemate on 38th parallel

1972 : First North-South dialogue produces no result

1991 : North-South agreement on mutual recognition

1994 : Kim Il-sung's death sets back diplomatic progress

1995 : North hit by famine as Kim Jong-il succeeds father

1998 : South's Kim Dae-jung launches "sunshine diplomacy"

fields.headline: Arch-professional became sacrificial victim
fields.standfirst:
Resignation Palace press officer was renowned for tact and flair
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Sandy Henney's resignation, apparently at the behest of St James's Palace, over an issue as apparently straightforward as the release of official photographs suprised many, not least because of her previous surefootedness.
fields.body:
Sandy Henney's resignation, apparently at the behest of St James's Palace, over an issue as apparently straightforward as the release of official photographs suprised many, not least because of her previous surefootedness.

When she was promoted to succeed Allan Percival in 1993 it seemed she was walking into an impossible job. The PR war between Charles and Diana was in full flow and as far as tabloid editors were concerned it was open season.

That she survived so long, navigating a course through the storms of Camillagate, Diana's infamous Panorama interview, and her subsequent death which saw Charles's popularity plumb new depths, was testimony to what one former royal correspondent called "her utter professionalism".

"She was a very business like person, but she managed to remain approachable."

A product of the government information service, Ms Henney spent some time at Downing Street in the Thatcher era gaining an insight into the workings of press and government.

Her credentials appeared peerless. After the GIS Ms Henney, who is married to a former head of Scotland Yard's royalty protection branch, moved to the Yard's press bureau, then on to the Ministry of Defence before taking charge of press relations for the director of public prosecutions -which gave her a crash course in handling unseemly scandal when Alan Green, then the DPP, was caught soliciting a prostitute.

But in joining Prince Charles's staff she was entering a world that no amount of civil service training could prepare her for. Prior to her appointment, when deference was still a given in many quarters of the media, St James's Palace regarded the press as an irritant. Press relations were still in the hands of courtiers, and the daily court circular was as close as they ever came to issuing a statement.

But with Diana winning the PR war, it was clear the old tactic of issuing a curt 'no comment' was no longer sufficient.

While Ms Henney's professional approach won friends in the media, it was the cause of tension with Buckingham Palace, which even now has a more staid approach to press relations. Those tensions were put to one side as, in the wake of the death of the Princess of Wales, the question of managing media interest in the two princes became paramount.

Initially, with the media stung by the public reaction to Diana's death and Earl Spencer's moving plea to respect his nephews' privacy, Ms Henney was able to protect her charges with relative ease.

The atmosphere of detente led to unfamiliar behaviour on both sides of the barricades. Tabloid editors sat on stories and photographs they would have rushed into print in the mid 1990s; likewise St James's Palace, through events carefully managed by Ms Henney, allowed access that would have been unimaginable prior to the demise of Diana.

Prince Charles and his sons were pictured together during a Balmoral summer break and photographers snapped up images of Prince William taking his first turn behind the wheel shortly after turning 17.

There was the odd skirmish. And there was unease as stories concerning cocaine use by those in royal circles appeared to taint William's image.

These stories were with met a typical Henney flourish however when reports that Prince Charles had issued a stern warning to his son about the importance of selecting friends wisely found their way into Sunday newspapers.

As recently as last weekend pressure from St James's Palace was reported to have persuaded the BBC to drop a planned programme unfavourably comparing the lot of an 18-year-old on Merseyside with that of the future king.

Yet the same day as the BBC story appeared, a far more significant story appeared in the News of the World. The announcement that Prince Charles's mistress, Camilla Parker Bowles, had met the Queen for the first time did not appear by chance. It was un derstood to have been the result of the close relationship between the editor, Rebekah Wade, and Mark Bolland, Prince Charles's deputy private secretary.

Mr Bolland is regarded as a more sophisticated operator than Ms Henney, a practitioner of spin rather than PR. That his hand was seen to be behind the thawing of relations between Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace would not have boded well for Ms Henney.

Statement

It is a matter of deep regret that confusion has arisen over the photographs commissioned to mark Prince William's 18th birthday.

The copyright of these pictures should have been established at the time they were taken to ensure that St James's Palace owned the copyright and that any proceeds arising from the use of the photographs went to charity as has normally happened in the past.

This issue was not resolved and copyright is now wrongly vested elsewhere.

The Prince of Wales hopes that, in the light of the clear and consistent policy, no one should profit from pictures, either of Prince William or Prince Harry, and that those who do own the copyright will make clear that all proceeds will go to charity.

To do otherwise would be to undermine the work the palace, the press and the Press Complaints Commission have all vested in the protection of Prince William and Prince Harry's privacy.

We share our part of the blame, in that we should have taken action to ensure that copyright was vested with us.

As a result of this, Sandy Henney, press secretary to the Prince of Wales, has this afternoon tendered her resignation from His Royal Highness's office. The Prince of Wales has with very deep regret accepted this.

Miss Henney made clear to His Royal Highness that she did so both because of the mistakes made over the issue of the copyright and to ensure that the privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry was maintained in the future.

That always has been and remains our first priority as it always has been that of Miss Henney.

Miss Henney has been a loyal and invaluable member of staff who has given outstanding service over seven years.

She has also been of immense service in putting together with the media the successful arrangements to safeguard the privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry.

It is because she believes the recent dispute with one newspaper over copyright threatens those hugely important arrangements that she has resigned.

We wish to underline our continuing policy reflecting the clear wish of the Prince of Wales to treat all newspapers and magazines, on matters relating to Prince William and Prince Harry, in an absolutely fair and equitable fashion.

It is not acceptable to the Prince of Wales that anyone should profit unfairly from their images and we intend that nobody ever should.

The burden of maintaining that policy rests in the short term with those who in this instance own the copyright of pictures taken to mark Prince William's birthday.

We continue to hope they will act fairly and responsibly by assigning the proceeds of Prince William's pictures to charity.

fields.headline: Aide quits Charles in privacy row
fields.standfirst:
Telegraph backs down after wrangle over school photographs of Prince William
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's press secretary last night became the first victim of media hysteria over Prince William when she was forced to resign over an unseemly row between St James's Palace and the Daily Telegraph about the copyright of a set of pictures taken to mark the prince's 18th birthday.
fields.body:
Prince Charles's press secretary last night became the first victim of media hysteria over Prince William when she was forced to resign over an unseemly row between St James's Palace and the Daily Telegraph about the copyright of a set of pictures taken to mark the prince's 18th birthday.

Sandy Henney, 47, who has been the Prince of Wales's press secretary for seven years, tendered her resignation, which was accepted "with very deep regret", because of an agreement she signed with a Daily Telelgraph photographer that gave him sole copyright of the images.

St James's Palace said Miss Henney had resigned because of the mistakes over copyright and to ensure that the privacy of Prince William and Prince Harry was maintained in the future. But royal sources said last night she had been forced out to protect Prince William from renewed hostilities with Fleet Street on the eve of his 18th birthday.

The embarrassing row over the photographs could not have come at a worse time for St James's Palace as it attempts to protect Prince William from unwanted intrusions from the press as he enters adulthood. It has threatened to cloud the relationship between Prince Charles and national newspapers over the way they deal with his two sons. Concern has been mounting inside royal circles for some time that photographs of Prince William will become as valuable as those of his mother, Diana, with the inevitable result that the paparazzi will follow his every move.

Royal sources said that the need to be seen to treat all newspapers "in a correct, fair and equitable way" was paramount at a time when he will have to be exposed more to media attention. "Many people will have thought that the palace giving favoured treatment to a Daily Telegraph photographer was a licence to print money," said one royal source. "Sandy had no authority to do that, it was not authorised - quite the reverse - and she has now done the honourable thing by resigning."

Personal dealings with the media and the press complaints commission code have protected Prince William during his schooldays. But under the code's terms he will cease to be a child on June 21 and lose what insiders call "that edifice of protection". The palace's strategy to "give the prince space to have a half-normal growing up" would have fallen to pieces had the palace not acted firmly and fairly once the error had been realised.

Lord Wakeham, chairman of the PCC, had been due to make a speech next week setting out guidelines for editors on how to cover Prince William as he becomes an adult. But yesterday the PCC cancelled the engagement, saying it would be inappropriate.

Last night Ian Jones, the Daily Telegraph photographer, agreed to transfer the copyright of the photographs according to the directions of the prince after the palace issued a strongly worded statement demanding he should donate proceeds from the sale of the pictures, which could amount to millions of pounds in worldwide syndication, to charity.

"I was offered the opportunity to take exclusive pictures of Prince William at Eton which I was honoured to accept," he said. "The law conferred the copyright on me and no suggestion has been made until today that I should donate it to the crown. Now that the suggestion has been made, I shall gladly assign the copyright as the Prince of Wales may direct."

The row erupted on Thursday when Charles Moore, editor of the Telegraph, accused the palace of breaking an agreement with the newspaper in handling the distribution of the pictures. The paper claimed it had been promised advance copies of the photographs, taken in Prince William's final term at Eton, as a reward for distributing and handling the pictures to the rest of the local and national press.

But after a complaint from Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail, St James's Palace issued copies of the pictures to the Times and the Mail, leading to accusations from the Telegraph that the Prince of Wales's office had reneged on its deal with the newspaper and its photographer.

Last night Mr Moore said he saw Miss Henney's resignation as an acceptance by the Prince of Wales's office that it had behaved unprofessionally to wards the newspaper. He said: "The Daily Telegraph was never party to any contractual arrangements in this matter and has no financial involvement whatever in anything to do with the pictures.

"Our concern throughout has been that agreements made with our royal photographer Ian Jones should be honoured and we were dismayed that this did not happen."

One insider said the episode had exposed Charles to a lot of criticism. "Her [Miss Henney's] head has rolled for it."

"I was offered the opportunity to take exclusive pictures of Prince William at Eton which I was honoured to accept," he said. "The law conferred the copyright on me and no suggestion has been made until today that I should donate it to the crown. Now that the suggestion has been made, I shall gladly assign the copyright as the Prince of Wales may direct." The row erupted on Thursday when Charles Moore, editor of the Telegraph, accused the palace of breaking an agreement with the newspaper in handling the distribution of the pictures. The paper claimed it had been promised advance copies of the photographs, taken in Prince William's final term at Eton, as a reward for distributing and handling the pictures to the rest of the local and national press. But after a complaint from Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail, St James's Palace issued copies of the pictures to the Times and the Mail, leading to accusations from the Telegraph that the Prince of Wales's office had reneged on its deal with the newspaper and its photographer. Last night Mr Moore said he saw Miss Henney's resignation as an acceptance by the Prince of Wales's office that it had behaved unprofessionally to wards the newspaper. He said: "The Daily Telegraph was never party to any contractual arrangements in this matter and has no financial involvement whatever in anything to do with the pictures. "Our concern throughout has been that agreements made with our royal photographer Ian Jones should be honoured and we were dismayed that this did not happen." One insider said the episode had exposed Charles to a lot of criticism. "Her [Miss Henney's] head has rolled for it."

fields.headline: Fox and Hounds, Bedfordshire
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort swaps cutting-edge cuisine for steak, chips and all the trimmings
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort swaps cutting-edge cuisine for steak, chips and all the trimmings
fields.body:
Address: Fox and Hounds, Bedfordshire
Thank you, Sharon. Without Sharon, I would never have explored the verdant hinterland of Bedfordshire. Without Sharon, I would never have found the Fox and Hounds. Without Sharon, I might never have succumbed once more to the irresistible sequence of prawn cocktail with Marie Rose sauce followed by steak and all the trimmings. Sadly, there was no Black Forest gâteau with which to fill in the gaps, so I had to make do with banoffee pie instead.

While we critics grapple on a day-to-day basis with roast cod and gremolata or mash swathed in truffle oil and oceans of balsamic vinegar; while we try to disentangle Italo/Thai, Franco/Chinese, Anglo/Japanese etc etc fusions week by week; while we work our wearisome way through cuisines de haut en bas and celebrate the improvement and mutations of the foods on offer, it is easy to forget that the menu at the Fox and Hounds represents the commonest eating-out experience for the majority of the population.

And who is to say that prawn cocktail and steak with all the trimmings are not dishes up there with the good and the great? Especially when the prawns are fresh from the coldest ocean waters, the sauce Marie Rose is made with a discreet hand, the iceberg lettuce has been reduced to crunchy shreds, the steak is a thick chunk of well-hung beef of good pedigree, cooked over a grill to the point specified and served with chips stiff as guardsmen on parade but light and floury within.

It is entirely to the credit of the Fox And Hounds that you can choose your steak from the long sections of nicely butchered sirloins, rumps and fillets that loll in a chill cabinet at one end of the bar, the rest of which is devoted to serving Charles Wells' admirable beers.

The steaks - sirloins; Sharon's medium and my rare - were pretty good. Aberdeen Angus, we were assured, hand-cut and trimmed before our very eyes to 8oz, plus or minus the odd gram. They were cooked exactly as specified and, if not definitive steak experiences, were at the upper end of the steak league. Sadly, what surrounded them, with the exception of a smoothly feisty bottle of Brown Bros Barbera from Australia at £14.75, was not. The chips were like guardsmen who had wilted in hot sun. The onion rings were more batter than sweet onion. The mushrooms had that stewed, rubbery feel. The salad was the usual dire assembly of miscellaneous chopped peppers, mushrooms, onions, cucumber and lettuce.

Sharon's Filey dressed crab beforehand was generous, but lacked the light, sweet delicacy of the freshest article. There was no niggardly portion control of my prawns, either, and Barbara Cartland would have approved of their pedigree. She would have swooned, however, to find them married to a sauce of such low estate. Sharon's spotted dick was hot from the microwave, but none the worse for that. The banoffee pie was a dentist's nightmare, and sent my sugar levels rocketing.

Even with a bill of £59.17, it seems almost pointless to criticise somewhere such as the Fox and Hounds (the title, not quite in keeping with the times, you might have thought, has a no-nonsense air to it). A utilitarian current runs through its red-brick exterior, comfortable beam, dark wood and red-carpeted interior with fake coal fire. The menu and the production of food have been systematised to provide a streamlined, seamless eating experience that is designed to provide satisfaction at an undemanding median, rather than anything of an exalted level.

I could take issue with aspects of the operation but that is to miss the point. The Fox and Hounds knows exactly what its market wants, and delivers it with unerring precision and more charm than many a smarter operation
