fields.headline: Web inventor says ads 'pervert' content
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Are the money men killing the net: special report
fields.trailText: The father of the worldwide web yesterday accused online advertisers of deceiving the public, claiming they trick surfers by making adverts indistinguishable from a web page's content.
fields.body:
The father of the worldwide web yesterday accused online advertisers of deceiving the public, claiming they trick surfers by making adverts indistinguishable from a web page's content.

Tim Berners-Lee, the man who invented the web, told delegates at the International Advertising Association conference in London that surfers are often tricked into clicking on ads thinking they are part of the contents or, worse still, a message from the computer system.

He called for measures to make ads easily distinguishable from the content of a web page. I find the practice of publishing ads that are indistinguishable from content unacceptable. It not only clouds the true message of the page, but also erodes consumer confidence in the website."

The physicist, who built the first web server and browser in 1990 while working at European Particle Physics Laboratory in Geneva, runs a non-profit group, the World Wide Web Consortium, which aims to set technical standards on the web. He wants clear signs demarcating ads on a web page.

"Newspapers insert a line saying an ad is an advertisement when it looks confusing. I want to see something similar on a web page. Perhaps the mouse should change shape when it passes over an ad to alert you to the fact."

In a swipe at Microsoft, Mr Berners-Lee singled out the Seattle company for attaching ads to emails sent by users of the successful Hotmail service. "This [either] perverts or distorts the message," he said.

Internet advertising agencies were unmoved by the accusations. "It is the responsibility of the publisher of the website to distinguish content from adverts," said Barry Salzman, president of DoubleClick International, the internet advertising agency. "It is an irrelevant distinction, the ultimate judge of what is acceptable and what is not, is the end user. The consumers vote with their mouse."

The issue of misleading advertising on the web flared up in Britain last month when a complaint was made to the Advertising Standards Authority about an ad published by Internet Service Provider LineOne. The offending ad was a banner with a yellow warning symbol, reading "ISP upgrade - please wait, analysing your system", and showed a progress bar.

Despite clicking on the cancel button the complainant was led to the advertiser's web page. The ASA upheld the complaint and ruled that "the advert was not clearly identifi able as an advertisement". LineOne conceded that the user should not have been redirected to the site and agreed to modify the banner advert and remove the button. However it defended its position saying that in 1,480,000 impressions on the ad they had received only one complaint. "Consumers make a trade-off between free net access and having to suffer ads," says Mr Salzman. "I think that is a fair swap."

Richard Holman, managing director of AdLink, said: 90% of ads are clearly distinguishable. When adverts are mixed with editorial they should be made distinct, but that is the responsibility of the publisher of the website."

In the UK the wheels are in motion to create an accreditation system that goes some way to fulfiling this wish. Later this year the ASA plans to launch an online advertising accreditation scheme in association with the industry body, The committee for advertising standards.

Once online advertisers accept certain criteria for advert content, they will be able to display an accreditation logo committing them to advertising according to the ASA guidelines, backed by laws governing trading standards.

Steve Ballinger, a spokesman for the ASA, said: "This scheme will mean that where consumers see the committee for advertising standards logo they will know they can take action over misleading or dishonest ads."

fields.headline: Easy everything (including A-levels)
fields.trailText: The world of shipping has descended on terror-torn Athens for a jolly beanfeast (sorry, important conference) called Posidonia, which all A-starred A-level pupils (i.e. everyone) will immediately spot as a reference to the ancient Greek god of the sea.
fields.body:
 The world of shipping has descended on terror-torn Athens for a jolly beanfeast (sorry, important conference) called Posidonia, which all A-starred A-level pupils (i.e. everyone) will immediately spot as a reference to the ancient Greek god of the sea. Britain's merchant marine may not be what it was, but last Sunday a colour squadron of shipping's finest assembled at Luton Airport for their EasyJet ride to the Med. They were, they were sure, in good hands, for EasyJet's founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou is himself the scion of a shipping family (papa loaned him five bars to get airborne in 1995). Alas, EasyJet's flight was delayed by 10 hours, leaving the mariners cooling their heels at Luton with £5 bar vouchers while shipping big shots swanned around Piraeus carving up the world's sea trade. And you wondered why the red duster is seen so rarely nowadays.

 Back home, and a spy has dug out an absolute gem from the bad old days of boom and bust, the October 1992 issue of Chequerboard, the Treasury's staff mag. Those with long memories may recall that the previous month had not been among the Treasury's finest, what with the total collapse of its economic policy following sterling's ejection from the ERM. So what was Chequerboard's lead story? "Equal opportunities have been moved high up the management agenda", complete with a cheery a pic of paymaster general Sir John Cope beaming next to "Sue Broyd of personnel". Golden Wednesday rates the briefest of mentions in a story headed: "Troubled markets keep MG [the Treasury's monetary group] busy". Page 6 promises a look "behind the scenes" at the European finance ministers' summit in Bath, but omits to mention what has since become public knowledge, that the assembled chancellors were at each other's throats.

 Over in the French treasury, France's newish finance minister Laurent Fabius is pedalling furiously away from his previous incarnation as a Gallic Tony Blair. The French phrase meaning to toe the party line, which is utiliser la langue de bois (use the wooden tongue), and the former speaker of the national assembly was doing just that on Thursday. Asked by a journalist if he resembled the incumbent at Downing Street, Mr Fabius dead-batted this one, citing two big differences: Mr Blair was the more handsome and his own spouse was not about to emulate Cherie. Nary a word about the symbiotic relationship between the left and the market place. But in haughty, centralised Paris, the market still knows its place, as seen in the French government's rejection of an auction of third-generation mobile telephone franchises in favour of a behind-closed-doors franchise share-out masterminded by sound, sensible chaps such as, er, Mr Fabius.

 And once again to Great George Street, where the top brass is boning up for Thursday's Mansion House speech. City worthies tried to meet Gordon Brown half way by dumbing down from white to black tie, but the Chancellor obdurately shows up in a lounge suit and his team - economic gurus Ed Balls and Gus O'Donnell and permanent secretary Sir Andrew Turnbull - feel obliged to do likewise, a cause of particular discomfort for the last-named. A mini-revolt fizzled out this year, we hear, when Mr Brown declared Sir Andrew ought to feel free to wear black tie should he wish. Not having reached the top by failing to spot a non-offer when he sees one, Sir Andrew declined and will be in civvies.

 Meanwhile, America's compo culture has hit new peaks with a ruling from the Alaska supreme court. Pipeline worker Lawrence Allen fell ill in August 1997 having eaten pork chops, mashed potato and brussels sprouts. A hospital found his innards to contain two balls of undigested food, with the sprouts the most likely culprit. Richard Wagg, the employer's attorney, said the ruling showed "how the far the Alaska supreme court and the workers' compensation board will go to find something compensable". One might have more sympathy for Mr Wagg if he spoke English

 Finally, we look forward greatly to reading Takeover, by Peter Waine and Mike Walker (John Wiley; £16.99), due out on June 29, effectively a business manual written as a novel. It is giving nothing away to retell Takeover's tale from the days of thievery in London's docklands. Night after night a docker called Jack Fletcher takes a barrowload of carthorse manure off the docks, is stopped by the ultra-suspicious dock police and the manure thoroughly searched. Nothing was ever found, but then, it wouldn't have been. Mr Fletcher was stealing wheelbarrows.

webTitle: Cook tries to block EU aid for Liberia

fields.headline: Cook tries to block EU aid for Liberia
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is desperately trying to block a £35m European aid package to Liberia because it believes that its president, Charles Taylor, is actively supporting the rebel campaign in Sierra Leone, Foreign Office officials admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain is desperately trying to block a £35m European aid package to Liberia because it believes that its president, Charles Taylor, is actively supporting the rebel campaign in Sierra Leone, Foreign Office officials admitted yesterday.

In a move likely to anger Britain's EU partners, who have already unanimously approved the aid, Robin Cook will call for the money to be blocked when he attends a meeting of EU foreign affairs ministers in Luxembourg next week.

The foreign secretary will press for the aid to be "put on ice" despite the fact that France, which is soon to assume the EU's rotating presidency, is reluctant to agree because it is unsure about the precise nature of Taylor's role in Sierra Leone. The UK government is not itself certain about the extent of Taylor's involvement with the Revolutionary United Front, but it is fairly sure that he is supplying it with arms in return for diamonds.

"It seems quite clear that the Liberian government is implicated and it is time to send a signal that this won't do. It is a pretty substantial chunk of money we're talking about," a Foreign Office official told the Guardian. The money is part of a two-year EU anti-poverty programme and all 15 EU countries, including Britain, have already agreed that it should be released as soon as possible. Britain's last-minute intervention comes as the European commission is poised to sign the final documents authorising the funds to be transferred and as British troops prepare to start withdrawing from Sierra Leone.

It is highly unusual for a minister to call for EU humanitarian aid to be delayed in order to send a political signal to undesirable governments, although Britain tried and failed to do just that with aid earmarked for Zimbabwe in April.

EU officials believe that the UK will succeed in holding up the aid for a few months but warn that it will be the people of Liberia who will suffer and not Charles Taylor.

"This package is designed to alleviate poverty and it is the Liberian population that benefits and not the government or the administration," one official argued.

Foreign Office officials counter, however, that it is legitimate to delay the aid because it is not urgently required and will not have an immediate impact. Once the Liberian government has got the message and stops backing the rebels in Sierra Leone the money can, they say, be unblocked.

"It's a half step towards suspending EU aid and it will send out a pretty strong signal. We are of course much more involved with Sierra Leone than other countries who are coming to this issue quite late. Some of them haven't really given it much thought."

The Foreign Office will try to rally support for the move in EU capitals in advance of the crunch decision, which is expected to be taken on Tuesday.

webTitle: Fighting talk as royal hunt is accused

fields.headline: Fighting talk as royal hunt is accused
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The cabinet's decision to commit government time to the campaign to ban hunting with dogs last night prompted both sides in the controversy to promise a knock-down fight right up to election day - and beyond if necessary.
fields.body:
The cabinet's decision to commit government time to the campaign to ban hunting with dogs last night prompted both sides in the controversy to promise a knock-down fight right up to election day - and beyond if necessary.

While anti-hunting campaigners expressed delight at Jack Straw's change of heart, their Tory and pro-countryside opponents were furious that ministers had pre-empted the publication next week of Lord Burns's £600,000 investigation and demanded an official inquiry into the waste of public funds.

The report, delivered to ministers last night, will be published by the home secretary on Monday. Though pro-hunting campaigners said Lord Burns'team would be furious at being "ignored", he will say nothing until next week.

The Burns report is expected to recommend extensive regulation of hunting and offer a series of options for doing so, on which MPs - among whom there is an anti-hunting majority - will have a free vote in a government bill in the autumn.

A BBC2 Newsnight investigation last night revealed that wild fox cubs are being looked after in man-made chambers so they can be hunted by Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles on the Royal Beaufort Hunt - one of the hunts visited by Lord Burns.

Newsnight showed the Beaufort hunt's official terri erman, Thomas Burton, shovelling offal, pheasants and chickens on stone slabs outside man-made fox chambers on land near the Duke of Beaufort's estate at Badminton in Wiltshire.

The practice appears to contravene the rules of the Master of Foxhounds Association, which governs the blood sport. They state: "Foxhunting as a sport is the hunting of a fox in his wild and natural state with a pack of hounds. No pack of hounds, of which the master or representative is a member of MFHA, shall be allowed to hunt a fox in any way that is inconsistent with this precept."

The Royal Beaufort Hunt is close to Prince Charles' country home at Highgrove, and is one of the most prestigious in the country. As well as Prince Charles and Mrs Parker Bowles, the prince's sons have been taken on the hunt, and the Princess Royal and Prince Michael of Kent are followers.

The disclosure of the feeding of foxes caused a furore last night.

Mike Baker, chief executive of the International Fund for Animal Welfare, said: "The investigation drives a coach and horses through the Countryside Alliance argument. The alliance has no choice but to suspend this hunt without delay and take the sternest possible action against the masters." He also called on Prince Charles to dissociate himself from riding with the hunt.

fields.bodyText: The cabinet's decision to commit government time to the campaign to ban hunting with dogs last night prompted both sides in the controversy to promise a knock-down fight right up to election day - and beyond if necessary. While anti-hunting campaigners expressed delight at Jack Straw's change of heart, their Tory and pro-countryside opponents were furious that ministers had pre-empted the publication next week of Lord Burns's £600,000 investigation and demanded an official inquiry into the waste of public funds. The report, delivered to ministers last night, will be published by the home secretary on Monday. Though pro-hunting campaigners said Lord Burns'team would be furious at being "ignored", he will say nothing until next week. The Burns report is expected to recommend extensive regulation of hunting and offer a series of options for doing so, on which MPs - among whom there is an anti-hunting majority - will have a free vote in a government bill in the autumn. A BBC2 Newsnight investigation last night revealed that wild fox cubs are being looked after in man-made chambers so they can be hunted by Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles on the Royal Beaufort Hunt - one of the hunts visited by Lord Burns. Newsnight showed the Beaufort hunt's official terri erman, Thomas Burton, shovelling offal, pheasants and chickens on stone slabs outside man-made fox chambers on land near the Duke of Beaufort's estate at Badminton in Wiltshire. The practice appears to contravene the rules of the Master of Foxhounds Association, which governs the blood sport. They state: "Foxhunting as a sport is the hunting of a fox in his wild and natural state with a pack of hounds. webTitle: Fearful but defiant, in the village where hunting is a way of life

fields.headline: Fearful but defiant, in the village where hunting is a way of life
fields.standfirst:
They may feel they are being hounded out of existence, but in Exford they are determined not to go quietly
The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The headline on the local newspaper billboard says it all: "Anxious wait for hunt report". The people of Exford, a compact Somerset working village that nestles on the edge of Exmoor, say they have knots in their stomach as they wait for the findings of Lord Burns' inquiry to be published.
fields.body:
The headline on the local newspaper billboard says it all: "Anxious wait for hunt report". The people of Exford, a compact Somerset working village that nestles on the edge of Exmoor, say they have knots in their stomach as they wait for the findings of Lord Burns' inquiry to be published.

Exford, more than any other place in the United Kingdom, relies on hunting for its economy. This is the home of the Devon and Somerset Staghounds and a number of foxhunting packs are based here or nearby.

Evidence of hunting is everywhere. Horseboxes and Range Rovers with "Endangered Exmoor" car stickers are all around and the howling of the kennelled hounds can be heard in the distance. In the bar of the Exmoor White Horse, the walls are hung with hunting trophies, memorabilia and pictures of the hunt. A sign on the bar says "Hunting First: What Next?", punters are urged to buy The Hunting Gene, a pro-hunting book, and a woman sipping a lunchtime drink has a stag's head tattooed on her arm. Here, hunting is in the blood.

Statistics vary but a large number of local people say they will be badly affected if hunting with hounds is banned. Pro-hunting lobby groups assert that it will bring about the end of the rural way of life, that countless people will be made unemployed. The Countryside Alliance claims that 16,000 jobs would be lost but the Burns report is expected to put the number much lower: between 350 and 6,000. Most of those will be concentrated in the south-west, the report will say.

Jeanette Branton is the owner of the village livery yard behind the Exmoor White Horse and a founder member of Endangered Exmoor, which campaigns primarily for the preservation of hunting. She keeps 15 horses for hunting people during the season, each paying £85 a week.

Sitting in the tack room amid cartons of hoof oil, tins of saddle waxes and rows of tack, she says: "If hunting was banned I wouldn't have a business at all. I rent the yard from Lord Townsend on an annual basis and I wouldn't carry on doing that. I just wouldn't have a business any more."

Mrs Branton has worked with hunters since she was 20. During the hunting season - Exford's is a long one at nine months - she employs two local girls full- time and another two part-time. She says: "Exford is a working village. We have got a blacksmith, a village school. Nearly everybody in Exford of working age is employed in and around the village, which is quite extraordinary. A ban would spoil Exford, a village like this would go forever."

Shooting

The Crown is a hunting hotel. Its sketches, paintings, even duvet covers are all representations of the hunt in one way or another. Mike Bradley has owned the Crown for six years and been in the Exmoor hotel business for 22 years. He estimates 15% to 20% of his business is hunting related and another 20% comes from shooting.

"We don't cater purely for field sports but the Crown has been synonymous with the hunt. It does bring a lot of revenue to the area," he says. "It's very, very important as far as the hotel is concerned. The hunting and shooting are at times of the year that without it there would not be a lot of trade. It actually enables us to keep staff all the year round."

Mark Malin runs a mobile farrier business, complete with portable forge in the back of his van. "In an average week, 50% of my earning comes from hunting - if not a little more. If that were to go I couldn't earn a living," he shouts over the sizzling as he brands a hot horseshoe into the hoof of Reggie, a hunter.

In the village post office, postmaster Dave Whitehouse runs the post office counter, a sorting office with four postmen, and the retail side of the shop. If hunting is banned, he fears an exodus from the village. "I reckon hunting represents 50% of my business."

More likely to be directly affected by a ban is Donald Summersgill, huntsman with the Devon and Somerset Staghounds. Along with a kennelman and two whipper-ins, he is in charge of 124 dogs.

Mr Summersgill, 34, left school with no qualifications. He has reached the top of his profession and lives in a tied cottage next to the kennels. His council tax, electricty and fuel bills are all paid by the hunt. He says he does not know what he will do if there were to be a ban. "I have never worked at or done anything else," he says. "I can't even drive a tractor.

"I wouldn't be no good doing farm work or anything like that. I would have to be retrained completely - the government would have to come up with something."

As he walks through the kennels, past the flesh cut from some stillborn calves and over to the gate behind which scrabble a few dozen bitches, Mr Summersgill shakes his head in regret. He calls each of the hounds' names and they in turn come to the gate for a little affection. He says: "It's my life, it's all I do. I eat, breathe, sleep hunting."

Like many others, Sid Westcott, master of the Minehead Harriers who hunt foxes, says the whole area would be "devastated" financially and socially. He lists the "countless" businesses that will be affected. He cites the social occasions organised by his hunt alone and points to a calendar of events that has at least one official social gathering every month. "Hunting keeps people together. They have got a common language," he says.

Cruelty

But others in Exford have quietly raged against the hunt, campaigning to have it banned for what they see as its unnecessary cruelty. Nigel Winter is one of those. He runs Exmoor Lodge, a vegan B&B in the heart of the village. He even has a "Ban Hunting With Hounds" sticker in the window and disputes that the village will be destroyed by a ban. He says a large number of tourist will not come to the area because they don't like hunting.

"I went to a meeting at which they said about 40 jobs would go but I think in total the hunt employs about 10 people," he says. "There are people who support my point of view and quietly tell me so. One couple told me that they are opposed to hunting but they don't actually tell anyone because they are concerned what might happen to their jobs. And then there are a small number who are very anti me being here. I do get some abuse.

"One chap challenged me about my anti-hunting sticker. I said everyone was entitled to their own opinion, and he said, 'If you live round here you are not.' "

Graham Floyd, of the League of Cruel Sports sanctuary on Exmoor, agrees. He used to follow the Devon and Somerset Staghounds but is now backing a complete ban. "There are far more people against hunting on Exmoor but are too scared to say anything about it," he says.

If the government goes ahead with a move to ban hunting with hounds, however, Exford will not go quietly.

"We are not going to say that's it, we better just carry on with our lives," says Mrs Branton. "The countryside is really going to rebel against a ban. I am not going to say that we are going to fight or there will be a civil war. But I am sure Mr Blair will be aware that it is going to cause huge unrest in the countryside."

In Exford, people are not prepared to say they will break the law and carry on hunting. But sometimes, when they are talking about the sport, their eyes tell you a different story.

webTitle: Putin flexes muscles with North Korea visit

fields.headline: Putin flexes muscles with North Korea visit
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's President Vladimir Putin is to visit North Korea next month in a pioneering trip to open a new front in his campaign against controversial US missile defence plans and signal his determination to restore Russian clout and prestige abroad.
fields.body:
Russia's President Vladimir Putin is to visit North Korea next month in a pioneering trip to open a new front in his campaign against controversial US missile defence plans and signal his determination to restore Russian clout and prestige abroad.

Mr Putin, the first Russian leader to visit Pyongyang, will use the talks with Kim Jong-Il, the North Korean dictator, to try to undermine the US case for its planned missile shield by trying to coax the North Koreans into scaling down their ballistic missiles programme.

The Kremlin confirmed yesterday that Mr Putin had ac cepted an invitation from Kim Jong-Il a day after the Russian and Chinese presidents spoke by phone about joint efforts to thwart the US national missile defence plan to intercept offensive ballistic missiles. Washington says the plan is aimed at North Korea and other "rogue states", while Russia and, particularly, China fear their strategic deterrents will be impaired if the plan becomes reality.

North Korea yesterday denounced the US plans, accusing Washington of fabricating the rogue state bogeyman for its own military purposes.

The diplomatic coup suggests that Mr Putin is bent on a double-pronged offensive against the "son of Star Wars" scheme which most big powers fear will undermine 30 years of strategic stability.

He is to travel to Pyongyang - building on earlier efforts to ease North Korea out of self-imposed international isolation - from his first Beijing summit with China's President Jiang Zemin. In the Beijing and Pyongyang meetings, Mr Putin will discuss retaliation should the Americans go ahead with their missile shield.

"We have made clear what we will do" if the US goes ahead, warned Sergei Ivanov, Mr Putin's national security adviser.

"This decision would kill Start I and Start II. The agreements on medium-range missiles would follow. There is no telling what China and other countries will do."

Meanwhile, Mr Putin is to seek to exploit west European misgivings about the American plans at next week's Berlin summit with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder.

"We propose talks with western Europe on these problems," the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, said yesterday, calling for a "pan-European early warning centre on missile launches and joint development of a pan-European system" for missile defence.

At his first meeting with Nato defence ministers since the Kosovo war disrupted relations, the Russian defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, outlined the Russian proposals to a sceptical reception in Brussels yesterday.

No Russian leader has ever visited North Korea and relations between the communist bastion and Russia have soured since communism collapsed in the Soviet Union a decade ago.

The thaw has been prepared by the Russian foreign minister, who went to North Korea in February, though the trip had to be repeatedly rescheduled, and Kim Yong Nam, number two to the North Korean ruler, visited Moscow in April.

The Putin coup highlights what is emerging as a bout of dynamic diplomacy from the new Russian leadership.

The North Korean talks will be sandwiched between a Russia-China summit in Beijing on July 18 and the G-8 summit of industrialised countries in Japan three days later.

Kim Jong-Il broke with 17 years of staying at home last week by travelling to China ahead of next week's Korea summit and it is believed that the Russian and Chinese leaders discussed Korea on Thursday by phone.

webTitle: Ministry denies Serbia link to envoy

fields.headline: Ministry denies Serbia link to envoy
fields.standfirst: November 17 cites role in Kosovo but MoD says he was in Kuwait
fields.trailText: November 17, Europe's most elusive and effective terrorist gang, yesterday said that it had murdered Britain's top military diplomat in Athens because of his role in Nato's bombardment of Serbian targets last year.
fields.body:
November 17, Europe's most elusive and effective terrorist gang, yesterday said that it had murdered Britain's top military diplomat in Athens because of his role in Nato's bombardment of Serbian targets last year.

In a 13-page proclamation, outlining its motives for the killing, the group said Brigadier Stephen Saunders, aged 52, was a "professional murderer" who worked for a government that had committed "Nazi-like crimes".

Brig Saunders, the first Briton to be attacked by the group, was assassinated because he had "participated in the planning of the barbaric air strikes" - an assertion that was immediately denied by the Ministry of Defence

The MoD said that Brig Saunders had no role in the planning of the campaign and was based in Kuwait as part of the UN observers mission when the 78-day bombing campaign against targets in Kosovo and Serbia began in March last year.

Likening the Nato offensive to the second world war annexation by Hitler of Czechoslavakia, the shadowy group said the Allies had deliberately killed "thousands of unarmed civilians".

The statement, sent to a left ist Greek newspaper at dawn yesterday, also claimed responsibility for five other attacks, including last year's rocket raid on the German ambassador's residence.

Analysts said the March date on the declaration suggested the murder, executed with extraordinary precision, had been planned several months in advance.

Brigadier Saunders, who had been based in Athens for almost two years, was driving unescorted in an unarmoured car when two gunmen, riding a motorcycle, ambushed him.

He managed to open the door of his white embassy Rover but four bullets lodged in his head, hands and chest were to bring about his death during surgery less than three hours later.

Ballistic tests confirmed that the diplomat was killed by the .45 calibre pistol used in five of the revolutionary organisation's previous attacks.

Brig Saunders was the group's 23rd victim since it emerged with the killing of the CIA's Athens station chief, Richard Welch, in 1975 shortly after the collapse of seven years of military dictatorship in Greece.

The publication of the proclamation was soon followed by an appeal by the diplomat's widow.

Heather Saunders implored Greeks to help find the "wicked men" who had killed her husband.

Speaking outside the couple's Athenian villa in the presence of her two, distraught teenage daughters, she said: "For the sake of the future of Greece, these people must be brought to jusitice."

The Greek government said yesterday that it would step up the restructuring of its police force and make more intense efforts to end terrorist attacks. "We must have results," a spokesman said.

Three Scotland yard detectives arrived in Athens yesterday as security was tightened around British diplomats, not least Baroness Symons, the deputy defence minister who is in Greece on an official visit.

But sources close to the Brit-ish-trained Greek counter-terrorism forces last night doubted the gang would ever be unearthed. "CIA agents, who are specialised in the field, have been here for years and they've never got anywhere," said one local analyst.

"I think it's now a matter of luck if November 17 is ever caught."

fields.headline: 'He was a wonderful loving man'
fields.trailText: The text of a statement from Heather Saunders, widow of Brigadier Stephen Saunders
fields.body:
The following is the text of a statement from Heather Saunders, widow of Brigadier Stephen Saunders.

Stephen was my life and our lives were so deeply entwined that today I stand before you half the person I was yesterday morning.

Stephen was a wonderful loving man. He was a man committed to peace and throughout his 35 years in the army, he never raised his gun to kill anyone.

In fact in the past, I know he hesitated once, when someone opened fire on him in Northern Ireland, in case he hit an innocent bystander.

He was a wonderful and proud father of our two daughters Nicola and Catherine, who now will have to go through their lives without him.

In fact to quote both my little girls, 'he was the best daddy in the world.' They loved him very much.

I only hope the people that carried out this cowardly act on an unarmed man, simply travelling on his way to work, will realise the total devastation they have caused.

Not only have they killed my husband, they have destroyed me and my family.

We must make sure this never happens again. I appeal to the Greek people and to anyone who knows anything... please tell the police.

For the sake of the future of Greece these wicked men must be brought to justice.

Stephen was a forgiving man. As yet I cannot forgive the perpetrators of this horrible crime.

But God may help me to forgive in time. I don't know.

fields.headline: Oooh, missus!
fields.standfirst: My advice to Tony Blair after the Women's Institute fiasco: go blue, old boy
fields.trailText: I see that the Diary has been asking professional comics for advice as to how the prime minister might deal with hecklers. The trouble with asking Bernard Manning is that he is bound to offer stock put-downs. The disadvantage of these is twofold. Firstly, they are open to the audience retort: "Heard it". Secondly, comics have them learnt by heart and are often trigger-happy with them. Defeating hecklers is such a prized skill and the fear of failure so high, that comedians, like politicians, can easily alienate an audience by being inappropriately aggressive. For instance, it would have been disastrous for Blair to round on a member of the WI with: "Can't hear you mate - your mouth's full of shit," - especially as she might have been shouting: "Excuse me, young man, could you speak up?"
fields.body:
I see that the Diary has been asking professional comics for advice as to how the prime minister might deal with hecklers. The trouble with asking Bernard Manning is that he is bound to offer stock put-downs. The disadvantage of these is twofold. Firstly, they are open to the audience retort: "Heard it". Secondly, comics have them learnt by heart and are often trigger-happy with them. Defeating hecklers is such a prized skill and the fear of failure so high, that comedians, like politicians, can easily alienate an audience by being inappropriately aggressive. For instance, it would have been disastrous for Blair to round on a member of the WI with: "Can't hear you mate - your mouth's full of shit," - especially as she might have been shouting: "Excuse me, young man, could you speak up?"

Blair's problems are compounded by the fact that he is terribly and uncomfortably posh. The harder he tries to sound ordinary, the dafter he sounds; somewhere between Joyce Carey in Brief Encounter and Dick van Dyke in Mary Poppins. Public schoolboys today tend not to make a virtue of their speech and manners. Had Blair begun: "Good afternoon, Ladies. I am Anthony Blair, your prime minister," it would have had an old-school charm about it. But he is too far down the road of losing consonants and pitiably protesting that he is a tremendous fan of football and pop music. And, whereas the privately educated once entertained us with humorous skits and sub-Coward songs at the piano, they now do stand-up in an ersatz, blokey way. When they have to deal with heckling, they go all snooty, trying to say earthy things when it would sound much better if they said something like: "Get the ruddy hell off my land".

I digress. My point is, Neil Kinnock has always had a beery, macho way with hecklers, but the style wouldn't work for Blair. Kinnock has dumped even more principles than Blair and has the viciousness of all those who have made that journey. There is a special kind of arrogance in people who wake up in the night screaming in guilt and shame. And yet Kinnock's bluff Welsh act still fools people, especially Labour party members, who are suckers for a regional accent.

Put-downs would not work for Blair. Neither do his efforts to appear winning. He has exhausted that schtick. He has never understood that endlessly stating one's values is not convincing. One cannot get away with saying: "I'm an honest kind of guy." The point is to say something that's true. And his attempts at vulnerability are irritating because they are so unsubtle as to be demonstrably vain. The Blair persona comes down to: "Y'know, guys, I'm just like you, but in a kind of god-like way".

O ne thing that might have worked with an exclusively female audience would have been to work blue. Elderly ladies are filthy when not being supervised by menfolk who like filth but not in front of the ladies. But, again, I don't think Blair could have pulled it off (eh missus?) because he's too posh. Cheeky is apt to sound pervy in the wrong accent.

Moreover, public figures being dirty or rude sound as though they are trying too hard. They usually only do it in private, which is especially annoying, because people who are foul-mouthed but able to control it cannot be trusted.

Politicians, being untrustworthy, have not crossed that watershed between private and public. There was no chance that Blair would cause the punters to complain: "I didn't mind the politics, but every other word was 'fuck'." In this instance, it appears that the politics was the problem, which is understandable. Tony Blair would be the obvious choice when trying to find a turn who is not too political. In fact, he can do 45 minutes without saying anything at all. He should seriously consider dropping the gags altogether and work up an act about a man trying to find his way out of a glass box. But he had to go and try political stuff on a WI audience before testing it in a smaller venue.

None of this means that Blair is going to lose the next election. It is entirely possible but, to do it, he would have to lose it to someone. We keep hearing and reading that Hague is scoring points with his oddball routines, but it is New Labour's breath-taking ineptitude and passivity that makes Hague's comedy-Northern persona seem successful. He hasn't suddenly gained charisma, any more than Blair has lost it having once possessed it.

Labour's problem is that it seldom tackles this kind of repulsive rubbish from the Tories. It has somehow allowed the heckler to become the main act. Given this situation, Labour should be shouting: "Bollocks!" at Hague's rightwing, racist material. Instead the government mutters: "He's a bit over the top for my taste, but I like the one about asylum-seekers. I'll nick that."

webTitle: Inquiry finds Ray alone killed King

fields.headline: Inquiry finds Ray alone killed King
fields.trailText: A new federal investigation into the assassination of Martin Luther King says it has found no credible evidence that anyone other than James Earl Ray, the man convicted for the murder, killed the civil rights leader in Memphis in 1968.
fields.body:
A new federal investigation into the assassination of Martin Luther King says it has found no credible evidence that anyone other than James Earl Ray, the man convicted for the murder, killed the civil rights leader in Memphis in 1968.

The 18-month justice department investigation - the fifth since the assassination of Dr King - rejects allegations, some of them from Ray, that a mysterious second man, acting with federal agents, may have participated in a conspiracy to murder King.

Though the allegations have been widely endorse by King's surviving relatives and close supporters, yesterday's report recommends that no further investigation into the assassination is warranted.

The findings are very unlikely to bring the controversy to a close. They were immediately denounced by the Reverend Jesse Jackson, who was present at the killing 32 years ago. "I do not believe in the conclusions of the report," Mr Jackson said. "James Earl Ray may have shot Dr King alone, but he did not act alone. He didn't have the motive, the mobility nor the money to have done it alone."

"The American public and the King family believe James was innocent," said Ray's brother Jerry Ray, "so it doesn't matter to me what the politicians say."

The report dismisses claims by a Memphis bar owner Loyd Jowers and a former FBI agent, Donald Wilson, that a man known only as "Raoul" participated in the killing.

Ray was convicted of the killing in 1969. He was sentenced to 99 years in prison and died - still in custody - two years ago.

The latest investigation was ordered by the US attorney general, Janet Reno, in August 1998, and follows two earlier departmental inquiries, a House of Representatives inquiry and an investigation by Tennessee state prosecutors.

webTitle: Hague attacks charmed PM who 'had it all but threw it away'

fields.headline: Hague attacks charmed PM who 'had it all but threw it away'
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday capped Tony Blair's rockiest week in power with an excoriating personal attack on the prime minister, describing him as the politician who "had it all and then threw it all away".
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday capped Tony Blair's rockiest week in power with an excoriating personal attack on the prime minister, describing him as the politician who "had it all and then threw it all away".

In a sustained assault on the government, speaking to his party's Welsh conference in Llandudno, Gwynedd, the Conservative leader coupled personal taunts with the populist targets he has been refining in recent weeks - the promotion of "mainstream majority" views on criminals, asylum seekers, "Islington cliques" and "liberal elites".

But the striking feature of his speech was its concentration on Mr Blair himself - "all mouth and no delivery" - a man eager to place the blame for his own failings on others, "the media, the Tories, the Labour party, now even the Women's Institute". Mr Hague's attack, dismissed by ministers as a "desperate speech" of a weak leader, came two days after Mr Blair was heckled at the WI conference in Wembley.

Mr Hague used yesterday's speech to talk up party morale in a region where there are no Tory MPs and where Plaid Cymru is emerging as a potent conservative force in the Welsh assembly.

"We can win the next general election because of the work of people like Tony Blair," said Mr Hague.

"Elected because he promised to deliver. Now all he does is talk. Elected because he promised to be in touch with the British people. Now he has been exposed as a man who always favours the conventional wisdom of a tiny liberal elite and holds the views of the mainstream majority in contempt," he said.

Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, insisted Mr Blair had been explaining real issues to the WI.

"One of the biggest problems we have in Britain is people thinking politics is nothing to do with their daily lives. It is actually where the decisions are made which shape those lives," she warned on Radio 4's Today programme.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said: "William Hague has nothing to say on the economy because he has nothing to offer on the economy. Nothing real to say on schools and hospitals because he has nothing to offer on schools and hospitals."

Mr Hague added: "Actually, when I heard Gordon Brown [attack the 'old school tie' elitism of Oxbridge universities] I wondered whether there might not be just a tiny hint of rivalry involved. Who do you think he had in mind when he started moaning about Oxford educated public schoolboys taking the top jobs?" said the Tory leader.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Yorkshire
fields.body:
While carefully driving through the River Swale as it washed across the road at Thornton Manor, I reflected on my writing two weeks ago, where I found great comfort in the wet weather of spring, delighting in the increased area of wetland. Last weekend, we got an extra bulk de livery of rain, the wrong sort of rain, it must be said. Streams and rivers burst their banks across South, West and North Yorkshire and bird-life, in the midst of the breeding season, suffered tremendously. Brian Moreland, who lives by the River Ure just above Ripon, found kingfisher chicks drowned just outside their burrows and he estimates that 80% of sand martin broods have been lost.

As I travelled across from Ripon to Sheriff Hutton, crossing the Swale, the Ouse, the Kyle and the Foss, the area of drowned fields must have resulted in losses for many ground nesting birds, such as skylark, lapwing, redshank and curlew.

Later this week I was able to see at first hand the physical effects of the high river flows. On the Aire at Riddlesden, near Keighley, large stretches of bank side had been scoured away, leaving trees hanging precariously and, on one stretch, a drystone wall leaning towards a watery grave. Again, a sand martin colony had been affected. Both kingfisher and sand martins may try nesting again, but they will have to do well if the young martins are to migrate in autumn or the kingfishers survive their first winter.

During the week my attention was drawn by Derek Bailey, a retired head teacher, to the shortage of sloes set on the blackthorn shrubs this year. He has found most of them with fruits either swollen, deformed and without a stone, or elongated, swollen and curved, looking like a big cashew nut. It looks potentially bad news for sloe gin drinkers, so I telephoned John Newbould, another botanist, but also a gin drinker. He pointed us to a fungal infection of Tapbrina padi in the "cashew nut" deformity, and T. pruni in the other. His thoughts for the cause of the exceptional outbreak - the wet weather we had in spring.

webTitle: Talking about transport and walking the dog

fields.headline: Talking about transport and walking the dog
fields.standfirst:
Susan Kramer
A mayor for London: special report
fields.trailText: Invitations to speak at international meetings of the great and the good have come Susan Kramer's way since she ran for London mayor.
fields.body:
Invitations to speak at international meetings of the great and the good have come Susan Kramer's way since she ran for London mayor.

She may have been dubbed the "Lib Dem woman" by Tory rival Steve Norris, but she went from relative political obscurity to reasonably well-known figure during the campaign.

Conferences in Berlin and Paris are pencilled in for later this year, as well as dozens of gatherings across Britain.

"The difference between me and, say, a Norris or Dobson is I had no prior public profile, and it now seems to be a permanent part of my life," she said. I can rarely manage to walk the dog without one or two conversations about London's transport."

Ms Kramer, 49, has accepted a seat on Ken Livingstone's London transport board, a body that will drive through congestion charges and bus, tube and rail improvements.

And she is setting up a new financial consultancy that will promote the US-style community banks she championed during the campaign.

But Ms Kramer, who stood unsuccessfully against the Labour employment minister Tessa Jowell in Dulwich three years ago, does not intend to build on her profile by running again for Westminster.

"I feel too much of a Londoner," said the woman who finished fourth.

Yet Ms Kramer admits she misses the cut and thrust of political battle.

"I have decided I have a peculiar genetic defect. You got up at six in the morning and went through to midnight for nine months. I got a tremendous kick out of it and haven't come out of it yet."

fields.trailText: We got the Queen Mother's birthday wrong in a short piece about a new portrait sculpture of her, page 12, yesterday. She was born on August 4, 1900 (not August 2).
fields.body:
We got the Queen Mother's birthday wrong in a short piece about a new portrait sculpture of her, page 12, yesterday. She was born on August 4, 1900 (not August 2).

In an article, page 2, Friday Review, yesterday, in comparing the effects of heroin and alcohol, we meant to refer to cirrhosis of the liver (not sclerosis of the liver).

The byline on our article on theatre in Serbia, pages 14 and 15 (Arts), G2, June 7, should have read Richard Crane and Faynia Williams. In the piece we reported someone quoting Drodsky. That should have been Brodsky.

The housing article on pages 6 and 7 Society, June 7, was by Bill Payne and Tony Stacey. The latter is chief executive of South Yorkshire housing association.

The readers' editor writes about the ins and outs of picture archives, page 7, today's Saturday Review.

webTitle: Is there life after losing mayoralty?

fields.headline: Is there life after losing mayoralty?
fields.standfirst:
Five weeks on from the election for London's supremo, Frank Dobson is still keeping a low profile
A mayor for London: special report
fields.trailText: He has been seen strolling through Bloomsbury, spotted dining at his favourite Chinese restaurant, glimpsed heading into a theatre, and - most tellingly of all - heard cracking a joke.
fields.body:
He has been seen strolling through Bloomsbury, spotted dining at his favourite Chinese restaurant, glimpsed heading into a theatre, and - most tellingly of all - heard cracking a joke.

Frank Dobson looks like a man who has had a great weight lifted from his shoulders since the end of the ordeal that was Labour's London mayoral campaign.

It is more than five weeks since his crushing defeat in the London-wide election at the end of a campaign that was widely perceived to have been badly handled by the Labour party machine.

Despite predictions that the former health secretary would be swiftly whisked back into government or the House of Lords, Mr Dobson's public profile has been non-existent since polling day.

"Frank's relieved that it's all over," said a friend in the trade union movement. "He knew he had to keep going when it was a hopeless task but he couldn't wait for it to finish."

He has lost £50,000 a year and a chauffeur-driven ministerial car after going from a seat on the cabinet to Parliament's backbenches via a very public ordeal.

The once loquacious Mr Dobson has not gone public and has declined requests for interviews, a clear indication of how bruised the former health secretary was by his treatment.

Tony Blair knows the damage the Holborn and St Pancras MP could cause if he exposed Labour's rivalries and in-fighting, and is privately praising Mr Dobson's "admirable" loyalty to a party that showed him little of the same commodity.

Downing Street has given no indication of what, if any, role is planned for Mr Dobson.

Westminster colleagues would be surprised if he returned as a minister but fellow MPs do not want him to become the forgotten man of Labour politics.

Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour party, said yesterday: "There is an enormous respect for Frank, not just for the battle he fought over the London mayor but for everything he achieved as secretary of state for health."

He added: "I don't doubt that Frank's talents and abilities will still find an outlet."

Mr Dobson, 60, has spent a couple of weekends recuperating in Strawberry Cottage, the ex-railway worker's house which the railman's son owns as a bolthole near York.

A political colleague said the West Ham fan is planning a trip to Holland, though he could not, or would not, say whether it was to watch Eng land in Euro 2000, take a romantic break with his wife Janet, or even to do both.

Janet Dobson, an academic, feared the continual public spotlight that goes with being mayor and is believed to be relieved that it is all over.

A prominent figure who worked closely with Mr Dobson in government speculated that he was more upset at no longer being health secretary than at not being elected mayor of London.

"He loved the NHS and they have taken his life away," complained the sympathetic minister. "The party owes Frank."

So what of the future for Mr Dobson? As a self-confessed Shakespeare "nut", he knows all about tragedy and betrayal in politics.

The once loquacious Mr Dobson has not gone public and has declined requests for interviews, a clear indication of how bruised the former health secretary was by his treatment. Tony Blair knows the damage the Holborn and St Pancras MP could cause if he exposed Labour's rivalries and in-fighting, and is privately praising Mr Dobson's "admirable" loyalty to a party that showed him little of the same commodity. Downing Street has given no indication of what, if any, role is planned for Mr Dobson. Westminster colleagues would be surprised if he returned as a minister but fellow MPs do not want him to become the forgotten man of Labour politics. Clive Soley, chairman of the parliamentary Labour party, said yesterday: "There is an enormous respect for Frank, not just for the battle he fought over the London mayor but for everything he achieved as secretary of state for health." He added: "I don't doubt that Frank's talents and abilities will still find an outlet." Mr Dobson, 60, has spent a couple of weekends recuperating in Strawberry Cottage, the ex-railway worker's house which the railman's son owns as a bolthole near York. A political colleague said the West Ham fan is planning a trip to Holland, though he could not, or would not, say whether it was to watch Eng land in Euro 2000, take a romantic break with his wife Janet, or even to do both. Janet Dobson, an academic, feared the continual public spotlight that goes with being mayor and is believed to be relieved that it is all over. A prominent figure who worked closely with Mr Dobson in government speculated that he was more upset at no longer being health secretary than at not being elected mayor of London. "He loved the NHS and they have taken his life away," complained the sympathetic minister. "The party owes Frank." So what of the future for Mr Dobson? As a self-confessed Shakespeare "nut", he knows all about tragedy and betrayal in politics.

webTitle: Business trips, a new car and the chance of a new job

fields.headline: Business trips, a new car and the chance of a new job
fields.standfirst:
Steve Norris
A mayor for London: special report
fields.trailText: The Jaguar has been traded in for a Bentley and within the next fortnight the Tory party will have a new election supremo to fight Labour in its urban heartlands.
fields.body:
The Jaguar has been traded in for a Bentley and within the next fortnight the Tory party will have a new election supremo to fight Labour in its urban heartlands.

Steve Norris has been busy since he finished a very credible second in the mayoral campaign, producing one of the best Conservative results for years.

Within days of the polls closing he had taken delivery of the Bentley, wisely deciding it would have been a mistake to do so during a campaign in which he promised to boost public transport.

The former car dealer was out of luck when as he got out of his flashy new motor in Buckhurst Hill, Essex - a thief pounced to rip his £9,000 Rolex from his wrist.

However, a business trip took him to Russia, and he has resumed work as a director with bus, recruitment and engineering companies, as well as being a transport consultant.

The ex-minister, once famous for his five mistresses, has also enjoyed a delayed honeymoon in Majorca with his wife Emma, 35, and their two-year-old son Harry.

Yet it is the prospective new political role that has been the most interesting development.

Mr Norris, 55, showed he could "reach out" to voters with his more caring Conservatism as he finished second to Mr Livingstone.

Talks with William Hague, with whom he got on well during the campaign, are at an advanced stage.

His title has yet to be decided but he will have a base at Tory central office in Smith Square, London, and will lead the charge in cities such as Birmingham and Bristol as well as in London.

"I am very keen to help William and the party in the run-up to the next election," said Mr Norris.

"We are talking about how I might be able to do just that."

fields.trailText: • Will anyone join me in hoping England does not win Euro 2000 (Supplement, June 9)? For 34 years we have had to put up with innumerable TV repeats of the 1966 World Cup victory. Can one imagine how many replays we could be subjected to if England should win this time?
fields.body:
 Will anyone join me in hoping England does not win Euro 2000 (Supplement, June 9)? For 34 years we have had to put up with innumerable TV repeats of the 1966 World Cup victory. Can one imagine how many replays we could be subjected to if England should win this time?
AA Kurtz
London

 In August there will be a new president of the Football Association. The Duke of York is taking over from the Duke of Kent. The people's game? I don't think so.
Malcolm Winkworth
Hardingstone, Northants

 "I'm sure the majority of people who bought Westlife's version of Seasons In The Sun had never heard the Terry Jacks original" (All bases covered, Friday Review, June 9). So how many fewer would have heard the original original, Le Moribund, by Jacques Brel?
Tim Chapman
Halifax

 I am surprised nobody has mentioned the following British linear measurements (Letters, June 8). The stone's-throw: the distance between a beach and a hotel. The kick-up-the-arse: the distance between two pubs. The midge's dick: used to line up the pattern when wallpapering, or when two men carry large pieces of furniture upstairs.
Bernard Hill
Middlesbrough

 Yes, Monaco is smaller than Wales. It's also rainier.
Michael Elwyn
London

 The best argument in favour of the apostrophe (Letters, June 9) was the Norfolk butcher's proud boast "Were the Best"
John Morgan
Cromer, Norfolk mailto:john@conncomms.co.uk

 End o' th' 'postrophe, lad. Pull t'other one!
David Northmore
London

webTitle: I believe in death penalty, says bomber

fields.headline: I believe in death penalty, says bomber
fields.trailText: The Old Bailey trial of the nail bomber David Copeland heard yesterday that he said in police interviews that he believed in the death penalty for killers.
fields.body:
The Old Bailey trial of the nail bomber David Copeland heard yesterday that he said in police interviews that he believed in the death penalty for killers.

Copeland said he believed "100%" that killers, perverts and sex offenders should hang.

He said that as a national socialist he believed in white domination and the "national lifestyle - no crime, no class."

Asked by a detective: "No crime?", he replied: "No, people would be put to death."

Asked if he thought capital punishment would be suitable for a thief, he said he thought 10 years' hard labour would be more appropriate. He went on: "I am talking about perverts and sexual offenders. This is what national socialists believe - hang them, kill them.

"I believe 100% in it for certain offences." Asked if that included murder, he said: "Of course."

Copeland, 24, has admitted causing blasts in three areas of London - Soho, Brick Lane and Brixton - during April last year, in which three people were killed and 129 injured.

He is being tried for murder after the prosecution refused to accept his pleas of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

The court was told that when Copeland was asked about the bombings, he said: "I was obsessed with them. It was something I wanted to do. I fantasised about the chaos that would be caused."

The Recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, adjourned the trial early yesterday because Copeland was unwell. The hearing will resume on Monday.

webTitle: Patten defends joke over 'boring Euro meeting'

fields.headline: Patten defends joke over 'boring Euro meeting'
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: It was a meeting on inter-institutional relations and Chris Patten was bored silly. So bored, that the EU foreign affairs commissioner admitted yesterday, that he stopped listening.
fields.body:
It was a meeting on inter-institutional relations and Chris Patten was bored silly. So bored, that the EU foreign affairs commissioner admitted yesterday, that he stopped listening.

So instead of focusing on links between the commission, parliament and the council of ministers, he thought he would work out how many hours he had left were he to live to be 75. The answer was 175,200.

Embarrassed but defiant, the former Tory party chairman and Hong Kong governor insisted that his jokey - and private - remark about the meeting had been taken out of context and leaked by Eurosceptic Tories.

But even by Brussels' standards, the session in question was dreary: it was not a meeting of the full 20-member commission, but a smaller working group on how the three key EU bodies deal with each other.

It took place at 8am, and was chaired by Loyola de Palacio of Spain, commission vice-president in charge of relations with parliament, transport and energy.

"No, its not the most scintillating subject on the commissioner's agenda," one aide conceded last night. "But it's OK if institutional links are your thing."

Later that morning, a full commission meeting passed without recorded incident. Agenda items included competition policy, labour and social affairs, agriculture and VAT. Mr Patten dealt with a proposal to give trade preferences to encourage recovery for the war torn Balkan region. Plans to ban sexual harassment were also discussed.

By the evening, when he addressed a private dinner for the British Conservative Association of Belgium, he was feeling more relaxed. After speaking about his plans for reforming the EU's aid budget, he told the audience that his day had started badly but ended well in their company.

"It was a complete joke," one official said. "It was 11.45 at night and he had just been given a vote of thanks for his speech when he said that at eight in the morning his day had begun with this very boring meeting."

Reports about his remarks demonstrated the "perils of having a sense of humour" in public life, Mr Patten said.

"I am 56 now, I will be over 60 when this job is over and there will probably only be one British commissioner after the inter-governmental conference this year. It seems to me perfectly sensible to decide when you are over 60 there are other things to do in life," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

Mr Patten has often said privately that Brussels is a grey and impenetrable place - a view shared by many officials who work there. Some Tories regard him as having gone native since taking up the job of Britain's second commissioner last autumn. He has spoken out publicly against William Hague's increasingly Eurosceptic line.

But he has impressed people by his workmanlike approach to reforming the EU's aid programme and made waves last month with ambitious proposals to close the gap between rhetoric and reality.

Mr Patten insisted his commission job was one of the most "interesting" he could do, but said he would serve only one term in office.

fields.headline: Football crazies
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000: torrid voices reach fever pitch
fields.trailText: To mark today's opening of Euro 2000, we asked a random cross-section of participants to give us their views. (Note to W Hague: Euro 2000 is a football tournament, not another Brussels plot.)
fields.body:
To mark today's opening of Euro 2000, we asked a random cross-section of participants to give us their views. (Note to W Hague: Euro 2000 is a football tournament, not another Brussels plot.)

The England fan: "Here we go, here we go, here we go. It's 1966 all over again; same suits even. I mean, innit? England's pride. Lions! Underdogs. Shearer's knee? Penalty shootouts? No problem. We'll show 'em! Just hope Keegan don't start crying again. Achtung, Spitfire!"

The Norwegian ref: "It is not true what your naughty tabloids say that I haf the snow-blindness. I haf two white sticks, but for ski-ing only. I leave them at home! Where is the door, please? Ha, ha!"

The Charleroi policeman: "Zut alors! Everything is ready down to the smallest detail. We are prepared. Nothing can go wrong. We have what your Monsieur Robin Cook he say, an exit strategy. The 'ooligans arrive, we exit. Voilà!"

The Yugoslav foreign ministry: "Our nation's glorious victory cannot be pre vented by the hegemonistic forces of criminal foreign oppression - or by the Slovenian offside trap (which as is well known is funded by the CIA)."

The Turkish pacifist: "Right at this moment, I feel very lonely."

The Italian journalist: "We reckon it's in Di Biagio. Italia is the A to Z of football: Albertini to Zoff. If they mess up again, well hey! They know some ripe fruit will be waiting at Milan airport."

The BBC commentator: "Amazingly, the venue for the Portugal versus Romania clash is Arnhem, an historic name that will ring very few bells in either country. Back to you, Gary!"

The ITV commentator: "See you after the break."

The England manager: "We have to do what we think is right to get the very best out of the players. That's my job. (Pauses to dry eyes.) If I get that right, then we can win it, I really believe that." (Sobs)

The Guardian: "The best of Euro-luck to England. They'll need it!"

fields.headline: The lottery's legacy
fields.standfirst: Booming Britain is a Major achievement
fields.trailText: A "blade of light" was the promise, and for once the reality did not disappoint. Norman Foster's Millennium Bridge across the Thames is a delight. It achieves what it set out to do: as London's first dedicated pedestrian crossing, it lets people stand - as if suspended in mid-air - in the heart of the capital.
fields.body:
A "blade of light" was the promise, and for once the reality did not disappoint. Norman Foster's Millennium Bridge across the Thames is a delight. It achieves what it set out to do: as London's first dedicated pedestrian crossing, it lets people stand - as if suspended in mid-air - in the heart of the capital. Free of the choking fumes of cars or the deafening thunder of trains, it is an oddly affecting sensation. The bridge is so light, without the vast uprights of conventional suspension structures, it feels immediate - even intimate. You hover above the water as if hanging in the basket of a hot-air balloon. And you realise what a beautiful city London can be.

For the capital, the bridge is an obvious boon. It serves to staple together the north and south of the city which, in a way non-Londoners may not appreciate, often regard each other with distance and suspicion. It forms a kind of silvery plait, binding the two places together. At one end the ancient cathedral of St Paul's, at the other that temple of the now: Tate Modern. Along with the London Eye, and in contrast with the Millennium Dome, the new bridge proves that the best things in life - and in art - are often the simplest.

But it is not just London which should rejoice. For the whole of Britain is currently in the grip of a building boom unseen since Edwardian times. The architects hail it as a golden age, a British renaissance - with bold new structures popping up across the land. Whether it is a new parliament in Edinburgh or a national botanical garden in Carmarthen, a redeveloped Bull Ring in Birmingham or a first-class art gallery in Walsall, Britain is being lavished with built riches. The launch yesterday of Architecture Week is almost redundant: people can see the boom all around them.

Who gets the credit for all this activity? Britain's designers and architects deserve some of it. As Foster's work, along with that of Richard Rogers and others, proves, this country has some of the world's best builders and dreamers. The trouble was, they rarely had the chance to have their head. That has all changed, thanks chiefly to the National Lottery, a pot of gold which has funded this building frenzy. For that, if nothing else, John Major should feel some satisfaction. By his introduction of the lottery, he - even more than his celebrated predecessor - has left his mark on the physical landscape of our country.

fields.headline: Poets' corner
fields.trailText: Thousands of words of special pleading by Andrew Crozier (Obituary, May 18) and Gordon Burn (Message in a bottle, June 1) on behalf of the late Barry MacSweeney were bad enough, but when Jeff Nuttall (Letters, June 7) weighs in with his tuppence worth of puff, the rot has to stop.
fields.body:
Thousands of words of special pleading by Andrew Crozier (Obituary, May 18) and Gordon Burn (Message in a bottle, June 1) on behalf of the late Barry MacSweeney were bad enough, but when Jeff Nuttall (Letters, June 7) weighs in with his tuppence worth of puff, the rot has to stop.

As a kid, MacSweeney was hijacked by an opportunistic publisher who made him look a fool, and now his "friends" are at it again - and managing not to say much about his poetry. Just to show how elitist I feel about this: MacSweeney admired Rimbaud. He might have wanted to be Rimbaud. But that didn't make him Rimbaud.
Alan Jenkins
London

 So Sulpicia makes her "debut" as an "undiscovered poet" in John Heath-Stubbs's translation (Impassioned voice, June 9). I wonder what I've been reading all these years, then, in an edition originally published in 1913.
Richard Caddel
Durham

fields.headline: Politics of cake-making
fields.trailText: How did a group of women allow themselves to be conned into believing there is anything that a prime minister could address them about that would not be political (We're not political, says WI, June 9)? If he had discussed cake recipes it would have been political.
fields.body:
How did a group of women allow themselves to be conned into believing there is anything that a prime minister could address them about that would not be political (We're not political, says WI, June 9)? If he had discussed cake recipes it would have been political. What kind of flour was used, where the ingredients came from; were they organic, fairly traded? All of the subjects which they apparently approved him referring to are political. If you live in society everything you do is political. If women were educated to understand that, they could begin to control their lives.
Anna Cheetham
Leicester mailto:acheetham@beeb.net

 We are political; we are not party political. There is a vast difference and this was the essence of the reaction to Tony Blair's speech. The WI was not "set up in 1915 to help women in rural areas to support the war effort" It was started with the aim of improving the conditions of rural life. There were already 800 institutes in Canada. We are still working to improve living conditions by all political and practical means.
Ruth Fennell
Glossop, Derbys alan@afen.freeserve.co.uk

 As a WI member who was present, I would like to point out that the vast majority of us listened with courtesy, even though his speech was too long and the list of achievements tedious. Why does the press never photograph the smart and young members? I assure you that they exist in great numbers.
Angela Singleton
Carnforth
Lancs

fields.headline: Last of the Dunkirk spirit
fields.trailText: John O'Farrell's important discussion of our attitudes to our own and other's identities (Heard the news? The war is over, June 7) points up the highly selective and often triumphalist images pushed out by the media.
fields.body:
It is seven years since the Council of Europe said history ought to occupy a privileged place in the school curriculum since it is "an essential subject in forming the attitudes of young people towards other countries, cultures, races and religions". John O'Farrell's important discussion of our attitudes to our own and other's identities (Heard the news? The war is over, June 7) points up the highly selective and often triumphalist images pushed out by the media.

It is more important than ever that an appropriate history curriculum be pursued by all pupils till the age of 16 at least. Yet history has become increasingly marginalised. There is, too, a downside to the stress on "relevance" that has produced so much local history and narrowly conceived national history; little can then be done to sketch a broader picture, do justice to the achievements of others or our own failings. The government's pretence we are a young country has not helped the need to confront the reality of our past.
Sydney Wood
University of Dundee

 Ending the commemoration of Dunkirk will not prevent football hooliganism. The real myth of the second world war lies in the films, books, comics, TV shows which have trivialised, sentimentalised and glorified war since. Heroic films of British victory are still shown regularly on TV. Hitler's tactics are among the reasons Dunkirk was not more of a disaster than it was, but the reality of the desperation of men machine-gunned on beaches and their rescue by those in small boats is no less real because of it.
Sandra Parker
London

 Thank heaven for some sense. I feel lucky to be from Britain where I have enjoyed freedom from persecution and a good education. However, I can't help feeling ashamed of our country from time to time. We didn't win the war alone, just as the Americans didn't crack the Enigma code. We shouldn't forget Britain's history of invading and "ruling" other countries. The "empire" is nothing to be proud of, considering the mess we all too often left behind.
Sarah Comben
Bristol

 For ex-servicemen, commemorating wartime events is not about pride or "cherry-picking history". It is about remembering comrades who were not so fortunate as yourself, who were laughing and drinking with you one day and gone the next. Presumably Mr O'Farrell hasn't gone through that experience.
Bob Charlesworth
Brough, N Humbs

 The second world war is one of the few conflicts where British involvement was for the preservation of democracy and liberal values and not economic or territorial gain. The defining moment of French history is the revolution and the toppling of the ancien regime, in the US it is their revolutionary war and the Declaration of Independence. They are still, justly, celebrated. They demonstrate a part of a nation's character and sense of identity and there is no reason why the British people should not similarly regard the second world war.
Ben Scotting
Norwich

 Something precious would be lost if the last of the wartime spirit (which led to the creation of the NHS) were allowed to go. It is because something like that is occurring that our politicians are going around like lost souls, seeking top-down, managerialist solutions for problems which are susceptible only to strategies based on a resurgence of trust and mutualism.
Drummond Hunter
Edinburgh

 After the films Saving Private Ryan and U-571, can we expect one showing how the US conducted the brilliant rescue operation at Dunkirk?
Cherry Lavell
Cheltenham, Glos

fields.headline: Problems of diplomacy
fields.trailText: I hope that the death of Brig Stephen Saunders in Athens (Death in the rush hour, June 9) will finally put an end to those frequent stories about the extravagent life of diplomats overseas.
fields.body:
I hope that the death of Brig Stephen Saunders in Athens (Death in the rush hour, June 9) will finally put an end to those frequent stories about the extravagent life of diplomats overseas. My daughter has worked for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office for 24 years and served in, among others, Warsaw, Kinshasa, Nairobi and Karachi. During that time she has had one friend shot and killed in Nairobi, another friend attacked and raped, and another seriously injured in a bus crash. She has been car-jacked, mugged and lived under constant fear of bomb attacks in Karachi. She has recurrent malaria and suffered from severe stomach problems. Her marriage failed due to the intense pressure of living, working and socialising with her husband in the goldfish bowl of a small embassy. Most of her colleagues have suffered similar experiences.

Diplomats overseas have to serve in difficult countries often with extreme climatic condition. They are often unable to leave their houses. It is impossible to maintain friendships. They are separated from their families and even their children. It is hard to cope when your parents are very sick - even harder when you are on the other side of the world. Swimming pools, tennis courts etc offer their only means of keeping sane. Cocktail parties form an essential part of diplomatic life and are often where important information is exchanged or contracts agreed. Furthermore, what many don't realise is how poorly paid diplomats are. The diplomatic life can be very rewarding, but is not the easy life frequently portrayed in the newspapers. It is a shame that it takes the death of yet another diplomat to bring this home.
Richard Zygos
London richard_zyg@hotmail.com
