fields.headline: Mothers and daughters
fields.trailText: I am sick of reading the sort of punditry that starts "men behave like this". In this case, it is "women envy" in the article on the actresseses Rosemary Harris and Jennifer Ehle (Green-eyed monsters, G2, June 8).
fields.body:
I am sick of reading the sort of punditry that starts "men behave like this". In this case, it is "women envy" in the article on the actresseses Rosemary Harris and Jennifer Ehle (Green-eyed monsters, G2, June 8). I am a woman in her mid-fifties. My two girls are now in their early twenties. They are drop-dead gorgeous and I enjoy walking down the street with them. I feel really proud of them and of myself. Furthermore, they think that I am gorgeous too, and admiringly show me off to their friends.

When the younger of the two went off to university, I fulfilled a life-long dream and started a part-time master's course. The vast majority of my peers are my daughters' age. Perhaps the greatest beauty of being older is the experience of establishing genuine relationships with the younger generation not tainted by deference. This it has been my privilege to experience. I say boo to the psychologists! You reap what you sow. Name and address supplied

 Terri Apter writes that Mary Hoffman and her daughter Rhiannon Lassiter "both have a children's book published". Which explicitly means that they wrote a book together, and it's their only book. In fact, they each have many books to their names. Rhiannon has finished a trilogy and has probably written half a shelf-full since then. Mary is a renowned star of children's literature whose works include many acclaimed classics.
Douglas Hill
London

 This week's Private Lives (G2, June 9) was a real treat. A woman wanted advice to help keep her unhappy daughter's marriage together, and was instead told in no uncertain terms that marriage often doesn't suit women and her daughter should get out! Good on your readers for their straight talking. I'm sure you've set a lot of women thinking hard about their situation.
Carla Randle-Conde
Crewe carla@sixofus.screaming.net

fields.headline: Agansing Rai
fields.standfirst: Indian army corporal awarded the VC for selfless bravery during the British advance into Burma
fields.trailText: In the spring and early summer of 1944, during the ferocious Japanese assault on Imphal, Agansing Rai, who has died in Kathmandu aged 80, was a  naik, or corporal, serving as a section commander with C company, 2nd battalion, 5th Royal Gurkha Rifles (Frontier Force). He was awarded the Victoria Cross for two episodes of extraordinary bravery during the fighting in south Asia.
fields.body:
In the spring and early summer of 1944, during the ferocious Japanese assault on Imphal, Agansing Rai, who has died in Kathmandu aged 80, was a naik, or corporal, serving as a section commander with C company, 2nd battalion, 5th Royal Gurkha Rifles (Frontier Force). He was awarded the Victoria Cross for two episodes of extraordinary bravery during the fighting in south Asia.

Although the Japanese offensive in Assam, launched in March 1944 in an attempt to stop the British 14th Army's advance into Burma, was virtually halted towards the end of May, part of the Japanese 15th Army, intent on forcing its way through to Imphal, pushed forward the attack.

Towards the end of June, the 17th Indian division was still engaged at Bishenpur, to the south-west of Imphal. The vital supply route, no more than a track through the hills to Silchar, was the scene of bitter fighting, as each side attempted to wrest control. Early on the morning of June 25, Rai's company received the order to take a Japanese position, comprising two mutually supporting outposts, dominating the track.

While dense jungle lay to the west of the hillside, elsewhere the ground was bare. The only route was by a precipitous ridge leading to a false crest, beyond which 80 yards of open ground had to be covered before the objective could be reached.

Preceded by an artillery bombardment, C company advanced on Mortar Bluff, which with Water Piquet formed the two Japanese outposts. Having reached the clear ground above the false crest, the company was pinned down by withering machine-gun fire from the post, and from a 37mm gun concealed in jungle to the west. Realising that speed was imperative to avoid heavy casualties, Rai, firing as he went forward, led his section in a charge on the machine-gun position, personally killing three of the four-man crew.

Inspired by his example, his section swept forward. As they secured the post, they came under renewed fire from the Japanese holding Water Piquet and heavy fire from the 37mm gun. In the charge towards the gun, all but three of Rai's men were killed or wounded before reaching the target. With his Thompson sub-machine gun jammed, Rai grabbed the section's Bren gun and continued the charge, killing three of the five-man gun crew while the survivors of his section dealt with the remaining Japanese in the group.

Returning to their former position, Rai and his men rejoined the rest of C company for the attack on Water Piquet. Initially, this second phase of the operation went well, but the Gurkhas came under grenade and machinegun fire from a concealed enemy bunker on the flank. Ordering his Bren gunner to give him covering fire, Rai went forward alone up a shallow trench and, with a grenade in one hand and his Thompson sub-machine gun in the other, rushed the Japanese bunker, killing the occupants.

Following this devastating display of courage, the surviving Japanese fled into the jungle, leaving the Gurkhas in control of the two positions. The official citation announcing the award of the VC to Rai spoke of his "magnificent display of initiative, outstanding courage and gallant leadership," which so inspired his comrades that "the result of this action was never in doubt."

Born in Amsara, in east Nepal, Rai enlisted in the Indian army in 1941. He was soon promoted, and received the military medal for his bravery in action in the Chin Hills during the early part of 1944. Rai received his VC, one of two awarded to the regiment for the same action, from the Viceroy of India, Field Marshal Lord Wavell, in 1945.

After the war, he served as an instructor at the regimental depot. He paid the first of many visits to London in 1946, taking part in the vic tory parade. Promoted subedar , or senior native company officer, he served with his regiment in the army of occupation in Japan.

Following the partition of India in 1947, he stayed with his regiment as part of the new Indian army, and subsequently saw service in the Congo with the United Nations. On retirement in 1971, he was granted the honorary rank of captain. Rai, who lived some three days' walk from Kathmandu, was married with two sons, one of whom is a lieutenant colonel in the Indian army, and three daughters. His wife died in 1988.

Widely respected as a man of great wisdom and stature, Rai concealed a keen sense of humour beneath a quiet and dignified demeanour. Some 5,000 people gathered at his funeral to pay tribute.

fields.headline: Natasha Tatarova
fields.standfirst: Letter
fields.trailText: Francesca Ball writes: The tragic story of the Roma refugee Natasha Tatarova (0bituary, May 30) is deeply shocking. One can only hope that her three young children will be properly cared for.
fields.body:
The tragic story of the Roma refugee Natasha Tatarova (0bituary, May 30) is deeply shocking. One can only hope that her three young children will be properly cared for.

I have been familiar with the political and social struggles in Slovakia for 35 years. The unjust, self-defeating policy of the Home Office that requires Slovak citizens to have (non-reciprocal) visas to enter Britain not only increases mutual fear, anger and resentment, but justifies all the more the Roma desire to seek democratic justice elsewhere.

A visa costs roughly half a monthly wage. It prohibits pensioners who have endured 50 years of claustrophobic isolation, students who need the experience of a broader ethnic Europe, and cultural exchanges, which become prohibitively expensive.

The Romathan theatre, where Natasha worked, is invited here in September, but the cost of the visas is casting serious doubts on the visit.

fields.headline: Doctors recant on Scotia claim
fields.trailText: Two doctors have apologised for causing a £30m collapse in the market value of drugs company Scotia Holdings by claiming its key cancer treatment, Foscan, caused serious burns.
fields.body:
Two doctors have apologised for causing a £30m collapse in the market value of drugs company Scotia Holdings by claiming its key cancer treatment, Foscan, caused serious burns.

Their retraction, in the British Medical Journal, followed a threat of legal action by Scotia. The editor of the journal has also backed down, admitting: "We did not do as well as we would have liked in publishing this point."

The clarification of the doctors' findings yesterday sent Scotia's shares up 9p to 123.5p. It was a much needed boost to the company - analysts are concerned about a convertible bond issue which will require the repayment of £50m debts unless the shares reach 340p by 2002.

Scotia's chief executive, Robert Dow, said: "The events have now been put into context and the authors have declared their conflicts of interest."

Foscan is an innovative light-sensitive treatment, under which patients are injected with a medicine which becomes active when they sit under a certain wavelength of red light.

The two doctors - John Clarke, a consultant at Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, and Shehan Hettiaratchy, of West Midlands Regional Burns Unit - said they treated unusually bad burns on the arms of a group of South African backpackers, who had been paid to try Foscan in a clinical trial.

Now, in a letter to the journal, they have conceded that these burns were likely to be due to poor administration of the product by doctors - some of the medicine may have leaked into the skin of patients' arms when injected, rather than going directly into the bloodstream.

They also said that the usual rate of such a side effect was "probably around 2%", rather than the 43% found in the initial trial.

Dr Dow still refused to rule out suing both the doctors and the journal: "We reserve our legal position."

He added: "It is up to the editor of the British Medical Journal to take appropriate action to see that this doesn't happen again."

Mr Clarke admitted that he had a "competing interest" because he provided a medical report supporting a claim for compensation by the South Africans against Scotia. Dr Dow has suggested that this compromised his objectivity.

Despite yesterday's news, Scotia has had a difficult week. On Tuesday, US regulators delayed a decision date on whether to approve Foscan for the treatment of head and neck cancer from July until October.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: News from Prudential that its Egg flotation offer was oversubscribed failed to lift the life assurer's shares during a modest day's trading in London, finishing just 1p up at £10.03.
fields.body:
News from Prudential that its Egg flotation offer was oversubscribed failed to lift the life assurer's shares during a modest day's trading in London, finishing just 1p up at £10.03.

But it bucked the downward trend which saw the FTSE close 52.8 points lower at 6,443.8 and the Techmark fall 56.70 points to 3,479.43. Only the FTSE Mid Cap and Smaller Cap indices managed to buck the dull trend.

The Pru will reveal on Monday a valuation expected to be somewhere between £1.5bn and £1.9bn and the float was reported to be five times oversubscribed.

At the smaller end of the market, luxury fabric maker Silk Industries fell 12.2% to 21.5p after saying it expected to report a loss for the year as a result of continued poor performance at the group's Paul Costelloe fashion business.

Profit-taking in technology, media and telecom issues was the order of the day. Sentiment was hit in early trade by Nasdaq's weakness overnight, and early gains on Nasdaq in the afternoon failed to inspire any real renewed confidence .

Reuters was one of the biggest losers, down 83p at £10.60, as investors mulled news that the company has delayed its planned Instinet.com launch.

Sage Group also saw a hefty markdown, 53p lower at 621p, hit by news that UBS Warburg has cut its current year estimates by 5%, though the broker has repeated its 'buy' rating.

Arm was down 11.5p to 708p, Logica 105p down at £16.40, Baltimore , off 18p at 577p, while Sema Group - exiled from one of Morgan Stanley's European investment lists yesterday - was 28p lower at 940p.

Blue Circle was marked down 19p to 417.5p on news that the Canadian authorities have given Lafarge two years to reduce its stake to less than 10%.

National Power rallied 5.75p to 399p, while Scottish & Southern firmed 20p to 540p, Billiton rose 5p to 259p, Rio Tinto firmed 29p to £10.65 and Anglo-American gained 50p to £30.75.

Bank of Scotland shed 24p to 612p, while Lloyds TSB - which has been linked to Dutch insurance giant Fortis - fell back 20p to 693p and Woolwich eased 8p to 296p.

British Airways fell 4.75p to 375.25p, as investors continued to fret about the proposed tie-up with Dutch carrier KLM.

At the smaller end of the market, luxury fabric maker Silk Industries fell 12.2% to 21.5p after saying it expected to report a loss for the year as a result of continued poor performance at the group's Paul Costelloe fashion business. Profit-taking in technology, media and telecom issues was the order of the day. Sentiment was hit in early trade by Nasdaq's weakness overnight, and early gains on Nasdaq in the afternoon failed to inspire any real renewed confidence . Reuters was one of the biggest losers, down 83p at £10.60, as investors mulled news that the company has delayed its planned Instinet.com launch. Sage Group also saw a hefty markdown, 53p lower at 621p, hit by news that UBS Warburg has cut its current year estimates by 5%, though the broker has repeated its 'buy' rating. Arm was down 11.5p to 708p, Logica 105p down at £16.40, Baltimore , off 18p at 577p, while Sema Group - exiled from one of Morgan Stanley's European investment lists yesterday - was 28p lower at 940p. Blue Circle was marked down 19p to 417.5p on news that the Canadian authorities have given Lafarge two years to reduce its stake to less than 10%. Bank of Scotland shed 24p to 612p, while Lloyds TSB - which has been linked to Dutch insurance giant Fortis - fell back 20p to 693p and Woolwich eased 8p to 296p. British Airways fell 4.75p to 375.25p, as investors continued to fret about the proposed tie-up with Dutch carrier KLM.

webTitle: Europe raises stakes in rates race

fields.headline: Europe raises stakes in rates race
fields.trailText: The stakes have been raised in the great global interest rate race. The Europeans have cranked up rates by half a per cent, following the recent lead of the Americans. Britain has stopped for a comfort break.
fields.body:
The stakes have been raised in the great global interest rate race. The Europeans have cranked up rates by half a per cent, following the recent lead of the Americans. Britain has stopped for a comfort break, encouraging industrialists' hopes that it might be about to drop out of the running altogether.

The European Central Bank's decision to raise rates from 3.75% to 4.25% caught markets on the hop. Most observers were anticipating only a quarter per cent rise - in line with the three previous increases. But surprise is traditionally the most powerful weapon in central bank armouries.

The ECB's move must be considered in the context of the US Federal Reserve's half per cent increase in official rates last month. At that time the euro was declining at an alarming rate, exacerbating the ECB's fears of future eurozone inflation. The wider the interest rate gap between America and Europe, the more remote a euro recovery, the greater the inflation risk.

The foreign exchange market hosted a modest rally by the euro between the US and European rate rises. This was based on a feeling that the Fed had delivered ample medicine to the US economy and that all rate action would now be in Europe. Over to you, Wim & Co.

One suspects that the ECB took a look at the euro's rally and decided to give it a helpful extra shove by surpassing the market's rate expectations. One can only imagine their response to the markets' reaction to the latest rate rise. After an initial increase the euro swiftly reversed its gains to close flat on the day. But then, if central bankers live to surprise, markets live to confound expectations.

The relationship between monetary authorities and foreign exchange markets is akin to that of puppeteer to puppet. The problem is, it's rarely clear who's in control of the strings. Just ask Norman Lamont and George Soros for their respective versions of the pound's October 1992 departure from the exchange rate mechanism.

While the European authorities are right to worry about the economic consequences of a weak currency - after all, that's what they're paid to do - there's little sign that price pressures are becoming a significant threat in the core economies of the continent. But the same could be said of the US and the UK where interest rates have also been rising.

This upward trend in the cost of money has been a major constraint on the performance of global equity markets. Dearer money creates more attractive alternatives for investors - fixed income products and cash on deposit. It also depresses company profits, reducing their investment appeal.

To date it is the first of these two influences that has weighed on stock markets. Bonds have produced a 3.3% return for investors this year, equities 1.9%, while dollar investors have suffered negative returns from both bonds and equities.

Around the world companies are not weighed down by the debt on their balance sheets. The painful lessons of the late 1980s, when soaring interest costs crippled over-borrowed companies, are still remembered. So rising interest rates should not generate many profit shocks.

A policy-induced slowdown in overall economic activity, however, could be damaging. In a world of low inflation, businesses boost profits through a combination of cost-cutting and volume growth. Choke off the benign influence of economic growth on sales and many companies will struggle.

At this stage of its economic cycle, continental Europe is unlikely to be knocked off its growth path by higher interest costs. The UK, on the other hand, is further through its cycle.

The monetary policy committee has decided that - for now at least - the combination of dearer money and a strong currency is slowing growth.

Industrialists have been squealing about the impact of strong sterling for months. Official statistics on industrial production bear out their concerns.

The service industries are more buoyant, but indications that house price inflation has slowed will carry weight with the MPC. Interest rate increases only grip economies with a lag. In the UK their impact is now being seen.

It's conceivable that, by the year end, European and UK interest rates will have converged at or slightly below Britain's current 6%. That would likely spell a cheaper pound. Bad news for British machismo, but good news for the stockmarket.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Opec faces a self-made Catch-22
fields.standfirst: Notebook Creative art of price control
fields.trailText: Last year the producer's club, Opec, finally showed that it had mastered the trick of marching the oil price all the way up from $10 to $30 a barrel. Now, however, it is having great difficulty in marching it back down again.
fields.body:
Last year the producer's club, Opec, finally showed that it had mastered the trick of marching the oil price all the way up from $10 to $30 a barrel. Now, however, it is having great difficulty in marching it back down again.

That the oil price should be stubbornly stuck above Opec's preferred price range of $22 to $28 a barrel should be little surprise. Critics were quick to attack the Opec decision in March to ease productions curbs as insufficient.

True enough, Opec did build in a mechanism to boost output if the initial increase proved insufficient, but when it should have been activated this week - adding another 500,000 barrels a day to the output - because the price had been above the reference rate for longer than the pre-set period, nothing happened. The producers simply sat on their hands and decided to defer a decision until later.

So Opec is to blame again, then? Well, not entirely. The organisation itself is in a bind. On one hand it cannot be sure that its production levels are the only cause of the price stickiness. Another factor adding to the price pressure is an extremely tight market for gasoline products in the US - according to the International Energy Agency, which reports that pipeline problems and production snags at some refineries are having an important short-term bearing on the market.

On the other hand, however, as the IEA noted yesterday, the persistence of high oil prices is forcing consumers to become more cost-conscious and to change their habits as a result.

For the second consecutive month the agency has forecast a reduction in world oil demand this year - which is not necessarily what the oil producers want to hear.

Last year they were able be boost the price because, unusually, they stuck to agreed production limits. Whether that discipline would hold in the face of a sustained drop in demand is another matter entirely.

Attention is now turning to Opec's meeting later this month. Saudi Arabia is already reported to favour a 1m barrel a day boost in output. The other members should listen carefully.

Turning the taps on now might produce a larger than expected price decline. Not doing so, however, risks putting the pressure on global growth. No prizes for guessing which outcome is easiest to reverse. Market volatility is one thing; slower growth quite another.

Deutsche angst

Rolf Breuer, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank, is a worried man. He is concerned that the bank - which has a market capitalisation of €53.5bn - is vulnerable to a takeover bid.

Some of Mr Breuer's shareholders, too, are worried that the bank is already in the process of being taken over by the Anglo-Saxon investment bankers who work for it.

The angst of both strands emerged at yesterday's annual meeting, which was never expected to be an easy ride for Mr Breuer in the wake of the collapse of the merger with Dresdner Bank.

The deal fell through over the future of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson amid reports that some of Deutsche's top investment bankers were, shall we say, less than fully supportive.

Little wonder, then, that one of Deutsche's shareholders asked whether the bank would be operated in future from Frankfurt or London, and questioned the extent to which the managers of the investment banking business, which earns just over half group profits, were pulling the strings.

To Mr Breuer, such thoughts are "total nonsense" - although titling the bank's annual report Results 99 is hardly designed to soothe ruffled sensibilities.

Outsiders might wonder what the linguistic fuss is about. Plenty of words cross the language barrier. The schadenfreude was almost tangible in parts of the banking community outside Germany when the Deutsche-Dresdner merger collapsed.

But there is more to "equity culture" and "shareholder value" - to use two of Mr Breuer's favourite English phrases - than the language in which they are expressed. They reflect an underlying concept about who calls the corporate shots which is at variance with the traditional approach to the issue on the Rhine.

Mr Breuer's own concerns - that the bank is vulnerable to a bid and that its capitalisation is short of what a buyer would get - suggest that he, too, should change some of his perceptions.

Deutsche Bank is not worth what he thinks it is worth; it is worth what someone will pay for it, be they individuals or a predator on the prowl. That is the nature of the beast and Deutsche employs plenty of people who make the bank money from spotting exactly that kind of opportunity Mr Breuer reckons his own bank represents.

If the Deutsche Bank chief has not got the message, perhaps the influence of the Anglo-Saxon investment bankers in the boardroom is being overstated.

fields.headline: Antidote for an American madness
fields.standfirst: Interview with Robert Shiller, economist and author of Irrational Exuberance
fields.trailText: The past 20 years have seen the inexorable rise of the Media Don. Brilliantly lampooned by Tom Stoppard in his play, Arcadia, the Media Don would dress up a tendentious theory in hyperbolic language and then hawk it round newspapers, radio and TV in pursuit of fame and fortune.
fields.body:
The past 20 years have seen the inexorable rise of the Media Don. Brilliantly lampooned by Tom Stoppard in his play, Arcadia, the Media Don would dress up a tendentious theory in hyperbolic language and then hawk it round newspapers, radio and TV in pursuit of fame and fortune.

Robert Shiller is the perfect antidote to Stoppard's Bernard Valentine, who comes a cropper by cutting one corner too many with his theory about Lord Byron. The Cassandra of the US stock market is a throwback to the days when academics were slightly suspicious of publicity and were more concerned that their books were right than popular.

That said, Shiller's meticulously researched new book - Irrational Exuberance - shows the sort of impeccable timing that would make a real Media Don go green with envy.

No swingeing attacks

The book was published in the United States just 12 days after the hi-tech Nasdaq index peaked at over 5,000 points - and it has already sold more than 50,000 copies to those who believe that investors in America have taken leave of their senses.

Sipping tea over a lunch of skate wing at one of London's discreet but quietly luxurious hotels, Shiller considers his words with care. He is in Britain to give a lecture at the London School of Economics and to publicise his book.

But there are no swingeing attacks on those - the vast majority of US analysts - who confidently predict that the good times will go on for ever, and there are no attempts to encapsulate his 300-page book in a soundbite. Yet his thesis is clear - a market that is hugely overvalued by any historical yardstick is inherently precarious and risky. "The most plausible scenario is that the stock market goes down a lot. 20 years from now the Dow [Jones Industrial Average] may be at 10,000, slightly below where it is today. That would be down in real terms assuming inflation at 2% a year."

The book looks at the three peaks in the US stock market in the 20th century - 1901, 1929 and 1966. By 1920, share prices had lost two thirds of their real value in 1901, in the three years after 1929 they lost 80% of their value, and by 1974 they were 56% down on the levels of 1966. Yet judged by the ratio of share prices to corporate earnings, the stock market was even more overvalued at the start of this year than it was at the end of any of the other bull markets.

Shiller is unimpressed by the claims that this time the internet means that everything is different. "I'm impressed by the number of new eras we have had. We have had a lot of new developments in the past. Even if we are going through a new era, it doesn't necessarily bode well for corporate profits of existing companies."

Like many of those who are sceptical of the new paradigm rhetoric, Shiller sees plenty of similarities with the 1920s.

"Like now, it was a period of conspicuous technological advance. The telephone was the 20s equivalent of the internet. Use was exploding in the 20s, but people were also getting their own cars and the radio was coming in. Communications and information technology went way up. You could hear the president on the radio, the talkies came in. It did create a sense of a new era. A typical family in the 20s saw a lot of changes between 1920 and 1929. They may not even have been wired for electricity by 1920, but by 1929 they had vacuum cleaners, cars, radios, telephones. It must have been spectacular."

Until recently, this has been a message that few in the US have wanted to hear, However, the volatility of the markets coupled with aggressive action by the Federal Reserve to slow down the pace of economic growth has meant that there is now more of an appetite for those sounding a cautionary note.

"It's not as good a business to be a Cassandra," he says. "Bureaus that organise speakers say that they can find talks for me but the prospects are not as good as they would be if I were bullish. Cassandras are less in demand at brokerage firms.

"The same goes for the non-stop business [television] channels that seem to prefer analysts who say the market is going up to those who suggest that it might be heading down. They bring on people audiences like and they tend to be salesmen for stocks. They try to be balanced but they feel nervous putting me on."

An academic at Yale for the past 18 years, Shiller looks younger than his 54 years. He was brought up in Detroit, because both his grandfathers moved to Michigan in response to Henry Ford's decision to increase wages at his car plant to $5 a day - on the grounds that his workers needed to be able to afford the cars they were building.

He was educated at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where all three of the academics who scrutinised his PhD were Nobel prize winners for economics, but came to the subject late. At school he taught himself Russian because of his love for Tolstoy and Dostoevsky - and briefly flirted with the idea of becoming a poet. "I didn't always want to be an economist. I thought about being an astronomer, a medical doctor or a physicist," he says.

Before arriving at Yale, in New Haven, he taught at Pennsylvania state university for five years and at Minnesota for four. "People move around a lot these days, but I don't like to move too much." He says his wife, Virginia, who is a psychologist has had a considerable influence on his thinking about the way in which people behave.

'Timing is important'

The way people act both individually and collectively is one of the man themes of the book, which had a gestation period of 13 years. It was started back in 1987 but was put on the back burner after the stock market crash in October that year, before being revived in the summer of 1999. "Timing is important", Shiller notes drily.

He testified before Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve Board in December 1996 that market levels were irrational. Two days later Greenspan made his now famous "irrational exuberance" speech from which Shiller's book takes its title.

Since then, of course, share prices have soared in the US as the economy has enjoyed its longest-ever boom and the new technologies have proliferated. Some analysts now accuse Greenspan of allowing America to be gripped by asset-price mania, and that his failure to take action earlier has shortened the odds on a hard landing for the economy.

Shiller believes that the "gambling urge" runs deep in Western societies. "There is something about human nature. You need something to do every day. For some people it's the excitement of their lives. You need excitement."

But he feels the idea that the markets are a one-way bet and that every fall in share prices should be seen as a heaven-sent buying opportunity is highly dangerous, even though it is now powerfully entrenched in the US.

"Consumer confidence is running at record levels and this is a very significant sign. I have been stressing the confidence side of the business cycle more than most. It could hold, but I could see it eroding and it could be quite a sharp downturn. A sharp recession is a real possibility."

So is Greenspan to blame? "It's hard to criticise him when there is low unemployment and low inflation at the same time. Greenspan is a very cautious man. So far his caution has worked all right."

He is more critical of the thesis of a book suggesting that the Dow Jones will go on rising to 36,000 because investors have learned - and are still learning - that share prices are no longer risky. "There is no research on that point. It's a get-rich-quick book".

Shiller believes that the confidence of investors is so ingrained that it will not be shaken overnight. He does not expect shares to fall in a straight line, but instead to follow the pattern of previous bear markets, where there was a prolonged period of decline.

Between September 1929 and June 1932, he says, there were three days when prices rose for every four that they fell. "There wasn't one day when it was all over."

The book's conclusion is that periods of irrational behaviour are inevitable in free societies. Shiller believes that individuals should be protected against some of the risks involved in investment decisions, but rather than curbing speculation he favours expanding the number and variety of markets to spread risk.

Febrile atmosphere

As an example, he says, people could buy property-linked securities that rose in value as the price of their homes fell.

In the febrile atmosphere of the Manhattan real estate market, such securities might provide a vital insurance policy for those who would be caught in a double whammy should a collapse on Wall Street be accompanied by a property crash.

Meanwhile, the author of Irrational Exuberance is taking his own advice. "I have liquidated most of my stock market holdings, he says, adding that he has gone long of indexed bonds. In addition, and somewhat ironically, he is an entrepreneur in an internet-based company, Case Shiller Weiss.

This provides an online service which can estimate for mortgage lenders the value of 70% of US properties within one minute. "It's making a profit", he says with some pride.

Owners of companies similar to Case Shiller Weiss have made their owners fortunes in the last couple of years when they have been floated on the stock market - but CSW has yet to go down the same route.

Nor - if Professor Shiller's darker predictions are right - is it likely to do so for some time.

He testified before Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve Board in December 1996 that market levels were irrational. Two days later Greenspan made his now famous "irrational exuberance" speech from which Shiller's book takes its title. Since then, of course, share prices have soared in the US as the economy has enjoyed its longest-ever boom and the new technologies have proliferated. Some analysts now accuse Greenspan of allowing America to be gripped by asset-price mania, and that his failure to take action earlier has shortened the odds on a hard landing for the economy. Shiller believes that the "gambling urge" runs deep in Western societies. "There is something about human nature. You need something to do every day. For some people it's the excitement of their lives. You need excitement." But he feels the idea that the markets are a one-way bet and that every fall in share prices should be seen as a heaven-sent buying opportunity is highly dangerous, even though it is now powerfully entrenched in the US. "Consumer confidence is running at record levels and this is a very significant sign. I have been stressing the confidence side of the business cycle more than most. It could hold, but I could see it eroding and it could be quite a sharp downturn. A sharp recession is a real possibility." So is Greenspan to blame? "It's hard to criticise him when there is low unemployment and low inflation at the same time. Greenspan is a very cautious man. So far his caution has worked all right." He is more critical of the thesis of a book suggesting that the Dow Jones will go on rising to 36,000 because investors have learned - and are still learning - that share prices are no longer risky. "There is no research on that point. It's a get-rich-quick book". Shiller believes that the confidence of investors is so ingrained that it will not be shaken overnight. He does not expect shares to fall in a straight line, but instead to follow the pattern of previous bear markets, where there was a prolonged period of decline. Between September 1929 and June 1932, he says, there were three days when prices rose for every four that they fell. "There wasn't one day when it was all over." The book's conclusion is that periods of irrational behaviour are inevitable in free societies. Shiller believes that individuals should be protected against some of the risks involved in investment decisions, but rather than curbing speculation he favours expanding the number and variety of markets to spread risk. Febrile atmosphere As an example, he says, people could buy property-linked securities that rose in value as the price of their homes fell. In the febrile atmosphere of the Manhattan real estate market, such securities might provide a vital insurance policy for those who would be caught in a double whammy should a collapse on Wall Street be accompanied by a property crash. Meanwhile, the author of Irrational Exuberance is taking his own advice. "I have liquidated most of my stock market holdings, he says, adding that he has gone long of indexed bonds. In addition, and somewhat ironically, he is an entrepreneur in an internet-based company, Case Shiller Weiss. This provides an online service which can estimate for mortgage lenders the value of 70% of US properties within one minute. "It's making a profit", he says with some pride. Owners of companies similar to Case Shiller Weiss have made their owners fortunes in the last couple of years when they have been floated on the stock market - but CSW has yet to go down the same route. Nor - if Professor Shiller's darker predictions are right - is it likely to do so for some time.

webTitle: Chance for IG punters to cash in

fields.headline: Chance for IG punters to cash in
fields.trailText: The spread-betting company, IG Index, yesterday announced it would float in July for about £110m. It expects to see further growth from the Euro 2000 football championship, which it predicts will be the largest sporting event in the company's history.
fields.body:
The spread-betting company, IG Index, yesterday announced it would float in July for about £110m. It expects to see further growth from the Euro 2000 football championship, which it predicts will be the largest sporting event in the company's history.

The listing aims to raise £15m - helping its founders to realise profits and managers and staff to cash in on valuable options.

Stuart Wheeler, the chairman and chief executive, said the aim of the float was to help shareholders realise cash and also to retain and give incentives to its 115 staff, rather than simply to raise money. Only 2m of the £15m will be new capital for the company.

Spread-betting has boomed thanks to the internet. The business, founded in 1974 by Mr Wheeler, has grown rapidly in the past 18 months and unaudited pre-tax profits almost tripled for the year ending May 31 from £3.5m to £10m.

He will sell 10% of his personal holding leaving him with a 33% stake and will continue as chairman and chief executive after flotation.

About 50% of the issue will be offered to existing IG clients. After flotation managers and staff will hold 15% of the company, new investors 17% and the remaining 35% will be held by other existing shareholders. Full details of the issue are expected in July.

webTitle: Dagenham in transit Blair told of fears for 35,000 jobs

fields.headline: Dagenham in transit Blair told of fears for 35,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Ford workers and union officials yesterday warned Tony Blair that the company's decision to end car production at Dagenham, above, could lead to the loss of another 35,000 motor jobs within seven years.
fields.body:
Ford workers and union officials yesterday warned Tony Blair that the company's decision to end car production at Dagenham, above, could lead to the loss of another 35,000 motor jobs within seven years.

They said Ford would choose to make key components for next generation cars closer to its existing assembly plants in mainland Europe.

Steve Turner, the regional T&G official for the motor industry, said component plants at Dagenham, Basildon and Enfield were at risk since they were more than 600 miles from the nearest assembly plants.

He added that Ford would probably transfer production of Transit vans from Southampton to Turkey, where its Transit plant was being rebuilt with double its previous capacity.

The shop stewards told Mr Blair that such a scaling down of British operations would lead to the loss of 9,000 Ford jobs and 26,000 in support industries.

A Ford spokesman insisted that the company was committed to Britain, where it was the largest automotive employer, with 50,000 people on the staff.

"We said last month that we would be investing $2bn in Ford Motor Company facilities over the next five years, including $600m at Dagenham," he said. "But you can never say never. Component plants have to remain competitive."

The Dagenham team told the prime minister that Ford could make Volvos and Mazdas at the plant. It reminded him that Ford had broken an earlier promise to make Dagenham the lead plant for pro duction of the new Fiesta. Union officials said Mr Blair had responded "very positively", accepted the force of their argument, and assured them he would assist whenever he could.

However, Mr Blair's office refused to comment on the meeting, which it said was private. Ford announced last month that it is to halt car making at Dagenham when the Fiesta model is withdrawn in 2002. That will lead the loss of 1,900 jobs, on top of the 1,350 lost because of the move to single shift production.

webTitle: PNC buys chain of mobile phone stores for £62.5m

fields.headline: PNC buys chain of mobile phone stores for £62.5m
fields.trailText: PNC Tele.com, the business to business telecoms firm, yesterday acquired one of the few remaining independent mobile phone retailers of significant size for up to £62.5m.
fields.body:
PNC Tele.com, the business to business telecoms firm, yesterday acquired one of the few remaining independent mobile phone retailers of significant size for up to £62.5m.

Geremy Thomas, PNC's chief executive, said he intended to expand the KJC retail chain from 30 to 50 stores by the end of the year. The deal comes two days after Britain's largest independent mobile phone retailer, Carphone Warehouse, said it would float at a valuation of between £1.6bn-£2bn.

"We believe it's a great time to be in the mobile market. All existing users are likely to upgrade their handsets to newer technologies between now and 2003," Mr Thomas said. "Mobile retailers independent from the networks will command a significant premium."

PNC will pay £30m up front in a mix of cash and shares and up to another £32.5m, depending upon performance of the business over the next year. The cash element will be funded by a £17.6m placing and open offer of PNC shares.

The acquisition of KJC more than doubles PNC's annual revenues to £75m, and the combined business will move from Aim to the market's main list.

PNC intends to put staff in each store to target small business customers and offer web consultancy and voice-call re selling. "We want to offer our customers a complete one-stop shop, and this deal adds mobile to our existing offers."

Trading in PNC shares, suspended for two months, will begin again on Monday.

Founded in 1988 by Darren Ridge and Joseph Case, KJC has an established corporate sales division as well as mail order and retail. It is connecting 10,000 users a month.

Mr Ridge, 37, and Mr Case, 55, will each collect £7.5m in cash and the same in PNC shares. PNC reported results for the year to April which showed turnover more than doubling to £29.1m, while pre-tax losses were recorded of £357,000 against a £4,000 profit in the previous year.

fields.headline: Years of overnight success
fields.standfirst: Brand values Moss Bros
fields.trailText: Charles Pond, a failed City stockbroker, had pawned his dress suit. But he could not pursue his new career as an entertainer without one. His predicament in 1897 was to be the catalyst that created the Moss Bros clothing hire business.
fields.body:
Charles Pond, a failed City stockbroker, had pawned his dress suit. But he could not pursue his new career as an entertainer without one.

Pond had been reduced to singing comic songs and doing sketches at parties in large private houses. His predicament in 1897 was to be the catalyst that created the Moss Bros clothing hire business.

Alfred Moss, who ran a small second-hand clothing and tailoring business with his brother George, lent Pond the necessary suit - on condition that the failed financier paid half a guinea a night and brought the suit back for pressing every morning after he undertook a music hall engagement.

Word got around among other impoverished entertainers, and the brothers found themselves in the hire business.

Their company had been started by their father, Moses Moses, in the late 1850s. Moses, a second hand clothes dealer, traded from a number of shops before moving to a site in King Street, not far from his home in Maiden Lane, Covent Garden.

Alfred and George, who were given £100 capital by their father, worked at King Street as buyer and tailor. They inherited the business in 1894.

Before the century was out they had changed their name to Moss and rebuilt the King Street shop, which displayed the name Moss Bros. But clothing hire was still a sideline to the tailoring business.

The firm quickly built up a reputation for knowing exactly what should be worn on every occasion and where it could be obtained.

Alfred Moss was reluctant to throw anything away and by 1910 he had enough bits of uniforms, including some Sam Browne belts, to open a military department.

The first world war created unprecedented demand for uniforms, new and old. Newly commissioned officers turned to Moss Bros to kit them out. The company could make a four guinea service uniform in 36 hours.

Peace brought demand for civilian clothing, especially from young men who had gone straight from school to the trenches. The inter-war years saw growth in demand for clothes to hire as ceremonial and social events proliferated.

The second world war renewed demand for uniforms. The firm was also asked to provide authentic German and French clothing for spies being parachuted into enemy territory. The firm has provided uniforms for Generals Haig, Allenby, Montgomery, Persh ing and Patton. On the civilian side, it has made clothes for at least three kings, actors such as Valentino and Noël Coward, composer Sir Edward Elgar, and explorers Nansen and Scott.

After the war Moss Bros opened shops throughout the country. Today it hires out more than a million articles of clothing a year, mainly for weddings and university balls. About 70% of its hire customers are 30 or under.

The wealthy and famous, as well as impoverished students, rely on it. Last year, it kitted out 30 of David Beckham's team mates in frock coats for his wedding to Victoria Adams. It also provided the groom's outfit for the marriage of John Major's son, James, to Emma Noble.

Moss Bros, which owns the Savoy Taylors Guild and The Suit Company, expanded its retail operations with acquisitions such as Cecil Gee in 1988 and Blazer in 1996.

It is now undergoing a shake-up - including board changes and the closure of 30% of its shops - to reverse a slump in profits. The company had been caught out by the trend to dress down.

fields.headline: Japan breaks cycle
fields.trailText: Japanese prime minister Yoshiro Mori breathed a sigh of relief yesterday as figures showed the country's economy has broken a two-year losing streak just in time for an upcoming general election.
fields.body:
Japanese prime minister Yoshiro Mori breathed a sigh of relief yesterday as figures showed the country's economy has broken a two-year losing streak just in time for an upcoming general election.

Thanks to a late surge in business activity Japanese output inched up by 0.5% in the 12 months to 31 March. It is the first full year of growth since fiscal 1996, when the economy started sliding into its worst post-war recession.

Although the expansion falls short of the government's 0.6% growth forecast the positive figures are a boost for Mr Mori, who is suffering from record low levels of popularity ahead of the June 25 poll.

Most encouraging was the latest quarterly data, which showed the economy surging forward between January 1 and March 31 at an annualised rate of 10% - the most rapid growth since the first three months of 1996.

The markets, however, were disappointed that the news was not as good as had been expected - considering recent encouraging signs of a pick-up in corporate investment and business confidence.

After the figures were released the Nikkei index of the Tokyo stock exchange fell for the fourth day and the yen lost ground against the US dollar.

webTitle: MoD accused of ferry tender fiasco

fields.headline: MoD accused of ferry tender fiasco
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence yesterday invited bidders for a controversial £1bn ferry contract to submit new terms within four weeks.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence yesterday invited bidders for a controversial £1bn ferry contract to submit new terms within four weeks.

Shipbuilders last night claimed the government acted because a foreign yard would have won the politically explosive deal. Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, has been under pressure from Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, to ensure the ferries are built in Britain.

"What the MoD is doing is quite extraordinary. The goal posts have been shifted to get the result they want," said one of the companies involved.

Govan is believed to be the government's favoured yard but industry sources speculated that the lowest bids were lodged by German or far eastern yards. The 20-year contract is to supply and maintain six roll-on, roll-off ships for mobile forces crucial to Britain's defence policy.

Four consortiums were in the running but the government would risk an electoral backlash if the work went abroad. The Scottish National Party and trade unions have mounted a strong campaign in favour of the Govan yard.

Suspicions of ministerial involvement were heightend by the MoD's decision not to publicise the move. A spokesman admitted the bids had been "close" but insisted European tender rules would be fully complied with.

fields.headline: British Biotech quits 'blue sky' research
fields.trailText: British Biotech, fallen angel of the drug industry, is cutting its workforce by 40% and withdrawing from several areas of "blue sky" research.
fields.body:
British Biotech, fallen angel of the drug industry, is cutting its workforce by 40% and withdrawing from several areas of "blue sky" research.

Chief executive Elliot Goldstein wants to concentrate on developing products in clinical trials, retaining just a small research team to find new treatments for infectious diseases.

The latest pruning comes after a turbulent year for the company. Its cancer drug Marimastat, once considered a potential blockbuster, has performed poorly in a series of large-scale studies. It has struggled to recover from the turmoil of 1998, when Andrew Millar, former head of clinical research, exposed flaws in the management strategy.

Staff numbers will fall from 230 to 140 over the next six months, with 51 to leave immediately. Three years ago, there were 450 on the payroll.

Dr Goldstein announced the redundancies at a meeting in the staff canteen yesterday. He said later: "Obviously there were some emotional reactions and disappointment from some people."

Most of those leaving are scientists, with the rest in support functions such as engineering, computing and finance.

Among those to go will be the research team which came up with marimastat. Dr Goldstein said: "It's painful for people, but it's got nothing to do with their quality."

The company had set a target of taking one new drug into trials a year. Last year, the research team exceeded expectations by coming up with two, and with a total of five products in development, Dr Goldstein said, the pipeline was sufficiently full.

The changes will cost £1.5m but yield annual savings of £8m. British Biotech will house its staff in one block and several neighbouring buildings will be sold or leased out.

Analysts greeted the reorganisation cautiously. Eva Haas, of Old Mutual Securities, said: "From a business point of view it makes a certain amount of sense but some people would probably argue that they should have done it earlier."

The group's shares rose 2p to 24.75p. They peaked at more than 300p three years ago, valuing the business at more than £1bn.

British Biotech's lead product remains Marimastat, which has been shown in some circumstances to reduce the size of cancer tumours. Analysts believe its best chance is in a trial for small cell lung cancer, where the size of tumours is much smaller. It has proved inconsistent so far and causes painful side effects.

A follow-up drug, BB-3644, is tipped to be more promising but is only in early trials.

Dr Goldstein said the company was withdrawing entirely from "very early, blue sky research areas" in which scientists look for entirely new technology.

webTitle: One year on, Annan fears for future of Kosovo

fields.headline: One year on, Annan fears for future of Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, has sharply condemned the upsurge in attacks on Serbs in Kosovo, for the first time accepting that they are not isolated revenge killings but part of an orchestrated campaign.
fields.body:
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, has sharply condemned the upsurge in attacks on Serbs in Kosovo, for the first time accepting that they are not isolated revenge killings but part of an orchestrated campaign.

In a report to the security council a year after the UN took charge of Kosovo's government and Nato-led troops replaced Serb forces, Mr Annan wrote: "The international community did not intervene in Kosovo to make it a haven for revenge and crime."

"Local leaders and the people of Kosovo have made some encouraging efforts to create a society in which all people can live without fear. But understanding and tolerance in Kosovo remain scarce and reconciliation is far from a reality," he wrote.

His gloomy analysis comes a few days after the moderate Serb national council dealt a heavy blow to Bernard Kouchner, the UN's top man in Kosovo, by walking out of the territory's transitional council which functions as a quasi-government under UN control. Its leaders were protesting at the murder of eight Serbs in two weeks.

The Serbs had only agreed to join the council as observers, claiming that security for their communities was too weak to justify full participation. Their decision to end cooperation will delight Belgrade. In a further significant change, the national council also wrote to the Serb president, Milan Milutinovic, appealing for help.

UN figures show that, although crime is affecting all communities, it is much worse for Serbs. Twenty-six Serbs were killed between February and May out of a population estimated at little more than 60,000, compared to 52 Albanians out of a population of around 2m.

Dr Kouchner is under pressure from the west to hold local elections in Kosovo in another effort to restore normality, but the chances that any Serbs will take part in the polls, scheduled for October, look increasingly slim. Elections in which only Albanians take part in large numbers will be another signal that Serbs see no future for themselves in the territory.

Mr Annan tried to sound upbeat in the rest of his report. He called Kosovo's economy "remarkably vibrant", with 70% of private enterprises now restarted, and producing and employing more than in 1998. Winter wheat planting was at 80% of the historical average and the construction sector was booming, he added.

But he added that unemployment remained at around 50%, and much remained to be done to establish the institutional and legal framework to encourage enterprise development.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: PwC accused of cover-up
fields.body:
PwC accused of cover-up

PricewaterhouseCoopers faces the most serious charges of professional misconduct yet brought against a big accountancy firm, with claims that it deliberately concealed evidence of fraud when auditing a client company.

The profession's main regulator says Coopers & Lybrand, now merged into PwC, uncovered evidence in 1992 that Robert Feld, managing director of Resort Hotels, committed fraud, but did not inform the company.

Christopher Dickson, head of the joint disciplinary scheme, and formerly senior assistant director of the serious fraud office, made the accusation yesterday against PwC collectively and against former partner Alun Thomas, former manager Mark Harwood and Ruth Way, a senior manager. His allegations will go to an independent tribunal. PwC and individual defendants could face unlimited fines, and the individuals expulsion from the profession.

Resort collapsed in 1992-93 and Feld was convicted of fraud in 1997.

Safeway exit worth £4m

The ousted chief executive of Safeway, Colin Smith, is set to receive a payment of more than £4m over the next 10 years following his departure from the company last November.

Mr Smith, 53, left Safeway after having failed to turn around the struggling supermarket chain in his six years as chief executive. He took with him a £1.16m pay-off, but he will also receive an annual pension of £290,903. He was replaced by Carlos Criado-Perez, a former Wal-Mart chief operating officer.

Microsoft gives price warning

Microsoft president and chief executive Steve Ballmer said implementation of the US anti-trust judgment against the company would increase prices for computer hardware and software.

Mr Ballmer told a news conference Microsoft "would love to settle this case" with the US government. "The judgment will restrict innovation and increase prices for personal computers and software. There were errors of law and fact in the judgment.

He added that "It is inappropriate to speculate here" on prospects for a negotiated settlement.

Asked about the European commission's investigation into Microsoft's Windows 2000 operating system, he said his company was complying fully with EC directives.

Tesco offers online stop-off

Tesco yesterday announced plans to develop in-store internet cafes as part of the supermarket chain's continued expansion beyond its core food business. It is opening 10 cafes after a successful pilot in its Kensington store. The scheme might be rolled out to 350 of its 659 British stores and even lead to standalone sites.

Time online will be charged at 50p for 20 minutes. A spokeswoman said the stores chosen would largely be in areas of social deprivation to encourage wider use of the net.

fields.headline: Airbus denies super jumbo turbulence
fields.trailText: Airbus Industrie yesterday dismissed concerns that the go-ahead for its A3XX was in trouble because of divisions among the group's partners.
fields.body:
Airbus Industrie yesterday dismissed concerns that the go-ahead for its A3XX was in trouble because of divisions among the group's partners.

The "authorisation to offer" - which would allow Airbus to sign contracts with airlines to buy the super jumbo - was expected to be approved at the Berlin airshow this week but that was suddenly postponed.

However, Airbus, a consortium made up of France's Aérospatiale-Matra, Germany's DaimlerChrysler Aerospace and BAE Systems, insisted yesterday that the A3XX plans remained on track.

"The commercial and marketing launch will be announced in the coming weeks," a spokesman said. "When you have a launch like this there will be some to-ing and fro-ing at the last minute."

At the end of the day, how ever, "the aircraft gets launched, the airlines buy it and passengers fly it".

A spokesman for BAE Systems said discussions were taking place among the partners. "They are just the normal kind of thing you would expect with a major project."

According to industry sources, one of the decisions yet to be decided is where final assembly of the aircraft will take place. Airbus Industrie's existing output is assembled in Toulouse but Dasa is said to be pressing for the assembly of the A3XX to take place in Hamburg.

This is occurring as Airbus Industrie seeks to turn itself from a partnership into an integrated company while at the same time two of the partners, Aérospatiale-Matra and Dasa, are merging to form the European Aeronautic, Defence and Space company (Eads).

According to German newspaper reports, Eads will be floated on the stock market next month with a market capitalisation of close to £10bn.

 BAE Systems said yesterday it had not decided whether to bid for Britain's air traffic control system when it is privatised. Boeing is reported to be considering a joint bid with the British group but BAE Systems said: "We don't know if we are going to bid or not, we don't know if we will do so with a partner and we don't know if that partner would be Boeing."

webTitle: Sheep blamed for scouts' E coli illness

fields.headline: Sheep blamed for scouts' E coli illness
fields.trailText: Concern over health risks to children who come into contact with farm animals intensified yesterday as it emerged that a group of scouts had fallen ill after pitching their tents near sheep droppings.
fields.body:
Concern over health risks to children who come into contact with farm animals intensified yesterday as it emerged that a group of scouts had fallen ill after pitching their tents near sheep droppings.

Scientists investigating an outbreak of E coli poisoning in the north-east of Scotland said that they had discovered traces of the potentially fatal bacteria in sheep droppings in the field where the scouts set up camp two weekends ago. Traces of the bug were also found in puddles at New Deer, Aberdeen.

Health officials said the number of young people confirmed with E coli poisoning had now reached 18. The most seriously ill child, an eight-year-old boy who had been receiving kidney dialysis in Aberdeen, was yesterday transferred to specialist care at Yorkhill hospital in Glasgow.

A spokeswoman for the hospital described his condition as "comfortable". The remainder of those infected - two girls and 15 boys - are not as seriously affected by the bug and are being cared for at home. Around 300 children attended the camp, which was billed as a weekend of millennium celebration, but was abandoned early due to severe weather.

Colin Houston, from Aberdeenshire council's environmental health department, said samples were taken from the site after the first case of E coli O157 came to light. "The results that were obtained were that all the faeces samples from sheep were positive," he said. He added that the wet weather may have spread the infected faeces more widely across the field.

All those who have tested positive for E coli O157 so far are from a group of between 30 and 40 who reported mild diarrhoea after attending the camp.

fields.headline: Public sector strike looms
fields.trailText: Germany faced the prospect of widespread strikes by more than 3m transport workers, dustmen and blue collar staff yesterday after the country's two main public sector unions voted to take industrial action in pursuit of a 2% pay claim.
fields.body:
Germany faced the prospect of widespread strikes by more than 3m transport workers, dustmen and blue collar staff yesterday after the country's two main public sector unions voted to take industrial action in pursuit of a 2% pay claim.

Leaders of the two unions -ÖTV and DAG - said selective strikes aimed at hitting employers rather than the public would begin on Tuesday unless government negotiators came up with an improved offer over the weekend.

"The government and local authorities can still apply the emergency brake, but we will want to see some precise movement towards our demands," ÖTV negotiator Christian Zahn said.

The unions want a pay rise of 2% this year. So far they have been offered 1.8% and a 2.2% increase next year. They are also demanding pay parity for eastern workers who have lagged behind since German unification.

ÖTV last struck in 1992 when a bitter 11-day walkout paralysed the country. But there has not been a major public service strike against a Social Democrat-led government since 1974.

webTitle: Russian missile plan falls flat in Washington

fields.headline: Russian missile plan falls flat in Washington
fields.trailText: A Russian charm offensive aimed at derailing controversial US plans to develop a missile defence system ran into trouble last night after Washington branded Moscow's alternative proposals as "totally inadequate".
fields.body:
A Russian charm offensive aimed at derailing controversial US plans to develop a missile defence system ran into trouble last night after Washington branded Moscow's alternative proposals as "totally inadequate".

The rejection will be keenly felt by Russia's defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, who made a special trip to Nato headquarters in Brussels to brief the alliance on how his country thought the threat of an attack from so-called rogue states should be countered.

It is also highly embarrassing for President Vladimir Putin since it was the first time a Russian defence minister had visited Nato since Moscow fell out with the organisation over the war in Kosovo.

But the US defence secretary, William Cohen, was adamant that Marshal Sergeyev did little to put flesh on the bones of an alternative Russian proposal announced by President Putin on Monday after a summit with the US president, Bill Clinton.

"It's unclear to me exactly what Russia has in mind. It's basically a statement about an idea. It's not a system," he said after the meeting. Mr Cohen also warned that Russia's proposals, if implemented, would leave large swaths of the United States and Europe unprotected from the threat of rogue missile launches from pariah states such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq.

"It is not a system that could provide protection to the United States, or to much of Europe. So at this point it's an idea that does not appear to be feasible or desirable for protecting us against the kind of threats that are emerging."

Mr Cohen was at pains to stress Washington's willingness to try to lay to rest concerns which have been raised by Russia and European countries such as France and Germany.

The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, warned earlier this month that America's determination to develop a sophisticated shield which could shoot down missiles in space risks rekindling a global arms race and weakening Nato. But the Nato secretary general, George Robertson, was yesterday keen to lower the temperature and played down any differences of opinion.

America is keen to have its own defensive system in place by 2005 when it believes that the threat of a nuclear strike from rogue states will be a real possibility. But to do this it needs to persuade Russia to amend the crucial anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty of 1972.

Mr Sergeyev said yesterday that Russia's proposals, which envisage a more limited missile defence shield, would require no such treaty revision.

"The Putin proposal for theatre defence does not compromise in any way the ABM treaty," he said. But American defence officials said the Russian proposal was even more complicated than their own.

fields.headline: Spanning the centuries
fields.trailText: The Tay bridge disaster in 1879, which as the poet William McGonagall immortally observed in one of the world's worst poems "Will be remembered for a very long time", sent a shock wave through the world of civil engineering and changed the science of bridge building for ever.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Tay bridge disaster in 1879, which as the poet William McGonagall immortally observed in one of the world's worst poems "Will be remembered for a very long time", sent a shock wave through the world of civil engineering and changed the science of bridge building for ever.

The engineer who designed it, Thomas Bouch, had taken the best advice available on wind force. On the night of December 28 1879, in a howling blizzard, the central spans of his year old bridge collapsed into the river, taking with them the Dundee express train and its 90 passengers.

The game plan changed from brute strength and spectacle to durability, controlled flexibility and above all wind resistance. The result, 130 years later, is a new generation of bridges ever longer, lighter and more slender, instead of the massive towers and buttresses of the great Victorian spans.

"I think everyone loves bridges because they're so easy to understand," said Denis Smith, past president of the Newcomen Society, dedicated to civil engineering and industrial archaeology. "Unlike most of civil engineering, which can seem very arcane and impenetrable to a layman, anyone can understand the principle of a bridge, and the form follows the function, which is one of the definitions of beauty."

Dr Smith's obsessive interest in bridges is regarded as slightly over the top even by his peers in the Newcomen Society. To him the object of any journey is not the destination but the bridges deviated to along the way. He is already planning his journey to the Oresund link.

"Just think of all those little stone bridges, built by rule of thumb by some medieval stonemason, designed to carry nothing heavier than a horse and cart, which now have juggernauts thundering over them every day - they're miracles of design."

Bridge building is a rare field in which Britain has led the world. What distinguishes British engineers from their peers abroad, he says, is their low status in the public mind.

"If I say in France that I am an engineer people expect me, however mistakenly, to be a person of culture and learning. Here I could just be the chap who comes round to mend the washing machine or the telly."

Here, in tribute to the engineering art, are the facts about 10 splendid bridges:

The Oresund link

When it opens next month, it will hold the world title of longest bridge to carry both trains and motorway traffic. The road and rail link between Sweden and Denmark has taken five years to build, and includes bridges and tunnels. The main section is the 7.8km Oresund bridge, carrying cars on one deck and a two track railway on the lower deck.

Clifton suspension bridge

A typically audacious design by Isambard Kingdom Brunel to cross a 250ft deep gorge, with a main span of 702ft. It was built against the advice of Thomas Telford, whose Menai suspension bridge had almost been destroyed by crosswinds. The original design of 1836 was modified many times in the financial crises which inevitably beset Brunel's big projects. It was completed in 1864, after Brunel's death, re-using the chains from another financially disastrous project, his Hungerford bridge in London.

Tower Bridge

In 1884 the corporation of London finally resolved to end the reign of the notoriously foul mouthed Thames ferrymen, and build the bridge the city desperately needed. The design, by Horace Jones and John Barry, hid under its charming Gothic exterior the largest and most sophisticated bascule bridge ever built. The hydraulically operated bascules - massive counterweights - still lift the arms to allow ships through, although since 1976 they have been driven by oil and electricity rather than steam. The bridge will close temporarily this year for the first major repairs to the bascules.

Pont de Normandie

Completed in 1995, this held the previous world record for longest cable-stayed - rather than suspension - bridge. Built at the mouth of the Seine, it takes 10 minutes to drive across and has withstood wind gusts of over 100mph.

The Brooklyn bridge

Crossing the East River in New York, it opened in 1883, 81 years after the first petition to build it. The first engineer, John A Roebling, was killed in an accident, one of 27 men who died on the site. His son, Washington Roebling, took over, became an invalid during the work, and finished supervising construction from his bedroom, with his wife relaying instructions to the builders and engineers.

The Charles bridge, Prague

It was begun in 1357, a date chosen, according to legend, because it was numerologically auspicious. The bridge, an outdoor gallery of baroque sculpture, outlasted wars and natural disasters to become the oldest stone bridge in central Europe. It is still the city's main meeting place, and now a haunt of buskers and traders.

Sydney Harbour bridge

This is the world's widest - though not longest - steel arch bridge. The central arch had to soar 134 metres above sea level to leave clearance for ships. Many of the steel parts were prefabricated in Middlesbrough, but the Australians boast that they made all 6m rivets. It opened in 1932.

The Golden Gate bridge

Stretched across almost a mile of San Franciso Bay, it has been named one of the seven wonders of the modern world by the American Society of Civil Engineers. It opened in 1937. Its colour is officially called Golden Gate Bridge International Orange, and was chosen over conventional silver, black or dark blue after passionate argument: the US Navy is said to have wanted yellow with black stripes to make it more visible to passing ships.

The Forth Railway bridge

Designed by John Fowler and Benjamin Baker, the bridge was opened by the Prince of Wales in 1890 at a party attended by international VIPs including Gustav Eiffel. It became famous as the bridge where painting never stopped. When it did stop, in a cost saving exercise, there was a public outcry and the painting resumed.

The Bridge of Sighs

The Venetian original has been copied in at least half a dozen places, including Las Vegas and St John's College Cambridge. It was built in 1600, by Antonio Contino, to link the dreaded inquisitor's room in the doge's palace with Venice's main prison. Its name came from the prisoners' response to their last glimpse of freedom, through the small barred windows looking out towards the lagoon.

It was completed in 1864, after Brunel's death, re-using the chains from another financially disastrous project, his Hungerford bridge in London. Tower Bridge In 1884 the corporation of London finally resolved to end the reign of the notoriously foul mouthed Thames ferrymen, and build the bridge the city desperately needed. The design, by Horace Jones and John Barry, hid under its charming Gothic exterior the largest and most sophisticated bascule bridge ever built. The hydraulically operated bascules - massive counterweights - still lift the arms to allow ships through, although since 1976 they have been driven by oil and electricity rather than steam. The bridge will close temporarily this year for the first major repairs to the bascules. Pont de Normandie Completed in 1995, this held the previous world record for longest cable-stayed - rather than suspension - bridge. Built at the mouth of the Seine, it takes 10 minutes to drive across and has withstood wind gusts of over 100mph. The Brooklyn bridge Crossing the East River in New York, it opened in 1883, 81 years after the first petition to build it. The first engineer, John A Roebling, was killed in an accident, one of 27 men who died on the site. His son, Washington Roebling, took over, became an invalid during the work, and finished supervising construction from his bedroom, with his wife relaying instructions to the builders and engineers. The Charles bridge, Prague It was begun in 1357, a date chosen, according to legend, because it was numerologically auspicious. The bridge, an outdoor gallery of baroque sculpture, outlasted wars and natural disasters to become the oldest stone bridge in central Europe. It is still the city's main meeting place, and now a haunt of buskers and traders. Sydney Harbour bridge This is the world's widest - though not longest - steel arch bridge. The central arch had to soar 134 metres above sea level to leave clearance for ships. Many of the steel parts were prefabricated in Middlesbrough, but the Australians boast that they made all 6m rivets. It opened in 1932. The Golden Gate bridge Stretched across almost a mile of San Franciso Bay, it has been named one of the seven wonders of the modern world by the American Society of Civil Engineers. It opened in 1937. Its colour is officially called Golden Gate Bridge International Orange, and was chosen over conventional silver, black or dark blue after passionate argument: the US Navy is said to have wanted yellow with black stripes to make it more visible to passing ships. The Forth Railway bridge Designed by John Fowler and Benjamin Baker, the bridge was opened by the Prince of Wales in 1890 at a party attended by international VIPs including Gustav Eiffel. It became famous as the bridge where painting never stopped. When it did stop, in a cost saving exercise, there was a public outcry and the painting resumed. The Bridge of Sighs The Venetian original has been copied in at least half a dozen places, including Las Vegas and St John's College Cambridge. It was built in 1600, by Antonio Contino, to link the dreaded inquisitor's room in the doge's palace with Venice's main prison. Its name came from the prisoners' response to their last glimpse of freedom, through the small barred windows looking out towards the lagoon.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Tory backbencher David Amess outwitted two ex-ministers yesterday by changing the date to debate his bill only minutes before it was due to be discussed in the Commons.
fields.body:
Wrecking move thwarted

Tory backbencher David Amess outwitted two ex-ministers yesterday by changing the date to debate his bill only minutes before it was due to be discussed in the Commons.

Former Tory ministers Eric Forth and David Maclean were caught out as they prepared to wreck the warm homes bill. The two had tabled about 70 amendments. David Hencke

Test case on disability rights

Mentally ill people will get more protection at work as a result of a judgment in the appeal court yesterday on the first test case brought by the disability rights commission.

The court ruled that Pravin Kapadia, a London accountant, should not have been forced to retire from his job at Lambeth borough council because he suffered from depression. John Carvel

Call girls get their cards

Plans to strip prostitutes' cards from phone boxes were unveiled by Home Office minister Charles Clarke yesterday. A new offence will be created to trap those responsible for the estimated 13m cards put up every year, he told MPs.

Guardian sales up

The Guardian sold an average 397,704 copies a day during May - up 2.65% month on month. This was the biggest rise of any UK national daily title.
