webTitle: Bridging modernity gap at a stroke

fields.headline: Bridging modernity gap at a stroke
fields.standfirst: Millennium bridge stands revealed as not just a beautifully economical design but a Flash Gordon blade of light across the Thames
fields.trailText: The Millennium bridge stands revealed not just as a beautifully economical design but as a Flash Gordon blade of light across the Thames.
fields.body:
It was a quintessentially English moment. Just before the firework display to celebrate the completion of the Millennium bridge across the Thames from St Paul's Cathedral to the Tate Modern, a swarm of suits, court heels and wraps emerged from the art gallery to join the plebs at the river's edge.

But then, bridges are about making connections - sometimes the most unlikely. Until the completion of the Millennium bridge, St Paul's Cathedral was affronted by the former Bankside Power Station directly opposite on the south bank of the Thames: a temple raised in praise of the state's God and the City of London's Mammon snubbed by a temple of industrial might and turbine-driven electric energy. On the north bank of the Thames, the densest concentration of capital in the world; on the south bank, one of the capital's poorest boroughs.

Bridges tend to be easier to like than most modern buildings. Architecture is, for better but often for worse, a subjective art and, unlike structural engineering, all too rarely a discipline. Its outward forms in recent, post-modern years have been too often overegged.

The Millennium bridge, in sharp contrast, is a beautifully economical design, its structure all of a piece with its catwalk looks. This is the longest horizontal or lateral suspension bridge yet built. So, it's a daring design, the forces acting within it and holding it together as powerfully stretched as a longbow at Agincourt. It looks so graceful, so natural and easy, and yet the competition winning design, by Lord Foster, Sir Anthony Caro and Chris Wise of the engineers Ove Arup and Partners, was subtly revised and mutated over many months as the challenge of building such a bridge emerged four years ago.

Why difficult? Imagine a conventional suspension bridge: Humber, Severn, Forth road bridges. Their swaying carriageways are held up by steel rods hanging from the great suspension cables that loop between the vertiginously high gateway pylons that mark the entrances to the bridges and act as their anchors and foundations. Now imagine you wanted to make a bridge that didn't sway, was based on the same principles, and needed to be as low as possible for both aesthetic and planning reasons. No one wanted the Millennium bridge to be marred by tall pylons that would have been controversial and probably unpopular.

Now imagine pushing down the pylons at either end of the Severn bridge until they lie flat against Welsh and English soil. Imagine the astonishing forces that would now be transmitted through the suspension cables. Enough, you can't help feeling, to send M4 Mondeo man into orbit if they snapped. These are early days for this model of bridge; if it was to carry the kind of traffic every other London bridge does - a ceaseless flow of lorries, double-deckers, cars, bikes and pedestrians - it would probably give up the ghost.

Now you see what a clever and muscular piece of engineering we have in the Millennium bridge. Where the architect - Foster - has made such a difference is that he has resolved the engineering solution into the most elegant forms. What Foster has brought into the equation is the aesthetic joy in engineering felt by Brunel and Eiffel. Just look at the suspension cables that keep the bridge in tension. They are finished as smoothly as the bodywork of a Mercedes-Benz. So how was it all done? The sketch Foster made at the beginning of the project was based on a discussion with colleagues and clients - the Millennium Commission and sponsors the Financial Times - a slashing, confident stroke of the pencil. A very big pencil was needed to turn this stroke of inspiration into reality, yet many of the best designs of buildings, and to an extent engineering structures, have been made this way.

The sketch was discussed with Chris Wise, the engineer who had realised Foster's communications tower in Barcelona a year or two before the Millennium bridge competition.

If such a simple, single span bridge had been designed using, say, brick, stone or concrete, it would have had to be enormous, of immense mass, to be stable in the fast, tidal waters of the Thames. Without resorting to arches as with most conventional bridges, the only realistic way across was by a walkway supported by tension cables. And only by keeping these as low as possible could the low, clean profile as seen in Foster's sketch function.

Caro worked mostly on the landing piers at either end of the bridge, but he also discussed the overall look of the bridge when complete. The construction of the bridge is, now that you can see it in its naked entirety, pretty much self-explanatory. The concrete piers with their Y-profiles are sunk deep into the riverbed. These support the tense steel cables that carry the walkway. They have been tightened to exacting standards, and a terrorist bomb would be wasting its energy.

Compromises have been made along the way from St Paul's to Tate Modern. The sculpted landing points designed by Caro have given way to more conventional and more generously sweeping ramps and stairs. The timber deck originally envisaged for the walkway has given way to aluminium: timber would have been slippery in poor weather.

The end result, all £18.2m worth, is delightful. Now, in poor weather, the bridge will be all but invisible, except by night when fibre-optics delineate its porcelain-fine profile as precisely as an etcher's line scratched across boxwood.

It is difficult to say who contributed exactly what to the design, but client, architect, engineer and sculptor have known pretty much what they wanted from the outset of the project - a Flash Gordon "blade of light" across the Thames - and this has been the bridge's moral strength. For a small bridge, it is a big gesture, a place for toffs and plebs to criss-cross through the modern London emerging step by bridge by fashionable bar. Now is the time to bridge the gap between the outward form of this new wave of London culture and the tired and deregulated physical structure that holds it awkwardly together.

fields.headline: Hunger strike
fields.standfirst: French mayor protests against village job cuts
fields.trailText: A mayor in northern France was admitted to hospital suffering from exhaustion yesterday, the 17th day of a hunger strike against planned layoffs at a local glassworks, her village's largest employer.
fields.body:
A mayor in northern France was admitted to hospital suffering from exhaustion yesterday, the 17th day of a hunger strike against planned layoffs at a local glassworks, her village's largest employer.

"I'm afraid I'd just reached the end of the line," said Colette Dessaint, 57, the mayor of Masnières near Cambrai. "I'd tried everything to persuade the company there must be another solution, but they did not want to listen. I'd run out of arguments, and I decided in a fraction of a second to stop eating. It was like a last call for help."

Staff at Cambrai hospital said she was "physically weak, but mentally and morally completely determined" to continue her battle against the threatened cuts, which would affect 223 of 650 jobs at the Bormioli-Rocco glassworks and are rumoured to be a prelude to a final closure. The firm refused to comment yesterday.

Ms Dessaint has the backing of Masnières' 2,600 appreciative if surprised inhabitants - French village mayors are not known for self-sacrifice.

"It's extraordinary how popular she is," a hospital spokeswoman said. "The most tiring thing for her now is the number of visitors and phone calls she's getting, not to mention the bouquets of flowers. She even had a message from the employment minister to wish her strength."

fields.headline: Botched injection delays execution
fields.trailText: A 49-year-old killer's execution was delayed for nearly an hour after medical technicians cut his groin and leg trying to find a vein for a lethal injection.
fields.body:
A 49-year-old killer's execution was delayed for nearly an hour after medical technicians cut his groin and leg trying to find a vein for a lethal injection.

Bennie Demps was the third person to be executed since Florida abandoned the electric chair earlier this year to avoid challenges under the US constitution, which prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.

"They butchered me back there," Demps told witnesses on Wednesday just before he died at Florida State prison. "I was in a lot of pain. They cut me in the groin; they cut me in the leg. I was bleeding profusely. This is not an execution, it's murder. This is a low-tech lynching by poison."

Demps, who was sentenced for his part in the murder of another inmate and who had spent more than half his life on death row, died 53 minutes after the time set for his execution. Prison officials said part of the delay was due to the late arrival of paperwork from the supreme court denying a final appeal. "We try to locate a vein as quickly as possible but if we don't, we take as much time as we need," said Debra Buchanan, a spokeswoman for the US department of corrections.

Florida's governor, Jeb Bush, said: "When the execution took place, there was no cruel or unusual punishment. It depends on who you trust. Do you trust a three-time murderer who's on his way out, basically, or a system that has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to make sure this is done right?"

Florida's switch to lethal injection came after a series of ghoulish errors with the electric chair. A murderer bled from the nose as he was being executed a year ago and previously prisoners had caught fire in the chair.

A lawyer for the next man due to die by lethal injection in the state said he would consider using the Demps case in an appeal. "Whatever the method, the department of corrections is not qualified to do the job," said Michael Reiter.

webTitle: Exploitation a world away from the glitz

fields.headline: Exploitation a world away from the glitz
fields.standfirst:
Euro 2000 at the tournament, a sorry tale behind top logos, and back at home, the search for a football free zone
FIFA
Euro2000
fields.trailText: Away from the pitch, an equally crucial battle will be played out as the world's leading sports companies battle for supremacy and exposure in an attempt to assert their brands.
fields.body:
Euro 2000, which kicks off today, involves some of football's highest paid stars. It is expected to draw a global television audience of 7 bn and generate millions of pounds in revenue.

Away from the pitch, however, an equally crucial battle will be played out as the world's leading sports companies battle for supremacy and exposure in an attempt to assert their brands.

And for one Euro 2000 visitor to the Netherlands this week, there lies behind the facade of the tournament a sorry tale of exploitation and oppression that is a world away from the glitzy promotion of some of the planet's best known logos.

For the past few days, Suthasinee Kaewlekai has been touring the competition venues to highlight the conditions in many third world factories where, campaigners claim, leading sports companies are manufacturing their goods with little regard to how workers are treated or what they are paid.

Ms Kaewlekai, 31, worked in a factory in Bangkok, producing goods for Adidas and Nike, two of the biggest sponsors of teams and players in Euro 2000. For less than £1 per day she worked 12 hour shifts seven days a week, producing sportswear, shoes and replica kits for the two companies.

She claimed conditions were poor in the Thai factory and the management was often brutal over meeting large orders within limited time, often denying workers statutory rights such as holidays and sick pay.

Ms Kaewlekai said: "It was not until I got to Europe that I realised how expensive the goods we produced are. I went into a shop and could not believe the cost of a sports shirt - it was almost the same as a month's wage for me.

"Our management did not want us to form unions and they persecuted workers who tried to organise themselves. We were forced to work overtime, often without pay, and were treated very badly."

Ms Kaewlekai was eventually sacked in 1998 along with 23 others after they formed a union in an attempt to win more rights. The factory management claimed she was a disruptive influence.

With around 1m fans expected to arrive in the Netherlands and Belgium for Euro 2000, Ms Kaewlekai was brought to Europe by the Clean Clothes Campaign, which was formed in 1990 and is attempting to raise awareness about the conditions in which leading brand clothes are manufactured.

Esther de Haan, the campaign's co-ordinator, said: "There's lots of money being poured into this tournament by sports companies, but people are working in slave conditions to ensure that these companies make a profit. We want football fans coming for Euro 2000 to be aware of this."

The campaign is working closely with a Thai non-governmental organisation to help the workers form unions.

Most Nike and Adidas goods are produced in third world countries, particularly in Asia, with orders being awarded to locally run factories. Many orders are further sub-contracted at local level, leading to claims that the companies have little idea of where and how their goods are produced.

Adidas and Nike deny ignoring workers' rights for the sake of profit, claiming they have strict labour codes and are constantly monitoring wage levels and conditions to ensure a good working environment.

Peter Csanadi, a spokesman for Adidas said: "We have factories where the conditions are very good and we take this whole issue very seriously. We know that we have had problems, and we had to terminate some contracts because we saw that the management were not interested in good working conditions.

"We work closely with factory management and demand that they ensure good conditions for workers. We also have a team of our own people who go to factories to sort out problems."

Nigel Powell, a spokesman for Nike, said the company also had a team responsible for checking on working conditions. "We exercise our responsiblity to ensure good and safe working conditions. We make sure workers are paid appropriately, and that under-age workers are not employed.

"We have had a code of conduct since 1992 and all our factory partners have to adhere to it," he added. "We are aware that we need to improve but all our factories are regularly inspected by internal and external organisations."

fields.headline: Soul music
fields.trailText: Sue Steward's otherwise excellent obituary of Tito Puente (June 3) was sadly lacking in mention of the great jazzman's finest hour - his appearance on The Simpsons.
fields.body:
Sue Steward's otherwise excellent obituary of Tito Puente (June 3) was sadly lacking in mention of the great jazzman's finest hour - his appearance on The Simpsons. Flush with the anticipated wealth of an oil-strike in the school basement, Lisa hired her hero Puente as Springfield Elementary's new music teacher. But evil local energy monopolist Mr Burns soon relieved the school of its new-found fortune, causing the dismissal of Puente and much other ill-will throughout the town. Many were under suspicion of attempted murder when Mr Burns was subsequently shot, including Puente. Tito's response was: "Sure I hate Mr Burns, but why should I try to kill him, when I can set his soul afire with a slanderous mambo?"
Martyn Giscombe-Smith
London

webTitle: Arts from land of the rising sun rise again

fields.headline: Arts from land of the rising sun rise again
fields.standfirst: The days when the Japanese were dominant in the salerooms as both buyers and sellers may be returning. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: It seems a long time since the Japanese dominated the salerooms either as buyers or sellers. But recently they have been back in force, or at least their wares have.
fields.body:
It seems a long time since the Japanese dominated the salerooms either as buyers or sellers. But recently they have been back in force, or at least their wares have.

On May 18 in New York the revitalised Phillip's auction house held its first-ever sale of 20th century Japanese ceramics and design, with new record prices being set. And in London Christie's held an unprecedented series of sales of things Japanese. This Tuesday there was an Arts of the Samurai sale, with sets of complete armour as well as helmets, masks, swords, saddles and other equipment on offer.

On Wednesday it held the sword fittings, netsuke, inro and pipecases from the Duncan Beresford-Jones Collection auction and a Japanese art and design auction, including ceramics. Again the sales went well with some record prices seen.

A highlight of the New York auction was a monumental stoneware vase by Shoji Hamada. The vase, with its deep olive green glaze, commanded spirited bidding and ultimately sold for a world record price of $63,000, sailing over its pre-auction estimate of $14,000-18,000. Another highlight was an extremely rare early Bernard Leach slipware dish with a design of a leaping deer that commanded a price of $18,400, far exceeding its pre-sale estimate of $5,000-$7,000.

Bernard Leach in a Japanese sale? Surely he is a famous English potter? The point here is that until now, Japanese ceramicists like Shoji Hamada and Kenichi Tomitomo, both of whom were declared "living national treasures" in Japan, were sold at auction in England as studio or craftsmen potters with one-off pieces as opposed to mass produced factory potters, along with other well known names from England and Europe like Michael Cardew, Lucie Rie and Hans Koper.

Bernard Leach became an honorary Japanese because of his association with Japan, generally, and Shoji Hamada, in particular. In 1918, when Bernard Leach was in Japan, he met Hamada in Kyoto, where they worked together fusing what they believed to be the most important elements in eastern and western pottery. In 1920 Leach invited Hamada to England and they established the famous St Ives pottery where they built the first English 3-chamber kiln.

The reason that Leach and Hamada are being marketed in New York is part of the game plan of Bernard Arnault, the French businessman who has bought Phillip's. He wants Phillip's to be up there with Christie's and Sotheby's, the two dominant auction houses which are almost 10 times bigger than Phillip's in terms of sales.This means getting into New York.

The person who almost single-handedly brought the potter out of the studio and into the saleroom is Cyril Frankel, who knew both Lucie Rie and Bernard Leach. He used to work for Bonham's. But Phillip's has poached him and his associate Ben Williams. Having established the market in England, Frankel now seems to have broken through in New York.

But whether you market these potters as Japanese, English or whatever, they have enjoyed a phenomenal rise in prices for their wares, as an auction dedicated to Lucie Rie and Hans Koper at Phillips in London on June 20 will undoubtedly show.

Ten years ago these potters sold for hundreds of pounds. Now they fetch tens of thousands for the better pieces. You can still find a Hamada or Leach from £1,000 but they are drying up.

These modern Japanese potters are a different market to what we usually consider as traditional Japanese ceramics and are subject to some confusion over nomenclature. When American Commodore Perry steamed into Nagasaki in 1853 he re-opened trading links between Japan and the west. Japanese ceramics made for export quickly began to flood the markets of western Europe. They were named after the two ports through which they were shipped, Imari and Satsuma. Imari was often blue or white with mono-colour enamels or glazes, while Satsuma pieces were usually earthenware with a creamy glaze and ornate decoration. These are the pieces found in abundance in antique shops and markets.

Ms Tsumugi Shoji at Barry Davies Oriental Antiques of London says: "There are plenty of pieces dating from the 19th century onwards. They can cost just a few pounds. The market here has not moved at all really in recent years. But there are older pieces which are sought after and they are valuable." By this she means 17th century wares like Nabeshima and Kutani. These were both made for the domestic market. The really top of the range pieces were those made for export, like Arita and Kakiemon.

Confusingly, Arita is an area close to Imari and these pieces are often called Imari. They are characterised, according to Mark Hinton at Christie's, by bold coloured enamelled overglazes on a blue background. Kakiemon, another generic name, also have these striking enamel overglazes. They became very popular in Europe in the 17th century as the Dutch East India Company and other traders shipped them from Japan. Large pieces were often imported to furnish William and Mary houses.

A highly mannered model of an Indian elephant once sold for £749,000. At the Christie's sale on Wednesday a late 17th century puppy with decoration in blue black, yellow and green enamels was estimated at £20,000 to £30,000. Mark Hinton says you can get a nice Kakiemon piece for around £1,500 to £2,000. But the market has begun to move in the past year as the Japanese economy has improved.

 For further information: Christie's, 020-7389-2965, Phillip's, 020-7468-8229 or Barry Davies Oriental Antiques, 020-7408-0207.

webTitle: The case for clamping down on cowboys

fields.headline: The case for clamping down on cowboys
fields.trailText: Victims of unscrupulous wheel-clampers will give at least two cheers for the Court of Appeal's decision in the claim brought by Marina Vine, 61, against the Waltham Forest Council.
fields.body:
Victims of unscrupulous wheel-clampers will give at least two cheers for the Court of Appeal's decision in the claim brought by Marina Vine, 61, against the Waltham Forest Council.

Driving home from hospital, she suddenly felt very ill. Believing it was unsafe for her to continue driving, she pulled into a small carpark. She rushed out of her car, was violently sick and returned three minutes later to find she had been clamped.

Despite explaining her condition to the clamper, he would only release her car on payment of £108. She wrote to the AA. The organisation, looking for a case to test the law, decided the way she had been treated would increase the chances of success. In the county court it emerged there had been a notice on a wall warning that illegal parkers would be clamped. For someone seated in a car it had been hidden by a parked Range Rover and Mrs Vine didn't spot it.

While the county court judge thought any notice was sufficient to justify clamping, the Court of Appeal disagreed. Mrs Vine didn't see it and couldn't reasonably have been expected to and that was crucial. The Court of Appeal contrasted the inadequate notice in this case with one that was clearly displayed at a car park's entrance. Parking in knowledge of such a notice would be tantamount to consenting to one's car being clamped. If it had been established that there is a clear notice, the courts would not be sympathetic to those who deliberately turned blind eyes. The council was ordered to repay her £108.

Reputable organisations may respect the decision and restrict clamping to situations where there is a fair warning. But cowboys who rent wasteland close to shopping centres to lure unwitting motorists to be clamped are unlikely to be deterred.

The approach of a Southampton solicitor whose car was clamped is not feasible for those with little knowledge of the legal system. He got an emergency court injunction requiring the clamper to release it. When the clamper refused the judge had him threatened with imprisonment for contempt.

An AA spokesman said: "This judgment doesn't deal with the problem of over-zealous clamping. The Private Security Bill, now before Parliament, would be an opportunity to introduce some form of licensing."

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Off track
fields.trailText: Credit where it's due: the shambles at Reading station is the responsibility of First Great Western, not Railtrack (Letters, June 7).
fields.body:
Credit where it's due: the shambles at Reading station is the responsibility of First Great Western, not Railtrack (Letters, June 7). The absence of train information is bad enough, but we also have potentially dangerous disinformation. Posters purport to show the station layout, but they don't include the ticket barriers (or "customer outlets") or the unclimbable fence along the footbridge; they do show an exit via the subway which was closed months ago. This is the sort of detail that comes out at public inquiries into major incidents. It's not too late for Redingensians to vote for their Station of the Year!
Adam Sowan
Reading

webTitle: When rustic retreats brings a rural retreat

fields.headline: When rustic retreats brings a rural retreat
fields.standfirst: Booming demand for second homes is fuelling anger as houses are priced beyond the reach of locals. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: Booming demand for second homes is fuelling anger as houses are priced beyond the reach of locals. Elizabeth Langton reports.
fields.body:
The Friday night dash to a refuge by the sea or in the countryside is a weekly ritual for thousands of second home owners. But the growing crisis in rural housing is fuelling demands for draconian measures to curb ownership of second homes in Britain. In Wales, campaigners are urging the government to introduce planning restrictions to safeguard local communities.

Low interest rates have encouraged buyers with high incomes to invest in a country or seaside getaway. Weekenders have poured into beauty spots from Wales to Cornwall, pushing up house prices to such an extent that locals have been priced out of the market.

While the latest furore is unlikely to see a return to cottage burning, there is a growing hostility to homeowners who critics say contribute little to rural communities.

About a quarter of a million people in the country own second homes - 58% of England's boltholes are to be found in the countryside.

One of the greatest bones of contention is the favourable tax rate enjoyed by second home owners: they pay 50% of local authority council tax on the property.

In April the Countryside Agency, the government's adviser on rural matters, called for changes to pave the way for councils to charge the full rate of council tax on second homes.

MP's, many of whom own a home in their constituency and a London pad, are acutely aware that the issue is a sensitive one. Environment minister Micheal Meacher, reported to be the owner of three properties, was pilloried in the press after voicing concerns about second homeownership.

In January this year, he told the environment select committee: "Those people who are privileged and fortunate enough to have more than one house should not prevent others from obtaining one house."

In Newport, Wales, 30% of properties have become second homes. Around Windermere in the Lake District, second homes are reported to make up 16% of the housing stock, in the Isles of Scilly 31% and in North Cornwall more than10%.

This may be enough to send guilty weekenders rushing to estate agents shouting, "sell, sell, sell", but are they really to blame for the housing crisis? Are holiday homes alone forcing families who have lived in villages for generations, out of the countryside?

Not entirely, says the Countryside Agency in its report, the State of the Countryside 2000, published at the end of April.

Rural areas have suffered from the same housing problems as the rest of the UK where low-income families are being squeezed out of popular areas, coupled with the biggest crisis in farming since the second world war. The Countryside Agency claims the "right to buy" policies of the 80s took 90,000 local authority houses out of the sector.

Putting the brakes on second home ownership alone won't solve the problem, says Jo Lavis of the Countryside Agency. However, an influx of part-time residents does have an impact on already fragile communities, she says.

"Second home owners don't use local services - shops, schools, buses - so their viability is reduced."

Campaigners hope the government will come up with some answers in its rural White Paper expected this summer. Meanwhile, turf wars are likely to get worse as the second homes market continues to boom. Low interest rates have encouraged homeowners to snap up country cottages and waterfront flats to use as weekend getaways, say estate agents.

Last year 4% of FPD Savills UK sales of second-hand older homes were sold as second homes. Already this year second homes account for 7.2% of sales. Last year 66% of second home buyers bought properties more than 30 miles away from their main residence compared to 18% who opted for a second home abroad.

There are two sorts of buyers looking for a second home, says Christopher Lacy, head of FPD Savills' Salisbury office. Firstly, there are those looking for a bolthole in the country. These buyers want somewhere accessible and secure so they can lock it up and leave it with confidence.

"While searching for a rural idyll they are unlikely to want anything too isolated, so the edge of a pretty and active village would be ideal.

"These buyers are looking for somewhere that offers all the benefits of country living, but because of the time constraints of their weekly visit, without high maintenance."

Agents have identified another trend: second homes are no longer "make-do" but are often as substantial as the main residence, says Edward Rook of the Knight Frank's country homes department.

"Increasingly, people are buying second homes that fall into the country house category. There are people with sufficient funds to retain a property in London at the same time buy a second home where they spend the weekend or part of the week - say, three days in London and the rest of the time in the country."

Tom Hudson, of Dreweatt Neate's country house and farm agency, has noticed a drop in demand for second homes in the countryside. Rather, "more and more people seem prepared to live in the country and buy a pied a terre in town as a second home and keep their family in the country".

Mr Lacy agrees: "These buyers are looking for a more substantial family home, with good reception rooms for entertaining, possibly with a few acres for ponies and access to good schools."

Hampshire, Berkshire and the Cotswolds are as popular as ever with London homeowners seeking a rural idyll, says Mr Rook.

"West of London is still position A. Kent and Sevenoaks are popular because you can get to Canary Wharf and London is just 30 miles away," he says.

At the top end of the market, Little Egypt, near Tonbridge in Kent, a grade II listed five-bedroom former Yeomans Hall set in 0.43 of an acre, is on the market though FPD Savills for £575,000.

In the town of St Ives in Cornwall, famed as a haven for artists, Millers recently sold a two-bedroom semi-detached home with sea and coastal views market for £155,000.

webTitle: US judges call for legalising of drugs

fields.headline: US judges call for legalising of drugs
fields.standfirst: The restricted sale of heroin, cocaine and cannabis 'would break the vicious cycle of violence'
fields.trailText: American judges are growing so uneasy about their country's drugs laws that they are to go public with their calls for change. The judge who will publish the names of his concerned colleagues is calling for the regulated sale of cocaine, heroin and cannabis as the only way to break the current international cycle of violence and imprisonment.
fields.body:
American judges are growing so uneasy about their country's drugs laws that they are to go public with their calls for change. The judge who will publish the names of his concerned colleagues is calling for the regulated sale of cocaine, heroin and cannabis as the only way to break the current international cycle of violence and imprisonment.

The move comes as an advertising campaign is launched advising jurors to acquit people on drugs possession charges even when they are guilty and as a citizen's commission publishes a report calling for drugs to be treated as a medical and social rather than a criminal problem. It also coincides with this week's report on the enormous disparity between the numbers of black and white people jailed for drug offences.

James P Gray, a superior court judge in Orange County, California told the Guardian yesterday that his new book will contain the names of more than 20 judges who favour a change in the policies, some of whom support his call for legalisation, and are happy to say so publicly. He said that three times that number of judges had given him permission to quote them by name. Many others had told him privately of their belief that a radical change to the drugs laws was urgently needed.

Judge Gray, 55, has been on the bench for 16 years and was previously a prosecuting attorney. His experience on the bench convinced him that the drugs laws were causing more crime than they were stopping and that the "war on drugs" had been a failure.

"There is an increasing num ber of judges who want change," said Judge Gray, the author of the soon-to-be-published Why our Drugs Laws have failed and What we can do about it. "The momentum is truly building, we're making progress and it is no longer a question of if there will be changes, but when."

Judge Gray, who is due to outline his views at a meeting in Los Angeles later this month, is critical of the United States' drugs tsar, General Barry McCaffrey, whose budget has just been increased from $17.8bn a year to $19.2bn (£13bn). He suggests that asking Gen McCaffrey whether the right policy is being pursued is "like asking a barber if one needs a haircut".

The changes that Judge Gray would like to see include the regulated sale to adults of heroin, cocaine and cannabis. No advertising should be allowed, said the judge, so that drugs could be "de-profitised". He also favours needle-exchange programmes. He believes that the likeliest route for change would be for individual states to be allowed to decide on what drugs policy suits them best.

"First of all, we have to legitimise the discussion," he said. He stressed that talking about change did not mean that he or fellow judges condoned the use of drugs, merely that the existing laws were causing more harm than good.

His move comes as the organisation Common Sense for Drug Policy (CSDP) has been placing advertisements in magazines headlined "Just Say Not Guilty".

The ad argues that "the jury right to say 'not guilty' is an essential safeguard against injustice. [This] dates back to English common law and the founding of the United States."

Doug McVay of the Virginia-based CSDP said yesterday that the aim of the advertising campaign was to remind people that "justice is not simply the application of the law. The current situation violates common sense". He said that the FBI made 1,559,000 arrests for drug violations in 1998, 78% of them for possession and the campaign wanted to "plant the seed" in the minds of potential jurors that they could acquit people if they be lieved that the punishment did not fit the crime.

The United States is now building a new prison every week to cope with the people serving mandatory minimum sentences for drug possession. The prison population in the US has risen from just under 200,000 in 1966 to 2m today accounting for a quarter of the entire world's prison population.

A further call for change has come from the influential Institute for Policy Studies in Washington which has published the findings of a citizen's commission on drugs policy entitled The War on Drugs: Addicted to Failure. In the foreword to the report, Professor Craig Reinarman states: "Drugs are richly functional scapegoats. They provide the public with a restricted aperture of attribution in which only the chemical bogey man or lone deviant come into view and the social causes of a cornucopia of complex problems are out of the picture."

The chairperson of the commission, actor, singer and civil rights activist Harry Belafonte, said: "Having grown up in Harlem during the Great Depression, I knew that the real roots of drug abuse and addiction had more to do with poverty, alienation and despair than crimes of malice."

He pointed out that in California five African-Americans were in jail for every one in a state university. The commission has called Gen McCaffrey's "war on drugs" a "monumental failure" and recommends the ending of mandatory minimum sentences for drug cases. It calls on President Clinton to revise the drug laws.

Belafonte's point was emphasised by this week's publication of a report by Human Rights Watch saying that 482 out of every 100,000 African-American men are in prison for a drug crime compared with 36 out of every 100,000 white men. In Illinois, a black man is 57 times more likely to be jailed for drugs than a white man.

The figures were described as a "national scandal" by the organisation, whose report was funded by George Soros's Open Society Institute.
fields.bodyText: American judges are growing so uneasy about their country's drugs laws that they are to go public with their calls for change. The judge who will publish the names of his concerned colleagues is calling for the regulated sale of cocaine, heroin and cannabis as the only way to break the current international cycle of violence and imprisonment. The move comes as an advertising campaign is launched advising jurors to acquit people on drugs possession charges even when they are guilty and as a citizen's commission publishes a report calling for drugs to be treated as a medical and social rather than a criminal problem. It also coincides with this week's report on the enormous disparity between the numbers of black and white people jailed for drug offences. James P Gray, a superior court judge in Orange County, California told the Guardian yesterday that his new book will contain the names of more than 20 judges who favour a change in the policies, some of whom support his call for legalisation, and are happy to say so publicly. He said that three times that number of judges had given him permission to quote them by name. Many others had told him privately of their belief that a radical change to the drugs laws was urgently needed. Judge Gray, 55, has been on the bench for 16 years and was previously a prosecuting attorney. His experience on the bench convinced him that the drugs laws were causing more crime than they were stopping and that the "war on drugs" had been a failure. "There is an increasing num ber of judges who want change," said Judge Gray, the author of the soon-to-be-published Why our Drugs Laws have failed and What we can do about it. "The momentum is truly building, we're making progress and it is no longer a question of if there will be changes, but when." webTitle: A taste of the bourgeois charms of the Brecht household

fields.headline: A taste of the bourgeois charms of the Brecht household
fields.trailText: I'd kill for Helene Weigel's crispy deep-fried chicken. But I could take or leave her vinaigrette and crouton salad.
fields.body:
I'd kill for Helene Weigel's crispy deep-fried chicken. But I could take or leave her vinaigrette and crouton salad.

No. Bertolt Brecht's wife never cooked me lunch. Though, in a way, she did - and from beyond the grave.

Looking for a place to eat, my assistant and I glimpsed some tables set out in a cobbled courtyard off Chausseestrasse, just to the east of the line of the old Berlin Wall.

Leafing through the menu, it dawned on us that we had stumbled into Brecht's former residence and that the foundation running it was helping to balance the books by serving visitors his favourite dishes, prepared according to the letter of his wife's recipes.

Brecht lived at 125 Chausseestrasse from 1953 until his death in 1956. Weigel stayed on until her death in 1971. They are buried together in the cemetery alongside the Dorotheenstädtische Friedhof, which is the final home of a number of other luminaries including Hegel.

It turns out that the playwright and his actress-manager wife are physically closer in death than they were in life. The guided tour of their house reveals that they occupied separate quarters on different floors. It is not the only revelation.

You learn from the carefully preserved book shelves that Brecht and Weigel brought back from their American exile a passion for cheap thrillers. And you see that even the most avant-garde of people cannot help but be prisoners of the aesthetic and social conventions of their times.

By today's standards, the Brechts had a very traditional marriage - a point which seems to have caught the attention of the artist Marc Chagall. He did a little sketch, which Brecht hung at the foot of his bed, showing the playwright stretched full length on the ground while Weigel hurries from an oven with what looks like a plate of cakes.

It was she who saw to the decoration and furnishing of the house and while much of it is in exquisite taste, the conservatory hosts a collection of pewter plates and jugs and a green glass fishing float of the sort you once saw in cheap Italian restaurants. It is pure 1950s middle-brow.

Brecht, as you might expect, enjoyed a privileged status in the defunct German Democratic Republic (GDR). Chausseestrasse 125 was given to him so that he would be near the Berliner Ensemble, which is about a quarter of an hour's walk away. Yet he never walked, always preferring to drive.

What passed for the good life in the former GDR was nevertheless a long way short of the comfort and convenience enjoyed by many lesser artists in the west. With its framed photograph of Lenin, its distinctly austere decoration and its glorious, pre-Sputnik era television set, the home which Brecht and Weigel shared is also a monument to an entire culture whose foundations collapsed in the space of a few months.

Not that the culture itself disappeared. Visitors to Berlin are struck by how difficult it is to see where the Wall once ran.

For those of us who live here what is equally striking is how different the two halves of the city remain outside a relatively small area in the centre.

I know someone who says he can tell the men apart by their shoes. I would not go so far as that, but I reckon I can tell the women apart by their make-up.

With their simpler yet warier air, all but the the youngest easterners still give an impression of being semi-detached members of the capitalist world into which they tumbled 10 years ago. Most say they would not like to turn back the clock, yet many resent the way in which the conquering westerners have swept aside the easterners' identity.

The Brechthaus is as good a symbol as you will find to that uneasy ambivalence. Notwithstanding the commercialisation of Helene Weigel's cookbook, it exists not to embrace capitalism, but to celebrate the lives of two of its more dogged opponents - and certainly the service at table on the day we dropped in gave little quarter to decadent bourgeois expectations.

fields.headline: Publican cleared of drinker's death
fields.trailText: A publican and her husband who goaded a drunken customer into drinking a fatal cocktail of spirits were cleared of manslaughter yesterday after a judge directed a jury to acquit them.
fields.body:
A publican and her husband who goaded a drunken customer into drinking a fatal cocktail of spirits were cleared of manslaughter yesterday after a judge directed a jury to acquit them.

In the first case of its kind involving a pub licensee, Mr Justice Turner said that in law Teresa Browning, 33, and her husband Kevin, 35, had no duty of care to their customers and could not be held responsible for their actions.

But he criticised the couple and said they bore a moral responsibility for the death of Barry Gates, 44, an odd job man who regularly drank at the Kingston Tavern in Portsmouth where Mrs Browning was licensee.

Mr Justice Turner said his decision did not mean the couple had not committed "that which may be justly criticised as being reprehensible, utterly wrong and irresponsible".

Mrs Browning wept and clutched her husband's hand as they were acquitted at Winchester crown court.

The judge said: "I would not want to leave this case without condemning as roundly as I can the conduct of these two defendants. They must and do bear a heavy moral responsibility for the unfortunate death of Mr Gates. But cases in these courts are not determined by such considerations.

"This has not been a case in which duty of care has been found to exist on the part of those who supply, by way of trade or profession, alcoholic drink to those who are willing to consume it." He said Mr Gates alone took the decision to consume the drink.

But he added that it would be a matter of "grave concern" if the couple were ever again involved in the management of licensed premises, although he had no powers to ban them.

The court had heard how the couple had encouraged Mr Gates to drink a pint glass filled with double measures of whisky, brandy, gin, Bacardi and vodka for a bet. They allegedly offered him £27 if he could down the drink.

When he hesitated, the couple egged him on and Mrs Browning drew pictures of chickens on pieces of paper and placed them in front of him, it was alleged.

Once Mr Gates had finished the drink, he fell off a bar stool and hit his head. The couple joked about his condition and took photographs. They then propped him up on a bench inside the pub, where he sat snoring.

Later, when they realised that he was no longer snoring, he was taken to the Queen Alexandra hospital, Cosham, where he was pronounced dead within half an hour of arrival.

On the day he died, Mr Gates who was described as a heavy drinker, had visited another pub with his flatmate, and had drunk pints of lager.

A autopsy showed that he died of acute alcohol poisoning which caused him to stop breathing. His blood alcohol level was nearly five times more than the drink drive limit and he had inhaled his own vomit.

Outside court, Mr Browning's solicitor, David Lancaster, said the publican was pleased by the outcome.

"He has lost a close friend in Mr Gates and his livelihood and his marriage seem to have collapsed. He has suffered from depression and has had thoughts of suicide," Mr Lancaster said.

webTitle: Double take as modern art re-examines Old Masters

fields.headline: Double take as modern art re-examines Old Masters
fields.trailText: In boxing terms, it is like Muhammad Ali squaring up to Joe Louis to decide who really was the greatest. For the past year, 24 of the world's most distinguished living artists have been testing their talent and technique against Old Masters.
fields.body:
In boxing terms, it is like Muhammad Ali squaring up to Joe Louis to decide who really was the greatest. For the past year, 24 of the world's most distinguished living artists have been testing their talent and technique against Old Masters.

In the dead of night, with only the occasional security guard for company, painters such as Lucian Freud and Howard Hodgkin have slipped into the National Gallery to sketch and measure themselves against the canvasses which changed the history of art.

Next week, the results go on show in Encounters, one of the most eagerly awaited exhibitions of the year.

Such a show, matching the greatest artists of our time with the greatest of all time, could only be staged at the National Gallery, according to its director Neil MacGregor.

"This collection has always been the one to which great artists have come to compare themselves. Nowhere else in the world can you see artists from Giotto to Monet in such depth. Monet himself came here in 1871 to see Turner and then painted his famous Thames view in response to his work. We did not have to prompt any of the artists at all. They knew straight away which works they wanted to respond to."

What is still more remarkable about the show is that the artists - who include the likes of David Hockney, Louise Bourgeois, Claes Oldenburg, Anthony Caro, Euan Uglow, RB Kitaj, Paula Rego, Cy Twombly and Jasper Johns - agreed "without the slightest hesitation" to do their paintings and sculptures for free.

Mr MacGregor said that even if the gallery were allowed to commission new paintings, which it is not, it could never have afforded to pay for them. "The costs, if we had to assemble them ourselves, are beyond thinking about," he said.

Several of the artists are matched with painters to whom links are clear. However, some of the most striking results have come through the more unlikely combinations such as Frank Auerbach with Constable's landscapes.

The experience has pushed a few of the beyond their usual boundaries. Hodgkin's Seurat's Bathers, after the French pointilliste's iconic Bathers At Asnières, is the biggest picture he has ever painted.

Richard Morphet, who is curating the show, said Hodgkin had wanted to paint a version of the picture for more than 30 years. "Despite many differences, the two painters' outlook and practice have much in common. To both the work of great classical artists, not least that of Poussin, is an inspiration. Like Seurat, Hodgkin works secretively. Paintings by Seurat could often take two years to complete, the same - and sometimes longer - is true of Hodgkin."

Encounters, New Art from Old, which is interspersed through the gallery's permanent collection, runs from Wednesday until September 17, and is free.

webTitle: Hey Preston! Security guard jailed for disorganised crime

fields.headline: Hey Preston! Security guard jailed for disorganised crime
fields.trailText: When security guard Allen Mills became annoyed by his colleague he made the decision of a lifetime - to go on the run with £22,000 cash stolen from his own armoured van.
fields.body:
When security guard Allen Mills became annoyed by his colleague he made the decision of a lifetime - to go on the run with £22,000 cash stolen from his own armoured van.

But he had to choose where to lie low while the heat died down. He eschewed exotic locations around the world which his new wealth might have opened up for him in favour of the Holiday Inn Express in Preston, Lancashire. And he got caught.

Police raided his £70 a night room there and found Mills surrounded by bags stuffed full of used banknotes. Cardiff crown court heard yesterday that Mills confessed to police that he turned to crime on the spur of the moment because his co-driver was irritating him.

Sentencing Mills, 28, to two and a half years' imprisonment for theft, Judge David Wynn Morgan told him: "It seems you did not think about this crime, or you would have arranged a more sophisticated plan."

Mills's barrister, Charles Cook, said: "He had been off work for four months and did not expect to be driving on his first day back. His colleague's conversation had a fraying effect on him."

Mills's colleague, David Morgan, was making a collection of cash from a business in South Wales when Mills snapped and drove off in the white Securicor armoured van. He dumped it near his home in Caerphilly. He pulled £22,000 out of the £462,000 the van was carrying and realised the first big gap in his criminal plan - how to make a getaway.

Mills called his brother, Paul, to get him to pick him up in his car.

The two brothers drove 200 miles, with the security guard deciding to stay in Preston.

Mills bought himself a portable TV so he he could watch news programmes about his theft, which was his first offence.

Meanwhile, his brother decided to drive back home to South Wales where police were waiting, and confessed where Mills was staying.

All but £3,000 of the money was recovered, it was stated.

Paul Mills, 25, who admitted impeding his brother's arrest and handling stolen money, was jailed for six months.

fields.headline: 'Modest' spinsters leave £27m to charity
fields.trailText: On the steep streets and narrow lanes of Highgate, north London, elderly spinsters Mary Coyle and Florence Reakes barely warranted a second glance.
fields.body:
On the steep streets and narrow lanes of Highgate, north London, elderly spinsters Mary Coyle and Florence Reakes barely warranted a second glance.

Even those who knew them well assumed they were retired and of modest means, passing their days happily as stalwart cake bakers, cleaners and dedicated parishioners at St Joseph's Roman Catholic church on Highgate Hill.

Yet the pair were far from impecunious pensioners. Yesterday it emerged that between them they bequeathed £27m to charity.

Ms Coyle, a retired nurse known locally as Kathleen, died this year aged 88 and her will, published this week, leaves an £18,62,469 estate to the Albert Hunt Trust, a charity fund established by her and her friend in 1979.

Ms Reakes, who died in 1996 aged 93, left more than £8m to the trust which is named after her uncle. In the four years since her death that sum has swollen to £17m, increasing the trust's total fund to more than £35m.

Each year the interest accrued by the fund, which is managed royal bankers Coutts and Co and a board of trustees, is distributed to more than 250 small charities nationwide, including youth projects and schemes for the homeless.

Neighbours of the pair who for 18 years shared a four-bedroomed flat at Highpoint were astonished to discover that their neighbours were sitting on a golden nest egg.

"I knew Kathleen as a charming, caring and delightful neighbour," said Thelma Anson.

"She and Florence lived very modestly and one never thought of money in relation to them. It came as something of a shock to discover she had left all that money. I know a million is not much these days, but you would not imagine she had even that much.

"I think its wonderful that it has all gone to charity. She did an enormous amount of work at the church, but it seems she must have spent a significant amount of her time in retirement turning her money into more money."

Renee Clasen, a friend of the women for nearly 20 years, said: "They lived fairly frugally really. There was no outward sign of wealth although I was aware they had some money."

Another neighbour said: "I knew there was some money - she had no dependants so there had to be - but I had no idea it was £35m!"

Other accquaintances confirmed the view. In addition to indulging her passion for the church, Ms Coyle was in charge of Highpoint's two and a half acres and was not averse to mucking in with the gardeners - she was a shrewd investor.

Evan Haora, co-ordinator of the Highgate private hospital where Ms Coyle spent the last four years of her life following a stroke, said she was regularly in contact with her bankers.

"Right to the end she had someone from her bank who would visit on a regular basis."

"She was sharp right to the end. She had a very dry sense of humour. Sometimes you would be half way out of her room thinking, 'Did she really just say what I think she said?', and you would turn round and she would have this wry smirk on her face."

Ms Coyle, who was born in Ireland, is understood to have inherited a small sum on the death of her parents which she augmented by the sale of property in Ireland in the 1970s.

Father Daniel Donovan, parish priest of St Joseph's, knew Ms Coyle for 12 years, but was surprised by the value of the estate. "Both she and Ms Reakes were involved in all sorts of parishioner activities. Miss Coyle helped to clean the church and baked cakes for us, but we would never have known that they had that kind of money," he said.

A spokeswoman for Coutts said the women had deliberately avoided publicity.

"All we can say is that it is a private trust set up to make small donations benefiting a large number of smaller charities rather than one cause."
fields.bodyText: On the steep streets and narrow lanes of Highgate, north London, elderly spinsters Mary Coyle and Florence Reakes barely warranted a second glance. Even those who knew them well assumed they were retired and of modest means, passing their days happily as stalwart cake bakers, cleaners and dedicated parishioners at St Joseph's Roman Catholic church on Highgate Hill. Yet the pair were far from impecunious pensioners. Yesterday it emerged that between them they bequeathed £27m to charity. Ms Coyle, a retired nurse known locally as Kathleen, died this year aged 88 and her will, published this week, leaves an £18,62,469 estate to the Albert Hunt Trust, a charity fund established by her and her friend in 1979. Ms Reakes, who died in 1996 aged 93, left more than £8m to the trust which is named after her uncle. In the four years since her death that sum has swollen to £17m, increasing the trust's total fund to more than £35m. Each year the interest accrued by the fund, which is managed royal bankers Coutts and Co and a board of trustees, is distributed to more than 250 small charities nationwide, including youth projects and schemes for the homeless. Neighbours of the pair who for 18 years shared a four-bedroomed flat at Highpoint were astonished to discover that their neighbours were sitting on a golden nest egg. "I knew Kathleen as a charming, caring and delightful neighbour," said Thelma Anson. "She and Florence lived very modestly and one never thought of money in relation to them. It came as something of a shock to discover she had left all that money. I know a million is not much these days, but you would not imagine she had even that much. "I think its wonderful that it has all gone to charity. She did an enormous amount of work at the church, but it seems she must have spent a significant amount of her time in retirement turning her money into more money." Renee Clasen, a friend of the women for nearly 20 years, said: "They lived fairly frugally really. There was no outward sign of wealth although I was aware they had some money." Another neighbour said: "I knew there was some money - she had no dependants so there had to be - but I had no idea it was £35m!" Other accquaintances confirmed the view. In addition to indulging her passion for the church, Ms Coyle was in charge of Highpoint's two and a half acres and was not averse to mucking in with the gardeners - she was a shrewd investor. Evan Haora, co-ordinator of the Highgate private hospital where Ms Coyle spent the last four years of her life following a stroke, said she was regularly in contact with her bankers. "Right to the end she had someone from her bank who would visit on a regular basis." "She was sharp right to the end. She had a very dry sense of humour. Sometimes you would be half way out of her room thinking, 'Did she really just say what I think she said?', and you would turn round and she would have this wry smirk on her face." Ms Coyle, who was born in Ireland, is understood to have inherited a small sum on the death of her parents which she augmented by the sale of property in Ireland in the 1970s. Father Daniel Donovan, parish priest of St Joseph's, knew Ms Coyle for 12 years, but was surprised by the value of the estate. "Both she and Ms Reakes were involved in all sorts of parishioner activities. Miss Coyle helped to clean the church and baked cakes for us, but we would never have known that they had that kind of money," he said. A spokeswoman for Coutts said the women had deliberately avoided publicity. "All we can say is that it is a private trust set up to make small donations benefiting a large number of smaller charities rather than one cause."

webTitle: Mystery portrait may be of Jane Austen's beloved sister

fields.headline: Mystery portrait may be of Jane Austen's beloved sister
fields.trailText: A portrait of a plumply pretty young woman in a white dress will go on display for the first time next week. Nothing is certain about her. The public will be invited to judge whether she is a lost literary heroine, the only known portrait of Jane Austen's beloved companion and correspondent, her only sister Cassandra.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A portrait of a plumply pretty young woman in a white dress will go on display for the first time next week. Nothing is certain about her. The public will be invited to judge whether she is a lost literary heroine, the only known portrait of Jane Austen's beloved companion and correspondent, her only sister Cassandra.

If it is Cassandra the picture is a treasure, and hugely valuable in the hectic collectors' market for Jane Austen memorabilia. If not, it is a reasonably competent amateur water colour, perhaps worth a few hundred pounds on a generous day.

Cassandra is a crucial figure in the Jane Austen pantheon: without her there would be almost no personal information about the country spinster who wrote Pride and Prejudice, Emma, Sense and Sensibility and the other novels which made her world famous. The sisters exchanged gossipy letters every day they were apart. Jane died in Cassandra's arms in 1817, and until her own death in 1845 Cassandra carefully kept her personal possessions, letters, journals, and drafts of her work, and bequeathed them as precious keepsakes to her nephews and nieces.

She also makes biographers grind their teeth: a very private person, she carefully censored personal details which she felt were unbecoming, the very details biographers crave. It has been suggested the evidence for at least one unhappy love affair, illness, and depression have been scratched out of the picture.

The picture has come on loan to the Jane Austen House museum, in Chawton, Hampshire, with gaping holes in its provenance.

In 1884 Lord Brabourne, a great nephew who knew her well, and was preparing a book of her letters, wrote to his publishers: "I find I have a picture of Cassandra." The book appeared without her, and the picture was presumably sold with the rest of his estate after his death in 1893.

In the 1930s Robert Tritton bought the home of one of Jane Austen's brothers, and began collecting Austen memorabilia - including, it is believed, though there are no records of the purchase, this picture. The family kept it after an auction of the contents in the 1980s, and a descendant has now offered it on loan to the museum.

Even at the museum opinion is divided.

Peter Russell-Jones, one of the trustees, is convinced it is Cassandra, possibly drawn by her brother Henry. He thinks the prominently drawn necklace is coral, possibly a present from her sea-faring brothers.

He compared the portrait with the only portrait of Jane Austen in her lifetime, a more amateurish sketch by Cassandra, which is now in the National Portrait Gallery.

"There was a really striking resemblance, not just in the details of the dress, and the cap, which is virtually identical, but in the lines of the face and head. When I superimposed one on the other the match was remarkable."

The curator, Tom Carpenter, is more doubting. "We really don't know: we can say this may be the picture that was traditionally said to be Cassandra, but it is not honest to say any more than that. We will invite the public to decide, and hope somebody will be able to give us more information about it."

webTitle: Village at the sharp end of the UN map makers' pen

fields.headline: Village at the sharp end of the UN map makers' pen
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Eyes straining behind bottle-thick spectacles, and spotless white keffiyeh set off by the fug from dozens of burning tractor tyres, a venerable village chieftain led his people to their date with destiny yesterday.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Ghajar, Israel-Lebanon border
fields.body:
Eyes straining behind bottle-thick spectacles, and spotless white keffiyeh set off by the fug from dozens of burning tractor tyres, a venerable village chieftain led his people to their date with destiny yesterday.

Their unwanted suitors flew in on a white helicopter: the UN cartographers who are to slice this village in two, apportioning half to Lebanon and half to Israel.

The division is part of the endgame of Israel's withdrawal from south Lebanon. If the UN is to deploy an expanded peacekeeping force in south Lebanon - which Israel desperately wants - the map men must first agree that Israel has abandoned every last scrap of its former occupation zone, withdrawing to the border sketched out in 1923 by French and British bureaucrats.

For the village chief, Suleiman Khatib, the larger concerns mean a second death of the village he has led for 42 years. The first came in 1967, when the village was lost to Syria, its 1,700 inhabitants torn from their families on the other side of a hostile frontier.

Since Tuesday, when UN and Israeli officials permitted the latest calamity to be visited on Ghajar, men, women and children have stood at the gates of the village - even the smallest of them armed with staves, flimsy defences against map makers from another land.

As the helicopter clattered overhead, they shrieked: "We will not be parted from our lands." Almost instantly bravado gave way to sobs. But the villagers could claim a minor victory; the UN team was forced to put off their visit for one more day.

Yesterday's tumult at Ghajar is only one of the obstacles to an orderly redrawing of the frontier. On the Lebanese side of the border yesterday, UN officials interrupted their work because of objections from the Beirut government.

To the west of Ghajar, the Israeli government is balking at UN demands that it dismantle four buildings of the Misgav Am kibbutz which stand over the 1923 line. A few miles to the east, the Beirut government and the Hizbullah guerrillas who now rule south Lebanon are demanding that Israel evacuate the Shebaa farms. The UN does not endorse their claim.

But nowhere will the border be as steeped in pain and loss as Ghajar. According to crumpled maps now passing hand-to-hand, the new border will cut straight through the middle of the village - a miniature version of the Berlin Wall, bisecting the school football ground, and the $250,000 (£166,000) home it took Ahmed Suleiman 10 years to build.

"My house will be crushed and destroyed. "It is a very sad thing - no, crazy," he said before dissolving in tears. "We are human beings. We are not stones and we are not trees. Imagine a father is here in his house, and he becomes Lebanese, but his son is Israeli."

Most of the villagers feel they are Syrian. They watch Syrian TV and they are followers of the Alawite sect of Islam as is Syria's President Hafez al-Assad.

Although they speak Hebrew and have taken Israeli citizenship, they remain on the very fringes of the Jewish state. Across the Hazbani, a stream whose gorge forms a natural boundary for the village, Lebanon begins. Other nearby lands are desolate, strewn with mines from the 1967 war. As in 1967, during this moment of truth, the people of Ghajar feel very much alone, said Mr Khatib.

At the end of that war none of the three countries which collide near this sliver of land was interested in Ghajar. Syria's army was far away and the Israeli conquerors saw no strategic gain here, so Mr Khatib led a delegation of notables across the Hazbani to Lebanon, seeking a country that would take his people in.

The Lebanese authorities were not welcoming, Mr Khatib remembers. "They told us: go back to your village and stay in your homes. If you cross that stream again, we will shoot you."

fields.headline: 'Please don't climb our rock'
fields.trailText: The traditional owners of the world's largest monolith hope that the debut appearance of the Olympic torch here this week will help get the message out that their most sacred of sites should not be climbed on.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn  at Ayers Rock, central Australia
fields.body:
The traditional owners of the world's largest monolith hope that the debut appearance of the Olympic torch here this week will help get the message out that their most sacred of sites should not be climbed on.

The steep ascent of the 348-metres high Ayers Rock is on most tourists' itineraries, despite the death of at least one climber a year, but the indigenous Anangu want it to stop.

Cassidy Uluru, the youngest of three brothers named after the rock and who was involved in the lighting of the torch on Thursday, said the debate about whether to climb was a matter of manners.

"If I go to another man's land, I would ask that man how I should act on his land," he said through an interpreter. "If I go to Melbourne or Sydney, I would ask someone who lives there what is right to do."

The Anangu are also lobbying for the colonial name, Ayers Rock, given by early explorers to commemorate a long-forgotten state governor, to be dropped in favour of its ancient title, Uluru.

It is estimated that fewer than half of the 400,000 people who venture deep into the red centre of this continent each year try to climb the rock, but to many white Australians it is almost a rite of passage.

The traditional owners of the surrounding world heritage site, Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park, which is jointly managed with the federal government, have not banned the rock's ascent but discourage it for spiritual and safety reasons.

The ascent is closed when winds are high or temperatures exceed 36C (97F) but some locals are concerned that closing the climb altogether will damage business. One tour operator said the debate was driven by politics as much as beliefs. "There are two things people come for and that's to climb the rock and see the Aborigines," he said. "They won't take the climb away as they'd lose too much money."

webTitle: Police look into baby's death in hospital

fields.headline: Police look into baby's death in hospital
fields.trailText: Police have been called in to investigate a consultant anaesthetist after a four-month-old baby died during a routine operation at a children's hospital.
fields.body:
Police have been called in to investigate a consultant anaesthetist after a four-month-old baby died during a routine operation at a children's hospital.

Mark Baxandall, a paediatric specialist, was suspended from Booth Hall children's hospital in Manchester last November following the death of Ijaz Ahmed, during a routine operation to correct a cleft lip and palate.

Dr Baxandall was sent home by the hospital trust and suspended from his job following the baby's death.

The boy's family returned to their home in Pakistan after their son died, but they have now returned to this country and have been contacted by the hospital trust about the investigation.

The request to carry out a criminal investigation has been made seven months after the baby's death by the Manchester coroner, Leonard Gorodkin, who has passed on a file to detectives.

It is not clear whether an inquest will take place until the criminal investigation has been completed.

Police officers have visited the hospital in north Manchester this week as part of inquiries into Dr Baxandall.

Hospital officials are also investigating another incident involving Dr Baxandall last year.

Another child almost died during surgery at Booth Hall hospital in March last year in an operation where Dr Baxandall was the anaesthetist. The child has not been named.

A retired consultant anaesthetist from Glasgow has already been appointed by the trust to investigate both cases involving Dr Baxandall.

The hospital's inquiry has been put on hold while the criminal investigation takes place.

Greater Manchester police confirmed yesterday that they are concentrating their inquiries on the death of Ijaz Ahmed.

The General Medical Council has also told the hospital it intends to investigate under its conduct and performance procedures.

The criminal investigation comes as NHS consultants are under increasing pressure to be accountable following the case of the gynaecologist Rodney Ledward, who botched operations during 16 years at a hospital in Kent.

Dr Baxandall has worked at Booth Hall hospital for three years. He has been qualified as an anaesthetist for 17 years.

A spokesman for Greater Manchester police said: "We can confirm that police officers are looking into the circumstances surrounding the death of a child at Booth Hall last year."

A spokesman for the Manchester Children's Hospitals NHS trust said: "We are aware of the Greater Manchester police involvement and we will co-operate fully with any investigation."

Dr Baxendall is a member of the Medical Defence Union, which assists medical professionals who are accused of misconduct or charged with criminal offences.

A spokeswoman for the MDU said: "Dr Baxendall is a member and we will be assisting him."

fields.headline: Computer failure brings air chaos
fields.trailText: A computer failure at London's air traffic control headquarters left thousands of travellers stranded yesterday, with flights delayed and cancelled across Europe.
fields.body:
A computer failure at London's air traffic control headquarters left thousands of travellers stranded yesterday, with flights delayed and cancelled across Europe.

One of the key systems at the West Drayton control centre went down at peak time during the morning, forcing staff to fill in forms manually.

The failure coincided with thunderstorms which caused a further backlog, leading to what one airline source described as chaos at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted airports.

The problem came at a bad time for the national air traffic control service, which is being groomed by the government for privatisation.

Any apparent weakness in the service's operations could affect its value - the government believes it is worth more than £500m.

A spokesman for the air traffic control service said: "A system failure, together with severe thunderstorms over the North Sea, the UK, France and Germany has led to serious disruption."

He added: "There were no safety implications because contact between air traffic control and aircraft was not affected."

Hundreds of short-haul flights were affected by delays, typically lasting between an hour and two hours.

British Airways was forced to cancel 12 flights and a source within the airline described the situation as appalling.

"It will take us two days to get things straight in Europe - the crews and the planes are all in the wrong places."

Although the system was only out of action for about 20 minutes, the knock-on effect was enormous.

Industry sources said that in some cases, fully loaded planes were forced to wait on the tarmac for two hours before taking off.

For a period during the morning, Heathrow ran out of gates and incoming planes faced long hold-ups in allowing passengers to disembark.

Airlines are likely to have suffered considerable financial losses as a result of yesterday's disarray.

BA declined to comment on whether it might seek compensation from the air traffic control service.

BA added that passengers should expect further "slight delays" today.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText:
Immigrants flee from camp.
About 150 illegal immigrants escaped from a detention camp near Derby, Western Australia, yesterday after two break-outs the day before at another centre in which three guards were injured.
fields.body:
Immigrants flee from camp.
About 150 illegal immigrants escaped from a detention camp near Derby, Western Australia, yesterday after two break-outs the day before at another centre in which three guards were injured.

About 500 who fled the Woomera camp in South Australia on Thursday in protest over conditions and the time taken to process applications for refugee status were camped out in a car park yesterday. Most of the escapees were from Iraq, Iran and Afghanistan. Reuters, Canberra

Ethiopia denies assault on port

Eritrea said yesterday that Ethiopia had unleashed an "all-out attack" along the southern front close to Eritrea's Red Sea port of Assab, marking a new escalation in their border war.

Ethiopia, which said the war was effectively ended late last month when Eritrea was forced out of disputed border areas, insisted it was responding to Eritrean attacks and denied launching an assault for control of the port. Reuters, Asmara

PM of Solomon Islands freed

Warring militias in the Solomon Islands agreed yesterday to a 14-day ceasefire to allow a visit by Commonwealth foreign ministers this weekend aimed at restoring peace after an attempted coup.

The prime minister, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, was released from house arrest after being detained on Monday by militiamen who took over Honiara, the capital. Reuters, Brisbane

Lagos hit by general strike

A general strike over sharp fuel price increases halted all flights at Nigerian airports yesterday and the action spread to seaports and the oil industry, witnesses and officials said.

The commercial capital, Lagos, was paralysed for the second day by the disruption. Reuters, Lagos

Inmates escape in helicopter

A gunman commandeered a helicopter and plucked three inmates from the roof of their prison in central France yesterday, officials said. They said guards at the Yzeure prison opened fire but could not stop the escape. The helicopter later landed in a field west of Lyon, and the four men, one of whom was serving a life sentence, fled in stolen cars. The pilot was shot in the knee. Reuters, Paris
