fields.headline: A deplorable slur
fields.trailText: Lord Jenkins of Hillhead has compared Tony Blair's caution on Europe to the Victorian attitude to piano legs.
fields.body:
 Lord Jenkins of Hillhead has compared Tony Blair's caution on Europe to the Victorian attitude to piano legs. Is this not a deplorable slur? On the Victorians, I mean, not on Blair. I thought I had read not long ago that the notion that Victorians used to clothe the legs of their pianos in the interests of modesty was a myth cooked up in the present century*. Jenkins is an historian, so he ought to know the truth of the matter, but maybe, like so many rampant Europhiles he let his enthusiasm sweep him away. The usual prizes are offered for the first piece of evidence that the table legs story is true.

I have had to show a red card to the pedant who so often infests these pages. He is banned for two weeks. This is because while complaining of something or other, he used the word preprepenultimate. A reader points out, correctly, that there isn't a word prepenultimate, so there can't be a word preprepenultimate either. He cites a song by Flanders and Swann, which I fear to quote because of what happens to people who quote from songs, but which I think I can say contains the word antepenultimate. So, logically, the word employed by the pedant should have been anteantepenultimate, odd though it looks on the page. I have also had a complaint about my reference to Drogheda, which I said was pronounced to rhyme with embroider. So it is: but that does not mean it's correct to do so. "The main stress", I am now advised "is on the first syllable. The name should be said as fol lows DRO (drop without the p) HED (with a schwa) UH (another schwa)." (A schwa by the way is defined as an indistinct vowel sound, shown in Hebrew by two dots. No, I didn't know that either.) Some pronounce the -gh- in Drogheda as they would an aitch, others as in the Scottish "loch" or the Irish "lough". "Drogheda rhymes with embroider," says my informant, "like trumpeter rhymes with sequoia". What a beautiful sentence! It reads like the second half of a couplet. "Here is a rule I've espoused/ To guard me against paranoia./ Drogheda rhymes with embroider/ Like trumpeter rhymes with sequoia." Some also believe . .

A lawyer writes: I act for the River Og. Our attention has been drawn to the fact that in your column last Saturday you wrote in approving terms of our competitors the Ant, Can, and Len as if commending their brevity. My client would like to point out that "Og" takes up even less space. Few rivers have names of a mere two letters. As you probably know, my client having risen betimes near Ogbourne St George in Wiltshire flows salubriously northwards before merging on amicable terms with the Kennet just east of Marlborough. We await your apology. Thank you. That will be £70.

A pedant writes: Is it not the case that in Paraguay ..

Smallweed disdainfully counters: That is enough of that, chummy. You're suspended, remember?

 It is hardly surprising that a chain of cinemas should have cancelled plans to show a movie called Honest, starring some people called Appleton, because of its rotten reviews. What is a great deal odder is the disappearance from virtually everywhere outside the Curzon, Soho, of a film called The Insider, which won some enthusiastic acclaim. None of the local popcorn temples which Smallweed frequents has shown it at all, even at midnight. Like Erin Brockovich, the film is about industrial malpractice, the villains in this case being tobacco barons. Has it been banned? Have tobacco barons bought up all the available copies? Has it been kidnapped? I call on Erin Brockovich to investigate.

A Greedy Pig (Hunstanton) writes : You have failed to say what are the usual prizes.

Smallweed meekly retorts : My goodness me, so I have. My respect and my gratitude: who could ask more than that? *

That's the 20th, don't forget.

fields.headline: The lying game
fields.standfirst: 'Even our own funky film industry tells lies! It pretends there are no black people in Notting Hill and that Sadie Frost is a good actress'
fields.trailText: 'Even our own funky film industry tells lies! It pretends there are no black people in Notting Hill and that Sadie Frost is a good actress'
fields.body:
A while ago I was reading - purely in the interests of sociology, you understand - a weighty tome called You'll Never Make Love In This Town Again, an anthology detailing the first-person adventures in the skin trade of a bunch of call girls, courtesans and downright slappers hawking their wares among the rich and famous of Hollywood. While I admit that I now know more than I want to know about certain wrinkly household faces, not to mention scrotums (I could, for instance, do without the description of the ever-so-spiritual George Harrison being pleasured while playing the ukulele), it was, on the whole, a rewarding experience.

One particular testimony came to my mind, curiously, while reading the recent reviews of the new Hollywood blockbuster, U-571, in which Jon Bon Jovi and Harvey Keitel double-handedly fool the Nazis into handing over an Enigma code machine, thereby changing for the better the entire course of the second world war. Everyone is now up in arms over the fact that the machine was, in fact, captured years earlier by HMS Bulldog, when America wasn't even in the war. Only the protests of the Tory MP Julian Lewis persuaded the producers to acknowledge this at the end of the film, with a dedication to the crew of HMS Bulldog. And now Chris Smith is wetting himself over the indignity of it all.

The hooker's lament that seemed particularly appropriate to these Disgusted of Islingtons was the one where our heroine, having had paid sex with a big-shot film star, goes and lies on the floor of the shower stall and asks him to urinate on her. He obliges, and soon after asks her to dress and leave. Our girl then, amazingly, goes into a whole number about how this guy doesn't, like, respect her any more! I'm a good feminist by anyone's standards - nine times out of 10 and all things being equal, I'll take a woman's side against a man on principle - but when I read this I couldn't help laughing out loud, and the title of an old dance record came to mind: Am I Looking For Love In All The Wrong Places?

I thought of it again as I read about the caddish manner in which Hollywood has been treating the noble history of this island race. As if being pipped to the Enigma machine wasn't indignity enough, a film about the escapes from Colditz is planned, starring Tom Cruise and Ben Afleck. Of course, no Americans were even incarcerated in Colditz, let alone escaped.

For this, they are to be "warned against distorting history" by Secretary of State for Culture, Chris "Mr Muscle" Smith. Being mauled by a marshmallow isn't in it. And so little, so late! I dislike Americans as much as anyone, but can we really blame them for treating us like air-headed bimbos who will do anything without complaint providing the price is right, when, for the past half-century, we've been encouraging them to use us as an airstrip, a toilet and a hooker all in one? Whether it is something as apparently mild as having our high streets disfigured by the endless Gaps and Starbucks, or something as important as allowing, nay, begging , the Yanks to stick their wholly incompetent beaks into our business in Northern Ireland, we have given the government of the US and its citizens every indication that we consider ourselves completely worthless.

Anyway, Hollywood lies about everything. It always has. It pretended that Cole Porter was heterosexual, that the Vietcong made US PoWs play Russian roulette, and, to this day, it ceaselessly repeats the lie that the biggest fantasy of every beautiful, intelligent, 22-year-old woman is to have an affair with a man old enough to be her grandfather. And guess what? Even our own red-hot and funky English film industry tells lies! It pretends that there are no black people in Notting Hill, that murder is funny and gangsters are charming, and that Sadie Frost is a good actress.

And now it transpires that the berks at the London-based Working Title, responsible for the upcoming film of the loathsome Captain Corelli's Mandolin (romantic, cuddly Fascist soldier versus smelly, cruel Greek Communist partisans), have been forced to assure the islanders of Cephalonia that they will keep out of politics and focus on the love story. All this after the author, Louis de Bernières, was, hilariously, forced by his Greek publishers to rewrite whole swathes of his novel after local historians pointed out its inaccuracies. De Bernières wrote the book in south London after a two-week package tour to Greece, which must have further added ire to the words of Cephalonia's mayor when he said: "What I would really like is to ask him where he got his information from. If they turn it into a political film, we will take measures. We will take the issue to the international court of justice at The Hague - we will fight it all the way."

Film-making is lying and pretence, and that's all it ever has been. It might behove us to clean up our own back lot before we accuse the Yanks of dirtying theirs. And also not to expect respect from a john we have been inviting to urinate on us for the past 50 years.

I've always been suspicious of attempts to "reclaim" words and take the sting out of them. So far as I can see, calling each other "nigga" has done nothing to raise the self-esteem of young black American men, who are killing each other in unprecedented numbers. Similarly, routinely referring to black women (surely the race/gender mix most worthy of respect imaginable, if one measures these things in terms of oppression, grief and fortitude) as bitches and ho's does not seem to have smoothed the path between the sexes greatly.

And now white women have decided to have a bash at reclaiming "bitch", too. A new book by Stephanie Theobald, Biche, informs us on the cover that THERE'S A VERY BAD GIRL ON THE LOOSE IN PARIS; while, in The Bitch Rules, Elizabeth Wurtzel tells us sternly that bitches earn their own living and, um... want to get married eventually. You can also get T-shirts that proclaim you as a BITCH, SLUT or HYSTERIC.

What do Bad Girls and Bitches do? Enjoy sex and earn their own living, according to Wurtzel and Theobald. But this is exactly the way the traditional right-wing has always defined Bad Women. What's changed, except that we now appear to be spreading the misogynists' propaganda for them? Wouldn't it be slightly more accurate to challenge these stereotypes and point out that it tends to be Good Girls who enjoy sex and work hard, while contemptible lazy bitches (of both sexes) fake orgasms and live off their lovers? No?

webTitle: Marchers seek support for sign language

fields.headline: Marchers seek support for sign language
fields.trailText: Up to 1,000 activists are expected to take to the streets of Birmingham today to demand official recognition for an expressive minority language used by more people than Scots Gaelic.
fields.body:
Up to 1,000 activists are expected to take to the streets of Birmingham today to demand official recognition for an expressive minority language used by more people than Scots Gaelic.

The march, with another to follow in London on July 8, has been organised by the Federation of Deaf People as part of its campaign for British sign language, which has its own distinctive syntax and grammar and in which conversations can be as fast and fluent as any in a spoken language.

The federation says BSL - not spoken English - is used by 70,000 deaf people and 100,000 others who communicate with them. It claims government backing would give those who talk with their hands a higher quality of life through access to better jobs, education and healthcare.

It wants ministers to act on a 1988 European parliament resolution, strengthened in 1998, that member states should recognise sign languages as having the same status as spoken languages.

Because there is no legal recognition of BSL, deaf children are not legally entitled to be taught in British sign language at school. They want it to be recognised as a separate language within the British constitution.

"The general public is not aware of the problems deaf people face every day," said a march spokesman. "People see sign language being used more and more on television, in the theatre and at rock concerts and assume that all is well.

"What is not understood is that deaf people can never be guaranteed an interpreter and have problems accessing the most basic information. Deaf children are often not allowed to sign. Imagine going to school to learn and not being allowed to speak English while being forced to try to understand a teacher speaking to you in Swahili."

BSL's supporters say signing is more useful than lip reading, which is tiring and inefficient. It offers both the means to cope with practicalities of life and a method for the effective exchange of ideas.

The campaign is backed by the Royal Association in Aid of Deaf People and the British Deaf Association, a charity that has produced its own sign language policy statement which calls for more use of signing in schools and on television.

BSL is not derived from spoken English and is unrecognisable in Ireland and the US, which have their own sign languages. As with any language, it takes time and effort to learn, and classes are available at centres throughout the country.

But campaigners say there is a shortage of skilled interpreters who can help deaf people communicate with bank managers, doctors and local officials.

They also reject the charge that children who learn to sign will never learn to speak.

Rozwanna Banaris, who was born deaf, used BSL when she was asked to sign for Ronan Keating's song When You Say Nothing At All at a recent Boyzone concert.

"I have a beautiful language. I can do anything that hearing people can do - except hear. I have lots of friends, both deaf and hearing. I go to university and I enjoy my life, she said.

"BSL is incredibly important to my life. It is my language, it is how deaf people communicate."

webTitle: Riddler rictus - the smile on the face of a tamed tiger

fields.headline: Riddler rictus - the smile on the face of a tamed tiger
fields.trailText: I 'm fascinated by the way Tony Blair handles criticism. As the barracking and slow handclapping grew louder at the WI on Wednesday, his face forced itself into the famous rictus grin, only wider and more terrible than ever before.
fields.body:
 I 'm fascinated by the way Tony Blair handles criticism. As the barracking and slow handclapping grew louder at the WI on Wednesday, his face forced itself into the famous rictus grin, only wider and more terrible than ever before. He looked like the Riddler when he realises Batman has finally got him cornered. Later he described the event as "a debate" and, in the Commons, "an interesting exchange". No it wasn't, it was a slow handclap. A debate is when people exchange ideasand beliefs. This was simply abuse. You might as well describe a fight in a pub car park as "a lively discussion of the issues".

 One of the many reasons people can't stand Esther Rantzen is that insufferable smugness. Years ago I was on a breakfast show with her and made some mild remark about the royal family. She paused, turned to the camera, and flashed the teeth in a pitying sort of way. "I always think it's so unfair to say things like that. You see, the royal family can't answer back." Can't answer back? Not only do they answer back, but they get their retaliation in first nowadays. What with spin doctors, speeches, off-the-record briefings and signed articles, they're as mute and retiring as Jonathan Ross at an awards dinner. Now they're squabbling in public with each other about GM foods. It all fits in with my theory that the royals are about to give up. They've finally decided that enough is enough, we're not grateful, and they're fed up with being constantly abused by the media. We know from Lord Goodman's confidante that Charles is, at best, ambivalent about being king, and would rather lead a quiet (though incredibly luxurious) life with Camilla. Now the family has decided to give us all a piece of their minds. It's rather like a couple leading for an acrimonious divorce: "and another thing I always meant to tell you, your feet smell horrible in bed."

Dorset place-names: I had no idea how many people had already strolled down this particular lane. Hilary Forrest of Manchester sent in a Lewis Carroll parody called Cattistocky, written by her late father SJ Forrest and based entirely on Dorset villages: "Twas Swanage and the Durdle Door / Did Swyre and Chettle in the Cerne, / More Crichel was The Gallows Gore / And the Kimmeridge Pimperne."Beware the Cattistock, my son! / The jaws that bite, the paws that grub! / Beware the Lydlinch bird and shun / The Batcombe Melbury Bubb! . . ." Ann Hummel describes the Somerset Critics' Circle, to be found a little west down the A303, including "the stately doyen of dance writers, Compton Psuncefoot, enlivened by the trio of rural music aficionados, Corton Denham, Charlton Horethorne and Chilton Cantelo . . . keeping himself very much to himself, though, is Farmers' Weekly fashion correspondent, Mudford Sock."  While in Dorset I had a dreadful epiphany. I've noticed how, increasingly, people go to gorgeous places such as Lulworth Cove and then get on their mobile phones. It seems a little odd, especially since the conversations seem to be (I am an expert eavesdropper) of the "and then I'm like, and you are not going to believe this" variety. If they were offering a "talking beauty spots for the blind" service ("and to my left, the spray from the waves is illuminated by glorious orange sunshine as it dashes against the rocks") I could understand it. Still, as I stood under the cliffs near Bridport on a glorious sunny, wind-freshened day, my mobile phone rang, and I actually heard myself saying: "Yeah, I'm on the beach. Now, I'm going to need those numbers by 4 o'clock tomorrow . . ." Suddenly, as the Irish say, I caught myself on, and was tempted to play ducks and drakes with the wretched thing. Instead, I shame-facedly switched it off and kept it off till I got home.

A friend reports a new and worrying trend: schools sending out incredibly long questionnaires to the parents of children who are about to start their primary education. Most seem to consist of almost unanswerable questions, possibly designed to elicit more information about the family than about the children themselves. "I helped a neighbour fill hers in," she reports. "It had questions on such as 'how do you indicate to your child that you are upset with him/her?' and 'how do you indicate that you are pleased?' "The correct answers are, of course, 'I hit him' for the first, and 'I stop hitting him' for the second. But naturally we wrote: 'I admonish him gently but firmly.' It doesn't seem much use. They don't ask anywhere if he can read or write, or any skills he might have, or anything much about him really."

 Thanks for your letters about Radio 1 disc-jockeys. There's a lot of anger out there, but I suspect that people who complain about wank jokes on air at the time children are arriving home from school are afraid to complain for fear of being thought Daily Mail readers. I gather Chris Moyles spent much of Monday afternoon being rude about me because of what I wrote about him. It's an excellent deal. I get the prestige of being accused of drivelling by a Radio One DJ ("like being called ugly by a frog," to quote Jimmy Carter) and they have a real topic to bang on about. They remind me of the inhabitants of an old folks' home, bored to tears with their lives, having nothing to say to each other. My article must have been the equivalent of a new bloke coming to change the roller towels - it kept them going for ages. Oh well, apart from the Kenny Everetts and the John Peels, that's the fate that awaits many Radio 1 disc jockeys. Sacked by a new, ambitious controller, reduced to reading local traffic reports, followed by opening a new branch of B&Q for £250, cash if you don't mind.

To the Creative Freedom awards, held in aid of the Centrepoint charity for young people at risk. For the third time I (or The News Quiz), had been nominated for an award, and for the third time I lost - in this case to the richly-deserving Andy Marr, the new BBC political editor. My nomination said" "He brings reality to a world that is trying to avoid it," which is a shame, since I see that as the precise opposite of my job. By now I have practised my overjoyed Oscar-style smile at hearing the news of defeat, and was looking forward to doing it again. It's dazzling, almost like Tony Blair's rictus. But the audience was in darkness, and no one could see.

fields.headline: Abuse of trust
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... unauthorised re-use of photographs
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... unauthorised re-use of photographs
fields.body:
Over the past few years, it will not have escaped your notice, the Guardian has become much more pictorial, much more highly illustrated than it used to be. Almost all stories of any size are now accompanied by a photograph, a drawing, a cartoon or a graphic.

Editors, under pressure to find illustrations quickly and within their budgets, have one great resource: the combined picture archive of the Guardian and the Observer. This comprises a print library of more than 5m photographs, predominantly black and white, plus an electronic archive, mainly colour, that has grown to about 330,000 images in less than 18 months and which, before very long, will have overtaken the print archive in size.

Theoretically, it is perfectly possible to mark both hard prints or electronic images in a manner that draws attention to any important restrictions on their use. This is sometimes done but often is not. In the case of the Blair baby, for instance, all the stored images are marked with a symbol that alerts an editor to the following line, "One use only - £500 fee. Do not use without picture editor's permission." (The fee, you will recall, was to be paid to a nominated cause).

This is, one is tempted to say, a mere commercial consideration. How good are we at protecting the interests of those whose lives might be disturbed or intruded upon by the re-publication of a picture, often in quite a different context to that for which permission was originally given?

There are obvious examples of sensitive areas. Photographs in which old people are depicted in residential homes or hospitals. Does it matter if the relatives of a recently deceased parent, say, open the paper to find the image of the dead person, photographed several years earlier, confronting them?

People in prison who now not uncommonly allow their faces to be shown in photographs are unlikely to want new friends or employers, even though their history may be known to them, to be starkly and publicly reminded of their past. I think it is clear that photographs for which permission was necessary in the first place should not be used on subsequent occasions unless permission for that has also been given.

Particular care should be taken where children are involved. This is a principle expressed in various parts of the code of practice drawn up by the Society of Editors and ratified by the Press Complaints Commission (commonly called the PCC code), although the code has nothing to say on this specific point of archive photographs.

No restrictions had been marked on the back of an archive photograph which we re-used recently, more than 10 years after its first appearance, and which brought a cry of anxiety and anguish. The picture showed a woman and a child, neither of whom, one would have said, were recognisable because of the way the photograph had been taken and cropped. Indeed this was the conclusion of the section editor who decided that it was, therefore, safe to use, even though the original purpose for which the picture had been taken was rather different and specifically stated.

The woman in the picture, from whom the complaint came, had judged it to be in the interests of the child to allow the photograph to be taken and used in the first place, when the difficult and controversial matter of the care and upbringing of the child had become a matter of public argument. Their identity was known only to friends or those closely involved in the matter. It was a friend who drew the attention of the woman in the picture to its reappearance in the Guardian.

What the woman was concerned about was that others involved in the case would also make the connection, and conclude quite wrongly that she had given permission for the picture to be used again, thus breaching the spirit at least of the terms under which she continued to care for the child. I have written to her making it clear, should she need to offer an explanation to anyone else, that the picture was used without consulting her. The picture has been withdrawn from our archive. It is important that people who allow pictures of this kind to be taken for a specific purpose at a specific time can be confident that they will not be used on any other occasion. The newspaper has a responsibility to see that they are not. It can do that by not archiving pictures in this category or by clearly marking them with any restrictions. It is not acceptable to say that the alternatives are time-consuming and costly: taking fresh pictures; using agency pictures with models; using artist's illustrations.

We are talking about a tiny number of the millions of pictures to which our archive now gives us access - the small number of pictures which are there, so to speak, on trust. Arguing the public interest to justify a breach of this trust is only very rarely likely to be convincing.

fields.headline: This septic isle
fields.trailText: Rough Science | Changing Rooms | The Talk Show Story with Michael Parkinson
fields.body:
You might think, given recent events, that the BBC would run a mile from anything that involved dumping people on a desert island and screening the results. But in the case of Rough Science (BBC2), the guinea-pigs were a minimum-risk bunch, comprising a physicist, an ethno-botanist and a handful of egg-headed colleagues. Their mission was to bring electrical power to an unnamed Mediterranean island, and to brew up some potions that would soothe the alarming ailments - hair loss, wind - that afflicted them. While they got busy with some rudimentary kit, presenter Kate Humble passed among them, making the odd withering remark and smiling attractively.

Rough Science is one of those peculiar hybrid programmes that the BBC has come up with of late. Remember Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen getting butch with a spade in When Changing Rooms Met Ground Force? This was When Changing Rooms Met Open University in all but name, as the team raced against time to pull off the desired effects. As the old island prison was converted into a pharmacy, we were even treated to that well-worn device of watching the transformation speeded up, as if hyperactive elves were at work.

Outside, competing physicists Mike Bullivant and Jonathan Hare hacked up bits of wood in an attempt to build a generator. The air was soon thick with testosterone as each stuck doggedly to his own doomed design; this, we were led to believe, was typical male behaviour. It was left to Vanessa Griffiths, a marine biologist, to suggest a compromise: thus the sweet light of female reason came to bear on the dark Lawrentian struggle of the masculine principles. And lo! thanks to a makeshift windmill, a handful of magnets and some coiled wire, there was enough juice to make a few tiny lightbulbs flicker fitfully.

Things went better in the pharmacy, where Oxonian Mike Leahy brewed up alcohol in which to macerate myrtle leaves for antiseptics. A nasty green gloop derived from nettle leaves was dumped over balding Bullivant's head, and he was also given a handful of fennel seeds to chew, the theory being that this would cure him of gas. Whether either remedy worked we can only guess.

Changing Rooms , the onlie begetter of so much of this type of television, came to the end of its umpteenth series on BBC1. Something has happened to this hardy perennial over the last couple of years. Any pretence that the show is about two sets of neighbours doing up each others' houses with a little help from the professionals has been abandoned. Last night, designer Mike Jewitt ignored his clients' disgust at the blue he had chosen for the kitchen, while next door Anna Rider-Richardson rode roughshod over a shared hatred of cerise. While the neighbours emitted horrified whimpers, the paint was splashed on regardless. "Yes... no, I see what you mean... no, I like it..." muttered poor Sarah, bravely convincing herself that the designer must know best.

We seemed set to end the series with a bang, relishing the fact that each hated what the other had done to their home, fantasising about the acrimony and repainting to follow. Disappointingly, the "reveals" were met with gasps of unfeigned delight, and there were hugs all round. Carol Smillie cosied up to the camera and waved us off. Her role in the show seems ever more marginal.

The main burden of The Talk Show Story with Michael Parkinson (BBC1) was that hosting a bit of chat is jolly hard work fit only for the few. Classic clips were trotted out to reinforce the point, but let's face it, if you can't get a decent performance out of Billy Connolly or Les Dawson you must be clinically dead. The highlight was Dame Edna Everage reminiscing about her encounter with Kim Basinger, and admitting to sapphic yearnings. "For once," she said, "I could understand what spooky women do in the privacy of their own homes."

webTitle: She's clever, she's funny. But she's not great with kids

fields.headline: She's clever, she's funny. But she's not great with kids
fields.standfirst: Fiona Shaw breaks new ground in Medea, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Fiona Shaw breaks new ground in Medea, says Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
We hear her long before we see her. A distant cacophony of rage and grief from a woman for whom love has turned rancid. Something wild. So when she appears, it is a bit of a surprise.

She is dressed in a little black number with a cardie. She laughs nervously. Cracks jokes. Rubs one foot against the other, for all the world like a suburban matron cracking up.

Director Deborah Warner and actress Fiona Shaw have done something extraordinary at the Abbey in Dublin: given us the first comic Medea. Shaw's Medea is more Winnie the Witch than evil sorceress. More sad than bad, infected with the bitter humour of the terminally despairing.

In other circumstances this sly, witty and fascinating Medea would grace any dinner party. She chats to the women of Corinth, outlining her plans for revenge, like a mother holding court at an NCT meeting. And those little boys... there is no doubt how much she loves them, hugging them until it hurts.

There are disturbing signs, though. The way she burns the children's teddy. The fact that the young nanny has thought fit to hide the kitchen knives. The way that, as her plans unfold, her sense of purpose becomes more defined. For the final slaughter she changes into the plastic uniform of the butcher in the abattoir. Still she falters. It takes three attempts before she can kill her sons, obliterate the future and all hope of happiness.

This Medea is about the failure of romantic love, the breaking of promises and the canker at the heart of male/female relationships: what men want and what women need. In the perspex palace where country and western plays continuously in the background, Patrick O'Kane's muscle-bound Jason makes Houdini-like efforts to explain himself to Medea. To have his cake and eat it. It is no-go because Medea bought the whole romantic myth, she believed the promises and the songs. Her madness is that, despite everything, she would still have him back. The approach makes the play smaller, but also bigger. It is no longer a tornado of terror and pity, but an appalling domestic tragedy. This is the first Medea I've ever seen that I've wanted to cradle in my arms.

At the end, Medea stands behind the despairing Jason, flicking water at him, trying to get his attention. The dead children's sailing boats still bob upon the water. After everything, the hunger of Medea's want for Jason is frightening, like a child's. That is real madness. And real horror.

 At the Abbey, Dublin (00 3531 878 7222), till July 1.

fields.headline: Genes
fields.standfirst: A more important set of instruction books will never be found by human beings. -  James Watson
fields.trailText: A more important set of instruction books will never be found by human beings. - James Watson
fields.body:
News this week of the imminent completion of the Genome Project means that humankind stands at an exhilarating and vertiginous point in its history. Despite being a species which, in relative terms, has not existed for long, we are on the verge of understanding our own genetic blueprint. Like an eye that has learned to see itself, humanity has reached the point where it can trace its own development - and tinker with it if it wishes.

Genome research is that province of biology called genetics, the science of how organisms bequeath anatomical, physiological and behavioural traits to their offspring, and how such traits express themselves in the formation and development of individual organisms. Central to this enquiry is the concept of the gene, a chemical packet of information which is the fundamental unit of heredity.

The word was coined in 1909, but the idea dates back to the work of the 19th-century Moravian monk Gregor Mendel, who studied heredity in peas and proposed a mechanism - thus filling a gap in Darwinian theory - by which characteristics are passed from one generation to the next.

The genome is the sum of all genetic material in a given organism. It is a hugely complex chemical storehouse of information, a code or script in which is written the secrets of every physical aspect of a living creature. The quantity of information in a single human genome is equivalent to the amount of data in 1,000 telephone directories each 1,000 pages long.

When the code can be read, each individual's genetic makeup will reveal not only his heredity - for example, which forebears bequeathed him his height, colouring and other traits - but something of his fate also, for example, the diseases he has or might be prone to, and the possibility of his offspring inheriting any of his characteristics and conditions.

Genes are made of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid), a long slender molecule made of two intertwined strands of "bases" - chemical compounds strung together like a necklace of beads. There are four such bases, known by the letters A, C, G and T, and they form the genetic "alphabet" out of which are made "words" (codons) which in turn, when suitably organised, tell "stories" (genes), several thousand of which together constitute a chapter (a "chromosome") of the human book. The human book is in turn 23 chapters long - and it is this book which is just about to be read by geneticists.

A gene is a segment of DNA that codes for a protein. Proteins make and manage all living processes in the body. But only a minority of genes do this; most - called "junk DNA" - seem to be redundant, leftovers perhaps from replication in earlier phases of human evolution.

Genetics has already explained much and made many things possible, especially in medicine where it has proved itself a uniquely powerful tool. Transplant surgery, prenatal diagnosis, cancer treatments, the manufacture of insulin for treatment of diabetics, would all be impossible without it. Genetics is likewise crucial in research into cystic fibro sis research and Alzheimer's disease.

What has been described as the "holy grail" of human genetics is close at hand. James Watson, one of the discoverers of DNA, said "A more important set of instruction books will never be found by human beings. When finally interpreted, the genetic messages encoded within our DNA will provide the ultimate answers to the chemical underpinnings of human existence."

The future of genetics is filled not only with promise but problems. Armed with a directory of the human genome and with knowledge of how to interpret and manipulate it, will we be tempted to alter the genetic material of future people not just to exclude hereditary diseases, but to make them taller, more intelligent, more athletic? Would doing so be wrong? Should employers or insurers know our genetic profiles? How shall we best live with the new knowledge rushing upon us? It is not yet too late to reflect on these and a thousand similar questions, but it soon will be.

webTitle: Mao, he's making eyes at me

fields.headline: Mao, he's making eyes at me
fields.standfirst: A state visit by a dodgy politician should not translate into great opera. But John Adams pulled it off with Nixon in China.  Andrew Clements celebrates its long-overdue arrival in London
fields.trailText: A state visit by a dodgy politician should not translate into great opera. But John Adams pulled it off with Nixon in China. Andrew Clements celebrates its long-overdue arrival in London
fields.body:
It has taken far too long - 13 years to be precise - for a British company to put on John Adams's first opera, one of the most important and successful of the last quarter of the 20th century. Now that ENO has taken the plunge, reviving the superb staging that Peter Sellars created for the premiere in Houston in 1987 (and which the American company brought to the Edinburgh festival a year later), all opera-goers should give thanks, and make sure they get to see what is a gripping and often wildly entertaining event, superbly realised both musically and dramatically at the Coliseum.

Nixon in China has been heard in London before - Kent Nagano conducted the LSO in a concert performance three years ago. Experiencing it in all its splendour in an opera house, however, makes the achievement of Adams and his librettist Alice Goodman seem all the more impressive. Sellars, too, played a crucial part in the work's genesis. It was he who suggested to Adams that Richard Nixon's visit to Beijing in 1972 might be the starting point for a stage work, and it was he who brought composer and librettist together. As realised by Goodman in her wonderfully fluid, vivid text, this historic event becomes the stuff of opera on the grandest scale. With its focus shifting between the public and private worlds of the protagonists, its vivid tableaux and dance episodes, it echoes the scale and scope of Don Carlos.

But Nixon has one ingredient that Verdi's masterpiece lacks. Adams may have set out to write a "heroic" opera, peopled with larger-than-life figures, but there is a wicked vein of humour running through music, text and production that pricks the pomposity of all concerned. Richard Nixon's platitudes and his transparent ambition to use the PR, pre-Watergate, to get himself re-elected for a second term, is counterpointed with the doddering Chairman Mao's endless stream of metaphors. Madame Mao and Henry Kissinger are portrayed as monsters of different kinds - she a terrifyingly cruel ideologue, he a cold and calculating schemer. Only the Chinese prime minister, Chou En-Lai, whose insomniac eloquence ends the opera, and Pat Nixon, whose contact with the ordinary people of China and her horrified reaction to t he propagandist ballet The Red Detachment of Women (outstandingly choreographed by Mark Morris) are genuinely touching, attain real human form.

All this is wonderfully captured in Adams's score; his dramatic pacing is so sure (though a couple of scenes are too long), it's hard to believe that this was his first opera. There are moments of tremendous grandeur - the touchdown of Nixon's plane is portrayed in brassy magnificence - alongside passages of highly coloured pastiche. Paul Daniel and the ENO Orchestra ensure that no element of Adams's rich tapestry is overlooked.

As always, Sellars has revived his staging personally in Adrianne Lobel's sets, tightening every detail and making the focus as sharp as possible. He does not follow all of Goodman's stage directions, but his glosses are always compellingly interesting. Crucially, too, he has worked with the cast to make every characterisation totally believable, so that there is not a caricature anywhere on stage.

The amazingly high standard of the acting is set by James Maddalena, who sang Richard Nixon at the premiere, and remains a scary lookalike. He captures every particle of the man's insecurity, his desperate efforts to keep his head up in the treacherous waters of international diplomacy. Janis Kelly brings real pathos out of Pat Nixon, and Judith Howarth real horror out of Madame Mao, while Stephen Owen's awkward, self-conscious Kissinger is closely observed. Robert Brubaker's Mao is first-rate, and David Kempster's Chou is a performance of enormous vocal and dramatic stature. The three automata-like secretaries to Mao are winningly played by Victoria Simmonds, Ethna Robinson and Rebecca de Pont Davies. It's a great company achievement with only one disappointment: too few of the words are audible. Though Adams apparently intended the voices to be electronically "enhanced", that is a mistake in the Coliseum, where amplification does the text no favours. And every detail of this remarkable work deserves to be appreciated.

 At the Coliseum, London WC2 (020-7632 8300), till June 21, and broadcast live on Radio 3 tonight.

webTitle: Still angry after all these years

fields.headline: Still angry after all these years
fields.standfirst: Robin Denselow salutes the singer Janis Ian
fields.trailText: Robin Denselow salutes the singer Janis Ian
fields.body:
The middle-aged lady with the cropped black hair and blue shirt was clearly enjoying herself, playing with echo effects as she bashed out a bluesy riff on the guitar, telling self- deprecating stories about smoking joints with Willie Nelson, and constantly changing the mood of her songs. Standing by the pulpit in London's Union Chapel, in front of a capacity crowd, she switched from jazz to country, and the immaculately treated, painful and intimate ballads that became her trademark.

Janis Ian first shocked the US 34 years ago, and she is still a refreshingly brave performer. She was just 15 when she wrote and recorded her first, banned hit, Society's Child, and found herself hailed both as a controversial teenage sensation and the female answer to Bob Dylan. From then on, she specialised in thoughtful, gently gloomy and world-weary ballads of personal and public angst. She picked up a batch of Grammy nominations in the 70s, disappeared from public view in the 80s, and has now re-appeared with a new set of songs that once again set her apart.

Her new album, "god and the fbi" (sic), shows off her current range - from an angry but jaunty song about J Edgar Hoover (based on the FBI surveillance of her left-wing parents) to a highly successful excursion into country, marked by her now famous duet with Nelson, along with a dash of good-natured pop and jazz, and a couple of pained and personal ballads.

Her two lengthy solo sets at the Union Chapel showed that she is capable of handling all this backed just by her own guitar. She constantly changed styles throughout the show, switching from mischievous good humour to intimate tragedy. The best songs of the evening included a tribute to Ireland and Mary Black, a personal song of lost love, She Must Be Beautiful, and the country weepie, Memphis. Then there was the no-nonsense treatment of that early ballad of teenage angst, At Seventeen, and her lengthy, gloomy reflection on fame, Stars.

Ian clearly enjoys performing. She has had her fame as a pop star, and has quit the music business several times over, but always returned to song-writing, "the best job in the world". She deserved her standing ovation.

fields.headline: Class act
fields.standfirst: Forget the mess that was Notre-Dame de Paris: the Comédie Française's take on Molière proves the French can make good theatre.
fields.trailText: Forget the mess that was Notre-Dame de Paris: the Comédie Française's take on Molière proves the French can make good theatre.
fields.body:
Forty million Frenchmen," said Shaw, attacking some endlessly popular Gallic comedy, "can't be right." But, of course, they can be. And never more so than in their love of Molière, whose Les Fourberies de Scapin (Scapin's Trickery) the Comédie Française have brought to the Barbican theatre. After torture by musical, in the shape of Notre-Dame de Paris and Lautrec, it's good to be reminded of the heights to which French theatre can rise.

But why is Molière a great dramatist? In part, it's because he has the fundamental sanity of genius: the ability to view human beings, for all their follies and fixations, with a calm, Olympian understanding. This is precisely the quality that makes Shakespeare greater than Ben Jonson, Ibsen superior to Strindberg. But Molière also realised, like Shakespeare and Mozart, that comedy must also contain its opposite: that an awareness of pain, transience and even death counterpoints comedy's celebratory urge.

You can see all this in Les Fourberies de Scapin, which Molière wrote in 1671 towards the end of his relatively short life. On one level, you could say it is knockabout farce borrowing the tricks of the Italian commedia. Two young men are in love with girls they fear their fathers will reject. Needing money to help the girls out, they use the servant Scapin to prise the loot out of the skinflint fathers' hands. But, since the two girls turn out to be the respective fathers' daughters, all ends happily; except that Scapin enters, ostensibly on the point of death, seeking forgiveness.

In strict plot terms, Scapin's actions are unnecessary: the misunderstandings would have sorted themselves out anyway. But Molière's play is not about plot, it is about the superior wisdom of servants and the assertion of natural justice. You see this in its most famous scene where Scapin, falsely accused by one of the fathers, persuades the old man to escape his enemies by hiding in a sack. Scapin then thwacks the sack with a stick while playing the dual role of the old man's protector and his pursuing foes.

This scene becomes the comic centrepiece of Jean-Louis Benoit's wondrously cool, alert production. It has the cruelty of farce as the sack, containing the black-and-blue Géronte, goes swinging back and forth across the stage. But it also becomes about crime and punishment and a delight in role-playing. Gérard Giroudon's brilliant Scapin gets so carried away by the mock-drama he is enacting that he starts to flagellate and pinion himself; and, even after Malik Faraoun's Géronte has raised his head out of the sack to tumble the ruse, Giroudon exits swinging his cudgel with unfazed insouciance.

Scapin is one of the great roles of French theatre. Copeau played him as gentle and romantic, Barrault as an exuberant clown. But Giroudon, more intriguingly, makes him a rueful Beckettian philosopher in a battered trilby. His muscular, athletic legs are also belied by his wispy, white locks, which suggest an aged wisdom. This Scapin is a natural solitary who has clearly been bruised by life and who, when he tells us that "it's better to be married than dead", shoots a questioning glance at the audience. What drives him on is a passion for justice. He beats Géronte because his integrity has been traduced; and, when he cons the old dads of their loot, it is as if he is carrying on a private campaign for the redistribution of wealth.

Giroudon and Benoit realise the play is not a farce: it is a philosophic comedy. It is also part of a great theatrical and literary tradition that shows servants as infinitely wiser than their masters. It is there in Shakespeare, Marivaux, Goldoni, Brecht and continues right up to PG Wodehouse: as Penelope Gilliatt once said, "without the appallingly expert European sense of class distinctions, a good half of post-antique comedy would scarcely exist."

But Molière's wise comedy goes even beyond an assertion of the moral and practical wisdom of servants. At the end, as the reunited fathers and children dance off in celebration, a dazed, blood-spattered Scapin is left alone on stage reminding us that, while his assumed death may be a ruse, mortality is an inescapable fact. As in all great comedy, we are caught between laughter and tears.

Sadly, on the first night there was a far-from-full house to share the experience. There are only a handful of opportunities left to catch Giroudon's performance and Benoit's staging of a play that proves why Molière, even when writing in prose, was a consummate theatrical poet.

 At the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), till Wednesday.

fields.headline: She who has everything
fields.standfirst: Maddy Costa thrills to the pure ham of Shirley Bassey
fields.trailText: Maddy Costa thrills to the pure ham of Shirley Bassey
fields.body:
When it comes to hammy performances, Shirley Bassey is in a league of her own. She is camp in the extreme, scrunching up her face as she wrenches every ounce of emotion from each song, flinging her arms in extravagant gestures of pride, defiance, delight. And the audience at London's Royal Festival Hall, clutching their programmes where the "ss" in Bassey's name is arranged to form a heart, are with her all the way - squealing as she flashes a pert bottom cheek during Big Spender (which, for a time, Bassey couldn't sing for laughing at the reaction) and piling her piano with flowers and gifts. It's tacky, but there's no point resisting. Bassey is too good.

After four decades honing her performance, she knows how to keep an audience rapt. That powerhouse voice literally stuns: at the start of the show she sounds surprisingly quiet, but that's just the soundman trying to ease us in gently. Before long you're convinced that one more belter and your forehead will be bouncing off the ceiling. Two hours and 20-odd songs later, you're exhausted.

More mesmerising still are the passionate expressions. Bassey is so immersed in her songs that during some songs, especially Remember and Born to Lose, she looks as though she is making every effort to keep tears from flooding out. What's fascinating is how genuine that feeling appears to be. Closing with This Is My Life, she sings "This is me" while grabbing armfuls of her feathered gold cape (so voluminous she could take off if she flapped her arms) and brandishing them at the audience. It might be hilarious, if she looked any less serious and sincere.

Elsewhere, the incongruity between Bassey's lyrics and her appearance is blissful: she sings about resorting to chips for dinner and declares "I have nothing, I have no home", while shimmering in a gold dress with diamonds at her cleavage, tassles down her back and a train unfurling behind her. She may be hammy, but there is still something very real and unfeigned about her, qualities that the average camp superstar so often lacks.

 Till June 18. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

Closing with This Is My Life, she sings "This is me" while grabbing armfuls of her feathered gold cape (so voluminous she could take off if she flapped her arms) and brandishing them at the audience. It might be hilarious, if she looked any less serious and sincere. Elsewhere, the incongruity between Bassey's lyrics and her appearance is blissful: she sings about resorting to chips for dinner and declares "I have nothing, I have no home", while shimmering in a gold dress with diamonds at her cleavage, tassles down her back and a train unfurling behind her. She may be hammy, but there is still something very real and unfeigned about her, qualities that the average camp superstar so often lacks.  Till June 18. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

fields.headline: A shuffle in the dark
fields.standfirst: Cat Power leaves  Keith Cameron ill at ease
fields.trailText: Cat Power leaves Keith Cameron ill at ease
fields.body:
Cat Power must be one of the least comfortable performers ever to creep on a stage. Playing in near total darkness at London's Spitz, she fiddles around with a guitar, stares intently at a set-list then starts to sing. Two seconds later she stops, giggles, then starts again. What follows is a wobble along the tautest of emotional high-wires.

Any suggestion that this Atlanta singer-songwriter recently released an album of cover versions to make playing live less distressing is demolished here. Pathologically shy when placed in front of an audience, her technique involves segueing each song into the next, so that the audience have no chance to applaud and alert Marshall to its presence. It works, for a while.

Shrouded behind her fringe and rocking gently, she doesn't so much sing the songs of others as invade them, subverting their intent. So completely does Marshall inhabit and rearrange (I Can't Get no) Satisfaction, dropping the chorus and slowing the verses down to an icy mantra, that Keith Richards might struggle to recognise it.

The blues really descend when Marshall has to stop and move to the piano. The cheering has its feared effect, and barely two lines into Wild is the Wind she decides that she has messed up beyond repair. Thereafter, songs are aborted, Marshall worries that her water bottle is bringing her bad luck and she threatens to lurch into Knocking on Heaven's Door.

Cat Power's voice is a rare and special one. One trusts for her sake that she derives something positive from such exquisitely painful exercises.

fields.headline: The real Jules and Jim
fields.standfirst: Ian MacKillop on Pierre Roché, author of two novels based on his unconventional life and loves
fields.trailText: Ian MacKillop on Pierre Roché, author of two novels based on his unconventional life and loves
fields.body:
An unassuming man smiles and sidles through the biographies of the founders of the Modern Movement in art and literature. He introduced Picasso to Gertrude Stein, he was a close friend of Marcel Duchamp, and he was in on Duchamp's "Fountain" joke, that is, the contribution of a urinal, signed "R. Mutt", to the 1917 "Independents" art show in New York. Many French masterpieces which hang today in American galleries owe their presence to this slender, fastidious man, who arranged their purchase as Parisian scout and buyer for John Quinn, the great collector and patron of writers like Joyce and Eliot.

This unassuming man was Henri Pierre Roché who died at the age of 80 in 1959. He was an art collector, in a small way, adviser and dealer, a writer and a life-long conscientious - though shy - Casanova. Last year he finally had a biography of his own in France, by Scarlett and Philippe Reliquet (Editions Ramsay). Roché was in many ways a modest man, but it was a series of accidents which kept him in the shadows. One reason was his practice of chronicling his life in his journals: thousands of pages of observation as precise as that of Montaigne, or indeed Casanova. There was simply too much to publish.

Now fortunately these journals - preserved, like many literary papers, at the Harry Ransom Centre at Austin, Texas - are being slowly issued and edited by a specialist publisher in Marseilles, André Dimanche. But another reason why Roché became a mere extra in the biographies of others is that he so effectively fictionalised himself in his two autobiographical novels, which tell the story of two love triangles, Jules and Jim (1953) and Two English Girls and the Continent (1956). The real Roché disappeared behind "Jim" in the first - in which the eponymous heroes simultaneously fell in love with a German girl - and "Claude" in the second. Both were filmed by François Truffaut, Two English Girls becoming Anne and Muriel (1971). The young Truffaut had been a friend of the elderly Roché in the late 1950s and these two films are regarded by many critics as among the most profound in his oeuvre. The filmmaker said Anne and Muriel should be like a film about Proust in love with the Brontë sisters .

The novel was an account of a turn-of-the-century menage à trois between the bohemian Nietzschean Pierre Roché and two sisters from a Kent village near Ashford, devout Anglicans Violet and Margaret Court (their last name has been changed to protect their surviving family). It was a passion that lasted until 1914. The love affair began in 1899, when Violet, then - like Pierre - aged 20, went to Paris to enrol at art school. Her widowed mother had arranged for her to lodge with Mme Clara Roché. Pierre's mother, also a widow, thought Violet so plain that it was safe to allow Pierre to show her the sights. But Pierre was definitely interested in this girl, whom he described in his journal as boyish - and as a refreshingly good listener compared to quick-witted Parisian coquettes. He was interested in having an English girlfriend in emulation of his favourite poet, Jules Laforgue, who married a red-haired London girl. Laforgue declared: "There are three sexes - men, women and English girls; and I want English girls."

Violet was a brunette but she said her sister, a year older, was red-haired and wonderful: better at everything. Inspired by Violet's heroine worship, Pierre manoeuvred his mother into vacationing with the Courts at a holiday cottage in North Wales, near Conway Castle. Margaret was indeed beautiful, cleverer than Violet, religious, but an avid reader of Dar win, and abundantly red-haired. It was a perfect summer, with beach games, conversations about books (he recommended Zola's Germinal), language lessons, and naked sea-bathing, the sisters disrobing and swimming further up the estuary. They were like male friends, unaware of Pierre's desire to kiss the nape of Margaret's neck. He became the sisters' tame European. "M le Continent, bonjour," they ceremoniously said at breakfast.

The affection grew when Mrs Court decided she and Margaret should accompany Violet to Paris for a few months. Pierre therefore introduced the sisters to French students, including his best friend Jo Jouanin, who read them Laforgue's poetry. They saw sculpture (Rodin), went to the opera (Charpentier's Louise) and learned about French morality. Pierre told Margaret that there was such a thing as sex distinct from love and that sexual affairs for pleasure were socially tolerated. He also explained that he was a socialist and believed that the confinement of women to one man in bourgeois marriage was a tyranny typical of property-based capitalism.

He did not yet say to her that he had experimented with sexual freedom, having tried to share girl-friends with Jo without jealousy. Nor did he say that he and Jo tried to create a "radiating" non-restrictive social life, fanning out from family and friends, by placing newspaper advertisements for contacts, especially women. On one day alone they received 100 responses, which they sorted in a rented cafe room.

Clara Roché now assessed Margaret as a real threat to her only child. She was relieved when the sisters returned to Kent and Pierre embarked on military service. But Pierre and Margaret were powerful letter writers (he called her style "Shakespearian") and their correspondence was intense. For Roché, Margaret, politics and England became an increasingly potent cocktail. Pierre was fascinated by the depredations of capitalism and European metropolitan poverty was to be seen at its worst in London. He moved to the east end to live in the student settlement, Toynbee Hall, a magnet for young socially-conscious women like Margaret who had joined the Charity Organisation Society, which surveyed families considered in need of aid.

Pierre and Margaret joined up, and, when Violet was home, the trio linked arms and roamed the Kentish lanes - so freely that Mrs Court quizzed Pierre about his intentions with Margaret. Pierre was exhilarated to be treated as a potential suitor and promptly proposed to Margaret. She refused, bewildered. How could an anarchistic socialist contemplate bourgeois marriage? When Pierre began to confess details of his sexual experience, she was disgusted. But the more they talked about their incompatibilities, the more of a couple they became.

Clara Roché intervened to help Mrs Court prise the couple apart. At a family conference, Pierre and Margaret were separated for a year and forbidden even to write. They consented with uncharacteristic meekness. But at Toynbee Hall, Pierre's sense of mission as a reviser of all values, inspired by Nietzsche, was incandescently expressed in journals which combined lucid self-analysis with sexual fantasy: he wanted Margaret - and Violet - to become his partner in psychosexual experiments.

He returned to Paris, where Clara bought him a flat but suddenly, in 1904, his close friend Jouanin contracted typhoid and died. On impulse Pierre ended his liaison with Margaret by sending her his journal of the previous months. It was Violet who delivered it.

Margaret had been shaken by enforced separation - she had been ill and lost weight - and was shattered when the journal arrived. On an impulse of her own, she made her confession to him by letter. She wrote to tell him that she was not "a virgin". She admitted that she had shamefully "pleasured herself". In the course of her social work she had come across an American book on girls' education, What a Young Woman Should Know by Mary Allen Wood and Sylvanus Stall, published in Philadelphia in 1899. Here she learned she was guilty of "Solitary Vice". There was some exaltation in her confession, but within weeks she descended into a deep depression.

In Paris, Pierre was becoming a success in the world of art and letters and Violet, enjoying art-school life, was mixing with the Russian bohemian set. Pierre visited her in her attic lodgings and they embarked on a passionate affair - her first sexual experience. But Violet began to enjoy the admiration of other men and was soon also engaged in a love affair with the Russian poet, painter and anthroposophist, Maksimilian Voloshinov. Despite Pierre's principles, he was tormented - foreshadowing, like his shared relationships with Jouanin, the story of his novel, Jules and Jim.

Meanwhile, Margaret had begun to recover and went to see Violet in Paris. On the last day of her sister's visit, Violet arranged for Margaret to see Pierre alone in her studio flat. They talked awkwardly, then he was astounded that Margaret crossed the bare boards, took his cheeks in the flat of her hands and kissed him before leaving. "The ache, again," he wrote in his journal. "He is galloping inside me," she thought as her train sped past the oasthouses of Kent.

Pierre continued to travel and write, determined to be an art critic, an encourager of artists and a social observer or " informateur ", as he called it. He sometimes had sex with Violet and they would talk about Margaret. In a letter to Violet, when she was visiting Kent, he asked whether the sisters could make love together. He even speculated in his journal about making love with their mother, always thinking of one face or body over-laying another.

A year passed and Margaret returned to Paris. He sent a note suggesting they go to Holland to spend a week together. The night before Margaret and Pierre were due to meet, Violet told her sister that she had some serious news to impart. Margaret knew Violet had men friends, and there were three special ones. One was Max ,another was a boy called Todia. There was a third "friend", she said, and Margaret must know who it was. The name of Pierre was finally wrenched from her. For a few minutes, Margaret was paralysed. She began to talk incessantly and by the end of a long night she had convinced herself that Violet was "really" Pierre's. How, anyway, could she have been his when she was unchaste? She had effectively lost her virginity to her "secret vice". At dawn she went straight to Gare du Nord. Back in England she wrote to Pierre, explaining that he was Violet's and they could never marry.

A further year passed and Margaret wrote directly to Pierre, giving a time for him to meet her at Gare du Nord in February. They went to his freezing top-floor apartment and slept chastely together for two nights. On the third night, they had intercourse. "No pleasure," wrote Pierre in his journal, "only love." Back in Kent, Margaret was disappointed to find that she was not pregnant. She wrote to Pierre saying that she felt like using black-edged notepaper. They could never see each other again, she insisted.

She subsequently married, happily, another man in 1914. He was a long-standing friend who tenderly heard out her confessions of "unchasteness". She died of cancer in 1926 at the age of 45. Violet had always been drawn to Russia and in the end she married a Russian stage designer, who worked for Bakst. She lived a longer life than her sister, dying in 1950, but after the night she made her confession to Margaret, she never saw Pierre again either.

Roché lived the longest of all, until 1959, and exorcised his passion in his novel, Two English Girls. When Truffaut came to film the novel as Anne and Muriel, he said he had wanted to show "the horrors of being just above 20 years of age".

 Ian MacKillop's book, Free Spirits: Henri Pierre Roché, François Truffaut and the Two English Girls is published by Bloomsbury (£16.99) on June 19.

webTitle: Dulcie Domum: Something borrowed, something blue

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Something borrowed, something blue
fields.standfirst: 'When I was Harriet's age, I couldn't even say "blue tit" to my mother without blushing'
fields.trailText: 'When I was Harriet's age, I couldn't even say "blue tit" to my mother without blushing'
fields.body:
I want to become a Buddhist and smile in silence and emptiness, but it will have to wait till next weekend. So much to do, so little time. I must paint my room to get rid of the brown. I have abandoned the idea of cream - overtones of saturated fat. Instead, I am entering my Blue Period. But which? Duck-egg or china? I don't want that synthetic baby-blue - such a sexist cliché. Cambridge Blue? Too elitist. I ransack the universe for the perfect blue. I tear the label off the sauce-bottle. I stare impertinently into the eyes of Aryan strangers. I am mad about blue. It's worse than being in love.

Other chores intrude. We must return the borrowed vacuum cleaner to the brothel next door. It's one of those vacs that looks like a little man with a face and a long, obscene nasal organ. Tremendous suck on it, too. It didn't seem content with mere dust and showed every intention of devouring the whole carpet. One wouldn't ever want a blue carpet, of course. Or a blue tooth or a blue sandwich. I'm not that obsessed.

"Would you like to take the vacuum cleaner back next door?" I enquire sweetly of ex-Spouse, who is watching cricket. I cannot feel the same about cricket since the match-fixing allegations. Cricket is almost an anagram of trickery. But if it is fixed, they could learn a trick or two from wrestling. Nasser should strut to the crease, wearing dreadlocks and a Lycra posing pouch, escorted by strumpets in leopardskin bikinis. I wonder if Nasser has blue eyes? Cricket-captain blue. Sea-captain blue. Blue birds buccaneering beneath a British sky. That's what I want - in eggshell emulsion.

Ex-Spouse seems more inclined to inspect fine leg than the tarts next door. Unless, of course, he's been there already. "I'm not at my best in brothels," he confesses with what is intended to be an elegant shrug.

"No," I sneer. "You prefer it free-range and furtive with people we have dinner with!" Damn it! As usual, sinful syntax undermines my indignation.

"What are you talking about?" cries Harriet, entering en her latest déshabillé: a red-and-black satin corset, mini-skirt, fishnet tights, high heels and a spiky dog-collar. Convince her we are arguing about factory farming. Will obviously have to return the vacuum cleaner myself. Hate Ex-Spouse for disguising his laziness as moral scruple. Harriet tags along, intent on penetrating the knocking shop. Innocence departed some time ago. Thanks to satellite TV, the theory paper, at least, of depravity would present her with no difficulties. When I was her age, I couldn't even say "blue tit" to my mother without blushing.

The "Therapy Centre" is a large Victorian house shielded by massive horse chestnuts. The door is opened by a young woman in a chaste shirt and skirt. She looks like a schoolgirl; Harriet looks like a tart. Maureen teeters out of her inner sanctum reeking of scent. She smiles in rapture at Harriet. Perhaps she is charmed by the sight of enthusiastic amateurism. The vacuum cleaner is solemnly handed over and Maureen seems on the verge of offering us a cup of tea when the front door bursts open and four delectable young women come in, none of them, alas, wearing blue of any sort.

"Ah, here comes my bwidge party," beams Maureen. "Do you play bwidge, Dulcie?"

Admit not. Too much like maths. Wonder if "play bridge" is a code for something else. Wonder how many girls Maureen has. Enough for a cricket team?

"Do you think they were real call-girls?" whispers Harriet in rapture as we skulk back to our bungalow. "They were so cool! And Maureen's wallpaper is, like, so lush! I'm going to paint my room exactly that red."

A cosmic collision seems likely between her red and my blue. Blood and guts versus spirit and sky. I shall need Zen calm even more than I thought. Arrive home to find large parcel being signed for by Great Aunt Elspeth. "Cool!" cries Harriet, "it's the flat-packed computer workstation!" Aunt looks preoccupied, and confesses quietly to me that she fears her large intestine is intent on rebellion.

"Come on, Mum!" cries Harriet, tearing open parcel. "Let's put the work-station together!"

Fear it will be some time before I gain that Clear Blue Water.

"You prefer it free-range and furtive with people we have dinner with!" Damn it! As usual, sinful syntax undermines my indignation. "What are you talking about?" cries Harriet, entering en her latest déshabillé: a red-and-black satin corset, mini-skirt, fishnet tights, high heels and a spiky dog-collar. Convince her we are arguing about factory farming. Will obviously have to return the vacuum cleaner myself. Hate Ex-Spouse for disguising his laziness as moral scruple. Harriet tags along, intent on penetrating the knocking shop. Innocence departed some time ago. Thanks to satellite TV, the theory paper, at least, of depravity would present her with no difficulties. When I was her age, I couldn't even say "blue tit" to my mother without blushing. The "Therapy Centre" is a large Victorian house shielded by massive horse chestnuts. The door is opened by a young woman in a chaste shirt and skirt. She looks like a schoolgirl; Harriet looks like a tart. Maureen teeters out of her inner sanctum reeking of scent. She smiles in rapture at Harriet. Perhaps she is charmed by the sight of enthusiastic amateurism. The vacuum cleaner is solemnly handed over and Maureen seems on the verge of offering us a cup of tea when the front door bursts open and four delectable young women come in, none of them, alas, wearing blue of any sort. "Ah, here comes my bwidge party," beams Maureen. "Do you play bwidge, Dulcie?" Admit not. Too much like maths. Wonder if "play bridge" is a code for something else. Wonder how many girls Maureen has. Enough for a cricket team? "Do you think they were real call-girls?" whispers Harriet in rapture as we skulk back to our bungalow. "They were so cool! And Maureen's wallpaper is, like, so lush! I'm going to paint my room exactly that red." A cosmic collision seems likely between her red and my blue. Blood and guts versus spirit and sky. I shall need Zen calm even more than I thought. Arrive home to find large parcel being signed for by Great Aunt Elspeth. "Cool!" cries Harriet, "it's the flat-packed computer workstation!" Aunt looks preoccupied, and confesses quietly to me that she fears her large intestine is intent on rebellion. "Come on, Mum!" cries Harriet, tearing open parcel. "Let's put the work-station together!" Fear it will be some time before I gain that Clear Blue Water.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Alastair Reynolds
fields.trailText: Alastair Reynolds
fields.body:
Alastair Reynolds was born in South Wales in 1966. After completing a degree in astronomy and a PhD, he moved to the Netherlands, where he works as an astrophysicist for the European Space Agency. His sci-fi stories have been translated into Czech, German and Italian, and his first novel, Revelation Space, has just been published.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Small things - a hot cup of tea after coming in from the rain; a new Fall album; seeing a woodpecker.

What is your greatest fear?
I'm still bothered by the threat of nuclear war.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I'm not a morning person: I can't function until I've had a coffee, or several.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Being bright and cheerful first thing in the morning.

What makes you depressed?
Mornings.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
Lack of bright-eyed, bushy-tailed-ness.

What is your favourite word?
'Malingerer'.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Crumpled old Post-It notes with phone numbers on them.

How did you vote in the last election?
I didn't - I'd like to say it was because I was in Holland, but really it was because I couldn't give a toss.

How will you vote in the next election?
Probably for Blair.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
Phased-out due to natural wastage.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes.

Which living person do you most despise?
I'm not massively fond of right-wing nutters or war criminals.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Temperance.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
Old Monty Python and Fawlty Towers lines, that sort of thing.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
To get rid of my asthma once and for all.

What keeps you awake at night?
An owl.

How would you like to die?
Temporarily.

Do you believe in life after death?
See above.

How would you like to be remembered?
To be remembered at all is an achievement of sorts.

fields.headline: How to watch TV
fields.trailText: For some people, watching television is a big event, like going to the cinema. They study the listings, and make a decision to watch the programme on bats. Then they write it in their diary, and look forward to it for the whole week
fields.body:
For some people, watching television is a big event, like going to the cinema. They study the listings, and make a decision to watch the programme on bats. Then they write it in their diary, and look forward to it for the whole week. The time of dinner is altered and, finally, they sit down in front of the television in their best cardigan and with a mug of tea, chocolate biscuits and the remote control in a bank vault. This is generally when a neighbour pops by and you start building a reputation for being a surly old grouch.

Other people view the TV as part of the family. It gets up with them and stays on all day. They never watch entire programmes, but just dip in and out. These people can quite happily chat away on the phone and do a jigsaw puzzle while their favourite programme is on. If this kind of person lives with the cardigan kind of person, there'll be a violent killing before long, generally around about the same time as the screening of the bat documentary.

The remote control allows you the liberty of controlling the TV without getting out of your chair. Which is great because, generally, you're pretty exhausted after spending half an hour searching the entire house for it. Zapping between channels is a popular national pastime. If you decide whether to watch motor racing or a soap opera, you can just skip between the two. This is especially easy with motor racing, as nothing happens from start to finish. Of course, you can zap too much and end up rather confused, thinking Mika Hakkinen is somebody on EastEnders.

Watching TV gives us a sense of community with other people who have all watched the same programme. If you watch soaps, you have an instant point of communication with millions of other people. If you watch nerdy programmes about bats, you also have an instant point of communication, but probably with bats.

Staying at home watching television with a plate of fish fingers in a comfortable chair with a comfortable partner has got to be one of the high points of western civilisation. As with all high points of civilisation, they rarely happen, as the chance of you having the seat, meal, partners and programme of your choice are fantastically slim.

Television can be pretty addictive. It's when you have sets in the lavatory, shed and airing cupboard that you know you are in a bad way. Of course, if you want to watch nerdy programmes on bats in total silence, that's probably where you'll end up.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Love is in the air
fields.body:
It all started with a beautiful but anonymous glass vase full of gorgeous white roses from jwflowers.com; then Anji, my secretary, said that Sir Kevin (our new chairman) wanted to see me in his office. As soon as I went in, I noticed a gold-monogrammed Nokia WAP 7110 (www.nokia.com) mobile casually lying on his desk. Could Sir K be a net addict, too? Around us, enormous digital screens showed New York, Tokyo, Frankfurt and London stock prices; in front of me, Sir K's eyes glowed incandescent with desire.

'Did you like my roses, Tanya?' he asked in an insinuating voice. The screens changed to immense images of me surfing, as naked as the Guinness horses. Sir K had seen me on the net and downloaded the webcam pictures! As I fled in shock, he cried: 'Just tell me what you want, Tanya! I can give you anything! Let's fly to Monte Carlo in my Learjet (www.bombardier.com)!

That evening, Migraine Alan, who's been to The Priory (www.prioryhealthcare.co.uk) to overcome his sexual obsession with Ann Widdecombe (www.annwiddecombemp.com) dropped in to surrender a signed photo of her, his personal treasure that will become a competition prize on my upcomingwebsite. 'I'm giving this up only to show you how much I need you! Help me, please!' he sobbed, and his pleading reached my heart.

Next morning, the phone rang: 'Hi, Tanya!' It was Ricky, the golden surfer, my key to instant paradise. 'Let's go to Casablanca (www.rickscafe.simplenet.com/humphreybogart). After El Niño, the waves there are huge!'

I m bewildered. Sir K could be my platinum future, Ricky is a magic carpet to sweet bliss, and yet Migraine Alan is lost without me. What should I do? Please be my focus group: email me at tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk, and advise me. Then I'll be able to tell you what happens next.
