fields.headline: Trickle treats
fields.standfirst: Some made him gush; others were enough to make him weep - Christopher Lloyd on the ups and downs of the water that featured at the Chelsea Flower Show
fields.trailText: Some made him gush; others were enough to make him weep - Christopher Lloyd on the ups and downs of the water that featured at the Chelsea Flower Show
fields.body:
There seems to be quite a craze for water features. A visitor recently commented on my garden's lack of them. Well, I have a formal pond and two more of the "natural" kind; that is enough for me. I live in an area of sluggish, muddy streams and have no desire for simulated rushing torrents, not even for the piddling spout, which still requires you to turn it on and relies for its functioning on a circulating pump.

At this year's Chelsea Flower Show, I believe there was not one display garden lacking water in a prominent role. I did not go along with the judges' Best Garden in Show choice - that made for Gardens Illustrated and John Brown Publishing. Box played a major role and I liked the heaving masses of neglected box topiary that were a major ingredient. But the plantings in front of them with red valerian and purple salvias were weak and fidgety. They needed pulling together with something stronger. Two or three clumps of the oat-like grass, Stipa gigantea, would have been ideal. By way of a central feature, there were stainless-steel basins periodically expectorating footling water jets at one another. If anything could be guaranteed to go wrong, with the jets falling short of their target and drenching the formal box surrounds, it was this. It was happening already.

On the other side of Main Avenue was a garden I much preferred, though the judges did not. Called A City Space, it was made for Cartier Ltd by Mark Walker. It was restful, with ample space for sitting and contemplating (or enjoying a drink) in pleasant surroundings. Shade was provided by a bevy of fastigiate oaks, their stems trimmed up (I have not seen this treatment before).

There was an awful lot of horrifyingly obvious sculpture on offer at the show in general, but here was a couple that I found agreeable and not in the least fidgety: they were black wooden spires formed of ellipses, diminishing as they rose and ending in fine points. The walls were nice, made of brick but looking like baked earth, solid and unpretentious. And there were water canals and planted beds of moisture-loving things, including gunneras and my favourite "sensitive" fern, Onoclea sensibilis .

Minimalist gardens are trendy among those who dislike gardening. You can define minimalist as you please. It should, I think, contain as few plants as possible and express a brisk disrespect for natural materials. I therefore did not warm to Christopher Bradley-Hole's Living Sculpture Garden, made for the Daily Telegraph and RF Hotels. The central feature of fissured rock had been brutally sawn to a horizontal, at the top. It looked thoroughly uncomfortable. The boundary wall could have belonged to a building site. Water was skilfully treated, however. Plants all had narrow, grassy foliage. No big leaves. Of course, Bradley-Hole can make a success of many styles, and this one pleased the judges. They would have been branded fuddy-duddy had they denied it a Gold medal.

There was a lovely garden by Arabella Lennox-Boyd for the Evening Standard, perhaps her best ever. She loves plants; that was given expression. She is Italian, and had successfully introduced three, grey-green olives either side of the central canal. Also four pencil cypresses near to the front, three on one side, a singleton on the other. And there was more besides.

Homage to Le Notre, by Tom Stuart-Smith for the Garden History Society, was largely an intricate exercise in clipped box hedges forming a labyrinth, a platoon of bay globes on tall trunks, and a nice mirror at the back with water sliding over it. Le Notre, a charming man who designed Louis XIV's greatest gardens, died 300 years ago and deserves celebration.

And there was an even more palpable connection with France in the Cabbages & Kings and Chateau de Bosmelet garden, a relaxedly stepped affair, with water at each level alternating with generous single-species, oblong plantings. Young cabbage plants, which are very ornamental, were prominent, and two beds of globe artichokes in handsome leaf. The water slid from level to level in zig-zag steps, but the implied axis was finally established at the summit, with a controlled explosion of purple allium heads in an expanding fan, and grey tree foliage (perhaps Elaeagnus 'Quicksilver') behind them. There was a feeling of spaciousness, yet plenty to take the eye.

The organised chaos of Time The Healer, designed by the staff and inmates of Leyhill Prison, won a deserved Gold. Organising chaos, so that all looks like a natural takeover of the works of man, yet is pleasing to look at, is no easy matter. This being on the Rock Bank, a rushing stream seemed a perfectly natural feature.

It would be a shame to leave unmentioned the Alpine Garden Society's great achievement on this same bank, where the somewhat fidgety bittiness of small alpine plants, even when massed, was offset by vast rocks - real, natural, weathered rocks, one of them unbelievably large. There was tumbling water here, inevitably. But I liked the plant cascade in a principal fissure between rocks of Genista lydia - lots of it, just coming into bloom

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck sadly ponders the fact that sometimes wines can let you down
fields.body:
You can buy wine by clicking on a mouse, but you cannot so easily send it back. As long as corks are used to seal wines, there will be incidences of tainted fruit and variance between one bottle's quality and the next. Wines can let you down. So ask any internet wine dealer how they will handle a duff bottle.

If you deal with a supermarket, you can get your money back fairly pronto. Thus, if you wish to spend £3.99 on ItsWine.com's James Herrick Cuvée Simone Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (£3.99, 16.5 points out of 20), then ask them the above question. At Somerfield, however, the question is redundant. It offers the same product at the same price (until June 20). It has a certain smooth Englishness to it, this red wine (belying its provenance, Narbonne, but confirming the origins of its maker) in that its soft-fruit richness and sveltely polished texture are polite rather than outspokenly rustic. Herrick has sold out to Penfolds since this vintage, so I expect the wine to change. Wines do, when the personalities behind them change. This contradicts those innocent dupes who think soil makes wine, but we all need romantic fiction in our lives, do we not? Many wine-drinkers swallow little else.

We also need Tesco and Sainsbury. The former has three new arrivals, all red, which are just about to go on to certain branches' shelves today (0800 505555 for details). Valdivieso Carignan 1999 (16 points, £4.99) has lovely, earthy fruit, herby and warm, with a resounding sense of pleasure-seeking demeanour. It's an ample quaffing wine - as well as going robustly with food. Rasteau Ctes du Rhne Villages 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99) is drenched in herbs of subtlety yet resonant incisiveness, and the fruit is bold, textured and fully charged from nose to throat. Santa Ines Cabernet/Carmenere Reserva Legado de Armida 1999 (17.5 points, £5.99), from Chile, has a level of richness and balanced tannicity that defies belief at this price. The ruffled velvet texture is very classy, so are the finely meshed acids and tannins.

Sainsbury's has Alteza 775 Tempranillo Cabernet Sauvignon (16 points, £4.49), a non- vintage wine from Spain. It's the juicy style of cabernet, vivacious and deep, but it has solid tannins to give it serious presence. Terra Mater Zinfandel Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile, gallops juicily over the tastebuds in fairly rumbustious fashion, then cools its heels, courses softly down the throat, before - and, yes, there is a further dimension - it leaves a lush, savoury afterglow. Sicilian Red (15 points, £2.99) parades spice, cherries, plums, earth, a toffeed ripeness and an urgency to please. Bright Brothers Roman Vines Negroamaro Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £4.49), from Italy, is gorgeously sticky, yet not overbaked or overspiced. It flaunts blackcurrants, earth, plums and strawberries buttressed by excellent tannins.

Enate Cabernet Merlot 1998 (16.5 points, £5.99) has sweet cherries and gently warm plums on the finish, but the overture is beautifully savoury and ripe, stylishly smooth and finely textured. South African Pinotage (16 points, £4.29) has terrific modernity and chutzpah. It shows a hint of civilised boy-racer rubber, spice and a lovely, dry, tannic finish to the cassis/plum fruit. Fairview Pinotage 1999 (17 points, £5.99) is one of South Africa's, perhaps the world's, most joyously juicy yet seriously delicious, multi-layered wines. It has wonderful graduated texture, a middle wallop of berries and a striking, witty finish.

To end at Sainsbury's on a rich, white note, there is Canepa Winemaker's Selection Gewürztraminer 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile. Gewürz equals spice, for sure, but it also means a playful (if gently crisp) construct of massive quaffability. Soft, roseate, subtle yet insistent, it makes a refreshing change from chardonnay.

Until June 20, Somerfield has three further bargains. Vina Cana 1998 is a deliciously crisp and unfussy white rioja, reduced to £3.49 and rating 15 points. Courtilles 125 1998 is a handsome red 15.5-point Corbières of vigour, bite and no little elegance, reduced to £4.39. And Gouts et Couleurs Syrah/ Mourvedre Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 is marvellously herby, subtly cassis-tinged and reduced to a risible £2.99. It easily walks off with 16 points.

Valdivieso Carignan 1999 (16 points, £4.99) has lovely, earthy fruit, herby and warm, with a resounding sense of pleasure-seeking demeanour. It's an ample quaffing wine - as well as going robustly with food. Rasteau Ctes du Rhne Villages 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99) is drenched in herbs of subtlety yet resonant incisiveness, and the fruit is bold, textured and fully charged from nose to throat. Santa Ines Cabernet/Carmenere Reserva Legado de Armida 1999 (17.5 points, £5.99), from Chile, has a level of richness and balanced tannicity that defies belief at this price. The ruffled velvet texture is very classy, so are the finely meshed acids and tannins. Sainsbury's has Alteza 775 Tempranillo Cabernet Sauvignon (16 points, £4.49), a non- vintage wine from Spain. It's the juicy style of cabernet, vivacious and deep, but it has solid tannins to give it serious presence. Terra Mater Zinfandel Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile, gallops juicily over the tastebuds in fairly rumbustious fashion, then cools its heels, courses softly down the throat, before - and, yes, there is a further dimension - it leaves a lush, savoury afterglow. Sicilian Red (15 points, £2.99) parades spice, cherries, plums, earth, a toffeed ripeness and an urgency to please. Bright Brothers Roman Vines Negroamaro Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £4.49), from Italy, is gorgeously sticky, yet not overbaked or overspiced. It flaunts blackcurrants, earth, plums and strawberries buttressed by excellent tannins. Enate Cabernet Merlot 1998 (16.5 points, £5.99) has sweet cherries and gently warm plums on the finish, but the overture is beautifully savoury and ripe, stylishly smooth and finely textured. South African Pinotage (16 points, £4.29) has terrific modernity and chutzpah. It shows a hint of civilised boy-racer rubber, spice and a lovely, dry, tannic finish to the cassis/plum fruit. Fairview Pinotage 1999 (17 points, £5.99) is one of South Africa's, perhaps the world's, most joyously juicy yet seriously delicious, multi-layered wines. It has wonderful graduated texture, a middle wallop of berries and a striking, witty finish. To end at Sainsbury's on a rich, white note, there is Canepa Winemaker's Selection Gewürztraminer 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile. Gewürz equals spice, for sure, but it also means a playful (if gently crisp) construct of massive quaffability. Soft, roseate, subtle yet insistent, it makes a refreshing change from chardonnay. Until June 20, Somerfield has three further bargains. Vina Cana 1998 is a deliciously crisp and unfussy white rioja, reduced to £3.49 and rating 15 points. Courtilles 125 1998 is a handsome red 15.5-point Corbières of vigour, bite and no little elegance, reduced to £4.39. And Gouts et Couleurs Syrah/ Mourvedre Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 is marvellously herby, subtly cassis-tinged and reduced to a risible £2.99. It easily walks off with 16 points.

fields.headline: Sphere of influence
fields.standfirst: Visionary inventor Buckminster Fuller was the master of the dome-shaped home - long before  that Dome ever existed. Dominic Murphy remembers a maverick and polymath whose dreams helped define a generation
fields.trailText: Visionary inventor Buckminster Fuller was the master of the dome-shaped home - long before  that Dome ever existed. Dominic Murphy remembers a maverick and polymath whose dreams helped define a generation
fields.body:
Six months into the Millennium Experience, you'd think the public had had enough of domes. But if a new exhibition is anything to go by, there are some who reckon this is far from the case. Just a few miles up-river from the Greenwich site of Britain's most derided tourist attraction, the Design Museum is to hold a show on the work of R Buckminster Fuller, the charismatic American inventor who died in 1983. "Bucky", as he liked to be known, had many strings to his bow - architect, mathematician and engineer among them. But his big idea, which has earned him a name-check in history, was the geodesic dome.

Forget the cantilevered dome designed by Lord Richard Rogers. Instead, think of a spherical structure made up of triangles of differing sizes. Disney's Epcot Centre, say, and, before that, the US pavilion at the 1967 Montreal World Fair. Since Fuller got his patent in 1953, around 200,000 of his domes have been built, enclosing more space on the planet than the work of any other architect.

While Fuller's interests ranged from teaching to transport, Plato to plumbing, his life's work was dominated by housing. As early as 1927, he predicted the homes shortage that would emerge in the US in 1944. Fuller also wanted to see the world's resources used more efficiently and, to this end, set about designing revolutionary buildings that would maximise space and minimise materials and energy. In 1929, he conceived the "Dymaxion" house, a hexagonal-shaped building radiating from a central mast. The Dymaxion bathroom would follow, a "wet cell" rather like that in an aeroplane, but bigger. And, by the late 40s, he had perfected his idea for a geodesic dome.

This grid of intersecting arcs distributed weight in the most economical way possible ("geodesic" lines mark the shortest distance across a globe between given points). Using lightweight materials such as aluminium, the dome was aerodynamic, which meant it stood up to the wind, while its spherical shape enclosed more space in less surface area. In comparison, the traditional comfy notion of bricks, mortar, timber and tile, realised as an oblong or square, didn't get a look in.

Though Fuller went on to build many domes, he would never fulfil a dream to mass-produce them. But the idea would never fall into obscurity - thanks, in some measure, to the hippy generation. Fuller would have been well into his 70s when the 60s was in full swing, but his ideas - such as saving the planet's resources, diverting the energy from weapons manufacture into that of housing ("Livingry", he called it), and trading individual gain for mass welfare - were just as popular as the Pill.

This, according to one of the largest of America's 40-odd dome manufacturers, is reflected in buying habits today. "A lot of people in the 60s who were counter-culture types fell in love with them because they're eco-friendly and their shape is very spiritual - there is a lot of native dwelling that is round, the world is round . . . that kind of thing," says Jim Hawkins of Oregon Dome Inc. "Now these people are in their 40s and 50s, have a bit of money and are coming back to us."

Oregon sells some 70 buildings a year in kit form and, says Hawkins, they cost around $10 (£7) per foot less than standard buildings. You can get a "nice" three-bedroom, two-bathroom, 1,8000sq ft home for between $16,000 (£10,500) and $40,000 (£24,500), depending on the kit specification. (The Americans like to fit their own bathrooms, while a recent consignment to Japan wanted much of the interior supplied, too.) Then there is the cost of putting up the structure - anything between $70,000 (£46,000) and $200,000 (£132,000), depending on how much work you do yourself.

Besides ageing hippies, says Hawkins, Oregon's other main clients are people who live in areas of severe weather - such as tornado zones in the south-east states and very hot or very cold areas such as Arizona or the Rocky Mountains.

"Most dome houses are in places people think of as back-to-nature places - Maine, Oregon, Washington state," says Kathy Schrock, a dome-house owner since 1987.

While alternative lifestyle enthusiasts are drawn to such houses, there are also many "ordinary Americans", herself included, who own them - sometimes as second homes.

She is impressed with her dome, she says, but it is not perfect. All the angles create areas of low ceilings, which makes it difficult to place furniture. "I can't say I haven't smacked my head. Before we built it, I made a model with cardboard furniture - I wanted to make sure it fitted."

A recurring problem for dome homes is the rain. Because of all the joins needed between all those triangles, there are more places that need sealing than a conventional home, and they are more prone to leaks. At Brithdir Mawr, a sustainably-managed community in South Wales, there is a dome home built by local company Geodomes. According to Tony Wrench, one of the members of the community of "13 adults and lots of teenagers and one newborn baby", they have cured the leaking by spending a fortune on the seals. "You can design it by computer, but you need pretty skilled labour to make them watertight," says Wrench.

Whatever their disadvantages, these domes have few equals as lightweight, space- and energy-efficient (up to 30% saving on bills, claims Oregon Domes), quickly-erected structures that will withstand the worst of weather. After the Kobi earthquake in Japan, for example, Oregon Domes was inundated with orders. And in Cornwall, the £75 million Eden biosphere - designed by Nicholas Grimshaw on a difficult site that would have needed major drilling for a conventional building - includes two "biomes" made up of inter-linking geodesic domes, covering 23,000 sq metres.

So why are there not more dome homes? According to Wrench, whose community includes other homes with non-mainstream designs, there is a resistance to radical architecture among the establishment. Planners today still want to see buildings designed with traditional materials. (What if, speculates Wrench, plastic roofing membranes were invented in Victorian times: would planners still be demanding we use tiles?) And there is still consumer demand - we love our stone-and brick-built traditional dwellings.

Fuller had the same problem with changing attitudes. He was largely self-taught, and his domes were viewed with scepticism by the architectural establishment. Some thought he was a genius; others a charlatan. But by 1953 - when he designed a lightweight geodesic roof over the courtyard of the Ford Rotunda in Michigan, a job that had baffled the car company's engineers - the doubters had to eat humble pie. Fuller had gone from maverick outsider to celebrated architect and engineer. A true American hero, if ever there was

 Buckminster Fuller: Your Private Sky, is at London's Design Museum, Butlers Wharf, from Thursday. Details on 020-7378 6055 (www.designmuseum.org)

fields.headline: Get fresh
fields.standfirst: Lime soda
fields.trailText: Lime soda
fields.body: Francophiles who think no thirst-quencher can beat a citron pressé clearly haven't had the pleasure of sipping a fresh lime soda in an air-conditioned bar in some steamy exotic spot. For the perfect lime soda, which is the home-made lemonade of India and Sri Lanka, you'll need to make up a sugar syrup in advance. Melt sugar (raw cane, preferably) in the same quantity of water and leave to cool. Then, in a tall glass, squeeze a lime or two (you need about and inch of juice) and add half as much sugar syrup (or less or more to taste). Fill with ice-cold soda water, and lick your parched lips as you watch it effervesce. Substitute sparkling water for soda, if you like, or still, if you hate fizz. To give your lime soda an alcohol-free kick, transform it into a ginger punch - as served in the deluxe Malabar House Residency, in Kerala's historic Fort Cochin. Just add a shot of fresh ginger juice - process the root to a pulp, or crush it in a garlic press, then strain off the juice.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Cream genie: cottage cheese
fields.trailText: Cream genie: cottage cheese
fields.body:
The subject
Don't bother me, I'm trying to lose weight. Oh, sorry. Ahem... Milk, heated and curdled and drained of whey. A fresh cheese first made in Pennsylvanian Dutch homes in the 19th century and now industrialised.

The basics
Cottage cheese is known through much of the English-speaking world as the constant companion (usually about as welcome as a genital wart) of people who are trying to lose weight. In her song Dieter's Prayer, the American singer Amanda McBroom implores the Almighty: 'Teach me, tonight, to love cottage cheese/Grapefruit and celery, Lord, if you please.'

The details
The Slimming Knowledge knows that cottage cheese doesn't deserve its bad rep. Like tofu, rice, pasta, etc, it's a bland base for the good stuff. Mix with fruit, or with tomatoes, cucumbers and a soupçon of chopped herbal things for delicious lunches, even if you're not in slimming mode. Place on toast, top with slivered spring onions, dribble on balsamic vinegar. Use as the basis for a lower-cal vinaigrette or dip. Or smoked-salmon canapés. This list could go on until I had you whimpering for double cream. Caloric un-damage: around 100 calories per 100g, and that's the fattening variety. Ultra-low fat should untip the scales at around 80kCal. By comparison, 100g of cream cheese will land 275 calories on your love handles.

The easy way out
You could buy those tubs pre-flavoured with chives/prawns/pineapple/pork rind or whatever, but then you'd be guilty of the basest sloth. At the other extreme, it's possible to make your own. If you want to be convinced that it's a bad idea, pay a visit to www.muextension.missouri.edu/xplor/agguides/agchem/g09550.htm.

Where to buy
Not where, but what. Cottage cheese must be moist and creamy rather than dry and crumbly. The Knowledge is a longtime fan of Eden Vale. Loseley is good, too. Supermarket own brands are respectable.

fields.headline: Mothers without men
fields.standfirst: What do you do if you really want a child, but somehow you haven't yet met your soulmate? For an increasing number of women, the answer to the dilemma is donor insemination. Four women who have had babies with the help of a clinic or friends explain why they're glad that they decided to go it alone. By Amanda Riley-Jones
fields.trailText: What do you do if you really want a child, but somehow you haven't yet met your soulmate? For an increasing number of women, the answer to the dilemma is donor insemination. Four women who have had babies with the help of a clinic or friends explain why they're glad that they decided to go it alone. By Amanda Riley-Jones
fields.body:
There was a time when a woman without a husband find herself consigned and resigned to childlessness. For an unmarried woman to have a child was a brave decision, or an accident to be made the most of. But, in just a couple of generations, there has been a transformation in the self-image of single mothers - from the shame and secrecy of "being caught out" to the quiet pride of going it alone. And now, at the start of the 21st century - when divorce has become commonplace and many women bring up children virtually single-handed - a new type of family is appearing.

Increasing numbers of heterosexual women in the thirties are deciding to do without a man, and are choosing to have children on their own. Women who don't find Mr Right no longer have to settle for Mr You'll Have To Do, nor "accidentally" get pregnant by a lover reluctant to commit. They no longer have to accept that, if they cannot find a suitable partner, they'll never have children, either.

Donor insemination (DI) for single women has made it possible to have a baby without so much as setting eyes on the father. The relationship has been reduced to a biological transaction. With no emotional trauma, deceit or messy sexual shenanigans, it is a kind of immaculate conception. How fitting that our own 21st-century Madonna was reported to have been considering DI for her second child, until Guy Ritchie came along. The Artes Clinic in Rome has claimed to have had enquiries from other equally high-profile women. There's even a new TV sitcom, Oh Baby, starring a woman, with an uncommitted boyfriend, a ticking bodyclock and . . . a DI baby. So, with the old patriarchal family collapsing and science giving women a new path to reproduction, is the 21st century going to mark a radical shift in the relationship between men and women?

Hospital chef Caroline Webb was just 28 when she gave up hope of finding a suitable partner and made the decision to have a baby on her own through DI. She says, "I always assumed I'd work for a bit, meet someone and then have children at about 24. One by one, it happened to all my friends, but not to me. I don't know where the years went. I saw someone on and off from when I was 20 to 27, but he was a real womaniser. I used to go out to pubs and clubs, but never found anyone on a par, or stronger, than me. The few boyfriends I had were off as soon as I mentioned children. At the Mothers and Toddlers, I wouldn't want any of my friends' husbands. One's really boring, another's selfish and immature, and the third is always in debt. Men have always been a big disappointment."

Now 30, Caroline has a 16-month-old daughter, Eleanor, and they live in a two-bedroom house on the south coast. "My sister's a nurse, and as soon as she told me about donor insemination I went straight to my doctor," she says. He referred Caroline to the private Esperance Hospital, in Eastbourne, where, after the standard counselling session, they agreed to treat her.

"Because you have to justify yourself, you think all the issues through. I asked myself how hard it would be for the child and came to the conclusion that it's much harder for children whose fathers suddenly disappear from their lives. At least there'd be no upset in the home and my child would benefit from my happiness." As Caroline was single, the clinic asked her to write down her colouring, height and build so they could match her with a similar-looking sperm donor. "My mother came with me when I went in for insemination - it was a bit like having a smear - and I got pregnant on the second attempt.

"The first time I held Ellie, I whispered, 'I'm your Mummy and I'm so happy to have you.' People say we have the same face shape, but she's much better-looking than me! And she doesn't have our family build - she must be slight, like her father. It would have been nice to see a picture of him."

Ellie bangs on the kitchen door to get Caroline to open it and runs in, pointing to the top of the units for her favourite cereal. "When you're one to one with a child, you talk to them as you would to an adult," says Caroline. "At 13 months, Mum used to say to her, 'Come in, Ellie, and shut the door', and she would!

"I hope Ellie will feel she's had a good upbringing and is very loved," Caroline continues, "but I am worried she might resent me for what I've done, and get upset and frustrated that she can't trace her father. I shall say, 'You're special and I have as much love for you as two parents.' But I expect she'll always feel there's a missing part of her. I've reserved some sperm from the same donor so that, if I have another child, they'll have the same parents and be the same blood. They'll look similar and feel close. When I'm no longer here, they'll have each other."

Even if she doesn't have another child, she feels the family unit is complete. "Having Ellie has taken the edge off finding a partner. She's the most important thing in my life now." And she's pleased to go public about Ellie's conception. "I want to balance out all the negative stuff you read about single mums," she says. "I'm proud of what I've done and I want the world to see."

The existence of a group called Single Mothers By Choice - with 3,000 members across America, the UK, Canada, the Netherlands, Belgium, Japan and Israel, and two-thirds of whom have conceived through donor insemination - would have been unthinkable two decades ago. Since the 70s, the rate of mothers in England and Wales not registering the father's name on the birth certificate has almost doubled - from just below 28,000 in 1978 to nearly 50,000 in 1998. This year, one in seven mothers will be leaving the space under "Father" blank. Even allowing for the certificates that are re-registered at a later date to include the father's details, it's clear that something is happening.

There are no official figures for the number of British women having DI, but a spokeswoman for the Donor Conception Network confirms, "Five years ago, hardly any fertility clinics were providing DI for single women. Today, around a third do. In the past two years, especially, it has become more common." Between 1987 and 1998, the Bridge Centre in London, one of the UK's largest infertility clinics, has treated 122 heterosexual single women (47% of whom became pregnant).

So why are increasing numbers of women having children on their own? They are largely women in their thirties - the transitional generation brought up to believe that they could and, indeed, should have it all. With a whole world of opportunities denied to their mothers, some saw good reason to postpone having children for their careers - or just to extend the fun and fecklessness for as long as possible. Others have spent years in ultimately fruitless relationships and, when they become single again, don't have the time or the optimism to start searching for suitable father material. Some have such high expectations that they spend years sifting through and rejecting men, then turn around and realise that there isn't enough time left to find the ideal mate from an an ever-dwindling pool.

It's easy to be caught out. And it's a vicious trick that, at 40, a woman can feel 20 and look 30, but her reproductive organs are heading for retirement.

The Donor Conception Network says, "Half our enquiries are from single, middle-class 33- to 40-year-olds who are working and financially independent. They'd prefer to be in a relationship, but haven't found the right person and feel the clock is ticking. They're not ashamed of what they have done, but usually don't want to reveal their circumstances to work colleagues."

Tellingly, the three women who agreed to be photographed are full-time mothers, outside the working system, and less vulnerable to what people think of them. Only "Laura", as I will call her, a part-time teacher, wished to be anonymous.

Forty-four-year-old Londoner Viki Matten says, "I'm prepared to 'come out' to show people that women who choose to be single mothers through DI are not raving man-haters. I'm an ordinary, middle-class woman. The more people talk about DI, the more acceptable it's becoming. In an ideal world, I would have liked to have a child with a partner, but it didn't happen like that."

What did happen is ingenious. Viki inseminated herself at home on three consecutive days with the sperm of three male friends. Her son, Alex, now eight, knows this - that his father is one of three family friends. Viki is completely self-assured: "The identity of Alex's father is not an issue. First and foremost, Alex is mine, and he knows he is very, very loved."

Viki spent 11 years with a man who didn't want children, and had already lost one ovary through pelvic inflammatory disease when the relationship broke up. "It's bad enough if you have fertility problems, or if you don't have a man. But the odds were against me on both counts. The only single men seemed to be the football-and-boozing types. The sort of responsible, thoughtful man I wanted already had a family.

"It was more important for me to be a parent than in a relationship. And I've always believed that one dedicated parent is better than two indifferent ones, so I started to think of ways to have a child on my own. Having donor insemination is not the worst thing you can do to a child. What about all the children who are unwanted or who have abuse or constant arguing in the family? Alex's background is unusual, but he has one parent and two grandparents who adore him, and that's as good a start in life as any."

It was after four months of unsuccessful treatment with frozen sperm via a clinic that Viki's friend told her that her partner was willing to donate some of his own fresh sperm. "I was scared of involving people I knew," says Viki. "The advantage of a clinic was that it was anonymous - both in terms of the origin of the sperm and the procedure. But after talking to two other friends and their partners, the idea evolved of using sperm from more than one man to keep the biological father's identity unknown. That took the pressure off all three of them, and made it clear that the arrangement was to give a sperm donation, not to father my child. I hope that doesn't sound hard - I'm very grateful to them."

All six friends came to visit mother and baby, but there were no emotional undercurrents. "After Alex's birth, they went straight back to their original roles as my friends' husbands or partners. We stay in touch and meet once or twice a year, but none of them has a special relationship with Alex. He gets no more or less attention than if I'd had him with someone else. They care about Alex and give him presents, but that's because he's my son, not because he might be their son.

"My only regret is that I didn't do it earlier. I had my remaining ovary removed after I had Alex. But we're a very happy little unit of two. Ideally, I'd like a relationship with a man with a good sense of humour, who's kind, strong and generous of spirit. I do know women who've met sensitive, aware men, but the price they have to pay is that the men can be weak and they have to be the strong ones in the relationship.

"I never feel resentful or disappointed, because I've always known I'm 100% responsible for Alex. And if, one day, he says it was all a big mistake, I can't share that with anyone else. But the two most important things you can give a child are honesty and love. Alex knows I love him to bits, and I started to tell him about his parentage from the age of three. Because, if he found out I wasn't honest about the biggest issue in his life, how would he trust me about anything else?"

Professor Robert Edelmann, a clinical psychologist, agrees: "Families founder on secrets but, unlike most couples who have DI, most single mothers having DI do tell their child of its origins."

Viki continues: "Alex has occasionally said he'd like a father, and I've explained, 'That's the one thing I can't give you. You know who the possible people are, but you'll never have a father-type relationship with them.' He seems to accept that. The donors have said they'll talk to him about it when he's older, if he wants. And if Alex had a medical need or really wanted to take a paternity test when he was older, we'd have to deal with that. Most of our social circle know, and people have been much less reactionary than I'd envisaged."

But Viki is honest about not having all the answers. "Alex may well miss out by not having a father - I can't imagine not having mine. My mother was an opera singer away from home much of the time, so it was my father who was always there. But Alex has lots of male company and is very close to his grandparents. We visit nearly every other weekend, so it's almost as if three of us are bringing Alex up."

In the bathroom, above a child-height poster about courtesy, another poster reads, "Why chocolate is better than men". You can't help wondering if being a DI baby is harder for boys. With mothers who've got on with their lives without men, isn't there a risk that males will get the message that they're a problematic or unneccessary minority group? "But as he gets towards puberty and manhood, I may have to work on the image and role of men so that I can make him feel good about being one."

Like all the mothers interviewed, she says the parents bringing the child up, and the child's experiences, are going to be bigger influences than the father's genes. Surely she can see tell-tale traits of another person in Alex?

Viki insists, "If I see a characteristc I don't recognise as my own, I put it down to Alex being his own person. Without having someone here to compare Alex to, I don't see or think about the other half of him."

As the law stands in the UK, children born of DI through a clinic will only ever know one half of their family tree. How are these children going to feel when they discover that their mother has made a deliberate decision precluding any possibility of completing the jigsaw puzzle?

Dr Sebastian Kraemer, consultant child and adolescent psychiatrist from the Tavistock Clinic, argues, "The absence of a father may not, in itself, be damaging, but the deliberate concealment of his identity is another matter. A child is entitled to ask, 'Why can I not see the man who made half of me?' A wanted child is very lucky, but the wishes of parents should not automatically take precedence over the wishes of children."

"It's a fundamental right to know both parents," insists Eric Blyth, professor of social work at Huddersfield University. "Most of us take it for granted that we know about our genetic inheritance - about two thirds of adopted people decide to trace a birth relative at some stage in their life."

As a member of PROGAR - Project Group on Assisted Reproduction - set up by the British Association of Social Workers, he is lobbying for a change to Section 31 of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990, which prevents the offspring of DI from learning the identity of their father.

"I'm in contact with a donor offspring who's in her 50s now," says Blyth. "She's very sorry that no records were kept, because she would have liked information for the benefit of her own children. So there are inter- generational implications, too. We're also lobbying to make sure patients get a decent service from clinics, treating them as individuals, and that high-quality counselling is available to the donor, the mother and, one day, the individual born from this technique."

In America, at least some information about donors is available. There, solo mothers of DI children are queuing to list their children on a unique registry specifically created in the hope of locating half-siblings born from the same donor.

The registry, which lists the sperm bank and donation number used, was started by Jane Matten, psychotherapist and director of support group Single Mothers By Choice, who says, "With the supply of donors limited and the number of single mothers growing, you assume there are half-siblings who share the same sperm donor all over the place. When we started the registry four years ago, the mothers had newborns and it wasn't an issue. But now the children are four and five, they are starting to ask questions. It was only a matter of time before mothers would try to find siblings to give their children a sense of a larger family."

Last year, history was made when three mothers and three sets of twins from the same donor met up in a Californian playground. While the four-year-olds played together un-selfconsciously, their mothers marvelled at how similar they looked. Ninety-five per cent of mothers who discover that their sperm donor has fathered another child arrange to meet the other woman and her child - and 90% plan to continue meeting regularly. Matten explains: "Since most of our members only have one child, and yet very much wanted their children to have siblings, this is the closest thing to being able to realise that dream."

Amanda Hunt's terraced house outside Brighton is a child's heaven, with Disney mobiles and balloons all over the living room, two walls covered in professional portraits of four-year-old Thomas, a huge fishtank, three cats mooching in and out, and rabbits and guinea pigs in the garden.

"Of course, I would have preferred to have a baby with my husband. What woman wouldn't?" says Amanda, 39. When David, her husband of six years, finally admitted in therapy that he didn't want children, Amanda moved out the next day.

She says now, "I thought the worst thing my husband could do was cheat on me, but this was much worse. I was 32, angry and bitter. Tricking David into having a child would have been totally against my principles, and I wasn't prepared for another relationship because David had totally shattered my faith in men. So I decided to have a baby on my own, on my own terms." Amanda's GP referred her to the Esperance Hospital and, when she felt ready two years later, she started trying for a baby - even though she was only given a 10% chance of success.

"I joked with friends that I wanted my donor to be a strapping six-footer with blue eyes. But staff simply matched the donor as closely as possible to my appearance." It certainly worked. Thomas is the spitting image of his mother - down even to the Kirk Douglas dimple on his chin. There isn't anything I can't do, and men don't contribute a big amount to child upbringing, anyway. I feel sorry for women who find themselves single mums through no choice of their own, but it's different for me."

Once Thomas is back from play school, she can hardly get a word in as he starts climbing over her and demanding snacks. While he's distracted with his second ice-lolly, I ask where Thomas thinks he is from. Without missing a beat, he quips, "Where are you from? Outer space?!" and bursts out laughing.

"From the outset, I've been totally honest," says Amanda. "I told him that Mummy couldn't find anybody who was right to be his father, so I went to hospital, and that's where he was made. He tells people, 'I've got a special Daddy', and seems to accept it. Maybe, one day, he'll hate me for it, but I don't look too far ahead. I honestly don't think he'll miss out on anything. Even children who have fathers spend 90% of their time with Mum."

Amanda is thankful to the donor, but doesn't want to know anything about him, no longer interested in meeting men and unapologetic about being a single mother on benefits, saying, "I worked and paid tax for 18 years." She agrees that her situation is not ideal. "I'm not saying to women, 'Forget about men, and go and do it on your own.' But we are not always dealt the hand we want in life. I wasn't, and I've made the best of what life has thrown at me."

She has no regrets about giving up married life - "new cars, holidays, meals out and a man I loved" - and says, "I would be happy living in a tent, as long as I had Thomas. It makes me wonder what life was about before."

So far, five-year-old Robin hasn't asked about his father, and Laura doesn't think he has yet worked out that there's another person related to him. She's keeping the information about his biological father in a drawer, along with his birth certificate. As Laura's parents are in their 80s and frail, she's never felt it necessary to tell them about Robin's origins. But it's a sign of the times that the neighbour asked over the fence, "Is there a boyfriend we didn't know about, or did you do DI or something like that?"

"I would have loved Robin to grow up in the countryside with a Mummy and Daddy and masses of cousins," says Laura. "But you have to make the best of life, and I'm confident I can provide him with a good experience so he'll grow into a happy, balanced person. I expect he'll throw it into my face at some time, and I'll have to be confident and firm on my feet that I did the right thing.

"But I am very worried that he'll be missing a male role model. His school doesn't have a single male teacher, and most of the women I know are single. The bottom line is, there aren't many men I like as people, although the younger generations are less chauvinistic. Robin sometimes says, 'I don't have a Daddy, but you can share yours.' When I asked why he wished he had a father, he replied, 'We could play killing games.' I'm trying to find good male role models for him in books, but it's not easy."

Every month, the London DI Support Group members meets up with all the children. "I'm glad Robin will grow up knowing lots of other children in the same position," says Laura. "Being a single parent with one child is very, very intense, and there's a risk of becoming co-dependent, which is why I never considered giving up my career. But a few weeks ago, Robin asked if I'd had him because I wanted a friend. I can't remember what I said; I was so thrown. That night, I decided I ought to start going out more and called some personal ads in the paper.

"It's interesting that people always ask single mothers why they wanted a child so much, while so many other people have children without giving it a thought. And we're accused of being selfish. But everyone who has a child is being selfish. We all want someone to love. Why should I have accepted my lack of a partner as a sentence of childlessness?"

In an ideal world, people wanting babies would be able to find someone with whom to have a child and share a future. And that is still the case for the vast majority of people. Despite rumours of their demise, marriage and the family survive, and 60% of married couples stay together. Single mothers using DI are still a tiny proportion.

But who would bet on that number decreasing, unless men and women somehow battle out a new set of ground rules?

They no longer have to accept that, if they cannot find a suitable partner, they'll never have children, either. With no emotional trauma, deceit or messy sexual shenanigans, it is a kind of immaculate conception. How fitting that our own 21st-century Madonna was reported to have been considering DI for her second child, until Guy Ritchie came along. The Artes Clinic in Rome has claimed to have had enquiries from other equally high-profile women. There's even a new TV sitcom, Oh Baby, starring a woman, with an uncommitted boyfriend, a ticking bodyclock and . . . a DI baby. So, with the old patriarchal family collapsing and science giving women a new path to reproduction, is the 21st century going to mark a radical shift in the relationship between men and women? Hospital chef Caroline Webb was just 28 when she gave up hope of finding a suitable partner and made the decision to have a baby on her own through DI. She says, "I always assumed I'd work for a bit, meet someone and then have children at about 24. One by one, it happened to all my friends, but not to me. I don't know where the years went. I saw someone on and off from when I was 20 to 27, but he was a real womaniser. I used to go out to pubs and clubs, but never found anyone on a par, or stronger, than me. The few boyfriends I had were off as soon as I mentioned children. At the Mothers and Toddlers, I wouldn't want any of my friends' husbands. One's really boring, another's selfish and immature, and the third is always in debt. Men have always been a big disappointment." Now 30, Caroline has a 16-month-old daughter, Eleanor, and they live in a two-bedroom house on the south coast. "My sister's a nurse, and as soon as she told me about donor insemination I went straight to my doctor," she says. He referred Caroline to the private Esperance Hospital, in Eastbourne, where, after the standard counselling session, they agreed to treat her. "Because you have to justify yourself, you think all the issues through. I asked myself how hard it would be for the child and came to the conclusion that it's much harder for children whose fathers suddenly disappear from their lives. At least there'd be no upset in the home and my child would benefit from my happiness." As Caroline was single, the clinic asked her to write down her colouring, height and build so they could match her with a similar-looking sperm donor. "My mother came with me when I went in for insemination - it was a bit like having a smear - and I got pregnant on the second attempt. "The first time I held Ellie, I whispered, 'I'm your Mummy and I'm so happy to have you.' People say we have the same face shape, but she's much better-looking than me! And she doesn't have our family build - she must be slight, like her father. It would have been nice to see a picture of him."
