"Most of us take it for granted that we know about our genetic inheritance - about two thirds of adopted people decide to trace a birth relative at some stage in their life." As a member of PROGAR - Project Group on Assisted Reproduction - set up by the British Association of Social Workers, he is lobbying for a change to Section 31 of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990, which prevents the offspring of DI from learning the identity of their father. "I'm in contact with a donor offspring who's in her 50s now," says Blyth. "She's very sorry that no records were kept, because she would have liked information for the benefit of her own children. So there are inter- generational implications, too. We're also lobbying to make sure patients get a decent service from clinics, treating them as individuals, and that high-quality counselling is available to the donor, the mother and, one day, the individual born from this technique." In America, at least some information about donors is available. There, solo mothers of DI children are queuing to list their children on a unique registry specifically created in the hope of locating half-siblings born from the same donor. The registry, which lists the sperm bank and donation number used, was started by Jane Matten, psychotherapist and director of support group Single Mothers By Choice, who says, "With the supply of donors limited and the number of single mothers growing, you assume there are half-siblings who share the same sperm donor all over the place. When we started the registry four years ago, the mothers had newborns and it wasn't an issue. But now the children are four and five, they are starting to ask questions. It was only a matter of time before mothers would try to find siblings to give their children a sense of a larger family." Last year, history was made when three mothers and three sets of twins from the same donor met up in a Californian playground. While the four-year-olds played together un-selfconsciously, their mothers marvelled at how similar they looked. Ninety-five per cent of mothers who discover that their sperm donor has fathered another child arrange to meet the other woman and her child - and 90% plan to continue meeting regularly. Matten explains: "Since most of our members only have one child, and yet very much wanted their children to have siblings, this is the closest thing to being able to realise that dream." Amanda Hunt's terraced house outside Brighton is a child's heaven, with Disney mobiles and balloons all over the living room, two walls covered in professional portraits of four-year-old Thomas, a huge fishtank, three cats mooching in and out, and rabbits and guinea pigs in the garden. "Of course, I would have preferred to have a baby with my husband. What woman wouldn't?" says Amanda, 39. When David, her husband of six years, finally admitted in therapy that he didn't want children, Amanda moved out the next day. She says now, "I thought the worst thing my husband could do was cheat on me, but this was much worse. I was 32, angry and bitter. Tricking David into having a child would have been totally against my principles, and I wasn't prepared for another relationship because David had totally shattered my faith in men. So I decided to have a baby on my own, on my own terms." Amanda's GP referred her to the Esperance Hospital and, when she felt ready two years later, she started trying for a baby - even though she was only given a 10% chance of success. "I joked with friends that I wanted my donor to be a strapping six-footer with blue eyes. But staff simply matched the donor as closely as possible to my appearance." It certainly worked. Thomas is the spitting image of his mother - down even to the Kirk Douglas dimple on his chin. "When Thomas was born, I was thrilled not to have to share him with anyone and to know I could put his interests first. I'm surprised when people look at me sympathetically. There isn't anything I can't do, and men don't contribute a big amount to child upbringing, anyway. I feel sorry for women who find themselves single mums through no choice of their own, but it's different for me." Once Thomas is back from play school, she can hardly get a word in as he starts climbing over her and demanding snacks. While he's distracted with his second ice-lolly, I ask where Thomas thinks he is from. Without missing a beat, he quips, "Where are you from? Outer space?!" and bursts out laughing. "From the outset, I've been totally honest," says Amanda. "I told him that Mummy couldn't find anybody who was right to be his father, so I went to hospital, and that's where he was made. He tells people, 'I've got a special Daddy', and seems to accept it. Maybe, one day, he'll hate me for it, but I don't look too far ahead. I honestly don't think he'll miss out on anything. Even children who have fathers spend 90% of their time with Mum." Amanda is thankful to the donor, but doesn't want to know anything about him, no longer interested in meeting men and unapologetic about being a single mother on benefits, saying, "I worked and paid tax for 18 years." She agrees that her situation is not ideal. "I'm not saying to women, 'Forget about men, and go and do it on your own.' But we are not always dealt the hand we want in life. I wasn't, and I've made the best of what life has thrown at me." She has no regrets about giving up married life - "new cars, holidays, meals out and a man I loved" - and says, "I would be happy living in a tent, as long as I had Thomas. It makes me wonder what life was about before." At the same time as demand from single mothers rises, there is a national shortage of sperm donors. The UK's largest sperm bank has fewer than 50 contributors. Professor Gedis Grudzinskas, medical director of the Bridge Centre in London, explains: "The donor has to be committed - there's one batch of tests at the beginning and another after the sperm has been in six months' quarantine. We only accept 5% of donors who come forward. The others are excluded on grounds of medical history or personality traits." Jane Skelton, senior embryologist at the Esperance's assisted conception unit, adds, "I advertise at Sussex University, and usually get around 10 new donors a year. But at the moment I have no new donors at all, and have to use one of the big sperm banks in London." Everyone cites the acute shortage in Scotland, where one man is single-handedly producing Glasgow's supplies. Elsewhere, fair-haired couples are having to use sperm from dark-haired donors, and sperm is having to be bought in for ethnic minorities. Experts claim potential donors are being deterred by the HFEA Act 1990, which requires that their name must be logged on a central register held by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority. And subsequent consultations about what information should be given out to donor offspring have led to nervous rumblings that the law guaranteeing donors' anonymity could be changed. Discussions about the possibility of phasing out the £15 payment to donors haven't helped, either. Apart from the problems of supply, UK clinics give out little information about donors, and many women wish they could know more. Jane Skelton says, "Around half the single women we have treated have specified in great detail what interests they'd like the donor to have, such as being sporty or musical." But with women specifying certain characteristics (not to mention American models selling their eggs), is there a danger of reproduction becoming like an outing to Baby-U-Like? Could it be argued that, if 95% of potential donors are refused, we have already stepped into the arena of eugenics? Dr Tom Shakespeare of the Policy and Ethics Research Institute, a new collaborative project set up to explore the social implications of the new genetics, argues, "I'm not against the idea of single women choosing to have a baby via donor insemination - and plenty of women I know have done this - but I am concerned when babies begin to be seen as a 'right' or 'commodity'. There is a difference between women choosing to have a child and choosing to have a particular child - say, with blond hair and blue eyes." According to Viki, "Striving for the perfect baby with the perfect brain smacks of designer babies and discredits what I've done. I wanted a child for who that child could be. I didn't have a checklist of specific qualities in mind." Laura, a part-time teacher living in the home counties, wanted a child so badly that she had artificial insemination 30 times and two miscarriages before her son, Robin, was born in 1995. "Having a child by DI is a wonderful opportunity to let your child be their own person from the start," says Laura, 46. "You don't have specific expectations. I said to the clinic, 'Just choose someone who's had a good success rate.' "I had a year off work after Robin was born and I was a wreck at first," she admits. "If a single woman has a child by DI, there's a taboo against saying how difficult it is, but it can be exhausting. I still miss having emotional support and someone to share the joys of having Robin. "There was always this family mythology that I was the pretty one who'd marry young and have babies. I did have a very good relationship from 17 to 27, and we both wanted children, but I never felt ready. When I needed to come to London for my career, I decided to move on without him. But I've never met anyone I could relate to as well. In 19 years, I've had three relationships with completely unsuitable men. My perfect partner would be emotionally alive and able to communicate, and that cuts out most of them. But I'd rather be on my own than compromise." Two years after Robin was born, Laura realised he was entitled to know as much as possible about the donor, and contacted the clinic again. "Friends had always said his father must be a farmer or carpenter, because he's so passionate about tools and tractors. So we laughed our socks off when I found out that his father had such a similar profession and interests to mine: tennis, photography and the flute. If there had been a catalogue of donors, that's who I would have chosen." So far, five-year-old Robin hasn't asked about his father, and Laura doesn't think he has yet worked out that there's another person related to him. She's keeping the information about his biological father in a drawer, along with his birth certificate. As Laura's parents are in their 80s and frail, she's never felt it necessary to tell them about Robin's origins. But it's a sign of the times that the neighbour asked over the fence, "Is there a boyfriend we didn't know about, or did you do DI or something like that?" "I would have loved Robin to grow up in the countryside with a Mummy and Daddy and masses of cousins," says Laura. "But you have to make the best of life, and I'm confident I can provide him with a good experience so he'll grow into a happy, balanced person. I expect he'll throw it into my face at some time, and I'll have to be confident and firm on my feet that I did the right thing. "But I am very worried that he'll be missing a male role model. His school doesn't have a single male teacher, and most of the women I know are single. The bottom line is, there aren't many men I like as people, although the younger generations are less chauvinistic. Robin sometimes says, 'I don't have a Daddy, but you can share yours.' When I asked why he wished he had a father, he replied, 'We could play killing games.' I'm trying to find good male role models for him in books, but it's not easy." Every month, the London DI Support Group members meets up with all the children. "I'm glad Robin will grow up knowing lots of other children in the same position," says Laura. "Being a single parent with one child is very, very intense, and there's a risk of becoming co-dependent, which is why I never considered giving up my career. But a few weeks ago, Robin asked if I'd had him because I wanted a friend. I can't remember what I said; I was so thrown. That night, I decided I ought to start going out more and called some personal ads in the paper. "It's interesting that people always ask single mothers why they wanted a child so much, while so many other people have children without giving it a thought. And we're accused of being selfish. But everyone who has a child is being selfish. We all want someone to love. Why should I have accepted my lack of a partner as a sentence of childlessness?" In an ideal world, people wanting babies would be able to find someone with whom to have a child and share a future. And that is still the case for the vast majority of people. Despite rumours of their demise, marriage and the family survive, and 60% of married couples stay together. Single mothers using DI are still a tiny proportion. But who would bet on that number decreasing, unless men and women somehow battle out a new set of ground rules?

fields.headline: On the road again
fields.standfirst: In the past, young travellers took to the Hippy Trail in search of new experiences, new ideas and a new way of living. But with the revolution in air travel, today's 'hippies' have different goals entirely - to have a laugh before they settle down. Melanie McGrath sees a shift in spiritual and social values
fields.trailText: In the past, young travellers took to the Hippy Trail in search of new experiences, new ideas and a new way of living. But with the revolution in air travel, today's 'hippies' have different goals entirely - to have a laugh before they settle down. Melanie McGrath sees a shift in spiritual and social values
fields.body:
A man at my local Buddhist Centre in Brighton used to be a hippy, but he gave it up and became a monk instead. Just over 26 years ago, Padamasana (not his real name) was a garden-variety hippy teen from a middle-class London suburb. He didn't wash all that often. His hair was long. When he wasn't hitching to free festivals or dropping acid at the houses of his friends, Padamasana was inclined to shut himself away in his bedroom, re-reading Siddharta and spacing out to the Floyd. His mother, who loved him in spite of this, nonetheless despaired of his sanitary habits. Mercifully, she knew nothing of his drug ones.

In 1974, Padamasana felt moved to act. "I knew I was missing out on something," he says. After months of saving and planning, he took himself off on the Hippy Trail to Kathmandu. Hitching a ride in a friend's VW camper-van, he trundled through Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey, into Iran, across Afghanistan and Pakistan, before arriving, after four months on the road, in Kathmandu. There, he re-read Siddharta, spaced out to the Floyd and dropped acid with his new friends. But this time something more momentous happened. A few months after arriving in Kat, he decided his life should take a different turn and, after many years of rigorous meditation and spiritual practice, became a Buddhist monk. Which is what he is today.

Padamasana might well get along with Rupert Evans, though the two have nothing very obvious in common. Evans is 28. He's an art director for the advertising agency Bilko Multimedia. Some months ago, Evans felt the stirrings of a formless discontent. A couple of weeks later, he bought a cheap flight to Bangkok and went off travelling, "to get my head together". Following the New Hippy Trail, Evans island-hopped around Thailand from Ko Phi Phi and Ko Lanta to Ko Samui and Ko Pha-Ngan. From there, he travelled north to Chiang Mai, then crossed the border into Laos and drifted along the Mekong River to the city of Vientiane. From Vientiane he caught another cheap flight to Hanoi, bussed down the east coast of Vietnam and pitched up in Indonesia. A quick hop through Sumatra, Java, Lombok and Timor led him to Darwin, Australia, from where he went over the top to Cairns, Melbourne and Sydney. Then Rupert caught a flight back home.

On his return to Heathrow (Terminal 4), Rupert proposed to his girlfriend Emma, a textile buyer for River Island. "You've got jet-lag," scoffed Emma, but later she thought again and said yes. They've recently bought a house in Acton, west London, which they are doing up. In August, they'll be married.

This is the story of two well-beaten paths, the Old Hippy Trail and the New Hippy Trail, and the men and women who've been down them. It is also - inevitably - a record of the revolution in the way we travel and, perhaps not surprisingly, how that revolution has changed us along the way.

Journeying has always served as a metaphor for the passage from one life state to another, from childhood to adulthood, ignorance to wisdom, life to death. But leisure travel and, still more, mass leisure travel now seems so everyday that it's hard to believe how recent it actually is. Only 40 years ago, travelling for fun was still the province of the very wealthy. In Middle English, the word "journey" means a day's work. For the vast majority in the west, for hundreds of years, travel has implied economic necessity, political persecution or war (as it still does for most people in the developing world). Ironically, it was the second world war that opened the idea of leisure travel to a new audience, creating for the first time a whole generation of men (and it was mostly men) who had actually experienced a world beyond Britain's borders. People such as my grandfather, an Eastender who would probably have gone no further than Poplar on the bus had His Majesty's Army not despatched him by sea to Mandalay.

Post-war writers such as Hemingway and Kerouac picked up on the new allure of travel and ran with it. The economic migrant, the political dissident, the demobbed soldier became the self-starter, the freedom fighter, the railroad hobo, the cowboy, the rolling stone. A man (and it was always a man) who cut his own track. A living homage to individualism. Before the invention of this man, it was hard to be different from the pack. Now, all you had to do was travel.

Middle-class kids, freighted with the obligatory resentments of their teenage status (itself a novel concept) and with a new set of social aspirations brought on by prosperity and consumerism, began finding the outlet for both in travel. (Though not of the Costa Brava variety that was, in the same moment, enthralling their mums and dads.) Teens wanted more than simply to mature into wives, husbands, teachers, lawyers, mothers. They were individuals now, with an individual identity to locate. But where? Not at home, among the debris of the old order.

The 60s was the kick-off point for many a trip. After all, the Beatles were getting gurus and the Stones were getting stoned, and free love was getting everywhere. It was easier to tune in, turn on and drop out abroad. And so travel became part of the great hippy project.

"On LSD, you see monsters with hundreds of arms, like visions of Vishnu," says C J Stone, the former Guardian Weekend columnist and author of The Last Of The Hippies. "There's something Hindu about an acid trip, so I suppose it was inevitable that India became the place to go." But how? Air travel was prohibitively expensive and the routes were limited. The only way of getting to India for the (relatively) shallow-pocketed was overland.

Snaking 4,500 miles through Holland, Germany, Austria and former Yugoslavia, on through Bulgaria to Istanbul, then across Turkey into Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan, the Hippy Trail terminated finally at the hippy mecca of Kathmandu in Nepal, where hookahs met the Himalayas. Tributaries wound their way south through the ganja-growing Kullu valley to the hippy beaches at Anjuna and Calangute in Goa, and there were odd ox-bows through Morocco, Peru and Guatemala, but the real thing was London to Kathmandu, over-land. No one seems to know who began it, or how. Like so many things in the 60s, it just sort of happened.

Eileen Campbell, now publisher of the New Age imprint Thorsons, followed the trail in the mid-70s with her erstwhile partner, Brian. "There were no guide books. You had to go to Compendium [an alternative bookshop in north London] and pick up a photo-copied booklet, which gave you tips on the route. And that was it." The couple bought an ex-Dutch post office van for £270 and painted it maroon, pink and black, "like a Rothko painting". They set off along the trail with the booklet, a pocket full of savings and a few dried goods. As they travelled, they accumulated pet birds, a cat in Iran and, in India, a dog and dysentery. "Some days, we might drive 250 miles, another day 10. We did it on a remarkably small amount of money," says Campbell. The Dutch van was their home for 18 months.

Though the trail itself was well established by the time Campbell took off, points along it were still genuinely remote. There was no such thing then as a backpacker hostel. "Often, we couldn't find a campsite," says Campbell. "People would invite you to their home. In some places we'd go slightly off the beaten track and the locals would look at us as though we'd come off the moon."

Campbell was in no doubt that she was taking a spiritual journey. "After my father died when I was 15, I became a confirmed Christian, but at university I wanted to be part of the swinging 60s, and being a Christian just wasn't cool." A four-year spell working for the publishers Routledge had put her in contact with Bhagavad-Gita and the eastern mystics. She was spellbound. "India was like a magnet."

It was a long, slow trip getting there. "Afghanistan was like going back into the middle ages." The Dutch post van broke down between Herat and Kandahar, and Brian had to hitch into Kabul for parts, leaving Campbell on her own. In Turkey, their van got stuck behind a convoy of tanks en route to the war with Greece in Cyprus. Occasionally, they'd meet fellow hippies making their way back home who would recommend places to stay, and there were certain well-known hangouts, such as the Khyber Cafe in Kabul, but all the same the trail felt hypnotically exotic. "It never seemed dangerous, though it must have been. There were wars going on, and bandits, and the driving was hard. Some of the mountain passes in India were horrendous." Nonetheless, the couple sensed that they had embarked on an epic journey that would change their lives. "It was just a glorious, glorious adventure."

At the same time as Campbell was making her way across the Khyber Pass, Jeremy Slocombe was heading north through India from his home in Australia, bound for Kathmandu. Slocombe was an early developer, presenting, at 14, his own TV talk-show on ABC Canberra. By 19, he was the creative director of Canberra's largest ad agency. The inevitable happened. Jeremy Slocombe burned out.

He spent a few months recuperating before setting off for Kathmandu. "That nervous 'breakthrough' made me realise there was a spiritual dimension to my life I needed to explore. Kathmandu was one of the places to do that, a crossroads where you felt you could meet anyone from anywhere. And there were enough mind-altering substances about to shake up your complacency." Did he consider anywhere else? "Not really. Kathmandu was the place to go."

Back in England, CJ Stone was also shaking up his complacency. While at Cardiff University, he had discovered acid and, by the mid-70s, was working in a steel factory by day and doing drugs and dropping out most nights. A working-class boy cut adrift by his own intellectual ambition, he found temporary shelter in hippiedom. "I guess I was looking for a guru. And, yeah, my initial impulse was naive, but it was a romantic time. And what 19-year-old isn't a bit self-indulgent?"

In 1975, Stone packed up and set out on the Hippy Trail, destination Kathmandu. "There were six of us in a VW camper-van, two New Zealand girls on their way back home, me and my mate, and another couple." It was the first time Stone had left England. "By the time we got to Kathmandu, we all hated each other."

Though they were in Kat at around the same time, Slocombe and Stone remember it very differently. For Slocombe, the hippy epicentre lived up to its reputation. "It was smelly, filthy, noisy and wonderful. The place had a genuine spiritual magnetism. We'd all get stoned, drink beer and tell our stories. You felt a sense that you could overcome whatever it was the straight world was telling you to do with your life."

Stone loathed the place. "We ended up at a lake by the Annapurna Himal, near Pokara. The mountains were reflected in the lake and it was beautiful, but already the huts were turning into hotels, serving pancakes and western food. You realised you were the first wave of what would become a tourist industry. One cafe used to play Elton John. I remember some hippy saying to the owner, 'Hey, you must really like Elton John', and the owner just turning around and saying, 'No, I don't like Elton John, but I know you do.' And there was just this look of complete weariness on his face."

There were enlightening times, too, though. And Stone met other hippies who were, unlike himself, part of the jet-set. The trail opened him not only to the world beyond Britain but to the world beyond the working class.

After Kathmandu, Slocombe flew to Britain and joined the "New Age" community of Findhorn, near Inverness, where he has remained for the past 23 years. Eileen Campbell also returned to Britain and dropped out for a while before becoming one of the UK's first and most successful publishers of alternative health and spirituality books. Her partner, Brian, fell in love with Buddhism and devoted himself to it.

Stone quickly became disillusioned with the "game-playing hippy edifice". "Angry and cynical", he came back to a Britain that mirrored his sentiments and dived headfirst into punk rock, which, as he put it, "didn't involve being up your own arse".

All the same, but in different ways, the Hippy Trail had lived up to its promise. It had changed their lives.

The old trail is gone now. A well-worn myth of sex, drugs and the long, hard road now sits in its place. Most of what it represented has altered or disappeared. If the Islamic Revolution in Iran and the civil war in Afghanistan had not made the original route impassable, then the more recent revolution in the travel industry would have made it impractical. Young people (and anyone else) can now fly directly into the orient for less than the price of a first-class return to Edinburgh. And they do - in droves. The number of tourists piling into Thailand increased 64-fold between 1960 and 1998. Nothing about the old trail makes much sense today. It's not so much a pathway to enlightenment as a track back in time.

Last year, STA Travel, specialists in youth and student travel, sent half-a-million young Brits abroad - 10 times the number of a decade ago - many on RTWs (Round The World Tickets). Until the mid-90s, RTWs were expensive and limiting. Now they're ubiquitous. "Airlines have merged into global entities, working together and making the whole thing cheaper and easier," says Jonathan Nye, long-haul manager for Trailfinders, a travel agency that focuses on the "independent" market. In five years, the RTW has become part of the social culture. "We are now getting repeat RTWs - people who were first-timers on the Thailand-Singapore-India-Australia-NZ route who are now wanting something more sophisticated," adds Nye.

An average RTW ticket costs £800 and, unlike Eileen Campbell's Dutch van, there's nothing to sell at the end. Says Dawn Howell, marketing manager of STA, "When the student-loan system came out, we thought it would be a problem for us, but it wasn't. Students seem to think, 'If I'm in debt for a grand, I may as well be in for three or four.' If anything, it's helped, because students have access to cheap loans." Nye agrees: "Young people see it as their right to travel. People will accept the debt because of that, and parents are more willing to pay."

Divested of the more familiar western end of the old trail by the fall in the price of flights, the New Hippy Trail has begun to creep south across south-east Asia into Australia, and from there out to the wider world. "Back in the 70s, there was more of a join-the-dots approach to the trail," says Silke Kerwick, a Rough Guides author and marketing manager of YHA in New South Wales, Australia. "Nowadays, it's not just Ko Samui or Kathmandu, but a cluster of continents. The trail has gone global."

But if the trail has changed, then so have the hippies. Julian Ruffle is a 27-year-old sales consultant at STA. This year, Julian is taking 12 holidays abroad. He's thinking about flying to Corsica for a weekend soon, and maybe to Australia and Japan at Christmas. He was in Kathmandu a while ago, "doing" India and Nepal, before following the New Hippy Trail across south-east Asia. "I've wanted to get into the personal development thing," he says, "but I just haven't had the time. Sometimes, I think I'd like to learn - what is it? - Ayurveda, because it would be nice to know how to chill out properly."

Julian is not a hippy - or at least not in the old sense of the word. "Hippies took loads of drugs and wore stupid clothes, and I probably would have hated them." His work allows him "a young and free lifestyle", but he has nothing whatsoever against the establishment and he's pretty much apolitical. Julian is part of a new breed; a realist and a pragmatist. "I'm doing long hours at STA, I'm taking care of my future," he says. He likes tuning in and dropping out for the odd month or two is all. A place for everything, and everything in its place.

Silke Kerwick identifies two styles of new hippy. "First, there are the hardcore hedonists, who I'd call the nouveau hippies, and then there are the faux hippies. The hardcores are more like your tune-in-turn-off-drop-out type of travellers, but the others are often young professionals."

Julian's friend, Rupert, mentioned earlier, is more of your hardcore type. For a while, back in the mid-90s, he dipped in and out of the Full Moon beach party scene on Ko Samui and Ko Pha-Ngan. "You'd get up at 11, go down to the beach, have a bit of breakfast and start drinking, recognise faces from the night before. By four or five o'clock, there'd be 20 people in your group having a drink and chatting about which club they fancied that night." It was - as Alex Garland astutely describes in his satirical novel about new hippies, The Beach - "careless hedonism, too diligently pursued to ring true". After three years, Rupert set out on the New Hippy Trail. "I felt I was a two-week package boy, where everyone laughs at you and doesn't talk to you, and I wanted to be a traveller."

A traveller. Ever since the days of the Grand Tour there has been status in being a traveller, rooted, maybe, in the British fascination with exclusivity. How long you stay, how remote you go, how many bargains you strike and how many drugs you deal, these are all rungs on the new hippy ladder, just as they were on the old; "proof" (if proof beyond combats, trainers and nose-ring were needed) that hitch-hikers, trailers, backpackers are the modern-day hobos - travellers, voyagers, adventurers, not remotely like (ugh, don't even say it) package tourists.

In their efforts to pin down an "archaic" and "authentic" experience, travellers express a contradictory sense of the consumerist west as inauthentic while making a consumer choice to escape it for a while, as well as the desire to connect with a culture whose rules are surer and more timeless than their own. That's the arrogance of the old hippy/new hippy thing; but it's a kind of idealism and a kind of sweet delusion, too.

The sheer volume of trailers has made the search for somewhere off the beaten track increasingly desperate. Stephanie Theobold, a young novelist, recently returned from treading the trail in Thailand. "People at Ko Lanta were trying to kid themselves that they'd done really well in getting away from it all because their filthy, insect-infested huts were still cheap. Basically, you have to go further and further south. On Ko Buton Leh, there were only 15 or so bungalows, and there were people running like mad from the boat to be the first to get them."

Whereas the original hippies were pretty much forced to camp or to stay with locals, whole backpacker infrastructures have, more recently, sprung up like weeds in Kathmandu, supported by lavish guide books, films, websites and magazines, all selling the mystique of independent travel while rendering its actuality meaningless. Backpacking has lost its presumption of innocence. It is no longer just young people setting off on their life's first adventure. It's a brand. Marketed, managed and sold back to its target demographic in the same way as Coca-Cola or Nike.

Many new hippies, like other tourists, now expect places to resemble the commodified version familiar from their media. Snow-capped mountains, deserts sprinkled with sand-dunes, oceans deep and blue. Charlotte Hindle, of Lonely Planet, "can't think of any place that's too horrible to merit a Lonely Planet guide".

During the filming of Alex Garland's novel The Beach, grasses were uprooted, sand-dunes razed and 100 coconut palms planted at Maya Bay in Thailand to comply with the film's requirement for a paradise-island-type location. That's "paradise-island-type", not actual paradise island. The film caused a furore among local environmentalists, but has been, as Dawn Howell of STA admits, "key" in drumming up business from so-called "independent" travellers, many of them new hippies. (Incidentally, the novel from which the film was made is about the self-indulgent and amoral hedonism of new hippies, and you'd have to be terminally postmodern to find that twist of irony and counter-irony anything but dizzying.)

Under particular fire for diluting the independence of independent travel has been the Lonely Planet series of guide-books. According to William Sutcliffe, the author of Are You Experienced?, an amusing satire on new hippiedom: "The real purpose served by the Lonely Planet series is not to allow you to find unique and undiscovered places, but rather the opposite - to give you security in that, wherever you go, you can take a book out of your backpack and look up where all the other travellers are hanging out."

Lonely Planet founder, Tony Wheeler, erstwhile old-style hippy, veteran of the original hippy trail and now a rich man, is happy to admit that "a lot of backpackers are sheep". The fact is, this was ever and understandably so - way back in 1975, Eileen Campbell "wanted to take the road less travelled", but ended up tramping the Hippy Trail instead. However, the urge to go somewhere no other westerner has visited and, by implication, unspoiled, runs deep. "I have even met some who use the Lonely Planet to identify places they don't want to stay in," says Wheeler. There are no pedaloes in paradise.

Some new hippies are more pragmatic. "I like to get to the middle of nowhere, but if there were no other travellers I'd be bored," says Julian Ruffle. "I'm not one who thinks it's cool to hang with the locals. I'd rather go away and meet like-minded British people."

The authorities in new hippy havens such as Goa and Ko Pha-Ngan are becoming less tolerant of their "like-minded" visitors' behaviour. The perception is that new hippies deliver negligible economic benefits (though studies show the average backpacker spend is actually higher than that of the average two-week Samsonite-packer), are less easily controlled, and create social and cultural problems. The number of arrests for drugs possession among new hippies in Goa and Thailand has risen sharply in recent years, and the Goan authorities are now actively discouraging backpackers.

The original hippies were left pretty much to themselves in Kathmandu. A few sporadic protests in Goa against nude bathing by female hippies led to an influx of lone men from all over India, keen to add their voices to the cries of outrage. But, by and large, hippy ways were tolerated. That's changing, and new hippy destinations are increasingly arming themselves against cultural "pollution". What used to be tuned in, turned on and dropped out is now thrown in a cop car, turned inside out and dropped off at the local jail.

Dr Heba Aziz, a researcher at the Roehampton Institute in London, has made a study of Dahab in Egypt, a low-rent Red Sea resort surrounded by traditional Bedouin settlements. To cope with the influx of a culture so alien to their own, the Bedouin have "reconstructed [the beach] as a separate world, a tourist world with its own set of values and morals and with its neo-nomadic community". Bedouin children weave friendship bracelets to cater to the new hippies' desire for souvenirs that reflect the New Hippy Trail brand. And horny hippettes can even buy temporary marriage certificates in Dahab, allowing them to have sex with Egyptian men without attracting adverse attention from the locals. New hippies themselves often require encounters with the host culture to be contained and predictable. "There is an expectation that, wherever you are, you will be able to get Nescafé and peanut butter," observes Charlotte Hindle.

It's easy to be critical of the old hippy project. Sure, "a lot of it was egotism disguised as spirituality", as CJ Stone points out. Young people pursued the idea of sacredness in India because the dope was cheap and the living was good and they felt released from spying eyes and wagging tongues, but also - and importantly -because the opportunity for a spiritual life in the west seemed ever more remote. They may not have understood that the price of western economic affluence is non-western economic impoverishment, but they did at least see that consumerism had made the west spiritually ragged.

In many ways, the New Hippy Trail is a less hypocritical journey. A journalist character in William Sutcliffe's Are you Experienced? moans, "It's not hippies on a spiritual mission who come to India any more, just morons on a poverty tourism adventure holiday . . . going to India isn't an act of rebellion these days, its actually a form of conformity for ambitious middle-class kids who want to be able to put something on their CV that shows a bit of initiative. All the top companies want robots with initiative these days . . . Your kind of travel is all about low horizons dressed up as open-mindedness."

Yet it's hard not to mourn the substitution of spiritual aspiration (however naive) for experimental acquisition (however good-natured). "Young people want to travel for experience, not to find themselves," says Dawn Howell. "They know themselves already. Young people don't think of themselves as having an essential self. You are what you experience, and most of what you experience is a choice between consumables. Young westerners are less likely to pursue the idea of the sacred in other cultures because it is so completely absent from their own. It makes no sense to blame them. The profane world may be all they know."

For tens of thousands of years of human history, the journey has constituted one of our most potent cultural and spiritual metaphors. In the past 20, its power has faded. We no longer expect travel to change our lives. The journey has become pretty much like life. More comfortable, less innocent, fuller of things and emptier of thoughts.

But there's hope. Mark Mann, author of The Gringo Trail and a lobbyist for ethical travelling, thinks "the thing is not to go further but to go deeper into local culture, engaging at a deeper level with local people and their needs". And there is some evidence that this is happening. Tourism Concern, a charity promoting ethical travel, has just launched The Community Tourism Guide, listing destinations managed by and for the benefit of local people, while Dawn Howell says, "young people are beginning to want to put something back". We are still very far from the point where first-world-to-third-world travel, even by new hippies, constitutes anything like a genuine or fair exchange, but that, at least, may be the direction in which we are headed.

Julian Ruffle remembers his recent trip to Kathmandu with disengaged fondness. "I seem to recall that there used to be a hippy hangout in the west of Pokara on the edge of a lake," he told me. He didn't know it was the one where CJ Stone had stacked his chillum 25 years earlier. "Something happened to the hippies, though. I think that they must have been booted out. Or maybe they just quit."

Old hippy hotspots

Kathmandu, Nepal
The hippy epicentre.

Dharamsala and nearby McCleod Ganj, India
Seat-in-exile of the Dalai Lama.

Manali, India
Centre of India's marijuana-producing area.

Kabul, Afghanistan
Mid-point on the Old Hippy Trail.

Panajachel, Guatemala
Now a second-generation hippy enclave.

Marrakech, Morocco
Neither hideous nor kinky.

San Cristobal, Mexico; Calangute and Anjuna, Goa
Then, only one hotel on each; now, Bhajee Benidorm - Anjuna still holds Full Moon parties for new hippies, though.

Gilli Islands, Indonesia and Eilat, Israel
As Calangute.

Ibiza
Ditto.

New hippy hotspots

Muang Sing, Laos
Once the biggest opium market in the Golden Triangle.

Ko Chang, Ko Tao, Thailand
Stoner hangouts on the more remote beaches.

Ko Pha-Ngan
Widely dissed by hardcore new hippies, but still attracting 5,000 westerners each month to its Full Moon parties.

Siem Reap, Cambodia
Pizza seasoned with marijuana available in street cafes.

Wodong/Wairterang, Flores Island, Indonesia
Great beaches.

Cape Maclear, Malawi
Big lake, cheap dope.

Byron Bay, Australia. Dahab, Egypt. Essouira, Morocco. Cuzco, Peru
Ancient spiritual centre and, according to legend, navel of the world. Ready availability of mescalin, ayahuasca and garden-variety dope all help.

Arrecifes, Colombia
Great beach and famous for huge amounts of cocaine.

Dhungri, Vashist, Kullu Valley, India
Where hippies went when Manali got too crowded.

Chapora, Vagator, Arambol, Goa
Where hippies went when Anjuna got crowded.

Dusallan, Bhagsu
long-term hangouts for new hippies gathered around the Dalai Lama's base at McCleod Ganj. Nimbe, Sydney.

Up-and-coming

China, Panama, Borneo, Cuba, Georgia, Madagascar, El Salvador, Libya.
fields.bodyText: A man at my local Buddhist Centre in Brighton used to be a hippy, but he gave it up and became a monk instead. Just over 26 years ago, Padamasana (not his real name) was a garden-variety hippy teen from a middle-class London suburb. He didn't wash all that often. His hair was long. When he wasn't hitching to free festivals or dropping acid at the houses of his friends, Padamasana was inclined to shut himself away in his bedroom, re-reading Siddharta and spacing out to the Floyd. His mother, who loved him in spite of this, nonetheless despaired of his sanitary habits. Mercifully, she knew nothing of his drug ones. In 1974, Padamasana felt moved to act. "I knew I was missing out on something," he says. After months of saving and planning, he took himself off on the Hippy Trail to Kathmandu. Hitching a ride in a friend's VW camper-van, he trundled through Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey, into Iran, across Afghanistan and Pakistan, before arriving, after four months on the road, in Kathmandu. There, he re-read Siddharta, spaced out to the Floyd and dropped acid with his new friends. But this time something more momentous happened. A few months after arriving in Kat, he decided his life should take a different turn and, after many years of rigorous meditation and spiritual practice, became a Buddhist monk. Which is what he is today. Padamasana might well get along with Rupert Evans, though the two have nothing very obvious in common. Evans is 28. He's an art director for the advertising agency Bilko Multimedia. Some months ago, Evans felt the stirrings of a formless discontent. A couple of weeks later, he bought a cheap flight to Bangkok and went off travelling, "to get my head together". Following the New Hippy Trail, Evans island-hopped around Thailand from Ko Phi Phi and Ko Lanta to Ko Samui and Ko Pha-Ngan. From there, he travelled north to Chiang Mai, then crossed the border into Laos and drifted along the Mekong River to the city of Vientiane. From Vientiane he caught another cheap flight to Hanoi, bussed down the east coast of Vietnam and pitched up in Indonesia. A quick hop through Sumatra, Java, Lombok and Timor led him to Darwin, Australia, from where he went over the top to Cairns, Melbourne and Sydney. Then Rupert caught a flight back home. On his return to Heathrow (Terminal 4), Rupert proposed to his girlfriend Emma, a textile buyer for River Island. "You've got jet-lag," scoffed Emma, but later she thought again and said yes. They've recently bought a house in Acton, west London, which they are doing up. In August, they'll be married. This is the story of two well-beaten paths, the Old Hippy Trail and the New Hippy Trail, and the men and women who've been down them. It is also - inevitably - a record of the revolution in the way we travel and, perhaps not surprisingly, how that revolution has changed us along the way. Journeying has always served as a metaphor for the passage from one life state to another, from childhood to adulthood, ignorance to wisdom, life to death. But leisure travel and, still more, mass leisure travel now seems so everyday that it's hard to believe how recent it actually is. Only 40 years ago, travelling for fun was still the province of the very wealthy. In Middle English, the word "journey" means a day's work. For the vast majority in the west, for hundreds of years, travel has implied economic necessity, political persecution or war (as it still does for most people in the developing world). Ironically, it was the second world war that opened the idea of leisure travel to a new audience, creating for the first time a whole generation of men (and it was mostly men) who had actually experienced a world beyond Britain's borders. People such as my grandfather, an Eastender who would probably have gone no further than Poplar on the bus had His Majesty's Army not despatched him by sea to Mandalay. Post-war writers such as Hemingway and Kerouac picked up on the new allure of travel and ran with it. The economic migrant, the political dissident, the demobbed soldier became the self-starter, the freedom fighter, the railroad hobo, the cowboy, the rolling stone. A man (and it was always a man) who cut his own track. A living homage to individualism. Before the invention of this man, it was hard to be different from the pack. Now, all you had to do was travel. Middle-class kids, freighted with the obligatory resentments of their teenage status (itself a novel concept) and with a new set of social aspirations brought on by prosperity and consumerism, began finding the outlet for both in travel. (Though not of the Costa Brava variety that was, in the same moment, enthralling their mums and dads.) Teens wanted more than simply to mature into wives, husbands, teachers, lawyers, mothers. They were individuals now, with an individual identity to locate. But where? Not at home, among the debris of the old order. The 60s was the kick-off point for many a trip. After all, the Beatles were getting gurus and the Stones were getting stoned, and free love was getting everywhere. It was easier to tune in, turn on and drop out abroad. And so travel became part of the great hippy project. "On LSD, you see monsters with hundreds of arms, like visions of Vishnu," says C J Stone, the former Guardian Weekend columnist and author of The Last Of The Hippies. "There's something Hindu about an acid trip, so I suppose it was inevitable that India became the place to go." But how? Air travel was prohibitively expensive and the routes were limited. The only way of getting to India for the (relatively) shallow-pocketed was overland. Snaking 4,500 miles through Holland, Germany, Austria and former Yugoslavia, on through Bulgaria to Istanbul, then across Turkey into Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan, the Hippy Trail terminated finally at the hippy mecca of Kathmandu in Nepal, where hookahs met the Himalayas. Tributaries wound their way south through the ganja-growing Kullu valley to the hippy beaches at Anjuna and Calangute in Goa, and there were odd ox-bows through Morocco, Peru and Guatemala, but the real thing was London to Kathmandu, over-land. No one seems to know who began it, or how. Like so many things in the 60s, it just sort of happened. Eileen Campbell, now publisher of the New Age imprint Thorsons, followed the trail in the mid-70s with her erstwhile partner, Brian. "There were no guide books. You had to go to Compendium [an alternative bookshop in north London] and pick up a photo-copied booklet, which gave you tips on the route. And that was it." The couple bought an ex-Dutch post office van for £270 and painted it maroon, pink and black, "like a Rothko painting". They set off along the trail with the booklet, a pocket full of savings and a few dried goods. As they travelled, they accumulated pet birds, a cat in Iran and, in India, a dog and dysentery. "Some days, we might drive 250 miles, another day 10. We did it on a remarkably small amount of money," says Campbell. The Dutch van was their home for 18 months. Though the trail itself was well established by the time Campbell took off, points along it were still genuinely remote. There was no such thing then as a backpacker hostel. "Often, we couldn't find a campsite," says Campbell. "People would invite you to their home. In some places we'd go slightly off the beaten track and the locals would look at us as though we'd come off the moon." Campbell was in no doubt that she was taking a spiritual journey. "After my father died when I was 15, I became a confirmed Christian, but at university I wanted to be part of the swinging 60s, and being a Christian just wasn't cool." A four-year spell working for the publishers Routledge had put her in contact with Bhagavad-Gita and the eastern mystics. She was spellbound. "India was like a magnet." It was a long, slow trip getting there. "Afghanistan was like going back into the middle ages." The Dutch post van broke down between Herat and Kandahar, and Brian had to hitch into Kabul for parts, leaving Campbell on her own. In Turkey, their van got stuck behind a convoy of tanks en route to the war with Greece in Cyprus. Occasionally, they'd meet fellow hippies making their way back home who would recommend places to stay, and there were certain well-known hangouts, such as the Khyber Cafe in Kabul, but all the same the trail felt hypnotically exotic. "It never seemed dangerous, though it must have been. There were wars going on, and bandits, and the driving was hard. Some of the mountain passes in India were horrendous." Nonetheless, the couple sensed that they had embarked on an epic journey that would change their lives. "It was just a glorious, glorious adventure." At the same time as Campbell was making her way across the Khyber Pass, Jeremy Slocombe was heading north through India from his home in Australia, bound for Kathmandu. Slocombe was an early developer, presenting, at 14, his own TV talk-show on ABC Canberra. By 19, he was the creative director of Canberra's largest ad agency. The inevitable happened. Jeremy Slocombe burned out. He spent a few months recuperating before setting off for Kathmandu. "That nervous 'breakthrough' made me realise there was a spiritual dimension to my life I needed to explore. Kathmandu was one of the places to do that, a crossroads where you felt you could meet anyone from anywhere. And there were enough mind-altering substances about to shake up your complacency." Did he consider anywhere else? "Not really. Kathmandu was the place to go." Back in England, CJ Stone was also shaking up his complacency. While at Cardiff University, he had discovered acid and, by the mid-70s, was working in a steel factory by day and doing drugs and dropping out most nights. A working-class boy cut adrift by his own intellectual ambition, he found temporary shelter in hippiedom. "I guess I was looking for a guru. And, yeah, my initial impulse was naive, but it was a romantic time. And what 19-year-old isn't a bit self-indulgent?" In 1975, Stone packed up and set out on the Hippy Trail, destination Kathmandu. "There were six of us in a VW camper-van, two New Zealand girls on their way back home, me and my mate, and another couple." It was the first time Stone had left England. "By the time we got to Kathmandu, we all hated each other." Though they were in Kat at around the same time, Slocombe and Stone remember it very differently. For Slocombe, the hippy epicentre lived up to its reputation. "It was smelly, filthy, noisy and wonderful. The place had a genuine spiritual magnetism. We'd all get stoned, drink beer and tell our stories. You felt a sense that you could overcome whatever it was the straight world was telling you to do with your life." Stone loathed the place. "We ended up at a lake by the Annapurna Himal, near Pokara. The mountains were reflected in the lake and it was beautiful, but already the huts were turning into hotels, serving pancakes and western food. You realised you were the first wave of what would become a tourist industry. One cafe used to play Elton John. I remember some hippy saying to the owner, 'Hey, you must really like Elton John', and the owner just turning around and saying, 'No, I don't like Elton John, but I know you do.' And there was just this look of complete weariness on his face." There were enlightening times, too, though. And Stone met other hippies who were, unlike himself, part of the jet-set. The trail opened him not only to the world beyond Britain but to the world beyond the working class. After Kathmandu, Slocombe flew to Britain and joined the "New Age" community of Findhorn, near Inverness, where he has remained for the past 23 years. Eileen Campbell also returned to Britain and dropped out for a while before becoming one of the UK's first and most successful publishers of alternative health and spirituality books. Her partner, Brian, fell in love with Buddhism and devoted himself to it. Stone quickly became disillusioned with the "game-playing hippy edifice". "Angry and cynical", he came back to a Britain that mirrored his sentiments and dived headfirst into punk rock, which, as he put it, "didn't involve being up your own arse". All the same, but in different ways, the Hippy Trail had lived up to its promise. It had changed their lives. The old trail is gone now. A well-worn myth of sex, drugs and the long, hard road now sits in its place. Most of what it represented has altered or disappeared. If the Islamic Revolution in Iran and the civil war in Afghanistan had not made the original route impassable, then the more recent revolution in the travel industry would have made it impractical. Young people (and anyone else) can now fly directly into the orient for less than the price of a first-class return to Edinburgh. And they do - in droves. The number of tourists piling into Thailand increased 64-fold between 1960 and 1998. Nothing about the old trail makes much sense today. It's not so much a pathway to enlightenment as a track back in time. Last year, STA Travel, specialists in youth and student travel, sent half-a-million young Brits abroad - 10 times the number of a decade ago - many on RTWs (Round The World Tickets). Until the mid-90s, RTWs were expensive and limiting. Now they're ubiquitous. "Airlines have merged into global entities, working together and making the whole thing cheaper and easier," says Jonathan Nye, long-haul manager for Trailfinders, a travel agency that focuses on the "independent" market. In five years, the RTW has become part of the social culture. "We are now getting repeat RTWs - people who were first-timers on the Thailand-Singapore-India-Australia-NZ route who are now wanting something more sophisticated," adds Nye. An average RTW ticket costs £800 and, unlike Eileen Campbell's Dutch van, there's nothing to sell at the end. Says Dawn Howell, marketing manager of STA, "When the student-loan system came out, we thought it would be a problem for us, but it wasn't. Students seem to think, 'If I'm in debt for a grand, I may as well be in for three or four.' If anything, it's helped, because students have access to cheap loans." Nye agrees: "Young people see it as their right to travel. People will accept the debt because of that, and parents are more willing to pay." Divested of the more familiar western end of the old trail by the fall in the price of flights, the New Hippy Trail has begun to creep south across south-east Asia into Australia, and from there out to the wider world. Julian Ruffle is a 27-year-old sales consultant at STA. This year, Julian is taking 12 holidays abroad. He was in Kathmandu a while ago, "doing" India and Nepal, before following the New Hippy Trail across south-east Asia. "I've wanted to get into the personal development thing," he says, "but I just haven't had the time. Sometimes, I think I'd like to learn - what is it? - Ayurveda, because it would be nice to know how to chill out properly." Julian is not a hippy - or at least not in the old sense of the word. "Hippies took loads of drugs and wore stupid clothes, and I probably would have hated them." His work allows him "a young and free lifestyle", but he has nothing whatsoever against the establishment and he's pretty much apolitical. Julian is part of a new breed; a realist and a pragmatist. "I'm doing long hours at STA, I'm taking care of my future," he says. He likes tuning in and dropping out for the odd month or two is all. A place for everything, and everything in its place. Julian's friend, Rupert, mentioned earlier, is more of your hardcore type. For a while, back in the mid-90s, he dipped in and out of the Full Moon beach party scene on Ko Samui and Ko Pha-Ngan. It was - as Alex Garland astutely describes in his satirical novel about new hippies, The Beach - "careless hedonism, too diligently pursued to ring true". Sure, "a lot of it was egotism disguised as spirituality", as CJ Stone points out. Young people pursued the idea of sacredness in India because the dope was cheap and the living was good and they felt released from spying eyes and wagging tongues, but also - and importantly -because the opportunity for a spiritual life in the west seemed ever more remote. They may not have understood that the price of western economic affluence is non-western economic impoverishment, but they did at least see that consumerism had made the west spiritually ragged. In many ways, the New Hippy Trail is a less hypocritical journey. A journalist character in William Sutcliffe's Are you Experienced? moans, "It's not hippies on a spiritual mission who come to India any more, just morons on a poverty tourism adventure holiday . . . going to India isn't an act of rebellion these days, its actually a form of conformity for ambitious middle-class kids who want to be able to put something on their CV that shows a bit of initiative. All the top companies want robots with initiative these days . . . Your kind of travel is all about low horizons dressed up as open-mindedness." Yet it's hard not to mourn the substitution of spiritual aspiration (however naive) for experimental acquisition (however good-natured). "Young people want to travel for experience, not to find themselves," says Dawn Howell. "They know themselves already. Young people don't think of themselves as having an essential self. You are what you experience, and most of what you experience is a choice between consumables. Young westerners are less likely to pursue the idea of the sacred in other cultures because it is so completely absent from their own. It makes no sense to blame them. The profane world may be all they know." For tens of thousands of years of human history, the journey has constituted one of our most potent cultural and spiritual metaphors. In the past 20, its power has faded. We no longer expect travel to change our lives. The journey has become pretty much like life. More comfortable, less innocent, fuller of things and emptier of thoughts. But there's hope. Mark Mann, author of The Gringo Trail and a lobbyist for ethical travelling, thinks "the thing is not to go further but to go deeper into local culture, engaging at a deeper level with local people and their needs". And there is some evidence that this is happening. Tourism Concern, a charity promoting ethical travel, has just launched The Community Tourism Guide, listing destinations managed by and for the benefit of local people, while Dawn Howell says, "young people are beginning to want to put something back". We are still very far from the point where first-world-to-third-world travel, even by new hippies, constitutes anything like a genuine or fair exchange, but that, at least, may be the direction in which we are headed. Julian Ruffle remembers his recent trip to Kathmandu with disengaged fondness. "I seem to recall that there used to be a hippy hangout in the west of Pokara on the edge of a lake," he told me. He didn't know it was the one where CJ Stone had stacked his chillum 25 years earlier. "Something happened to the hippies, though. I think that they must have been booted out. Or maybe they just quit." Old hippy hotspots Kathmandu, Nepal The hippy epicentre. Dharamsala and nearby McCleod Ganj, India Seat-in-exile of the Dalai Lama. Manali, India Centre of India's marijuana-producing area. Kabul, Afghanistan Mid-point on the Old Hippy Trail. Panajachel, Guatemala Now a second-generation hippy enclave. Marrakech, Morocco Neither hideous nor kinky. San Cristobal, Mexico; Calangute and Anjuna, Goa Then, only one hotel on each; now, Bhajee Benidorm - Anjuna still holds Full Moon parties for new hippies, though. Gilli Islands, Indonesia and Eilat, Israel As Calangute. Ibiza Ditto. New hippy hotspots Muang Sing, Laos Once the biggest opium market in the Golden Triangle. Ko Chang, Ko Tao, Thailand Stoner hangouts on the more remote beaches. Ko Pha-Ngan Widely dissed by hardcore new hippies, but still attracting 5,000 westerners each month to its Full Moon parties. Siem Reap, Cambodia Pizza seasoned with marijuana available in street cafes. Wodong/Wairterang, Flores Island, Indonesia Great beaches. Cape Maclear, Malawi Big lake, cheap dope. Byron Bay, Australia. Dahab, Egypt. Essouira, Morocco. Cuzco, Peru Ancient spiritual centre and, according to legend, navel of the world. Ready availability of mescalin, ayahuasca and garden-variety dope all help. Arrecifes, Colombia Great beach and famous for huge amounts of cocaine. Dhungri, Vashist, Kullu Valley, India Where hippies went when Manali got too crowded. Chapora, Vagator, Arambol, Goa Where hippies went when Anjuna got crowded. Dusallan, Bhagsu long-term hangouts for new hippies gathered around the Dalai Lama's base at McCleod Ganj. Nimbe, Sydney. Up-and-coming China, Panama, Borneo, Cuba, Georgia, Madagascar, El Salvador, Libya.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
While enjoying Jonathan Glancey's enraptured article on the wolves of Yellowstone (The Wild And The Innocent, June 3), he did rather spoil it near the end by writing, 'I sit in the snow and watch my gray wolf ripple into the forest.' Surely the point he was trying to make in the rest of the article, and it is an important one, is that a wolf does not belong to him, or to anybody else. Proprietorial attitudes are a big part of the difficulty wolves face.
Richard Deacon
London SE24
fields.body:
While enjoying Jonathan Glancey's enraptured article on the wolves of Yellowstone (The Wild And The Innocent, June 3), he did rather spoil it near the end by writing, 'I sit in the snow and watch my gray wolf ripple into the forest.' Surely the point he was trying to make in the rest of the article, and it is an important one, is that a wolf does not belong to him, or to anybody else. Proprietorial attitudes are a big part of the difficulty wolves face.
Richard Deacon
London SE24

There is something appropriately spooky about Montague Summers writing on werewolves in 1961. He had been dead for 13 years.
Adrian Cunningham
Lancaster

Is Alexander Chancellor really naive or callous enough to compare war to a game of tennis (June 3)? Perhaps he would welcome an international convention to ensure that only men who are strong, courageous and psychologically fit engage each other in combat. Meanwhile, the puny, scared and dithery (mirabile dictu, such men do exist!) would fight separate actions against foe of similar calibre. After all, flyweight boxers are not expected to confront heavyweight opponents. Gender is nothing but a red herring in Mr Chancellor's specious argument.
Susan Roberts
Northampton

I usually read Alexander Chancellor in the same way I attend church with my mother; religiously, but with a kind of amused, tolerant air. This week, I must protest. His main argument against having women in the forces appears to be that once they are there, men treat them badly. Has it not occurred to him that if we were to follow his line of argument to its logical conclusion, women would still be uneducated, unemployed and at home, because the nasty men are horrible to them if they try to get into university or employment that pays enough to live on?

Among other devices to keep women out of 'their' spheres, men have used rape, belittling comments, ('playing' at being a soldier) and impossible ideals of womanhood (see the 'silly tart/stuck-up bitch' contradiction). They can do this in the knowledge that, usually, liberal writers such as Chancellor will stick up for them, saying not that the rape was wholly unacceptable, and resulted from intolerance, hatred and bigotry, but that the woman shouldn't have been there in the first place! Is this not simply an extension of 'she was asking for it'?

Finally, the comment that the actress Daniela Nardini shattered team morale in TV's Rough Treatment is utterly incomprehensible. Surely the actions of those who raped and abandoned her are what shattered team morale. Again, Chancellor is siding with the rapists; it is just another case of blaming the woman.
Ceridwen Trinder
Stockton on Tees, Cleveland

So, we really are a nation obsessed by some idea of what we think people ought, or ought not, to look like (Dear Weekend, June 3). And by our appearance only are we to be judged. I hadn't realised until reading Miss Deborah Gilshan's letter that Guardian readers are body fascists, too. However, I think we should have a picture of Miss Gilshan, otherwise how will be able to judge the worth of what she writes?
Gianna Knowles
Bognor, West Sussex

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email:
weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
