McCullin warns that, "with photo-journalism you have to be careful not to stray into that dodgy grey area of art. But Salgado is passionate about what he believes in, and you have to acknowledge his major achievements. He has made photo-journalism respectable." Salgado says that being at Gamma was exhilarating. "We would read the press wires for news anywhere on the planet. We'd get somewhere on a Friday night, meet the local press, shoot the pictures and on the Monday you'd ask someone at the airport to take your films back to Paris. Gamma would send a motorcyclist to the airport and two days later your pictures would be in Newsweek and Time. It was fantastic." This was a period of "massive stories" for photo-journalists with the on-going de-colonisation of Africa being accompanied by war and famine. But after four years he became increasingly disillusioned. "I began to repeat things, and we would only have two days to deal with these big issues. It became a big frustration to me and I began to explore whether I could work in another way." In 1979 he went to South America with a view to putting together a substantial body of work on the peasant population. Several charities have used his work to raise funds and awareness of third world poverty, and Christian Aid supported this trip by commissioning work. Joseph Cabon is its head of photography. "His images can convey to viewers who may not know anything about the situation a sense of what those people are going through," says Cabon. "What he has done is make a lot of difficult subjects easier to deal with for people who otherwise might have been turned off. It fits with the way Christian Aid wants to present issues that are important to us." Salgado spent four months in Bolivia, Peru and Equador. The pictures he took eventually contributed to his 1986 book Other Americas, but at the time he couldn't sell a single picture to a commercial buyer. His response was to leave the exclusively "hot-news" Gamma and move to the unruly cooperative that was the Magnum photo-agency, the home of "concerned photography", where he hoped to pursue his ideas of more substantial work. Magnum had been set up in 1947 by Cartier-Bresson, "the poet of the camera", and the war photographers Robert Capa, David Seymour and George Rodger. Capa and Seymour both died covering wars and Rodger abandoned war photography after finding himself looking for composition when photographing Belsen. Salgado was given more room to develop his preferred style of working but, ironically, he was working for Magnum when he took the Reagan shots. He was on a story covering the president's first 100 days in office. Reagan was speaking at a hotel in Washington. Because Salgado had eight pages to fill and needed lots of different shots he left the hotel just before the speech finished to capture Reagan leaving the building - 200 other photographers stayed inside the hall and got pictures of him smiling and shaking hands. "I started to take pictures just as the man [John Hinckley] started shooting," says Salgado. "Because I was on this story for the New York Times I had been driven to the hotel with security men, so they knew who I was, and I was actually standing inside the security ring when it happened." But he doesn't like showing the pictures or talking about them too much. "It gets so much attention that I could become just the photographer who took the pictures of the assassination attempt on President Reagan. That can destroy you for just one minute's work." He began to develop a mode of working that would satisfy both his clients and himself. He made 16 additional trips to Latin America to finish off his Other Americas project and he got magazines to pay for them all. "I would do a week for a magazine project in Bolivia and then three weeks for me," he explains. He has continued with this patchwork of funding and support ever since. "It allows me to use my ideas and not just the ideas of the magazines." While the high-spending glossy magazines pick up most of the bills for his trips he has maintained and developed links with aid agencies and other humanitarian organisations, such as Save the Children. Alan Thomas, the charity's picture librarian, says, "If Salgado thinks that our work will fit into what he is doing anyway then he will work for our measly rates and he will do what we ask him to do. His style of getting in very close with children and showing dynamic images links with a lot of our activities." Salgado relies on the support of agencies while on the road but usually travels alone, taking only three small cameras and three lenses. For all this apparent simplicity, his style of working is not universally popular. One aid worker who accompanied him in Africa described him as, "a complete prima donna. He is used to people paying homage to him and he doesn't muck in regarding accommodation. Having said that, in the end I forgave him everything because, of course, the pictures were brilliant." She says he had a wonderful knack of dealing with children in particular. "The children weren't frightened. He sort of mesmerised them and they would freeze for him." A fellow photo-journalist is less impressed. "His work in the early 80s was extremely technically competent and remarkable in many ways. But since he has been doing these huge projects there doesn't seem to be any soul to his work. It feels automated. I was with him in what was Zaire and he didn't seem to have a great deal of interest in the people he photographed." John Easterby defends him. "While of course it would be nice to make the down times in the evening as pleasant as possible, that is not why he is there. He has a job to do. This man's work, indirectly, inspired the public response to the Ethiopian famine." There is little doubt that Salgado, like most photo-journalists, is not without ego, ambition or determination. It is part of the job description and he had to call on all his powers of self belief when he embarked on his study to record the end of large scale manual labour. "For me we were arriving at the end of industrial revolution, with the arrival of intelligent machines," he says. "The relation between men and machine had changed for ever." The six-year study took in a slaughterhouse in South Dakota, textile factories in Bangladesh, steelworks in the Ukraine and workers digging the Eurotunnel in Folkestone. He found that while European factories had already been automated, the old manual versions had been shipped, almost piece by piece to the third world. He readily acknowledges that he does more than simply record his subjects. He explicitly sets out to show their dignity. "My pictures are not neutral. Photography is not objective There is no such thing as a neutral picture. When you take a photograph of something you come with your past, with the way you think. You photograph with your mind and, of course, as an economist I knew this world very well by theory. I wanted to record the end of an era." The length of time he spends making his pictures is important. Any documentary photographer will tell you of the problems of people either being camera shy or playing up to the camera. "When you are there for four weeks or four months then the relationship is completely different," he says. "You have time to wait for real things to happen in front of you." One of the artistic criticisms made of him is that his later work, can sometimes give the feeling that he is on autopilot, simply harvesting images. Critics have spoken of a sense of sterility and coldness. John Easterby says it is true that he has, "developed a fingerprint for his pictures. That's what artists try to do. He did that early and to great effect and has to some extent stuck to it. But you have to remember that many magazines now have a paranoia about upsetting the sensibilities of their readers." Easterby contends that Salgado has thought this through and developed a way to show horrific situations without making readers look away. "Many pictures from famine or from war border on the pornographic. But if people look at a picture and close their eyes or turn the page you have served no purpose at all. His pictures are beautiful manifestations of the unpalatable. He makes it possible to look at the unlookable." John Berger rejects the often-made accompanying criticism that because Salgado's work can be beautiful while depicting shocking events it is somehow hypocritical or exploitative. "For Christ's sake," he explodes, "I mean literally for Christ's sake. I've seldom heard a more half-baked argument. What about all the crucifixions in western art? What about the Pietá of Michaelangelo? Half of European visual art until the 20th century was about terrible things that at the same time were beautiful. In fact they were the definition of what people called beautiful." Not even Salgado's sternest critics have described his set of pictures of the Serra Pelada as anything but awesome. Salgado says he had tried to get to the mine for several years but, because it was under the jurisdiction of the federal police and he had a political past in Brazil, he was always refused access. It wasn't until 1986, when the police had ceded control of the mine to the cooperative that owned it, that he was allowed in. "It was a vision from the middle ages," he says. "There were no machines and all these men were working in a very primitive way." He stayed for three weeks and remembers the place as having a unique ambience. "There were no women allowed and there was this atmosphere that combined the danger of the work and the chance of huge wealth. People would work for months in the hope of getting some gold because you could get up to 2 kilos if you were lucky. Many of them never got any gold at all, but a lot of them did and went on to buy hotels or small farms." His project on workers naturally segued into an interest in migration. Everywhere he travelled he came across people on the move. "From just a few million eight years ago there are now 30m or 40m refugees today. And this is just people who have crossed borders, there are more again who are refugees within their own country." In 1994, soon after starting the project, he left Magnum and set up his own Amazonas agency, which is run by his wife. Chris Boot explains the complex dynamics of the Magnum co-operative. "They could be a very disputatious group. There is always a clash in the organisation between the independence of the individual and collective endeavour. Most photographers clash with the group at some stage. One of the problems is that people have almost family-like relationships and so a departure is somewhat akin to divorce." Working through his own contacts, Salgado planned the complex logistics of his migrants project. Arrangements were made to provide 12 magazines with excerpts from the work in progress, and the completed study now takes the form of two large books, a travelling show, a set of posters and a series of information packs for teachers to lead discussions in schools. The pictures themselves are an astonishing testament to perhaps the most significant global event of our times. "This is a serious problem and it needs to be discussed," he says. "I am accused of photographing misery but that is not true. I have photographed people who have lost their base, their way of life. But these people have dignity and are hoping to go to a new life. They all have a story. They are not statistics." He is adamant that the pictures are not about merely pricking consciences. "I want to tell people what is going on and how easily things can change. For instance, in the former Yugoslavia, people had lives very similar to life in Britain. They were not poor. They had cars and television and universities. Now they are in a very difficult situation. It can happen so fast and it can happen to anyone. Germans today are so rich, but 50 years ago they were at the side of the road as refugees. And that change can happen in Africa as well. It is terrible what is going on in Africa today and it is getting worse." He admits that changes in the media mean it is unlikely he could ever undertake another project in this scale. Magazines which have traditionally taken his work are becoming more and more reticent about photo-journalism. But Salgado will continue to take photographs and pursue other practical action to further the causes he believes in. Back in Brazil, on the ranch where he grew up, he is currently attempting to re-plant the forest that was destroyed when he was a boy. He has plans to plant 1.5m trees and build an educational establishment that will teach both children and teachers about environmental issues in their area. He has committed a considerable amount of money himself and in total has raised $1m of the $3.5m needed. Last autumn the first 82,000 trees were planted. "It won't change the weather," he says, "but it might change the mentality of people. That is the most important thing." "Salgado's work is an onslaught on public opinion," says John Berger. "His phrase is 'let us listen to the present'. Some photographers say 'no'. They record the shock or horror felt by the witnesses to terrible events but there is no sense of human effort and therefore no sense of human resistance. Salgado sees these are real people. The realisation of this dignity, even in their bereavement or mourning, is to say 'yes'. Salgado says 'yes'." Life at a glance Born: February 8 1944, Aimorés, Brazil. Married: 1967 Lélia Wanick (two sons Juliano and Rodrigo). Education: São Paulo University; Ecole Nationale de Statistique et de l'Administration Economique, Paris. Career: Economist, Ministry of Finance, São Paulo 1968-69; economist, International Coffee Organisation, London 1971-73. Photography: 1975-79 Gamma agency; 1979-94 Magnum agency; 1994-present Amazonas Images. Touring exhibitions: 1986-97 Sahel: Man In Distress; 1989-96 Ret rospective; 1990-99 An Uncertain Grace; 1992-99 Workers; 1994-98 Serra Pelada; 2000 Migrations. Books: 1986 Sahel: Man In Distress; Other Americas; 1990 An Uncertain Grace; 1993 Workers; 1997 Terra; 2000 Migrations. Honours: 1999 Alfred Eisenstaedt award for magazine photography.  Migrations: Humanity in Transition (£60), and The Children: Refugees and Migrants (£25), are published by Aperture, New York.

webTitle: How to source the best strawberries

fields.headline: How to source the best strawberries
fields.standfirst: Few fruits can match the glory of the British strawberry, says Clare Phipps. After all, it's as central a part of our summer as rain
fields.trailText: Few fruits can match the glory of the British strawberry, says Clare Phipps. After all, it's as central a part of our summer as rain
fields.body:
'Doubtless God could have made a better berry, but doubtless God never did.' God has had 400 years or so since William Butler, physician, eulogised the fruit, but He still hasn't come up with anything to rival the strawberry. Nothing seems to chime so well with the British summer than the British strawberry - even in the most rain-lashed of fortnights, 20 tonnes of the fruit are shifted at Wimbledon. And, of course, it is the "British" strawberry, not the "English" one, because a good proportion of today's UK growers are north of the border.

Even so, for me, strawberries are and always will be associated with the south-east; but then, I'm a maid of Kent, born and bred. To be sure, other areas may lay claim to being undisputed champions: "If you go to Wisbech in East Anglia, they'll say that the best strawberries are grown in Wisbech," says Nicholas Marston, managing director of KG Marketing, otherwise known as Kentish Garden, a soft- and stone-fruit growers' co-operative, whose 57 UK members currently supply around 50% of the strawberries we buy - four million packs a week at the peak of demand.

So, with apologies to Wisbech, it is for Kent that we are now heading, to the village of Mereworth, just west of Maidstone, and the Hugh Lowe Farm, one of the founding members of Kentish Garden.

Marion Regan has been MD here for five years, but the farm has been in the family since 1893, which is when strawberries - Royal Sovereigns, back then - were first planted in these fields. Few sites manage to sustain cultivation for so long a period (many will have suffered the ravages of the disease, strawberry sickness, or else will have succumbed to the developers and sold their land), but business here at the Hugh Lowe Farm is still booming. At peak season, the farm's energetic team of pickers will gather up to 90 tonnes a week.

The secret of Mereworth's longevity is that the strawberries here are rotated with arable crops, which keeps the soil in tip-top condition and the fruit free from berry fatigue. "And we make use of the different topography of the land," Regan points out.

This is easy to see from the top of Kent's Greensand Ridge, where the views in any direction are of fields of glinting polythene. These never-ending plastic tunnels not only help to protect the plants from the harsher touches of the British weather - and there have been plenty of those so far this year - but also enable harvesting to be controlled and regulated over several months. The standard Elsanta variety of strawberry is a June-bearer, while other fields will crop later, for they are planted with Everest and Bolero varieties, everbearers that fruit right through until November.

Today's growers are always looking for ways to extend the season - they don't want the strawberry "year" to be a mere five weeks any more than we consumers do. Fortunately, modern techniques keep the farmers more than busy, although, says Regan, "we always try to have Saturdays off". Sundays would be more conventional, of course, but this is impossible, seeing as Sunday's harvest feeds Monday's shoppers.

The speed with which British strawberries wing their way from field to bowl is, in fact, their trump card: berries can be picked in the morning and be waiting, weighed and packed, in the supermarket depot the same evening. Compare this with four-day-old Spanish imports, or US strawberries, which take five to six days by air freight.

Is this, perhaps, why strawberries from overseas just don't taste the same? "That's the nature of imported fruit," says Angus Coates, fruit manager at Firmin's Farm in Linton, another Kentish Garden grower. "Different varieties and different climates give them textures and flavours all their own. But the English is what you've been brought up with, and there's that very traditional flavour that you can immediately relate to. You can't beat an English strawberry."

But can you improve on it? Last year, Firmin's invested heavily in a new table-top production system, in which the strawberries are planted in growbags raised above the soil. Coates believes that the approach has many advantages: "The height aids picking," he says, "but there's also better air movement, which means a better atmosphere, and less disease potential, which means less chemical input. And you can choose where to plant them, even at the top of a hill, or on stony ground."

North-facing or south-facing, soil type, glasshouses, fields on the ridge or those in the weald of Kent - all these factors affect what strawberries can be grown, when they can be picked and, most important, how they taste. Those at Hugh Lowe Farm taste very good indeed, the slight differences in sweetness and juiciness evident in samples from two different fields (well, I had to). Growers also do their best to satisfy consumer craving for that perfect-tasting strawberry, tweaking the nutrients in the plants' liquid feed to affect the sugar levels, for example.

Ultimately, though workers can keep the strawberries dry, warm or even cold through the season, human intervention is best kept to a minimum. Both farms introduce natural predators (assorted mites) to the strawberry tunnels, as well as bumble bees to aid pollination. Nature, it's true, doesn't get its own way when it comes to picking time, when a critical human eye must separate the supermarket grade (no splits, good colour, not mis-shapen) from the others. Most pass the test. At Hugh Lowe Farm, every tray of fruit is labelled not only with the field it was picked from, but also with the date and time it was picked, and even the name of the picker. Accountability, indeed.

So, when we're in the supermarket, pondering the British or the Spanish berries, should we give a thought to their pre-shelf life? Marion Regan thinks so: "It's not just about the visual quality, or even the eating quality. It's knowing the history, whether they came from a well-managed farm, and that means right down to the ethical treatment of employees there. The trust that consumers have needs to be backed up. But people are still most interested in flavour." No worries there, then.

fields.headline: Bad relations
fields.standfirst: Esther Freud examines self-delusion in the pursuit of a happy family in The Wild
fields.trailText: Esther Freud examines self-delusion in the pursuit of a happy family in The Wild
fields.body:
The Wild
Esther Freud
Hamish Hamilton, £14.99, 248pp
Buy it at BOL

In Esther Freud's new novel we are on familiar if highly unpleasant terrain, the "wild" of the title being both a place and a reference to the savage ungovernability of a divided family. Tess, the nine-year-old from whose point of view we see nearly all the action, has come with her older brother Jake and mother Francine to The Wild, a rambling country house presided over by the smarmy William. He has three young daughters of his own, and loses no time in stamping his authority on the entire brood in a chilling approximation of The Brady Bunch. His idea of the good life, it seems, is a grim hybrid of self-sufficiency - nettle soup, chicken runs and nights spent crooning over the guitar - and rigid control by way of colour-coded domestic rotas.

Perversely, Tess adores this faintly sinister patriarch, and hopes devoutly to wheedle her way into his affections. This, of course, is a recipe for disaster, as he barely tolerates her, her attempts to please meeting with a steady stream of rebuffs. Meanwhile, Jake loathes him and Francine hops into bed with him - along with a rather forward American girl on the run from a brainwashing sex cult.

Although the plot line has all the hallmarks of literary cliché - the excluded child, the slowly gathering menace of deep unhappiness and inevitable disillusionment - it would be a mistake to under-estimate Freud's considerable skill and subtlety. Above all, this is a novel about people desperately trying to paper over cracks they hardly dare admit are there, and pushing themselves further into incommunicable misery in the process.

William is the foremost example of the self-defeating desire to unite and mollify, which, we slowly realise, is his own defence against a peculiar, masked urge to wound and control. On the telephone to his ex-wife, he callously limits her access to their children until she breaks down - and he is suddenly calm: "The sound of her crying soothed him." And just as he devises endless ingenious activities to bring this disparate group of women and children together, he plots his own escape into other women's beds and the anonymous streets of Soho. By the end of the novel we hate him almost as much as does the unruly Jake, whose fierce cat Odin he destroys in a fit of pique.

William is a kind of grown-up child, as is the deliberately undercharacterised, ineffective Francine, whom he quickly impregnates. But the real children of the novel are channelled into a maturity way beyond their grasp. For Tess, still imprisoned in a shameful nightmare of bed-wetting at nine, this takes the form of a neurotic urge to ward off disruption. "I'd like to stamp on a glass cello," fumes Jake, in the face of another piece of William's spite. Tess's reply is characteristically and point-missingly anxious: "Yes, but afterwards, just think, you'd have to sweep it up."

Freud manages this disastrous household well, cleverly building up an atmosphere of claustrophobia and tension that becomes all the more ironic when we know that The Wild stands on the edge of a genteel suburban estate near East Grinstead. Similarly, Tess and Jake's mostly absent father, the louche writer Victor, is seen as a far safer bet, despite the ever-changing cast of girlfriends and the unexpected appearance of stray mysteriously fathered children.

Freud is a sharp and intuitive writer, driven by a quiet analysis of emotional distress rather than by any self-conscious attempts at stylistic play. This, then, is a novel in a minor key, a study in the self-protecting - but ultimately self-destructive - lies we tell ourselves and one another as part of a doomed project to shore up the ruins. That delusion is excusable in children but less so in adults, and as the novel's accumulated nastinesses build into a rather more serious, violent ending, one sees the miserable price to be exacted when all concerned are bent on pursuing the uncertain rewards of the happy family.

Similarly, Tess and Jake's mostly absent father, the louche writer Victor, is seen as a far safer bet, despite the ever-changing cast of girlfriends and the unexpected appearance of stray mysteriously fathered children. Freud is a sharp and intuitive writer, driven by a quiet analysis of emotional distress rather than by any self-conscious attempts at stylistic play. This, then, is a novel in a minor key, a study in the self-protecting - but ultimately self-destructive - lies we tell ourselves and one another as part of a doomed project to shore up the ruins. That delusion is excusable in children but less so in adults, and as the novel's accumulated nastinesses build into a rather more serious, violent ending, one sees the miserable price to be exacted when all concerned are bent on pursuing the uncertain rewards of the happy family.

fields.body:
Last week we considered hardback bestsellers at specialist travel bookshop Daunt's. This week it's the turn of the paperbacks, headed by the morbidly brilliant Dark Room at Longwood, Jean-Paul Kauffman's account of Napoleon's last days on St Helena. Lurking behind the story, though never stated, is Kauffman's own incarceration as one of the Beirut hostages.

Next comes Roger Deakin's swim around Britain, Michael Jacobs's lyrical paean to Andalucia and some reflections on past adventures by that grand old traveller Wilfred Thesiger. A Woman Unknown, by Robert Graves's daughter Lucia, tells of growing up in Majorca and life in Spain, while Fulco's Happy Summer Days is an old favourite of Sicilian life rescued from obscurity. Better to be there for your holidays than to follow Shackleton's Arctic expedition (Endurance) or take in the View from the Summit with Sir Edmund Hillary.

fields.headline: Fight club
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  has staked his reputation on Hazlitt's vigorous style in The Fight and Other Writings
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard has staked his reputation on Hazlitt's vigorous style in The Fight and Other Writings
fields.body:
The Fight and Other Writings
William Hazlitt, ed Tom Paulin and David Chandler (Penguin Classics, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

There's a quote on the back of this book picked in order to sell Hazlitt to people: "the most exciting journalism you will ever read". It's from me, and they attributed it, too, a fact which makes me inordinately smug. So it would be churlish of me not to make this Pick of the Week; I have, after all, staked my reputation on it, in a way.

So here you'll find a good selection of some of Hazlitt's best pieces: his description of prize- fighting, as the title of the collection suggests; his blistering "On the Spirit of Monarchy" ("the slave admires the tyrant because the last is, what the first would be"); "My First Acquaintance with Poets", where he describes his first meeting, as a young man, with Coleridge and Wordsworth; and the glorious celebration of "The Indian Jugglers" ("I ask what there is I can do as well as this? Nothing. What have I been doing all my life?").

Hazlitt, you come to realise, can look at anything and become fully engaged; the hidden agenda seems to be the search for happiness. It's backed up with what appears to be an entire library in his head for constant verification and comparison, as well as a prose style that is so ahead of its time, so contemporary as to be capable of influence today. Reading him is still an extraordinary experience. You feel that he is not streets ahead of you but taking you by the hand with him, pulling your own thoughts out of your head.

He never sets himself above anyone; neither is he going to conceal the workings of his own mind. His responses are his material, and sometimes he comes across, in his endless and enlightened fascination, as a kind of pot-head whose insights are, for once, as perceptive as he imagines they are. "He has no reticence and he has no shame," said Virginia Woolf, with prissy approval, much later. And for him, his prose style was a function of his own mind: what he was after was the truth, first principles, and the directness and vigour of his style was the coinage he paid his dues in. "The truth shall set you free" might have been his personal motto. He was a radical - he loved the word - and unlike Wordsworth, saw no shame in remaining so.

"The very essence of Hazlitt is his dangerousness, and not only with respect to the reactionary climate of his own day but when and wherever freedom and truth are compromised by those actions which are summed up as 'the art of the possible'." That's from the introduction - but not the introduction to this volume. It's from Ronald Blythe's 1970 Penguin selection, which I re-read because I suspected there was something missing from Paulin and Chandler's.

And there certainly is. It very much pains me to say so, for I have abased myself before at Paulin's feet, both figuratively in print and almost literally in person at a Faber party, but you won't get here much sense of Hazlitt's bravery, idiosyncrasy, and sheer generosity of spirit - except, of course, from the writing itself.

Paulin and Chandler are strong on Hazlitt's stylistic technique, reticent about the biographical details, which, being no longer common knowledge, need another airing. They assume prior knowledge. Another gripe is the lack of an index. But no selection of Hazlitt is ever going to be less than enthralling. Buy this and be astonished at his relevance, his steely mind and his big heart.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The tension suffers as the tale of an old-school mafioso gets cut short
fields.body:
Omertá,
Mario Puzo
(Random House, 300mn, £12.99)

Hear an extract

The old Sicilian code of silence, omertá, meant a hood didn't squeal even when you stuck the capuccino steam-nozzle up his nose. These days, Puzo says with undisguised regret, mafia men sing like Caruso. He hankers for the days when dons were dons.

Young Astorre, hero of his eighth novel, is of the old school, however. He just wants to run his New York macaroni-import business and the family banks in peace, but rival mobsters and the FBI want to spoil it.

As usual, abridgement fatally dilutes the thrills. After a feeble dénouement at macaroni HQ, Astorre, weary of the new world, retires to "protect" the Sicilian village his family used to run and, in an absurd slushy coda, young and old joyfully welcome their feudal lord back. Joe Mantegna sibillates an appropriately reverential delivery and lends alarming conviction to the author's nostalgia for the bad old days.

fields.headline: Baroque complications
fields.standfirst: Nicola Barker tells John Cunningham about striving for perfect weirdness
fields.trailText: Nicola Barker tells John Cunningham about striving for perfect weirdness
fields.body:
"Everyone says my characters are weird," says Nicola Barker, "but to me they seem normal." She doesn't seek the unusual: it always finds her. Like the schoolfriend's mum who lived with a tapeworm inside her to keep slim; or the butcher her father knew who'd seen a cancer run across his chopping block.

Weirdness pays: Barker is about to go to Dublin to collect the world's biggest prize for a single work of fiction: the International Impac Award is worth £75,000.

Wide Open is set in a loony landscape - the Isle of Sheppey in Kent - where a cast of oddball brothers, a pornographer, a paedophile, several stroppy women, and a herd of boars interact frantically.

Up till now, Barker's odd take on the world hasn't made a huge impact. After Cambridge, she skivvied through jobs at a bookies and a bakers to make time for writing. Faber signed her up as a bright young hope and, after two volumes of short stories and a couple of novels, popped the inevitable question: "How about a big book now, Nicola?" The result was Barker's latest novel - Five Miles from Outer Hope - published earlier this year. In hindsight, the big book might already have come - when Wide Open came out in 1998, it generated goodish reviews and reasonable sales, but only now has it won a prize and been mooted for a film.

Barker, who is 34 and published her first novel, Love Your Enemies, in 1993, feels that Wide Open was hard done by. "There was the feeling that the time wasn't really right for a novel like that. Nobody wanted serious novels at that point, especially from a woman."

She is frustrated at the expectation that she should be what she dismissively calls "a girl writer". "It's something I never wanted to be. Girl writers don't get taken seriously. I don't take them seriously. I am a boyish writer."

In Wide Open, there is a mother and daughter, a pair Barker is clearly proud of: Sarah tending her smallholding on isolated in-grown Sheppey; coping, in the absence of her husband with that herd of boars - and the wilful, dirty-necked Lily (a weakness for the unwashed is one of Barker's eccentricities). This duo are certainly not anti-male (nor is Barker herself), but they have to deal with some troublesome men as boyfriends, neighbours and intruders.

Barker, slight and fair, is a self-confessed tomboy. She lives in a bit of Hackney, east London, that even daytime taxi drivers are wary of; and, having banished her longtime partner (a music journalist) to another room during this interview, she talks surrounded by all manner of kitsch, including a madonna adorned with voodoo symbols from the Dominican Republic.

Her off-centre fictional world isn't a literary device. It is the way she really sees things: there's always a missing person in the families she invents; one character will often have mutilated himself or herself, like the man who has fed his hand to an owl. A creative, baroque act, says Barker, who admits she has been fascinated by amputees since girlhood.

And as for the maddeningly unexplained events that kick off her plots - what is the link between the drifter and his would-be rescuer (both called Ronny) at the start of Wide Open? - they're always there for a reason. Barker says: "I like to write something that people have to struggle to understand; something to get over a prejudice."

The behaviour of one of the Ronnies, who keeps his soul in a box, only uses his left hand and keeps vigil on a motorway bridge, certainly tests the reader's patience. It is explained only at the end of the book as the result, in adolescence, of having a father who was a child abuser. "There is so much fiction and TV about violent events - a crime, a stabbing. I'm not interested in that; this book is about how the personality continues when it has endured a huge amount of trauma."

Some of that might also echo back to being transplanted into South Africa's unsettling society for five years as a child; witnessing apartheid, then coming back, as a 14-year-old, to home counties Britain with her mother after her parents split up. More tensions: she was the conformist daughter while her sister was a rebel.

Some critics have said that Barker over-complicates plots and character. She counters with this: "The world now is all about being normal, fitting in, so I like my characters not to be like that, yet to be loveable as well."

So if she's hard on her readers, she is also tough on herself. "I'm a perfectionist. You might not see it in the text, but that's how I am." Indeed, she goes over every sentence, paragraph and chapter so many times that she can't bear to re-read a book once it is published. As for reviews, good or bad, don't even mention them.

Given her hyper-sensitivity to all comments on her work, favourable or unfavourable, it's just as well someone dared to tell her she'd won that Irish prize.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A debut novel thick with urgency and intensity, plus The Colony Of Unrequited Dreams, The Dandelion Clock and The Happy Hunting Grounds
fields.body:
The Blue Bedspread
Raj Kamal Jha
(Picador, £5.99)

Buy it at BOL

Unity of time and of place - a long, Calcutta night of the soul when a man watches over his dead sister's child - produce a debut novel thick with urgency and intensity. A man is summoned to a hospital and handed a new-born child. When day comes he will hand over the baby to strangers, so in one night he must give it a history of its mother, its grandparents and the house where they lived. Jha's Calcutta is built of fragmentary pieces: bus routes that pass through a hodgepodge of colonial street names and Indian districts, and instances from the narrator's memories of childhood secrets - sometimes shocking, sometimes magical. The prose is rich with poetry, yet never precious.

The Colony Of Unrequited Dreams
Wayne Johnston
(Anchor, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Biography as fiction needs a judicious hand - which, unfortunately, is absent in Johnston's rambling recreation of the life of Joe Smallwood, the first premier of Newfoundland. Two of his subjects - the grim existence of Newfoundlanders and the hard-drinking heroine, Sheilagh Fielding - are intriguing, but Smallwood is fails to intrigue. Johnston, an exiled Newfoundlander, has an obvious passion to retell a piece of British colonial history that is barely known beyond this island off the North American coast, but ploughing through this Bildungsroman, I searched in vain for a centre to hold the whole together.

The Dandelion Clock
Guy Burt
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

A middle-aged man gets off a bus in a small Italian town. "Where is it you want to go?" asks a waiter. "I'm not going anywhere," the man replies. "I used to live here." Cue reminiscences of an Italian childhood redolent with the smell of rosemary and lemon trees and a tragedy to be revisited. Just the kind of book to take on to the veranda of a Tuscan holiday villa with an evening glass of Chianti. But The Dandelion Clock does the curiously blunt conversations of children rather well, and the hero, Alex, an expat English boy whose mind's eye cannot distinguish between past and present, gives this gentle read a more unusual perspective.

The Happy Hunting Grounds
Nanne Tepper
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Another über-conventional opening - train-station cafe where old friends meet up - opens out into an unnerving tale of the incestuous relationship between Victor and Lisa. The products of a dysfunctional household (father drinking and mother serving up inedible dinners), their solace is each other. Snatches of conceits, from Jack Kerouac to Barbara Cartland via Vladimir Nabokov, set the tone for each part. While Tepper is an overly conscious literary writer, there is an ironic delight to be found in his imitations. Highly original, deeply uncomfortable, Tepper destroys any notions of the Dutch as a well-balanced people.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Penguin gets on the couch with a series of Freud reissues including Unauthorized Freud
fields.body:
Freud's Women
Lisa Appignanesi and John Forrester
(Penguin, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

Shelf of books, fresh and reprints, from Penguin Freudfest (we imagine the Penguin on the couch, flippers behind head, recounting dreams of iced oceans): this volume meant as a defence of Sigmund and beliefs against contemporary female wrath. We remain unconvinced by the old man, but awed by the biographies of those he trained, especially Lou Andreas-Salomé, a radiant soul from a Klimt painting, except that she seems to have been a goddess of life not death. "There will be arms stretched out to receive me," she said before she died, looking happily and hopefully forward. So little known about SF's mother - the most significant of absences.

Unauthorized Freud
ed by Frederick Crews
(Penguin, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

Anthologised rebuttals of SF and his works, with the grand old man as a "psychic Inspector Clouseau", bullying patients, unscientifically making experiments prove whatever he thought they should, prying into our minds but barring access to his own... Freud as liar, paranoid, marriage counsellor whose advice caused misery, and patriarch of a religion to be professed. Neither spiteful nor jealous. Resounds with explosive guffaws of laughter when SF's culture-vulture analyses of Leonardo da Vinci, or of Little Hans and his willy, are challenged. SF changed the mental climate of the western world: but that doesn't mean he was right.

We remain unconvinced by the old man, but awed by the biographies of those he trained, especially Lou Andreas-Salomé, a radiant soul from a Klimt painting, except that she seems to have been a goddess of life not death. fields.headline: Excess baggage
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland  needs notes to follow Susan Sontag's travelling tale, In America
fields.trailText: John Sutherland needs notes to follow Susan Sontag's travelling tale, In America
fields.body:
In America
Susan Sontag
Jonathan Cape, £16.99, 387pp
Buy it at BOL

Let's face it: if this was a first novel by a literary unknown it would have been lucky to make it into print. What makes In America an object of interest is less its page-turning readability than its significance as the latest move in Susan Sontag's brilliant career. Ever since she declined to finish her PhD in 1957, Sontag has been the loosest of intellectual cannons. Her books, like those of her admired Roland Barthes, defy prediction. Who would have thought that in her sixties, with The Volcano Lover, this "high priestess of radical chic" would turn to romantic fiction - "that Hamilton Woman", no less?

Like its predecessor, In America is lush, multi-voiced, woman-centred and densely historical. It is also, if one looks for glimpses and hints, one of the more personal of Sontag's many books. In the prelude "Chapter Zero" she imagines herself, a contemporary American, transported to a hotel in 1870s Krakow. She eavesdrops on a group of Poles - theatrical types, it transpires - who are destined to be the "dramatis personae" of her novel. Sontag tells us that this prelude, the Jamesian "germ" of In America (the Master, incidentally, has a cameo part later in the narrative), took a year to write.

While musing on the diva who holds the company spellbound, Sontag notes: "I remember when I first read Middlemarch: I had just turned 18, and a third of the way through the book burst into tears because I realised not only that I was Dorothea but that a few months earlier, I had married Mr Casaubon... It took me nine years to decide that I had the right, the moral right, to divorce Mr Casaubon." This, we apprehend, will be the story of a Dorothea who does not, like George Eliot's heroine, bury herself in the obscurity of "private" good works. She will shine in the public blaze of celebrity.

There are huge difficulties in coming to terms with In America. Few readers outside the Polish émigré community will know where it is coming from (it cost me a day looking things up in my local library). In 1876, Helena Modrzejewska, at 35 years old Poland's greatest actress, emigrated to the "Brave New World" of America. Trailing behind her came her husband and her lover, the writer Henryk Sinkiewicz (later famous as the author of Quo Vadis, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature and - as Sontag disdainfully calls him - "the worst writer in the history of the world").

Helena was, although a mere woman, the moving spirit of the enterprise. The Poles set up a utopian community in Anaheim, southern California (now the site of Disneyland - with which Sontag has some sly fun). It failed, as did both Helena's marriage and her love affair. She went on, despite her age and the difficulties of mastering a foreign language, to become a star of the American stage - a rival to Sarah Bernhardt and Ellen Terry. She changed her stage name to Helena Modjeska, which was still recognisably Polish - she was "in America", not "American".

Perplexingly, Sontag changes some, but not all, the names of her historical characters. Modjeska becomes Maryna Zalezowska (stage name "Zalenska"); Sinkiewicz becomes Ryszard Kierul. But the actor Edwin Booth, whose long monologue ends the novel, is Edwin Booth (as Henry James is Henry James). Very mysterious. For those readers who are serious about In America (and I suspect the author would want no others), some preliminary study of Modjeska's 1910 autobiography, Memories and Impressions, is mandatory.

Sontag offers two reasons for writing In America. All four of her grandparents came from Poland. She herself, in the three years of the novel's conception, frequently visited "besieged Sarajevo" (the novel is dedicated to her friends in that unhappy city). Sontag sees parallels between war-torn Bosnia and 19th-century Poland, and they are not hard to see.

But the main inspiration is clearly the luminous and irresistibly magnetic personality of Helena Maryna. This heroine did not follow her menfolk to America; they followed her. She made her career and achieved her stardom, even if it meant ditching the men in her life. It was, as Sontag says of herself and her luckless discarded Mr Casaubon, "morally right" to do so. The truly womanly thing to do, that is.

fields.headline: Big in first novels
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell rounds up the latest debuts, including Special Delivery, If Only It Were True, The Time of Light and If I Told You Once
fields.body:
As we know, the billet-doux is not dead but currently wreaking havoc throughout cyberspace. However, the two lovebirds of Iselin C Hermann's Special Delivery (Harvill, £9.99) have to use the post. An impressionable Danish girl writes a fan letter to a well-known French artist, and before you can say "love bug" panting communications are whizzing back and forth between Holland and France.

But if love is blind, do we actually have to clap eyes on the object of our passion? This is a brief but brilliantly conceived epistolary exchange, in which Hermann exposes how compulsive correspondents remain separated by the very impulse that connects them: to consummate their longing would destroy the illusory bond they have created.

Marc Levy's If Only It Were True (Fourth Estate, £10) summons up so many manipulative cinematic clichés it could be the lost first draft of Truly Madly Deeply. A young medical student lies comatose in a US hospital; her family are about to give up on her and flick the switch. But the woman's spirit continues to inhabit her old apartment, much to the shock of the new tenant, the only person who can see and touch her. Lines like "I know this sounds kind of strange, but she's sort of a ghost" suggest that this is for diehard Bewitched fans only.

From love to war, and in The Time of Light (Bloomsbury, £15.99) Gunnar Kopperud observes, "Hate is like love, self-propagating as soon as it finds a target." Europe continues to replay the events of 1939-45, the roots of which the narrator of this astonishing and complex novel is desperate to understand. It's 1994 and Markus, a former German soldier, now lives in Armenia. While conflict rages around him, he confesses to a priest that he was involved in the Nazi invasion of Russia, and the story emerges of how events transformed Markus and his friends from idealistic teenagers into murderers and rapists. The opening chapters are a series of unrelentingly gruesome episodes, but what follows is a deeply moving and enlightening discourse on war, evil and cultural identity.

Cultural displacement is also at the heart of Judy Budnitz's engaging, if bewildering, If I Told You Once (Flamingo, £12.99), shortlisted for the Orange Prize. When Ilana glimpses a far-off city in a magical egg, she embarks on a journey that will lead four generations of her family from the frozen forests of Eastern Europe to the sweltering Jewish tenements of New York. Via Angela Carter and the Brothers Grimm, Budnitz uses fable and fairy tale to pick out ageless themes with a strange new brush - diaspora, the brutality of war and the necessary, unbearable suffocation of motherly love.

Buy Special Delivery at BOL
Buy The Time of Light at BOL
Buy If I Told You Once at BOL

fields.headline: Upstaged by the small screen
fields.trailText: TV stars provided the real glamour at the Orange Prize, where Moroccan dancers, orange cushions and gritted teeth witnessed a surprise winner
fields.body:
 "It's Tiffany's mum!" "My God, it is - and that's Jim Royle!" These snippets of star-struck conversation, overheard at the Orange Prize bash, refer to the assorted TV celebs who created rather more of a stir than any of the writers.

Bussed in to the V&A for the evening along with a troupe of Moroccan dancers, a henna tattooist, exotic drummers, a hundredweight of orange cushions and flowers and Ann Widdecombe - the general impression being somewhere between a May Ball and Changing Rooms - the actors wisely stood to one side and let the funny book folk get on with it.

A bemused Ricky Tomlinson sipped reflectively from a large can of beer, and refrained from shouting, in Jim Royle mode, "My arse!". Meanwhile, the poor shortlistees were paraded along the podium Miss World-style, handed a bouquet of orange flowers, and trooped back down again to watch a series of MTV-style videos of their beloved works. The words flashed by too quickly for us to make anything out, but the music was lovely.

 As Linda Grant stepped up to receive her cheque, the Zadie Smith camp smiled bravely. Minutes before, an insider had whispered nervously that there was the slimmest of chances that Ms Smith hadn't won, although the first murmur to that effect had been mounting since doors opened. A brisk trade in goodie-bags ensued, with as many as three or four Smiths changing hands for a Grant. Meanwhile, a clip-boarded canvasser sought reactions in the ladies' loo. Regrettably, the same facility was not available in the gents, or we may have heard the thoughts of that well-known feminist and unexpected guest, Norman Mailer.

 In slightly less glam surroundings on the same day, Kathleen Jamie scooped the Geoffrey Faber Memorial Prize for Poetry for her collection Jizzen. Don Paterson was pipped at the post, but as Jamie's editor at Picador, he can still bask in reflected glory.

fields.headline: Fante's inferno
fields.standfirst: Kasia Boddy  applauds the return of John Fante, Bukowski's god
fields.trailText: Kasia Boddy applauds the return of John Fante, Bukowski's god
fields.body:
Full of Life: A Biography of John Fante
Stephen Cooper
Rebel Inc, £16.99, 400pp
Buy it at BOL

Ask the Dust
John Fante
Rebel Inc, £6.99, 198pp
Buy it at BOL

Wait Until Spring, Bandini
John Fante
Rebel Inc, £6.99, 288pp
Buy it at BOL

If it's hard to get a novel published in the first place, it is harder still to keep it in print. And it takes extraordinary good fortune to bring a book back from the ever-expanding graveyard of fiction. John Fante's Ask the Dust is one such (deservedly) fortunate work, and the story of its rediscovery is the stuff of every out-of-print author's dreams.

When it was first published in 1939, Ask the Dust, Fante's second novel, received little publicity and sold poorly (its publishers, Stackpole, were involved in an expensive lawsuit over their unauthorised publication of Mein Kampf). By 1940, like many other writers, Fante turned to Hollywood to make a living. He kept writing fiction, but many of his works went unpublished (indeed, many of his screenplays were unproduced). Ask the Dust took its place in the Los Angeles Public Library.

There, over the years, all sorts of people came upon it, fell in love with it, urged it on their friends and wrote long admiring letters to the author, hoping he was still alive. Robert Towne discovered it while researching his screenplay Chinatown, and declared it to be the best novel ever written about Los Angeles. This was enough to send Stephen Cooper, the author of a new biography of Fante, Full of Life, in search of that well-worn library copy.

But the key figure in Fante's resurrection was novelist and poet Charles Bukowski, who read the book in the public library while "starving and drinking and trying to be a writer", and who subsequently described Fante as his "god". By the late 1970s Bukowski was an international success and in a position to urge his publishers, Black Sparrow Press, to reissue Ask the Dust, "the finest novel written in all time".

In 1980, three years before Fante's death, the book appeared to rave reviews. Today most of Fante's work is in print (including three novels unpublished before his death) and since 1980, 100,000 copies of his books have been sold in the United States, with nearly half a million copies sold in France. Ask the Dust and Fante's 1938 novel Wait Until Spring, Bandini were published in Britain last year.

The latter introduces Fante's alter ego, Arturo Bandini, in the days surrounding his 12th Christmas in snowy small-town Colorado. On the surface it is a tender and lyrical account of the traumas of adolescence. Arturo keeps a daily tally of his freckles and wants to be a good boy, only "he was afraid to be a good boy because he was afraid his friends would call him a good boy."

The real strength of the book, however, lies in its depiction of the parents and its balanced sympathies. Svevo, the father, struggles to be American and is weak; Maria, the mother, endures all and finds America an irrelevance. Arturo, proud and angry, fights to save their marriage through a winter that seems never to end. While Maria turns to her rosary for a "beaded passage into escape" and Svevo retreats to the bottle and the bed of the town's wealthy widow, Arturo hides in the warmth of the movie theatre. But these "drugged enchantments" provide only temporary relief; the brutal facts of poverty and human frailty are inescapable for the Bandini family.

In Ask the Dust we find Arturo struggling to find love and literary fame in an inhospitable but mesmerising Los Angeles. A tale of poverty, racism and desire, its humour is wry and forgiving and its stylistic energy compelling. In the same year that Nathaniel West created his enduringly apocalyptic version of LA in The Day of the Locust, Bandini wooed the city: "Los Angeles, give me some of you! Los Angeles come to me the way I come to you, my feet over your streets, you pretty town I loved you so much, you sad flower in the sand, you pretty town."

Two further Bandini novels are yet to come out in Britain: Fante's wildly exuberant first novel (only published in the States in 1985), The Road to Los Angeles, and his last work, Dreams from Bunker Hill (1982), a mordantly funny look at life as a "Hollywood whore", dictated to his wife after he became blind.

Whether Fante's writings are fictional autobiography, autobiographical fictions or, as biographer Cooper would have it, meditative confessions, it is certainly true that they are vivid reimaginings of his own life. Reading Cooper's sensitive and balanced biography, one becomes aware of what was reinvented, and why. Fante was born into an Italian immigrant family in Colorado in 1909, a time when anti-Italian and anti-Catholic feeling was running high. (By the 1920s, there was intense Klu Klux Klan activity in Colorado, much of it directed against Italian-Americans.) Racist slurs were common - among the humiliating memories recalled in a wonderful early story, "The Odyssey of a Wop", is being called just that by a Jesuit school principal.

Family life was no more harmonious. His mother suffered conspicuously, while the whole family feared, loathed and loved his attractive, neglectful father. Much of Fante's work explores his ambiguous relationship with the father whose name, Nick, he frequently took as his own. Writing opened the door to another world, and money, whether tainted by Hollywood or not, was something impossible to refuse.

Fante's writing is sometimes compared with that of contemporaries John Steinbeck and JG Farrell because of its concern with the lives of the poor. But his fiction has no socialist or even muck-raking agenda, and as such is both more humorous and more pessimistic than most 1930s proletarian writing. Fante was sceptical of what he called "parlour Marxism", and his great influences were the intensely subjective Knut Hamsun and Catholicism itself. "My business in life is to save myself," he wrote to his mentor, HL Mencken. "That's a tremendous job. I shall not dirty my hands trying to save the masses."

fields.headline: Sisters under the skin
fields.standfirst: Sanjida O'Connell   on Carole Jahme's study of the animal magnetism that draws female scientists to apes, Beauty and the Beasts
fields.trailText: Sanjida O'Connell on Carole Jahme's study of the animal magnetism that draws female scientists to apes, Beauty and the Beasts
fields.body:
Beauty and the Beasts: Woman, Ape and Evolution
Carole Jahme
Virago, £18.99, 320pp
Buy it at BOL

Rebecca Ham was gored by a wild buffalo, twice through her breast and once in her ankle. Jo Thompson caught the last boat out of the Congo when the region degenerated into civil war. Dian Fossey was kidnapped, raped repeatedly and urinated upon before being locked in a cage with 18 dead men.

Studying wild primates is fraught with difficulty and hardship: field work is frequently arduous and carried out in war-torn areas; it can take months for the animals to grow accustomed to a human presence; and the subjects can be violent - orang-utans, for instance, sometimes rape women. And yet primatology is the only area of science in which women outnumber men. Women make up 62 per cent of members of the World Directory of Primatologists; women run 90 per cent of primate sanctuaries.

Ironically, it was a man who was responsible for introducing women to primatology. Louis Leakey, a paleoanthropologist based in Kenya, selected and funded the three most famous female primatologists: Jane Goodall, who studies chimpanzees, Dian Fossey, who devoted her life to gorillas, and Biruté Galdikas, who works with orang-utans.

Leakey wanted primatology to be the study of the similarities between us and our nearest living relatives, the apes. A well-known womaniser, he was in love with Goodall and later Fossey. He chose naive women who were intellectual blank slates, often beautiful (Goodall was a 23-year-old blonde when they first met), and willing to live in remote areas of the jungle for at least five years while remaining totally reliant on him for academic guidance, support and money. Goodall called him "Fairy Foster Father"; his pet name for her was Mwendwa, Kikuyu for "My Most Beloved".

According to Carole Jahme, author of Beauty and the Beasts, a discourse on women and apes, these women have come to represent three archetypal images, and have inspired legions of fans and a new generation of primatologists. Jane Goodall's supporters tend to be middle-class women who admire chimpanzees and believe them to be the most intelligent ape; Dian Fossey attracts women who are disappointed with mankind and idolise the natural world; and Biruté Galdikas's fans are spiritual conservationists who want to save the rainforest and the jewel in the jungle's crown, the orang-utan.

Their fame spread not through academia but via the media: Leakey persuaded National Geographic to feature his women and their apes in what are now landmark films. Naturally, the filmmakers portrayed the women in a particular light: Goodall and Fossey, both nubile white women, were shown reaching out and touching the black fur of our savage ape cousins in the dark heart of Africa. As Jahme says, "The published images of the vulnerable women 'alone' with their apes were so powerful that they captured the imagination of the general public."

But just what is it about women and apes? Why are so many female scientists drawn to this field? Jahme believes, like Leakey, that it is because women are better at picking up non-verbal cues. Primed to be able to "read" a baby's or a man's intentions and desires without words, women are better at understanding primate motivations. "When women choose to study and communicate with non-human primates they are effectively choosing to return to a time before language evolved." Jahme continues, "65% per cent of human language is non-verbal. Most of the time we instinctively communicate with one another by means other than the spoken word, using eye contact, facial expression and gesture." As, of course, do primates.

Leakey also thought that women were ideally suited to study primates because, as Jahme says, "women were inherently patient and silent observers, whereas men were ambitious hierarchical careerists. A life of near-poverty watching animals live out long lives for 10 hours a day, decade by decade, was not going to turn men on at all". Jahme thinks that it is the male ego that has prevented men from disappearing into the jungle for years, and that the women she describes do not seem to be looking for fame and fortune.

When Goodall first began to publish papers, the academic world was horrified that she assigned gender to her animals and called them by name instead of giving them numbers. It was pioneering work such as Goodall's that allowed scientists to recognise the role female apes play in primate societies, and that individuals do matter: some apes make good friends, while there are bullies, thugs, peacekeepers and troublemakers, high-rankers and no-hopers in every chimpanzee group.

The ability of female primatologists to sit and observe all day, to look at all individuals and their activities - not just the infrequent but dramatic incidents, such as fights - has led to insights that arguably only women would have had. For example, Sarah Blaffer Hrdy, author of Mother Nature, has a theory that stems from her work watching male langurs killing infants and from seeing the obvious enjoyment female primates take in having sex. She thinks that the female orgasm originally evolved so that females would be encouraged to have sex with more than one mate, so that every male might think an infant was theirs and either care for the baby or, at the very least, not kill it (male primates will kill infants that are not theirs so that the female will come into season quickly and bear their offspring).

Jahme's book, while it is an interesting and insightful guide to "female" primatology, is not particularly well structured, and does not truly get to the heart of why women are interested in apes. Women may be better at understanding non-verbal cues and could be more patient than men, but if they are so skilled socially, then why do they abandon family and friends in pursuit of life in the jungle with only apes for company? In the past society would not allow them to pursue the kind of autonomy they have in the rainforest, but the situation has (hopefully) changed.

It is left to primatologist Sue Savage-Rumbaugh to suggest fleetingly that women are successful in this field because it is a new one - yet so is nanotechnology. Arguably, many modern female primatologists do behave like men, spending one to two years in the field before publishing papers and launching their career. Frequently, papers published on ape psychology are by men (perhaps because this requires working with captive apes), and there are increasing numbers of men, such as Bill McGrew, Richard Wrangham and Christophe Boesche, who have been inspired by the three female pioneers to spend years in the field themselves. They and others like them now run extensive field sites.

As for women not being ego-driven, in any field where rewards are scarce there are intense rivalries and jealousies, and the sisterhood of primatologists is no exception. Jahme describes how one woman murdered a chimp another was introducing back to the wild, and the equivalent kind of career sabotage sometimes occurs in the "gentler" world of academia.

One of the strengths that women have brought to primatology is treating the animals as individuals and becoming involved not only in their lives, but in helping to conserve them. However, there is a fine balance between supreme involvement in an animal's life and rigorous scientific analysis unswayed by personal bias or gender; when one is studying a creature that seems to be so similar to oneself, it is easy to overstep this boundary - whether you are a man or a woman.

 Sanjida O'Connell's book Mindreading: How We Learn to Love and Lie (Arrow, £6.99) deals with how we develop an understanding of what people and animals might be thinking.

fields.headline: The devil's party
fields.standfirst: Wilde's affair with Lord Alfred Douglas was not a one-sided disaster, as Douglas Murray makes clear in Bosie
fields.trailText: Wilde's affair with Lord Alfred Douglas was not a one-sided disaster, as Douglas Murray makes clear in Bosie
fields.body:
Bosie: A Biography of Lord Alfred Douglas
Douglas Murray
Hodder, £20, 370pp
Buy it at BOL

There is something for everyone to despise in Lord Alfred Douglas: those who have no criticism of his promotional homosexuality or his later homophobia will find his anti-semitism disgusting; anyone who can stomach this must have a hard time with his cruel treatment of friends and family, his litigiousness and absurd posing over his third-rate poetry. He is chiefly memorable as a partner in one of the great doomed love affairs of literary history. Here he is often presented as the villain, but it was not, as Douglas Murray makes clear in this generous biography, a one-sided disaster, with Oscar Wilde the passive victim of a beautiful, cock-teasing brat.

Their affair was more evenly matched than that, and also grimly familiar. A glance at any newspaper's court reports shows that it is not at all uncommon for a couple to share a destructive love that ruins each other's happiness and that of their family and friends. History sides with Wilde because he was incomparably the better person and the better writer.

It was Douglas who was the sexual revolutionary of the pair; he was much more daring than Wilde, who was content to laugh secretly at contemporary society, sniggeringly inserting references to homosexual slang such as "Ernest" or "Bunburying" into his works - clues that the sexual underworld would recognise while the bourgeois public saw only the play.

Douglas, however, wanted to conceal nothing: he would not only be homosexual, he would spread the message of a better form of love. It was Douglas who wrote of "the Love that dare not speak its name" in an undergraduate magazine, and even after Wilde's imprisonment wrote: "I am proud that I have been loved by a great poet... sodomites, and I know a great many, are intellectually superior to other men." His public pronouncements and letters detailing how he had made love with this or that boy were to dog him in later life, when he developed a new persona as the scourge of all deviants, cursing former friends in public as "a bugger" or "a habitual sodomite".

His conversion followed the consummation of another interesting relationship, between Douglas and the bisexual poet Olive Custance, who was one of the few women to be associated with the decadents. He made his attraction to her quite clear: "You are a darling Baby and you are exactly like a boy and you know perfectly well that I love you better than anyone else, boy or girl."

After a few years of happiness, Olive and her family also became victims of Douglas's demented outpourings. He was particularly vicious when she judiciously put her inheritance out of his reach to prevent him from squandering it on the libel actions to which he was addicted. He renounced their son at the age of 14 for "plotting" with Olive, and would address her in letters as "you miserable woman".

Douglas finally got what he had long so richly deserved: a prison sentence for a criminal libel on Churchill, who was said to have issued false information on the Battle of Jutland in order to assist Jewish financiers in Britain and Germany. Murray is wrong, though, to suggest that "the majority of the British public" in the 1920s believed in anti-Jewish conspiracy theories; very few people were ever taken in by the bizarre conspiracies about Jewish world domination, and the court found no difficulty in ripping through the tissue of nonsense Douglas had issued to give him six months in Wormwood Scrubs.

In an excess of spite worthy of Douglas himself, the prison authorities refused to let him keep the manuscript book of poems he had written in prison. It is a tribute to Murray's determination that the manuscript is now released, although the world could have got on well enough without Douglas's sonnet referring to Churchill's Jewish mother that starts "The leprous spawn of scattered Israel/ Spread its contagion in your English blood." Murray has a hard time attempting to elevate Douglas's poetry, but it is fun to see the old hater's comments on Eliot, "the supreme enemy of poetry", and his letter to Yeats explaining quite why the Nobel Laureate was the minor and Douglas himself the major poet.

While the publicity for this biography makes much of the author's youth (he is still an undergraduate), this is more a triumph of publishing than of literature: many of us finished books while we were still undergraduates, but it is Murray's unusual achievement to see his in print. And it is well worthwhile: Alfred Douglas is fascinating in the way that truly horrible people often are. "I have been badly treated all my life," he whined in old age. At 63, remembering his 21st birthday, he wrote, "I was so overcome with melancholy at the thought of my vanished youth that I retired after dinner to my bedroom and wept." It would be difficult to find a man more undeserving of tears.

fields.headline: The what if game
fields.standfirst: What If speculates on history's near misses with a fascinating dose of counterfactual history
fields.trailText: What If speculates on history's near misses with a fascinating dose of counterfactual history
fields.body:
What If
ed by Robert Cowley
Macmillan £20, 395pp

Let us praise meteorologist JM Stagg, to whom we owe the world as we know it. In the early hours of a June day, as Atlantic rain beat against south-coast window panes, he guessed it would ease by dawn, and after would follow 36 clearer hours. The man he was advising asked for a guarantee, and Stagg laughed. Both knew certainty was impossible: June predictions are wrong half the time. "OK," said General Dwight D Eisenhower, supreme commander of the invasion of Nazi-occupied Europe (already postponed by a day because of the gale). "Let's go." And he gave the order that sent Operation Overlord to the Normandy beaches on D-day, June 6 1944.

But what if Stagg's hunch had been wrong? Eisenhower could have recalled the invasion, but he would have revealed his destination. And if he had steamed ahead into bad weather, he could not have sent in air cover or reinforcements; his storm-tossed first-wave troops would have been captured or cut down by shore defences. He already had his statement of failure and resignation prepared. As the Allies slowly advanced from southern French beaches, Hitler might have made peace with Russia; Stalin might have ordered the Red Army through Europe to the Channel coast; and the atomic bomb would have been dropped on Berlin in summer 1945. That's the alternative version proposed by Stephen Ambrose, based on his researches into D-day.

Of the 30 speculations in this book, his is the easiest to connect with: who hasn't erred in a decision based on a desperate desire for good weather? And who hasn't stepped in front of a taxi, as did Winston Churchill in New York in 1931: an inch, a millisecond, and a minor politician who was running late would have been remembered for first world war failure in the Dardanelles, while in 1940, the British prime minister, Lord Halifax, would have surrendered to Germany, leading to Nazi victory in the 1939-47 war..

Exercises in counter-factual history such as these are based on the principle that what happened, happened - but only just, and far more accidentally and uncontrollably then we can bear to consider. This is especially true of battlefields, such as the one where humans risked all their futures on the motor reactions of a bodyguard to Alexander (22, and not as yet that Great), who speared a Persian as he hefted his axe for the blow that would have brained the king and denied the world Greek philosophy, art and literature.

It could all, always, have been so different: if only it hadn't been such a wet summer in 1529 (the Ottoman Turks would have taken Vienna); if God's winds hadn't scattered the Armada (all the New World would be Spanish-speaking Latin America); if Genghis Khan's third son had not expired, obliging his Mongol clansman to gallop back to the steppes to elect a leader (Paris, Rome and Catholic Christianity would have been obliterated)...

These pieces appeared originally in the US Quarterly Journal of Military History, and it is obviously difficult for the mostly American writers to imagine any historical sequence that does not lead chiefly to the establishment and current supremacy of the US. The book's Pentagonal bias can irritate a reader into speculating on events that also would have changed the world, without leading directly to Pennsylvania Avenue.

What if, say, the kamikaze, the "wind of the gods" had failed to blow and wreck Genghis Khan's invasion fleet that was on its way to destroy Japan? Would there have been a Columbus if Europe had not changed its trading patterns because of economic restructuring after the Black Death (rats, fleas, bacteria, spices and gold deserve their place as fate's agents)? Hernan Cortes didn't conquer Mexico: it was just one stroke of bastard's luck after another that his head didn't end up on the Aztec skull racks. With his cackhanded squad dead before Spanish typhus could sap their empire, the Aztecs could have challenged European settlement in North America (wagon trains versus obsidian knives - now there's a scenario).

Although its tone tends either to classic military jocularity or a slightly phoney sombreness, this is a genuinely unnerving book, because it proposes that nothing anyone does - and so everything everyone does - may matter. We just don't know what will be significant until afterwards. Army staff colleges must hate it that victory may result not from the well-planned courage of battalions, but from a lost order - like that of General Robert E Lee, found, wrapping three cigars, dropped in a field in the US Civil War (one man can change history, but not perhaps in the way he would have preferred).

And victory is inexplicably unrepeatable: it's claimed that every time the US Naval College wargamers replay the 1942 Battle of the Midway, in which an outnumbered US flotilla beat Japan's Mobile Fleet, victors of Pearl Harbour, the Americans lose. That roll of the cosmic dice that sent US dive-bombers down on Japanese aircraft carriers at the exact moment all Nippon's planes were on deck for refuelling never comes up again. Nothing is written, eh?
