Although its tone tends either to classic military jocularity or a slightly phoney sombreness, this is a genuinely unnerving book, because it proposes that nothing anyone does - and so everything everyone does - may matter. We just don't know what will be significant until afterwards. Army staff colleges must hate it that victory may result not from the well-planned courage of battalions, but from a lost order - like that of General Robert E Lee, found, wrapping three cigars, dropped in a field in the US Civil War (one man can change history, but not perhaps in the way he would have preferred). And victory is inexplicably unrepeatable: it's claimed that every time the US Naval College wargamers replay the 1942 Battle of the Midway, in which an outnumbered US flotilla beat Japan's Mobile Fleet, victors of Pearl Harbour, the Americans lose. That roll of the cosmic dice that sent US dive-bombers down on Japanese aircraft carriers at the exact moment all Nippon's planes were on deck for refuelling never comes up again. Nothing is written, eh?

fields.headline: Vive la difference
fields.standfirst: Clifford Geertz takes us on a fascinating tour of anthropology's anomalies in Available Light
fields.trailText: Clifford Geertz takes us on a fascinating tour of anthropology's anomalies in Available Light
fields.body:
Available Light: Anthropological Reflections on Philosophical Topics
Clifford Geertz
Princeton, £15.95, 271pp
Buy it at BOL

Clifford Geertz is one of those rare scholars: the thinking person's liberal, who spurns easy banalities about the benefits of multi-culturalism (indeed, he admits that "no one is quite sure what culture is").

For Geertz, diversity is not merely the harmless infiltration of Tesco's frozen-food section by Thai stir-fries, but the potentially explosive adjacencies of peoples who disagree on such profound matters as concepts of justice and loyalty to the state. In Available Light, he has assembled eleven essays that look back on a distinguished career as an ethnographer and forward to issues likely to confound his field in future. The book is impeccably written - droll, animated, and bright in both senses of the word - and should enlighten lay readers as well as specialists.

Anthropologists, writes Geertz, "hawk the anomalous, peddle the strange"; they are "merchants of astonishment". Wryly he mourns the loss of the primitive extremes on which this relatively young discipline cut its teeth: "Difference will doubtless remain - the French will never eat salted butter. But the good old days of widow burning and cannibalism are gone for ever."

In Geertz's view, anthropology thrives on its flaws. While the ill-defined field routinely steps on toes in sociology, history, psychology, archaeology and the cognitive sciences, encounters with the Other can prove as fruitful in academia as in Morocco. More, he is a great advocate of anthropology's hit-or-miss methodology of simply venturing forth: "We have turned out to be rather good at waddling in. In our confusion is our strength."

In perhaps his most revelatory essay, "Anti Anti-Relativism", he defends this much-maligned whipping boy of conservatives, who equate cultural relativism with lobotomised neutrality - a refusal to pass judgment on those who are not worse but merely "different" that amounts to moral cowardice.

Geertz clarifies: relativism merely recognises that we all come from a "special somewhere" that influences how we think. The term does not entail an apology for those origins or a refusal to apply their subjective standards. Rather, if you're going to condemn something, you're better off knowing what it is first. Hence westerners are wise to accept that the repellent nature of female circumcision may not seem self-evident to Somalis. Or, to cite one of the many distilled kickers with which Geertz is prone to conclude his paragraphs, "If we wanted home truths, we should have stayed home."

Geertz sees parochialism as a hazard more considerable than an overabundance of understanding: no war has raged because antagonists empathised with one another to excess. Though the complacency of ethnocentrism beckons, "We must learn to grasp what we cannot embrace... without smoothing it over with vacant murmurs of common humanity, disarming it with to-each-his-own indifferentism, or dismissing it as charming, lovely even, but inconsequent."

In his final essay, "The World in Pieces", Geertz portrays foreignness as anything but inconsequent. Examining ethnic and religious conflict in ex-Yugoslavia, Indonesia and Quebec, Geertz addresses the irony that while the post-Cold War world grows more technologically and economically global, it also grows more politically divided.

In 1945, there were about 50 countries; now there are nearly 200, and larger powers continue to atomise into new states. With accelerating immigration, even long-established countries are fragmenting from within. Multiculturalism sounds progressive, but melting pots court identity crises. Geertz presses the question, "What is culture if it is not a consensus?" only to conclude that "It is less consensus that is at issue than a viable way of doing without it."

Now more than ever, we need not hop on a plane to run into the Other, but need merely grab a taxi in Shepherd's Bush. Permeating this lucid, provocative and playful compendium is the suggestion that in the days ahead we'll all have to become anthropologists - merchants of astonishment.

webTitle: All roads lead to the Birmingham fair this weekend

fields.headline: All roads lead to the Birmingham fair this weekend
fields.trailText: Birmingham might be best known for its Bull Ring and Spaghetti Junction, but next weekend the city is a hot spot for graduates on the trail of work writes Eileen Sheridan. They'll be heading for the NEC for a two-hander graduate fair run by Aston and Birmingham Universities and organised by Venture Marketing.
fields.body:
Birmingham might be best known for its Bull Ring and Spaghetti Junction, but next weekend the city is a hot spot for graduates on the trail of work writes Eileen Sheridan. They'll be heading for the NEC for a two-hander graduate fair run by Aston and Birmingham Universities and organised by Venture Marketing.

Birmingham is the third biggest graduate fair after London and Manchester and at its current rate of growth - 114 exhibitors this time - it is catching up fast.

The central location and a series of free coaches from around the country (check the website for one near you) help to make it a huge attraction and there has, according to Aston Career Service spokesman Stewart Comfort, always been a serious culture of job seeking among students at his university.

"Aston," he says, "has got the best employment record in the country." This is because Aston students get a chance to try out the world of work during a placement year of their four-year courses, giving them a head start on other job applicants. "They apply theory to practice and it gives them maturity as well as all-around skills as an employee," says Comfort. Aston has a strong business school, life and health sciences such as pharmacology and optometry, and engineering so the Birmingham Fair is a useful venue for graduates with these degrees.

Comfort, in common with all careers specialists, advises that you plan well ahead, have several copies of your CV with you and take some advice from your own careers service before you go.

Over at Birmingham University Careers Service Richard Maynard has a few pointers of his own to add. "Take a look at the list of exhibitors on the website," he advises, "and go into your own careers advisory service to research the firms and their possible vacancies."

And if you have picked some companies in advance, tailor your CV to suit them if necessary. Don't just turn up with a bog standard CV for everyone. He also recommends adding a photo to help personnel people on the exhibitor's stand to remember you after the event.

"Focus on the employer," says Maynard. "There may be an impromptu interview, and I have heard that job offers have been made on the spot, but that is the exception rather than the rule. Most employers would not take the risk."

So the most you are likely to come away with is that first contact and the hope that you've made a good impression with the right people. And who are the right people? Who will you find setting out their stands?

There are all the usual big players like Andersen Consulting, Marconi, Alliance and Leicester, Nationwide, The Institute of Chartered Accountants, One 2 One, the Royal Air Force, the Royal Navy, Scottish Power, MBNA International Bank, Halifax, Barclaycard and the Bank of England.

But the Birmingham Graduate Fair also has Alstom Transport, Activate, Agilent Technologies, BASS Brewers, Squibb Company, Caradon, Astrium, the Birmingham College of Food and Tourism, Bristol Myers, CMC Group, FKI Plc, Lever Elida, Lucent Technologies, Netinvest and Netstep among others.

"Fairs are good for employers seeking recruits mostly in the commercial and industrial sector," says Maynard. "They're not really for people seeking to go into PR or journalism, places that are oversubscribed. You are window shopping to see what is on offer and also to get a feel for employment types and employers, and this is a very efficient way of doing it."

"It's a good investment from the employer's point of view as well," says Venture marketing's managing director Mel Stride. "It's cost effective. For the price of one newspaper ad, the exhibitor can meet thousands of prospects face to face. The NEC attracts graduates from all over the country."

There are extras too. The fair will offer a CV clinic and there will be presentation theatres for visitors to learn more about specific companies or specific industries, says Stride. A timetable for these is available on the website.

 If you fancy a trip to Birmingham, here are the things you need to know:

Dates: June 16 and 17.
Times: Friday noon to 6pm, Saturday 11am to 4pm.
Venue: Hall 8, NEC, Birmingham.
Freephone hotline: 0800-856-2492.
Transport: details of free coaches at www.gradjobs.co.uk

webTitle: How to...hunt down the best employer for you

fields.headline: How to...hunt down the best employer for you
fields.standfirst: Good prep work is step one in our graduate starter series
fields.trailText: Good prep work is step one in our graduate starter series
fields.body:
You have just gained a top academic credential and a few letters to add to your name, but now is not the time to rest on your laurels. If you want to land the job of your dreams, you must be prepared to put in some leg work and begin stalking your prey. Intelligence-gathering is crucial if you are to make sure that the employer in whom you entrust your future is not going to short-change you when it comes to working environment and corporate culture.

You'll already have discovered at job fairs or milk rounds that every employer offers the earth: excellent terms and conditions, competitive salaries, equal opportunities, training and development and fantastic holiday entitlements.

Trouble is, many companies portray a different face at recruitment drives and in their job ads - the true nature of its management style will not become apparent until you actually start the job.

The simplest way to research potential employers is to invest £14.99 in a copy of Britain's Top Employers , a guide published by Corporate Research Foundation. But in doing this, you will be restricting your search to around 100 firms. For a more comprehensive study you need to widen your investigations.

Starting with corporate fundamentals, you need to know whether your prospective employer is going to be in business for long enough to allow you to establish a decent track record. Otherwise, you risk a Boo.com-style letdown. It doesn't take long to research this aspect of any company: most public libraries now have good business reference sections complete with internet access.

Some of the bigger ones, for example file the annual report and accounts of nearly all the companies listed on the London Stock Exchange. These reports are a mine of information, and you don't have to be a chartered accountant to decipher most of the contents. At the back of the report is a printed record of the company's performance over the past five years; these figures should give you a clue to its future financial health. Data on company turnover over the five-year period is the key to recognising supply and demand dynamics in the market that accurately mirror the extent to which a company's fortunes have been rising or falling.

Once you get past the gushy statements from chairmen and chief execs, the relevant part to look up is the report of the directors, which will have information on any profit sharing schemes, and will list any donations to charitable and/or political causes it might be making.

Perhaps even more telling is the report on directors' remuneration, which cites all the basic pay, bonuses, perks, pension contributions and share options which the top bosses have trousered over the last 12 months. Compare this to a little item, staff costs, stuck in its notes to the accounts - this will reveal its annual wages bill. Divide this number by the number of its employees and you will have a rough guide to the average salaries it pays.

However, it may not be that easy to procure an annual report for some privately-held companies. Here, a trip to the Companies House register should do the trick. Companies House holds information on more than 1.5m registered companies and receives more than 5m documents each year. All this information is available through the internet too, at www.companies-house.gov.uk The internet has demystified corporate research and individual company websites have evolved as powerful information resources.

Typical of companies that successfully use their websites to communicate is Vodafone AirTouch, which proclaims: "Here you can read information about our company, what we stand for, how we're structured, and our global reach. If there's anything about us that you can't find on this site, simply use the 'Contact us' option to tell us your query and we will do our best to help you."

Vodafone's web content on its achievements and ambitions is supported by complete financial reports for the past three years plus its most recent presentations to investors.

If you are wary about working for firms that compromise your personal principles or beliefs, Ethical Investment Research Service monitors corporate behaviour on behalf of private and institutional investors. Its website can be found at www.eiris.u-net.com

Finally, don't forget to make use of social networks: this is especially important for graduates from minority ethnic communities, as despite their best efforts many corporations are still clueless about managing workplace diversity.

For many graduates of ethnic minority origin, looking for work can be a lonely chase, cold-calling reluctant employers and filling out dozens of unsuccessful applications. Therefore a social system which they can plug into not only for tips about where to find a job, but also to keep it and progress, is invaluable.

fields.headline: Top rung/ Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Top rung
fields.body:
Top rung

Claire Wheat
Aged 49
Regional director
Legal Services Commission

Bringing people into the legal process gives Claire Wheat the greatest satisfaction in her job. "I particularly enjoy being part of the government's wider programme of social development which is all about addressing areas of exclusion," she says.

Claire runs the West Midlands office of the Legal Services Commission (formerly Legal Aid Board). She supervises the contracts with suppliers - mainly solicitors - in both the civil and criminal law. A growing aspect is the development of community partnerships with local authorities, the public and local advice bureaux and neighbourhood centres.

Facts and stats: The 90 staff based in Birmingham -one of 12 regional offices - cover a territory of 6m people. The region handles 1,000 contracts with suppliers.

CV includes: Degree in agricultural botany at Reading University, food management at BHS, job centres adviser, training and enterprise councils and a trainer in industry before joining the Legal Aid Board.

Must-have qualities? "Graduates come to us from all degree disciplines. To succeed they must have the ability to communicate and be able to explain in simple terms a decision applicants may not like."

Bottom rung

Michelle Lowe
Aged 30 Lead assessor
Legal Services Commission

Michelle Lowe's spell working in industrial tribunals gave her a taste for a career in the law. "After graduating, I didn't have any career plans and temped for a while. I then had a two-year contract as a clerk and this gave me an insight into, and excited an interest in, the law," she says.

As a result, the former French and sociology student at Lancaster University became one of three graduate entrants to the Legal Aid Board in 1995, where she started as an auditor case worker.

Progress: After legal training, Michelle specialised in finance and began by assessing solicitors' bills. She later became a team leader - with 30 case workers reporting. More recently she has been lead auditor with responsibility for ensuring the proper running of the office's quality management system.

Training: Comprises a mixture of residential courses and on-the-job instruction and shadowing. There are six-monthly appraisals linked to a performance review. New graduate entrants are now covered by a training contract.

Current role: "As lead assessor I will be responsible for the training of new and present auditors."

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Speak for yourself
fields.trailText: Speak for yourself
fields.body: Your opening words when speaking in public are the most important, says Cristina Stuart, author of a forthcoming book on communicating. "Although people only half-listen to the content, it's at this stage that they are assessing how much of their mental energy you deserve," she says. "Your first words must create a stillness as the audience pricks up their ears and waits for your next sentence. You must grab their attention and suspend their mental questioning. Your opening words must be imaginative, stimulating and above all attention-gaining. Don't confuse your opening words with the introduction to your subject. That comes later. But your opening words must be enticing and seductive. It's a tall order, but essential if you expect to achieve your objectives."

webTitle: Never mind the money: Check out the label

fields.headline: Never mind the money: Check out the label
fields.standfirst: Employers face a brand new challenge in the battle for the brightest graduate talent
fields.trailText: Check out the label Employers face a brand new challenge in the battle for the brightest graduate talent
fields.body:
Brands are back. So said fashion bible The Face only a few months ago. We tried to hide the labels for a couple of years, but the Guccis and Stussys have come back with a bang.

As consumers we're suckers for big, powerful brands. But as employees, it seems we're now increasingly swayed by a company's "employer brand" too.

Many elements make up an employer brand, like its reputation as an innovator, its working practices and career development policies.

But if that all seems a bit messy, ask yourself if your employer passes the party test. When you meet someone for the first time and navigate through the pleasantries do you choose to reveal or conceal the name of your employer?

The war for top talent is becoming so intense that a company's employer brand - working for the "right" organisation - has more pulling power than a golden handshake or company car.

Ten or maybe even five years ago, the banks and consulting firms enjoyed a virtual monopoly of the brightest students spilling out of university. But the latest polls of graduate opinion suggest a shift in the balance of power towards the sexier, more caring, sharing employer brands.

Universum, a Stockholm-based company specialising in graduate recruitment, publishes an annual survey which monitors the work-related opinions, values, and priorities of students at 32 different universities around the UK. Its latest report reveals that for the second year in a row, BBC and Virgin Group are the companies for whom graduates would most like to work.

New to the top ten are Microsoft and Coca-Cola (up five spots each to number seven and eight respectively. Dropping out of the top 10 are Ernst & Young, now ranking 15, and KPMG, currently at 13.

It might be that auditing and accounting are losing their attraction as career paths. But the research indicates that it's the companies with the strongest employer brands which are climbing the table, irrespective of which sector they are in.

"Before, there was no need to promote yourself as a good employer," says Claudia Tattanelli, Universum's sales manager.

"The supply of graduates outstripped demand. Companies worked hard building up their consumer brands but could afford to be lazy when recruiting staff.

"But the booming economy means that demand for top graduates, particularly in IT-related areas, is now almost double the supply. The tables have turned and sending out random messages about what sort of employer you are is no longer enough." The tools of employer branding include campus presentations, brochures, websites and employee testimonials.

"The consulting firms like Andersen and McKinsey have always been good at promoting their employer brand on university campuses," says Tattanelli. "But they're facing competition now from smaller companies and start-ups who are willing to offer stock options, flexible working, fast-track development and more relaxed working environments to snap up the brightest and best graduates.

"The other change is that many of these newer firms can offer graduates careers across a whole range of disciplines."

Firms like Nokia, Ericsson, Microsoft and Coca-Cola have strong employer brands because many graduates identify with their consumer brands. But other companies, like consulting firm Razorfish owe much of their success to careful employer brand management.

"The losers have been the banks and the fast moving consumer goods companies who have been caught resting on their laurels," says Tattanelli. Eulogy!, a London-based public relations agency, is an example of a smaller firm working hard on promoting its employer brand to graduates.

"We have a team at Eulogy! responsible for our own PR and they treat Eulogy! as they would any other client," says joint managing director Adrian Brady. "It's a way of showing everyone who works at the agency or is considering a job offer at the agency that we take our own brand seriously. "We want people to be proud of where they work and prepared to tell their mates in the pub.

"We are also aware that Eulogy! will be a part of their career, not all of it. And so what we try to deliver is experience in a company which becomes integral to someone's career development.

"I'd love to look back in 10 years and have a successful agency, but also a successful alumni of former Eulogites all doing well in their careers and still proud of their Eulogy! heritage."

webTitle: Sixty seconds in...  the book trade

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in...  the book trade
fields.standfirst: Jonathan White, a UK representative for German publishers Köneman, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Jonathan White, a UK representative for German publishers Köneman, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Like many people I thought I was going to end up as an accountant or a lawyer but I walked out of an accountancy course after just two weeks and failed to even start the law. Today I'm responsible for selling and supplying books to shops across London and the southern half of the UK.

Köneman is an interesting company to work for because it trades quite differently to its competitors. It made its name producing very glossy, high quality coffee table books at very competitive prices. All the production is done in Germany and every book is carefully designed to have a wide appeal and more importantly, sell anywhere in the world.

The UK division comprises four people and we are more or less left to get on with it. My job divides roughly in two - half is spent on the road visiting existing customers and finding new ones - the rest of the time I'm in our London offices.

Unlike almost every other publisher, we don't offer books on a sale or return basis but make retail outlets buy them outright. While this means some shops refuse to deal with us, it does allow us to offer them 30% cheaper. The company has always operated a deliberate policy of never advertising and we don't have any point of sale material - the quality of the books is expected to do all the talking. As a result, when I visit a potential customer - again unlike most publishers - I always take the books along.

Although I'm not an obvious salesman, I really enjoy the selling side of the job. I think most people like doing business with someone they trust and I approach it with this in mind.

Books are still a rewarding commodity to sell. One area I've been developing is the selling of our books by other outlets. For example in Bath I've persuaded a kitchen shop to sell some of our cookery and interior design titles and they've done very well.

I'm fortunate in that we have a specialist company that dispatches and invoices the orders so admin is kept to a minimum. Although the company is run quite informally I'm usually in daily contact with Germany. It's just as well, as they're not beyond springing new titles on us at short notice.

Like many people, I fell into the book world almost by accident. Having returned from a trip to Australia I got what I anticipated would be a temporary job in Dillons bookshop, stayed for seven years and ended up managing one of its flagship stores in Trafalgar Square.

fields.headline: Turn over a new leaf
fields.standfirst: Working with words demands real passion and commitment. Eileen Sheridan assesses what it takes to become a books editor
fields.trailText: Working with words demands real passion and commitment. Eileen Sheridan assesses what it takes to become a books editor
fields.body:
The world of words is one of those areas of employment where passion and commitment will always come before financial reward. Like journalism, publishing has a few people at the top earning big dosh while throughout the business there are legions of wordsmiths beavering away for a basic living.

But publishing, like journalism, is sexy. So job seekers still come in droves, looking for employment, clutching their degrees and dreaming of long, lazy, but literate lunches with interesting writers.

"There is very little of the long lunches," says Professor Paul Richardson, head of Oxford Centre for publishing studies at Brookes University.

The fact that there are publishing studies available as first degres and postgraduate qualifications indicate how things have changed.

"It is not easy to get jobs in publishing. It is very competitive and it has changed significantly in recent years," Prof Richardson adds.

Even a decade ago, publishing was one of those areas of work where bright young things turned up, got a job, and then learned the business as they went along. It does still happen this way, but less frequently.

"The pace is so fast," says Prof Richardson, "few people have time to train entrants on the job. Companies are a lot leaner and a lot of work is outsourced, so there is a core team which does not have the time to do training."

Publishing houses, therefore, look for people with added value who can bring in skills and get going straight away. Understanding information technology and the use of electronic systems is crucial, as well as having some knowledge of the role of marketing and publicity.

The long, lazy lunches, where there are any, are the province of commissioning or list-building editors, people who, in the publishing world, can become as legendary as the writers themselves.

"A commissioning editor develops the publishing company's list, looking for market opportunities, finding authors or projects, talking to agents and tapping into new creative writers that way," says Prof Richardson.

A popular misconception is that publishing is dominated by fiction, where in fact the most profitable areas are business, legal, scientific, academic and educational publishing, and it is in these fields that editors hold the ring.

"The editor is central to the whole process. In these areas of specialist commissioning, the editor is orchestrating events. They have the ideas and work with designers, illustrator, writers, or team of writers, like the conductor of an orchestra. A high proportion of my students do not choose fiction," Prof Richardson says.

That is not to say that working as a fiction editor is without huge reward, just that the relationship with the writer is usually mediated through an agent and it is the agent who is more likely to develop the ideas.

Whatever their role, the commissioning editor needs a very high degree of good interpersonal skills.

At one end of the job they need negotiating skills to deal with their own marketing and publicity people, the book trade to persuade them of the virtue of their project and get their backing. They have to be team players. And, at the other end of their job, they have to maintain a good relationship with their authors.

"The author needs support," explains Prof Richardson, "and it is a delicate relationship, especially if the editor has to persuade them to make changes."

The hours expected of publishing staff, says the Publishing Training Centre's Graham Smith, can be long and demanding for comparatively small financial reward. "Commissioning is perhaps the role with the highest profile and potential rewards attached - and, with them, the higher risk if something goes wrong," he adds.

Most commissioning editors are educated to first degree level, although the subject is not crucial. "It obviously helps," says Smith, "to have a good understanding of science and technology if those are the areas covered by the publisher, but the ability to assimilate details of specialist topics can overcome any shortfall in expert knowledge."

Expert knowledge is more critical for a proof reader or copy editor and these people are the unseen army at the heart of the publishing world.

As a result of down-sizing fewer publishing houses employ in-house copy editors and proof readers. This is an area where work is increasingly freelance, and an area where many amateurs think they can break in. But it is not as easy as many people imagine.

The Society of Freelance Editors and Proofreaders (SFEP) warns that new entrants will be competing with an established workforce, many of whom will have trained with a publishing company.

Some areas are more in need of people than others, however, and anyone educated to a degree level obviously stands a better chance of finding work, especially if the degree is in engineering or law, sciences or mathematics.

"Expert knowledge of a subject is often highly valued," says Graham Smith, "particularly for scientific and medical publishing where complex terminology is used.

"A good command of English and an eye for detail are essential, as is the ability to manage projects."

The copy editor ensures that authors stick to house style, check for typographical errors, monitor the factual integrity of a narrative and make judgements about necessary changes. It is detailed and procedural work. The SFEP runs a series of training courses both in proof reading and copy editing - and both skills are closely allied.

The society says that some people find it confusing to learn copy editing before they are confident of their proof reading skills, but others like to learn both disciplines together.

"Many prefer to minimise the risk they are taking by not investing in copy editing training until they are earning money by proof reading," says the society.

It goes on to warn: "If you are having difficulty obtaining proof reading work, you are unlikely to find it any easier to obtain copy editing work."

Nor will you earn megabucks. "Most publishers pay in the range of £8 to £12 an hour," says the SFEP. "Some newcomers earn as little as £4 an hour. The work is unlikely to come in a steady flow even when you are established."

 Further details

Publishing Training Centre: 020-8874-2718, website: www.train4publishing.co.uk

Society of Freelance Editors and Proofreaders: 020-7403-514, website: www.sfep.org.uk

Oxford Brookes University: 01865-484952

webTitle: How to... come back from your wilderness years

fields.headline: How to... come back from your wilderness years
fields.standfirst: It's never too late for a rewarding career
fields.trailText: It's never too late for a rewarding career
fields.body:
You could have been someone. You could have been a contender. Instead, you're nearing 30, turning to fat and you still haven't done anything with your life. While your friends are enjoying the trappings of a successful career, you live in a rented bedsit, travel and do odd, unfulfilling jobs to keep you off the breadline. Your graduation photo stares sadly from your wall, a bitter reminder of what you could have achieved. You're trapped in the job wilderness.

Does this sound like someone you know? Or could it be you? Sophie Rowan, head of career development at Career Psychology, says it's not an unusual phenomenon. "We see lots of people like this," she says. "They are usually highly intelligent, academic people, with good degrees, but who - for some reason - were unable to make the transition from university to career. They've lost their momentum. Then, as they near 30, they get a wake-up call."

Rowan says that after graduating we all have a two-year grace period when it's fine to take time out before embarking on our chosen careers: "The danger is that if you don't have a clear idea of what you want to do in the long-term, you might not find it easy to come back into a stable career," she warns.

"Take too much time out and you won't be able to cope with the rigid structures of corporate life. Your confidence will ebb away, you'll lose your optimism and you may find yourself in a cycle of depression."

Sarah, 29, understands this problem only too well. Her 30-year-old ex-boyfriend, Peter, still doesn't have a 'proper' job, eight years after passing his masters degree with a distinction. What went wrong? "I'm still asking myself that," says Sarah. "Peter was 'the person most likely to succeed' - on paper, at least. He was charming, presentable and highly intelligent, a top student with loads of potential."

Sarah and Peter went travelling for a couple of years after they graduated. But while Sarah settled into a graduate career and is now a well-established PR manager, Peter lost his way. "He taught a bit of English, worked in a pub and then took odd jobs in the building trade," says Sarah. "He works sporadically, but has spent a lot of time on the dole. He's been very depressed for years. When we were together, I tried to push him to get a proper job, but he wasn't very interested.

"He always said he'd do something 'different', that he was too clever just to get on the graduate ladder. Sadly, his plans came to nothing. Now I'm afraid it might be too late for him. "

Is it too late? "No," says Rowan. "All isn't lost if you haven't established yourself in a career by the time you're 30, but it is more difficult. You'll be competing with bright, enthusiastic, new graduates and you'll have to explain why you haven't started your career until now.

"If you do get a job, you'll also have to deal with the possibility that you'll be working for a boss who's younger than you and you'll be years behind your peers, which can be humiliating.

"Many people in this position will be terrified at the prospect of starting a career job. They'll say 'I'm not going to do filing for anyone - I could be running the company'. It's usually their own insecurity which holds them back. It's important to remember that no matter how talented you are, the first two years of your career are usually a hard slog."

Rowan says it's a good idea to get a professional qualification before you start your job hunt. "This will give you new skills and renew your confidence. It's an ideal transition back into the working environment and it will give you something to offer an employer."

Next, swallow your pride and get back in contact with old friends and contacts. They'll be able to take a look at your CV, advise you of any job opportunities and they might even be in a position to employ you.

There's no point trying to cover up your lack of career success. "I've spent five years researching my novel," just won't wash with most employers and your patchy CV will give the game away.

Rowan says be honest, but explain your situation in a positive light. "Say your priorities were different before, but now you have a clear focus and self-knowledge. If you've been travelling or working, talk about the skills you picked up along the way. It might be difficult but the alternative is to remain where you are... frustrated and unfulfilled. The only person who can change your situation is you."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

According to Rowan once you've got a foothold on the career ladder, you're likely to rise more quickly than a 21-year old. "You're more mature, have had more life experience and you have a greater awareness of who you are and what you want," she says.

If you don't remember anything else, remember this... According to Rowan once you've got a foothold on the career ladder, you're likely to rise more quickly than a 21-year old. "You're more mature, have had more life experience and you have a greater awareness of who you are and what you want," she says.

Boost your brain power at work with a cup of herbal tea. Researchers at the University of Northumbria gave 20 volunteers a single dose of ginseng or ginkgo boloba and found that it improved their concentration, memory and speed of reaction.

The words 'struggling' and 'artist' don't have to be synonymous, says national artists' information service AN which has just published Fast Forward 2000 , an overview of the graduate career paths of 21 emerging and established creative practitioners. Priced £2.95, the booklet can be ordered on 0191 241 8000. See www.anweb.co.uk for more details.

 Public service:
High Fliers, which conducts regular surveys of graduate opinion has entered the elitism debate with research which suggests graduates who went to state schools are less ambitious and have lower expectations than those who went to private schools. There was also a marked difference in the salaries the two groups expected.

 Book of the week:
It's wall-to-wall Euro 2000 coverage from today, so why not go the whole hog and consider a continental career? Let The Insider's Guide to Working in Europe be your passport to 48 different destinations. Published by Bene Factum, this paperback can be ordered at the special price of £12.99 (plus p&p) from our Cultureshop on 0800 316 6102.

 Nose job:
Beware of telling your boss too many porky pies. Pinnochio's growing nose is a bona fide biological response to lying say researchers at the Smell and Taste Treatment Foundation in Chicago. Feelings of guilt increase your blood pressure which in turn boosts blood flow to the erectile tissues in your nose causing them to stretch. Apparently.

fields.headline: Reveal your hidden talents
fields.standfirst: Tonight, Matthew, I'm going to be the successful applicant for my dream job
fields.trailText: Tonight, Matthew, I'm going to be the successful applicant for my dream job
fields.body:
Being an aerial artist is not what Gisele Edwards planned for a living. She studied Oriental Studies at Cambridge. After graduating she joined Gartmore Investment as an equity analyst, no less. Today, she performs tightrope acrobatics full-time at the Dome.

By way of explanation, Edwards says she just "discovered" a natural aptitude for physical theatre and eventually felt "compelled" to pursue it professionally.

Finding a hidden talent may not necessarily lead you down a completely new career path. But it can give you that all-important edge at an interview. It can make you more confident and likeable. It can make you more memorable. It could even make you more suitable for the job in question.

But carrying this off is not easy. "It is tricky and it is risky," cautioned one career advisor. "You can end up looking rather foolish." Even Gisele Edwards acknowledges, "it would probably be a mistake to rave about your great dancing ability to a room full of suits and straight faces".

So there is a right way and wrong way to use your hidden talents during an interview. But first, you have to recognise them. "We are good at knowing what we can't do, but not very good at knowing what we can do," says personal and business coach Maria Hemming. "There is something about the human psyche that can stop us from seeing our own abilities."

To help her clients overcome this barrier Hemming asks them to answer the following:

What do you love to do?
What do you do naturally well?
What is your greatest strength?
What is your greatest desire?
What are you most proud of?
What do you daydream about?
If you won the lottery, how would you fill your days?
What would you do if you knew you couldn't fail?
How do you want to be remembered?

These questions are designed to enable people to realise what makes them unique. To job seeking graduates, this knowledge can bring its own rewards.

As Hemming notes: "It can make people feel much happier with themselves and in an interview situation this can be an invaluable advantage for two reasons. First, it creates a positive, productive energy around you - something that can be very attractive to prospective employers. Secondly, it helps you perform better in the interview. You feel more successful, therefore you can be more successful."

Finding a hidden talent can also be rather useful at an interpersonal level. If you've realised you have a particular flair or passion, it may be appropriate to mention it during the interview as a way of demonstrating your individuality. "This can make you stand out from the other candidates," says Jonathan Mansfield-Clarke, director of Absolute Graduates. "It can show that you are lateral, creative, enthusiastic, energetic and just that bit distinctive."

Shantal Abu Sharar, a graduate recruitment advisor with Price Jamieson, agrees. When all the other elements are equal, she says, talking about a hidden talent can give you a competitive edge. "You can be seen to be a rounded and interesting individual and this can be important to employers."

It worked for "Romany", who runs her own London-based business specialising in "high society entertainment". After graduating from Manchester University with a degree in English and Italian, her first job was as a BT sales executive.

During the interview, Romany used her long-discovered flair for all things theatrical to great effect. "I argued that people won't buy telephones from someone who is dry and dull. But they will buy them from someone who can perform with passion and energy."

The key, she says, is to look for links between your hidden talent and the job on offer. Recognise the skill sets involved in both and explain how they connect. Having an eye for photography, for instance, could demonstrate an ability to process new information, to identify new opportunities, to express ideas visually and to accomplish all of that within seconds.

You will need to apply what's called the "feature-advantage-benefit rule". Mansfield-Clarke explains: "First, look for the feature in yourself. Second, understand how it creates an advantage for you. Finally, explain how it offers a benefit for your employer."

Then go for it. After all, as Gisele Edwards says: "You just never know how high they might take you".

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to... effective visual aids
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to... effective visual aids
fields.body:
A. Key note

There are few occasions when you can command such undivided attention - no wonder most people feel terror at the prospect of giving a presentation that arouses compassion or loathing. An audience will pity you if you make a mess of it, hate you if you bore them but admire you for making it easy and enjoyable. You're there to entertain as well as inform.

B. Pointless power

Exploit rather than abuse a projector. Ensure you're offering something worth looking at and acquaint yourself with the off switch: a slide loses interest value after about a minute. Keep words displayed to a minimum by making them so large you can't fit many on and consider replacing some with pictures. An appropriate cartoon is a memorable and effective way of getting your message across. Anecdotes have the same effect, but both need to be used sparingly.

C. Short is sweet

Credit your audience with the ability to read: use slides as a prompt, not a script. Keep dull detail for hand-outs that can be read or ignored in private. Observe the look of relief and gratitude when you tell people they don't have to take notes. Watch for signs of boredom - if they're asleep, as glazed as an American doughnut or avidly reading the programme to see when this session ends, they've had enough. Aim to finish before they would have liked you to - no one ever complained a presentation was too short.

fields.headline: Sporting chance
fields.trailText: Sarah-Louise Prime.
fields.body:
Name:
Sarah-Louise Prime.

Status:
Development manager at the British Sports Trust, which encourages leadership skills among young people.

Past:
Switched from teacher training degree to BSc in sport and exercise science at Cheltenham and Gloucestershire College of Higher Education. Gained a first and worked as a sports development officer in the Cotswolds before joining the trust as a training officer.

Present:
Promotes courses - known as sports leader awards - which teach skills such as communication and organisation in schools, youth centres and prisons. Also trains tutors and writes course materials.

Future:
"Inspiring and motivating people in a sporting or non-sporting environment."

Strengths:
"Teaching and relating to a wide range of people."

Weaknesses:
"I'm not the best at managing my time and saying no in my over-enthusiasm to get things done."

Wisdom:
"Don't always follow the obvious route to achieve your career goals. I knew I wanted to teach, but discovered I could use my skills outside the school environment."

References:
www.thebritishsportstrust.org.uk

webTitle: Help: I'm going to regret this!

fields.headline: Help: I'm going to regret this!
fields.standfirst: I have just given in my notice for a job I hate with an employer I despise and am expected to attend an exit interview. Should I say what I think or tone it down?  Sean P, credit analyst, Exeter
fields.trailText: Both. Say what you think but tone it down. Words like hate and despise will sour the discussion. Even if you don't care, there's no point in leaving people with negative memories of you regardless of what you think about them.
fields.body:
Both. Say what you think but tone it down. Words like hate and despise will sour the discussion. Even if you don't care, there's no point in leaving people with negative memories of you regardless of what you think about them.

You're going, so you can afford to adopt a tolerant, reflective attitude. Aim to leave them feeling sorry to lose a thoughtful individual rather than heaving sighs of relief at the departure of a disturbing and discontent presence.

If things are so bad you can't trust yourself to remain calm and polite, suggest you postpone this interview for a few months. To say "I feel too negative about the whole experience to discuss it rationally just now", sends a powerful message and prevents a potentially embarrassing or damaging encounter.

Despite what you feel at the moment, exit interviews can be of great benefit to giver, recipient, the people you're leaving behind and those yet to come.

And reflection is good for you. There must have been a time when you felt as pleased to be offered this job as you now are to leave it. What went wrong? When relationships fail there's inevitably a contribution to the mess from everyone involved.

Perhaps your only real mistake was staying too long, but if you don't examine the causes of a disaster you're in danger of repeating it.

ijk@excite.com
